HEADLINE: Getting Alienated Freudians to Associate

BYLINE: By ROBERT S. BOYNTON 

 BODY:
Sometimes a bookstore is just a bookstore.
But sometimes, as today's Freudians should know, it is also a publisher, a Web site and a gathering place for readings, lectures and book parties. At least that is the case with Other Books, on the first floor of a turn-of-the century brownstone on West 20th Street in Chelsea. The store's window displays an Interpretation of Dreams T-shirt and a "Freudian Slips" post-it pad to "write what's really on your mind." Inside the front room, titles like "Before I was I" and "Ours, Yours, Mine" are packed into bursting shelves, while crammed in the back are desks and flat-screen computers for editing books and journals. And at the rear of the building is a small office (with couch, of course) where Michael Moskowitz, Other Press's publisher, sees his patients. 
 An analyst, an academic and an editor, Mr. Moskowitz, 49, is a psychoanalytic entrepreneur with a mission. He wants to rescue psychoanalysis from the academic isolation and bitter scholarly skirmishes that have dogged it for the last 20 years by bridging the divide between clinicians and theorists who work in various disciplines. In the process, he hopes to turn Other Books into an intellectual center for psychoanalysis, psychology and cultural studies.
"Postwar American psychoanalysis did itself a tremendous disservice by cutting itself off from the culture at large," he said one day recently, sipping a glass of wine over lunch at a Chelsea bistro. A compact man with shoulder-length hair and piercing eyes, Mr. Moskowitz speaks of psychoanalysis with the pained concern one might use to describe a wayward child. "On the one hand, it refused to recognize that all sorts of nonanalysts could legitimately use psychoanalytic theory. On the other hand, it cut itself off from real experimental science.
"At Other Press, we want to get scientists talking to humanists, clinicians to theorists, Lacanians to Freudians, and Americans to analysts all over the world."
Compared with the near-glacial time frame one associates with psychoanalysis, Other Press's progress has been extremely rapid. In less than two years, Mr. Moskowitz has opened the bookstore, published the company's first 30 titles, acquired three journals (including Psychoanalytic Quarterly, the oldest independent journal on the topic), and founded a new interdisciplinary journal, Infant, Child and Adolescent Psychotherapy. Last fall Other Press purchased Karnac Books, Britain's pre-eminent psychoanalytic bookseller and publisher, along with its two London bookstores and 250-title backlist.
Now Mr. Moskowitz is trying to turn his Web site into what he calls "the Amazon of psychoanalysis," offering a psychoanalytic best-seller list and chapters from Other Press's own books and journals.
"We want to be the destination for psychotherapists and people interested in cultural studies and related areas," Mr. Moskowitz explained. "There are over 500,000 therapists in the U.S. and several million around the world."
Other Press publishes widely in the field, including a series introducing the notoriously difficult ideas of the French psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan, that is being edited by Mr. Moskowitz's business partner, Judith Fehrer-Gurewich, a Belgian psychoanalyst with a law degree and a Ph.D. in sociology. It was she who raised funds for Other Press from European investment bankers with an interest in psychoanalysis.
Other new books are John Gedo's "Evolution of Psychoanalysis," a comprehensive overview of the field, as well as the reissue of several psychoanalytic classics, like "The Fifty-Minute Hour" by Robert Lindner and the feminist study "The Mermaid and the Minotaur" by Dorothy Dinnerstein.
Mr. Moskowitz is embarking on his venture at a time when psychoanalysis has taken a beating in both the academic world, where there have been nasty battles over Freud's theories and experimental practices, and the marketplace, where managed care and antidepressants have sharply curtailed the availability of therapy -- especially expensive, time-consuming psychoanalysis. Leading university presses like Yale and Harvard as well as established trade houses have virtually ceased publishing psychoanalytic books.
But Mr. Moskowitz is unfazed, and to scholars and analysts who have wearied of what they call the "Freud wars," Other Press represents a refreshingly open and nondogmatic perspective.
Jonathan Lear, a philosopher and psychoanalyst who teaches at the University of Chicago, says: "The best response to the critics of Freud is not to answer them point by point, but to do something new and interesting. And that is precisely what Michael is doing by providing a forum for the most creative work going on today." Elisabeth Young-Bruehl, the Anna Freud biographer and co-author of "Cherishment," a study of Eastern and Western theories of emotional attachment, says, "A wonderful rejuvenation of psychoanalysis is taking place, and Other Press is the cafe for the process."
Despite various setbacks, Mr. Moskowitz and others are convinced that psychoanalysis is developing a broader intellectual and social significance.
"Twenty years ago, psychoanalysis was predominately white, male and middle-class," said Kirkland Vaughns, an African-American psychoanalyst who is the editor of Infant, Child and Adolescent Psychotherapy. "A tremendous amount has been learned since then that can benefit emotionally disturbed black and Hispanic kids who are usually sent straight to the juvenile justice system."
There are few disciplines that have not been influenced by psychoanalysis, and new programs in psychoanalytic studies have recently been founded at Emory University, Columbia University and the University of Chicago. "As a cultural phenomenon, this is the great age of psychoanalysis," says Richard J. Bernstein, the head of the philosophy department at the New School for Social Research. "Our courses on it draw students from a greater variety of disciplines than ever before."
The son of an immigrant Hungarian plumber, Mr. Moskowitz has always perceived himself as someone who was, as in the title of his book, "Reaching Across Boundaries of Culture and Class." He grew up in Port Jervis, N.Y., an upstate town, and his first encounter with Freud came at age 14 when he found a copy of "The Interpretation of Dreams" his sister had brought home from college.
Arriving at Columbia in 1967, Mr. Moskowitz was shocked to find that the Psychology 101 course didn't include Freud. "No one reads that stuff anymore," he was told by a professor. Accordingly, in good 60's fashion, Mr. Moskowitz took over a class and brought in an analyst from the medical school. After receiving his Ph.D. in psychology from City University and his analytic training at New York University, Mr. Moskowitz taught, worked in mental hospitals and started a community-based counseling center for traumatized Vietnam veterans in New Haven.
In 1992 he joined Jason Aronson, a publisher of books on psychology and Judaica, and for the next five years ran the psychology half of the business. In 1998 he was approached by Ms. Gurewich with a proposal to start a press of their own.
Mr. Moskowitz is determined to develop Other Press's scope both here and abroad. He is talking to the London School of Economics about creating a think tank to analyze social issues from a psychoanalytic perspective, and he wants to start a journal in South America, where psychoanalysis seems to be thriving ("Every hill town in Argentina has an analyst," he says).
But New York is still at the psychological heart. "What I love about the bookstore is that it is a real space, a safe community where all are welcome and ideas can be freely exchanged," Mr. Moskowitz said. "The fact is that we are biological animals who live in culture. Psychoanalysis is the only theory I know of that tries to explain both these things."

HEADLINE: Helen Venturelli, 86; Fought for Police Widows

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Helen Venturelli, a champion of better benefits for widows of police officers and firefighters killed on the job, died March 15 at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx. She was 86 and lived in the Bronx.
In 1943, Mrs. Venturelli's husband, Pasquale, a policeman, leapt onto the running board of an automobile to try to apprehend two teenagers who were stealing the car. He died instantly when they rammed the vehicle into a wall. 
 Mrs. Venturelli was left with two sons, Robert, 9, and Alfred, 7, and a pension of $125 a month, with no increases for inflation. She earned extra money from various part-time jobs, and was eager to get involved when Florence Churchill, who was trying to raise three children with polio on a $125 monthly pension after her husband died in the line of duty, wrote her in 1960 about forming an organization to fight for higher payments to police widows.
At the first meeting of what became the Police and Fire Line of Duty Widows of New York City, Mrs. Venturelli pressed to include firefighters' widows, a suggestion that was immediately embraced. The group started a series of demonstrations at City Hall and elsewhere, and in 1962 won an increase in pensions equal to half the average monthly salary of a police officer, $347. In 1968, after years of struggle, they won hospitalization insurance, the same as that given to city workers.
Mrs. Venturelli succeeded Mrs. Churchill as president in 1977 and served in that post for 20 years. A striking woman with blue eyes, perfectly coiffed hair and a collection of distinctive hats, her powers of persuasion at City Hall and in Albany were keen, said Louise Crane, vice president of the widows' group.
"She knew how to talk, she could talk to anybody," said Mrs. Crane, whose husband was shot six times as he chased a robbery suspect up a Harlem fire escape in 1963.
Mrs. Venturelli is survived by her son, Alfred of Westchester; seven grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren.
Mrs. Venturelli visited Albany each year to fight for inflation adjustments. Beginning in 1978, she and her allies were successful each year.
"If you don't keep after something, you sometimes get forgotten," Mrs. Crane said. "And another thing Helen did: she always had them write thank-you notes."

HEADLINE: Clinton Lauds Technology As Key to India's Economy

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: HYDERABAD, India, March 24

 BODY:
President Clinton saluted India's information-technology industry today, the core of the country's steady economic growth and a supplier of brain power to Silicon Valley in California.
This was the last full day of Mr. Clinton's visit to India, and after having dealt with tricky strategic and political questions, it seemed appropriate that the president should concentrate on the economy, the area where there is probably the most commonality between the United States and India. 
 For the moment, trade between the two countries is relatively small, $12 billion last year compared with $94.9 billion between the United States and China. But it is the potential for dramatic growth, especially with an expanding middle class with a taste for American consumer goods, that excites the administration and American businesses.
The United States is India's largest trading partner. But India, because of its high tariffs and largely state-run economy, accounts for less than 1 percent of American global investments. Mr. Clinton, accompanied throughout his India trip by Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, made clear that he hoped that would change.
After touring booths that displayed information technology and receiving an Indian driver's license through the Internet, the president spoke at a software center, popularly known as Hitec City, an acronym for the Hyderabad Information Technology-Engineering Consultancy. Computer companies including Microsoft, Oracle and Toshiba have set up shop here, alongside new Indian giants and smaller start-ups.
In extolling Indian achievements in information technology, Mr. Clinton cited computer superstars like Vinod Khosla, who helped build Sun Microsystems, and Vinod Dahm, who created the Pentium chip.
India is "fast becoming one of the world's software superpowers," Mr. Clinton said, proving that "in a globalized world, developing nations not only can succeed, developing nations can lead."
The number of Internet users in India is expected to grow 10 times in the next four years, he added. The worth of India's information-technology exports have catapulted, to $4 billion from $150 million 10 years ago. The Indian government projects that by 2008 the exports will grow to $85 billion.
Most important for India, Mr. Clinton said, the significant effects of Indian computer engineers on the American industry is beginning to pay back at home. "We're moving from brain drain to brain gain," Mr. Clinton said.
A group, IndUS Entrepreneurs, whose members include the leading Indian software engineers in Silicon Valley, estimates that 30 percent of the software engineers there are of Indian origin. Most were educated at Indian technology institutes and went to the United States to give an impetus to Silicon Valley. But now, with the Indian economy growing at 6 percent a year, and with 10 percent growth within sight, some Silicon Valley veterans are beginning to return.
Mr. Clinton also struck one of his favorite themes about the Internet, that it can be used to lift the poor. India, he told his audience, accounts for 30 percent of the world's software engineers, but also 25 percent of the world's malnourished. Thus, he said, India is in a special position to show how its brains and inventiveness in the new technologies could improve health care and education across the nation's villages.
This is "good economics," Mr. Clinton said. If for example, villages had computers with educational software, and printers, that would create a potential for a revolution in education in a country where almost 50 percent of the population is illiterate.
"It would mean, among other things," he said, "that the world's most populous nation would have the world's largest number of educated people and, therefore, in no time would have the world's largest economy."

'Friends Don't Have to Agree'
 BOMBAY, March 24 -- Mr. Clinton ended his trip in India in this most populous city tonight. He addressed a group at the stock exchange and said he hoped that his presence would be the catalyst for a new relationship with the United States.
"Friends don't have to agree on every issue," Mr. Clinton said. "They just have to have an honest relationship about it."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Campaign by Confession in Bid for Kennedy's Senate Seat

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
PUT yourself in the shoes of Jack E. Robinson III.
Faster than you can say your own name, your fledgling campaign for Edward M. Kennedy's United States Senate seat has been clobbered by embarrassing accusations that you are sure came from the senator's camp: a rush of stories about your driving record, your legal history and, most mortifying of all, your love life. 
At the news conference to announce your candidacy, you find yourself forced to declare: "I am not a womanizer. I am not a groper."
Imagine how tempting it would be to fight back by dragging up the scandals that roiled your opponent's past.
Indeed, in an interview at the elegant home office that is so far his campaign's only place of operations aside from its Web site, www.robinson2000.com, Mr. Robinson suggested, "Perhaps, the senator should issue 'The Kennedy Report' to tell us exactly what happened at Chappaquiddick."
In that highly unlikely event, the report would be the second confessional exercise of the race.
Mr. Robinson, a 39-year-old businessman, sixth-generation Republican and first-time candidate, has already posted "The Robinson Report" on his campaign Web site. Perhaps the most notable effort at a pre-emptive political strike of the Internet era, it lists and explains every incident in his life that he thought might be fodder for attacks.
It includes an ex-girlfriend's restraining order against him, which was dropped, he writes, because he had phone-record proof that she was the real harasser, and a drunken driving charge that was dropped after he passed a Breathalyzer test. He also thrice flunked bar exams in other states before passing in Massachusetts, has had some lawsuit tangles and was once arrested for failing to pay a speeding ticket.
"Yes, there have been some embarrassing incidents, and we believe sources close to the Kennedy campaign have basically launched this attack," said Mr. Robinson, a bachelor. "So I decided to try to put an end to all these extraneous issues by just releasing everything I could think of in my entire life that could even possibly be used against us."
Senator Kennedy's spokesman, Will Keyser, dismissed as "completely ridiculous" Mr. Robinson's suggestion that the damaging information had originated in the senator's camp.
But that has not mollified Mr. Robinson. "You know, there's a candidate in this race who was actually convicted of a crime, and it's not me," he said. (After Mr. Kennedy's 1969 plunge off a Chappaquiddick bridge, which killed his car's passenger, Mary Jo Kopechne, he pleaded guilty to leaving the scene of an accident and was given a two-month suspended sentence.)
But the reasons for Mr. Robinson's frustration and anger just keep growing. Amid the rush of accusations, he was unceremoniously disowned this week by the Republican governor of Massachusetts, Paul Cellucci, and the State Republican Party, a rejection that Mr. Robinson called "unheralded in American history" and a "typical Beacon Hill back room double-cross."
And almost every day, local papers have carried a new source of embarrassment, leading some to comment that Senator Kennedy may finally have a rival with a past as problematic as his own.
On Tuesday, it was an unidentified woman's account in The Boston Globe that Mr. Robinson had subjected her to unwanted advances after a heavy-drinking dinner date, including French kisses that led her and her friends to refer to him as "Jack the Tongue." Mr. Robinson denies the accusation.
And on Thursday, it was reports that he left the scene of an accident that occurred while he was giving a radio interview on his cell phone. Mr. Robinson, who was not accused of being at fault, has said he was pulling forward to get out of traffic's way, not fleeing.
The flood of what he calls "fallacious and fraudulent allegations" has utterly obscured Mr. Robinson's campaign message: He presents himself as a Senator John McCain-style reformer who wants a radical overhaul of the country's education and campaign finance system, a less radical overhaul of the health care system and a more concerted foreign policy.
"We need to reform the system, and I don't believe the senator's capable of doing that," he said. "He is the system."
The accusations have also obscured what is otherwise a quite distinguished resume. Raised in Boston's Roxbury section, son of two entrepreneurs who divorced when he was 5, Mr. Robinson attended Brown University and received law and business degrees from Harvard. He was the top executive of an airline and wrote a book, "Freefall: The Needless Destruction of Eastern Airlines" (HarperCollins, 1992). In the mid-90's, he shifted to the cell-phone industry and founded a company doing business in the Caribbean.
ASKED why he was running now, Mr. Robinson said he had four goals in his life, and he had accomplished the first three: to graduate from Harvard; to be president of an airline by the time he was 30, which he made by about a week, and to be economically self-sufficient by 40. The fourth, he said, was to be a United States senator from his home state, Massachusetts.
He has been living out-of-state for a dozen years, in Manhattan and then Greenwich, Conn., he acknowledged; but he has voted here since the mid-90's, he said, and was moving his possessions back this week to the stone Tudor-style house on Boston's graceful Arborway where he grew up.
Some Massachusetts political analysts say that Mr. Robinson's candidacy is so laughable that the Republican Party should be ashamed for not being able to field a candidate credible enough to keep Senator Kennedy busy at home instead of off gaining votes for other Democrats.
But for Mr. Robinson, this is the fight of his life, he said, tougher and nastier than anything he has ever encountered.
He is putting out a "clarion call for help," he said, and plans to battle on no matter what.
"Party be damned, full speed ahead," he said, "because I don't want the next generation of politicians to live through what I just lived through."

HEADLINE: India Wins Battles in Its War on TB, but It Has a Long Way to Go

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: HYDERABAD, India, March 24

 BODY:
For a year, 10-year-old Chaitanya Pusa suffered from recurring fevers, a hacking cough and debilitating weakness. She saw healers who chanted mantras over her and private doctors who missed her real illness.
Her family, which survives on a meager income from three milking cows, sunk deeper and deeper in debt to pay the bills. The girl lay bedridden. "When she developed pain in her chest, we panicked and took her to the hospital," said her grandmother, Sandamma Pusa. 
 Doctors there promptly determined that Chaitanya was one of the two million people who develop tuberculosis each year in India, more than in any other country.
About 450,000 die from it -- more than from AIDS, malaria and tropical diseases combined -- but Chaitanya, now 12, will not be one of them.
Today, on World Tuberculosis Day, President Bill Clinton gave this little girl with dark brown eyes and long braids her final dose of the medicines that will cure her, and he signed the register that has documented each stage of her six-month treatment.
"TB kills more people around the world than ever before, including one almost every minute here in India," Mr. Clinton said, calling for intensified efforts to control the epidemic and to find a vaccine that will prevent it.
Chaitanya's is one of 40,000 lives that experts say have been saved by the use of a treatment that is popular here. It begins with an accurate diagnosis, then ensures that patients complete a six- to eight-month regimen in which an observer watches them take their medicines. Paramedics monitor the patients' records to double-check that the treatment is proceeding properly.
Last month a team of experts from the World Health Organization, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Bank, working with India's leading tuberculosis specialists, interviewed 1,000 patients and reviewed the records of more than 10,000 to evaluate the strategy, which has been used in India since 1993.
They discovered that this method, known as directly observed treatment, short course, or DOTS, has doubled cure rates to 84 percent and cut death rates to 4 percent from 29 percent.
Almost a quarter of a million people with tuberculosis, which is caused by bacteria and spreads through the air when an untreated patient coughs or talks, have been given the treatment in India. Still, it is available to only about 15 percent of India's population of one billion. The challenge in this vast, impoverished country with its shaky public health system is to expand the program, and fast.
Some critics say that the strategy is too cumbersome and that the public health systems in developing countries like India are too weak to make the program work on a much larger scale. But proponents say that more than five million patients have already been treated using DOTS and that the program has worked in poor countries like Tanzania, Vietnam and Peru.
"We have a cure for TB," said Tom Frieden, a doctor who ran New York City's tuberculosis program and now advises the Indian government about TB on behalf of the World Health Organization. "And it's cheap and cost-effective. It's just not being applied as widely as it should be."
More resources are coming in to spread the treatment to new parts of India. The World Bank, the largest contributor, has given India a five-year, low-interest loan of $142 million. The British government recently pledged $25 million over five years to combat TB in this southern state of Andhra Pradesh. The United States contributes a relatively small amount: $1 million for an applied research project in another southern state, Tamil Nadu.
The box of drugs, the size of a shoe box, required to treat a patient in India costs $10 to $15. And by saving the lives of young men and women, who are not only the most likely victims but their families' breadwinners, TB treatment also helps to prevent poverty.
The first thing this morning here in Hyderabad, Mohammad Jaffar, a social worker and father of six children 9 and younger, and Mohammad Fakaruddin, a leather worker with a 3-year-old son and a 4-year-old daughter, came into the Nampally treatment center. Both are in the early, intense phase of treatment. Jerripotula Urmila, a pharmacist, gave them their foil packets of pills and watched to be sure that they took them.
People with the disease in Hyderabad, where treatment is available, seem confident that they will be cured. For them the stigma of the disease has lifted.
Mohammad Mahaboob, 35, who drives a motorized rickshaw, got his final treatment this morning from the chief minister of Andhra Pradesh, Chandrababu Naidu. "I read in the newspaper that it is very much curable," Mr. Mahaboob said, "so I wasn't too worried."
And Chaitanya, dressed in her favorite full-length festival dress made of a shimmery golden fabric, walked confidently up to the president of the United States this morning for the last dose of medicine she would need to banish the disease.
She put the pills on the back of her tongue, tilted her head back and poured the water into her mouth, in the Indian way, without touching her lips. She was done with TB. Her ordeal was officially over.

HEADLINE: Pakistanis Are Uneasy Over Clinton's Visit

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 24

 BODY:
High anxiety has replaced great expectations in this capital, with people anticipating that President Clinton will arrive on Saturday not just to say hello, but also to deliver a scolding.
This is to be Mr. Clinton's final stop on a long-awaited visit to southern Asia. For months, Pakistan's military rulers, who took power in a bloodless coup on Oct. 12, had feared that Mr. Clinton would shun them entirely as their rivals in New Delhi wanted. 
 Instead, after five friendly days of talking, toasting and sightseeing in India, he will now make a meager five-hour stop here, enough time to meet with Pakistan's chief executive, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and to address the nation on television.
Given some of what Mr. Clinton has said in India, Pakistanis may prefer that he had gone straight home. "Reality is finally sinking in that this is the 21st century, the new world order, and that nations with strong economies will get America's attention, and that does not include Pakistan," said Rifaat Hussain, an international studies professor at Quaid-i-Azam University here.
Indeed, the difference in Washington's perceptions of India and Pakistan seems to be the difference between a potential market and a potential disaster.
India, a resolute democracy, is home to a booming software industry and a rapidly multiplying middle class. Pakistan, with democracy interrupted, is nearly bankrupt, relying on a steady intravenous drip of restructured loans from international lenders. Social upheaval appears to be a growing possibility, with poverty and corruption pushing people toward Islamic fundamentalism.
Today, the president's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said Mr. Clinton would carry a message of hard realities, telling General Musharraf that Pakistan was "a country in trouble" and that a nuclear-arms race with India would be a ruinous folly.
In May 1998, India and Pakistan exploded tit-for-tat tests of nuclear weapons, with New Delhi the first to hit the button. Last summer, the countries squared off in fierce battles in the mountains of Kashmir, the territory that the two have fought over since they emerged free from the British Empire in 1947.
India and Pakistan share more than a common boundary. They can watch each other's television stations. And this last week, Pakistanis scornfully viewed what seemed a love fest between their Indian enemies and America's president.
There was a sliding succession of indelible imagery. Mr. Clinton was wildly cheered in India's Parliament. He danced to folk music with Rajasthani village women, and he reveled at the sight of tigers in the wild.
"It's a personal and national victory for the Indians," said Najam Sethi, editor of a weekly, The Friday Times. "There's only one superpower in the world, and that superpower has come to them. When we see the Indian TV screen, we see such fawning over Clinton: 'Here, look, this is where Clinton sat!' And, 'Here, this is the kind of soup he ate!' "
Worse yet, the president appeared to be tilting toward India's side on Kashmir. In a widely quoted interview with ABC News, Mr. Clinton said, "I believe there are those within the Pakistani government that have supported those who engage in violence in Kashmir."
To many here, that seemed an endorsement of one of New Delhi's most constant accusations, that Pakistan has complete command over groups of Islamic militants that are creating bloody havoc in Indian-controlled Kashmir. The Pakistanis, to the contrary, routinely claim to supply only moral and political support to the "holy warriors."
General Musharraf had some reason to hope that Mr. Clinton would say something quite different. Recently, the president had called the subcontinent "the most dangerous place in the world today," a nervous observation that might well have preceded a United States move to involve itself in a coaxed settlement, something that Pakistan wants and India does not.
Instead, although Mr. Clinton did urge India to negotiate with Pakistan, he said emphatically, "I have certainly not come to south Asia to mediate the dispute over Kashmir." And at least in public, the president made no mention of well-documented human-rights violations by India's extensive army and paramilitary presence in Kashmir.
"It needs to be accepted that Washington's old policy of friendship with Pakistan is no more," Inayatullah, a columnist, wrote in a Pakistani daily, The News.
Often, America had employed Pakistan as reliable helpmate in the cold war. After the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan in 1979, Islamabad was used as the conduit for billions of dollars in military aid to the Mujahedeen resistance.
Today, some of those same warriors have shifted the focus of their battle to India and America. Among them is Osama bin Laden, whom the United States considers responsible for bombing two of its embassies in 1998. Mr. bin Laden's name will surely come up in the talks between Mr. Clinton and General Musharraf on Saturday. Mr. bin Laden is believed to be living in Afghanistan, with the ruling Taliban militia as his host. Washington has been disappointed in Pakistan's reluctance to use its influence with the Taliban to press for Mr. bin Laden's expulsion or arrest.
Another certain item on the president's agenda will be a timetable for Pakistan's return to democracy. On Thursday, General Musharraf announced that three rounds of local elections would be held from December to July 2001. But he gave no indications of when a full restoration of civilian government would occur -- and Washington immediately expressed dismay.
For his part, the general displays optimism about meeting the president. The two men may well hit it off. If Mr. Clinton can come across as a hail fellow well met, so can General Musharraf, a person with an easy manner around Westerners. His brother is a doctor in Chicago. His only son is an actuary in Boston for the State of Massachusetts.
But the two leaders are scheduled to meet one on one for only 40 minutes, a brief time that could be taken up simply defining what each means by troublesome terminology like "terrorism" and "democracy."
General Musharraf, however, has expressed confidence that when Mr. Clinton meets him in person he will find a trustworthy, altruistic soldier -- and not an enemy of freedom.
"We have to tell President Clinton our point of view," the general said. "I am confident that I will be able to convince him."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Share Prices End Volatile Trading Week on a Slow Note

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Stocks go up, and stocks go down. But yesterday stocks mainly went sideways.
A volatile week on Wall Street ended with a whimper, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell slightly and the technology-fattened Nasdaq composite index crept closer to the record it set earlier in March. The Dow was down 7.14 points, to 11,112.72, while the Nasdaq rose 22.42 points, to 4,963.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose slightly, 0.11 point, to 1,527.46. 
 The real action yesterday was in the bond market, with the price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond falling 1 7/32 , to 103 19/32 . That drove the bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, up to 5.99 percent from 5.91 percent.
Analysts said bond investors were worried by the report that some members of the Federal Reserve, which sets short-term interest rates, had argued for a half-percentage point increase in rates at the Fed's February meeting, whose minutes were released this week. The Fed has raised rates five times since June, most recently on Tuesday.
Each increase has been only one-quarter percentage point. A larger increase would indicate that the Fed is increasingly concerned about inflation, which is bad for bonds, because they pay a fixed return.
Generally, stocks and bonds move in tandem, with higher interest rates considered bad for stocks because they drive up corporate borrowing costs and make bonds more attractive as an alternative. But stock investors shrugged off the latest rate increase, confident that higher short-term rates would not slow the economy enough to hurt corporate profits and that the Fed was almost finished raising rates in any case.
"Every increase that occurs, people feel that we're closer to the ultimate time where the Fed's going to see the light at the end of the tunnel," said Vernon Winters, chief investment officer of Mellon Private Asset Management, which has $58 billion in assets. "Maybe a half-point rise gets it over with even sooner."
Mr. Winters said this week's action had been very positive for stock investors because it was the first time this year that stocks had risen across the board. He noted that the Wilshire 5000 index, which represents almost the entire United States stock market, broke out of a narrow trading range and set all-time highs for the last four days. Yesterday, the Wilshire closed at 14,751.64, up 17.39 points. For the week, the index was up more than 3 percent.
"Clearly, there's been a thrust in the last week that has a positive tone," Mr. Winters said. "The values of all stocks went up across the board, rather than just taking from one and giving to the other."
Big individual gainers yesterday included I.B.M., which rose $6.125, to $121.375, and Wal-Mart Stores, up $1.50, to $55.50.
The day's most noticeable decliner was Johnson & Johnson, which fell $7.50, to $72.50, after halting marketing of Propulsid, a heartburn drug that has been linked to heart problems and as many as 80 deaths. Propulsid sales, which were almost $1 billion in 1999, could be just over $250 million this year, analysts said. The drop wiped out more than $10 billion of Johnson & Johnson's market value.

HEADLINE: Son Chosen to Run for Mother's Seat

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., March 24

 BODY:
Nassau County Democrats announced today that they had chosen Craig Johnson, a lawyer, to run for the seat in the County Legislature left vacant by his mother, Barbara J. Johnson, who died earlier this month of cancer. Republicans are expected to pick their candidate for the crucial race early next week.
The outcome of the special election in the 11th Legislative District, which is to be held on May 2, will determine which party controls the 
 Legislature. The Democrats held a 10-to-9 majority for slightly more than two months, until the death of Mrs. Johnson on March 9 resulted in a 9-to-9 deadlock. She had just been elected to her third term, capturing 66 percent of the vote.
The Democrats had the majority for the first time in nearly 100 years when they took office in January after voters in November rejected Republican candidates, blaming them for the county's continuing fiscal problems.
Although the Long Island economy, like the rest of the nation's, is robust and the county is one of the country's wealthiest, Nassau faces a deficit this year of more than $100 million and its bonds have been reduced by Wall Street rating agencies to one step above junk status.
Mr. Johnson, 28, of Port Washington, said he looked forward to the next five weeks of campaigning. "It's going to be a hard campaign, and I can't stress that enough, but I know I have a great team with all the Democratic members of the Legislature behind me."
Mr. Johnson has not held elective office in county government but worked with his mother during her time in the Legislature.
Judith A. Jacobs, the Democratic leader of the County Legislature, will retain her title of majority leader if Mr. Johnson is elected.
"The voters put us here in November to clean things up, but we've only just begun," Mrs. Jacobs said. "We need Craig to hold on to the majority."
The 11th Legislative District is traditionally regarded as a swing district, where the number of Republican and Democratic voters are evenly divided.
The district is comprised of Greenvale; Port Washington, including the villages of Sands Point, Manorhaven, Baxter Estates, Port Washington North and Flower Hill; Roslyn, which includes Roslyn Estates and Roslyn Harbor; Manhasset, including the villages of Munsey Park, Plandome, Plandome Heights and Plandome Manor; and parts of the village of Old Westbury and Westbury.

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICAN BLUEPRINT: Details of Plan on Spending and Tax Cuts

 BODY:

The House passed a Republican budget blueprint early yesterday by a vote of 211 to 207. The nonbinding blueprint sets targets for spending and tax cuts for next year.
Republicans said the plan balanced the need to spend more on the military and education with their desire to restrain the growth of government and provide large tax cuts. Democrats said the plan would push the government back into deficit, put Social Security and Medicare at risk and force deep cuts in essential programs. 
 
OVERALL SPENDING: Total spending authority for the fiscal year starting on Oct. 1 would rise 3 percent, to $1.85 trillion.
 
TAX CUTS: Over five years, tax cuts would be at least $150 billion. The measure also created a $50 billion reserve fund that could be used to reduce taxes and would channel to tax cuts any increase in the projected surplus over the next five years, a figure that Republicans said could be as much as $40 billion. That would make the total tax cut as much as $240 billion over five years.
 
DISCRETIONARY SPENDING: Spending on programs that must be appropriated each year would rise 3.2 percent, to $596.5 billion. Of that, $307.3 billion would go to the Pentagon, an increase of 6 percent. Spending on all other nonmilitary programs would rise by less than $1 billion, to $289.2 billion. Some categories, like education, would have substantial increases, but nearly everything else would have to be cut after taking account of inflation.
 
DEBT REDUCTION: The part of the budget surplus generated by Social Security, some $2.3 trillion over 10 years and $1 trillion over five years, would be allocated to reducing the $3.5 trillion in national debt held by the public.
 
MEDICARE: Some $40 billion would be allocated over five years to pay for the addition of prescription drug coverage to the health insurance system for the elderly.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Slip, But Experts Remain Upbeat

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Orders for costly manufactured goods continued to slide in February, again weighed down by a plunge in demand for aircraft, the government said today.
Orders for durable goods like cars, computers and appliances and big-ticket items, intended to last three years or more, fell 2.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted $208.45 billion. But even so, economists said the manufacturing sector's recovery from the global financial crisis of 1997-99 remained on track. 
 February's report, released by the Commerce Department, was far weaker than analysts' forecast of a decline of 0.2 percent. The report followed a drop of 2.2 percent in January, which was revised downward from a previous fall of 1.9 percent. The February fall was the sharpest since April of last year.
But excluding an 8.7 percent drop in transportation orders, February orders were down a more modest 0.2 percent. Compared with February 1999, orders were up 7.3 percent. And in December of last year, overall orders rose 6.5 percent. Analysts underscored that there was little in the report to suggest an imminent slowdown in the booming economy.
"All of this is coming after a pretty lengthy period of strength," said Jay Feldman, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. "The rest of the economy is running red hot."
Financial markets showed little reaction to the report, which came just days after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the second time this year to try to keep the economy from overheating.
Bond prices, which are highly sensitive to inflation, initially ticked up on the report, but quickly resumed a downward slide on fears that the Fed might raise rates more aggressively in the months ahead given that its moves so far have had scant impact on the torrid pace of growth.
Such worries mounted after the release of minutes from the central bank's Feb. 1-2 policy meeting, which showed several Fed officials had pushed for a more drastic course of monetary tightening.
Today's durable goods report said orders for transportation equipment fell 8.7 percent, to $47.14 billion, led by a decline in aircraft and parts orders. Economists tied the drop to a 38-day strike by engineers at the Boeing Company that ended only last week.
Industrial machinery and equipment was down 4.6 percent at $40.63 billion. Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment, however, rose 6.4 percent, to $39.71 billion, in February.
Shipments of finished products fell 1.8 percent, to $205.71 billion. But the orders backlog, a harbinger of future production, rose 0.5 percent, to $519.04 billion, adding to January's 0.7 percent gain.

HEADLINE: Despite Talk of Vice Presidency, a Senator Focuses on His Day Job

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 24

 BODY:
In New York, there is the colossal battle known as Hillary versus Rudy. In the Senate race in New Jersey, the winner of a hugely expensive fight for the Democratic nomination will face the survivor of a four-way clash among obscure Republicans. But in Connecticut, things are so quiet that voters could be forgiven for not realizing that Senator Joseph I. Lieberman is actually up for re-election.
Mr. Lieberman, a two-term Democrat, has sky-high approval ratings, overflowing campaign coffers and, as yet, no opponent. The one Republican who has expressed any interest in mounting a challenge, Mayor Philip A. Giordano of Waterbury, has been discouraged from doing so by two of the most important members of his party, Gov. John G. Rowland and the state Republican chairman, Chris DePino. 
 So when Mr. Lieberman's name comes up these days, it is not in terms of the Senate race in November but the result of a recent bubble of speculation about him as a possible running mate for Al Gore. In a more substantive way, though, the lack of a United States Senate contest in Connecticut is allowing Mr. Lieberman to do actual work, like crisscrossing the state last week to visit schools and push for a major new education bill. "This bill actually dramatically increases federal support of education, by $7 billion," he told the 40 students in the senior class at Bridge Academy, a charter school in downtown Bridgeport, last Friday.
"We call it three R's: reinvestment, reinvention and responsibility," he said, standing at the front of a classroom used for history, art and Spanish lessons. "I hope that it will come up in April in the Senate."
Clearly, this was not the electrifying oratory of a candidate hot on the campaign trail. But in many ways, the visit encapsulated Mr. Lieberman's current political state: his confidence, his popularity and his bipartisan reputation.
Bridge Academy, with 160 students, was founded three years ago with the help of federal money made possible by a bill Mr. Lieberman sponsored with a Republican senator, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota. Mr. Lieberman arrived at the school to thunderous applause, smiled proudly as students told him of the school's success and spoke earnestly of the need for more federal money to replace a start-up grant that ends this year.
Questions from the students also served as a reminder of the delicate balance a senator must strike between the most global issues and the most local ones. The first hand in the air belonged to Zasha Soto, whose interests were purely parochial. "Would you be the speaker at our graduation?" she asked. Mr. Lieberman agreed, provided that it fit into his schedule.
After the talk, Yessenia Romero followed the senator into the hallway with a question at the opposite extreme. "How do you feel about maybe becoming vice president?" she wanted to know.
"It's nice to hear it," Mr. Lieberman said of the recent speculation, which includes a column urging his selection in the Capitol Hill journal Roll Call last week and a recent article in the conservative Weekly Standard. "But I don't expect it." Miss Romero seemed satisfied with that response.
A listing of possible vice-presidential contenders in the magazine Campaigns and Elections also puts him on the Democratic short list.
Far-fetched as a spot on the national ticket may be, the fact that Mr. Lieberman, 58, an observant Jew who does not work on the Sabbath, is mentioned at all is testimony to the heights his stature has reached, both in the Democratic Party and in the Senate. One reason for his increased prominence was his willingness to become the first Democrat to condemn President Clinton publicly for his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, a stand that reinforced Mr. Lieberman's reputation as one of the Senate's stronger moral voices.
But much of his rise has to do with his reputation as an independent-minded New Democrat whose religious observance is appreciated by some of his more conservative colleagues across the aisle and whose policy interests have at times diverged with the majority view in the Democratic Party. For example, he speaks favorably about school vouchers.
"People don't want you to agree with them on everything," Mr. Lieberman said over tea and a cheese omelet at a Bridgeport diner last Friday. "They want to feel that you are doing what you feel is right. Part of what I have tried to do is be independent and not walk the political party line if I didn't think the party happened to be right in that case. And this state is very supportive of that kind of representation."
It is a tad ironic that Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the man Mr. Lieberman ousted from the Senate in 1988, won acclaim in some of the same ways -- by being one of the first Republicans to condemn Richard M. Nixon over Watergate, for example. Mr. Lieberman keeps that 1988 race in mind, in particular how he overcame a 24-point deficit in the polls to topple a seemingly invincible incumbent.
That race is a constant reminder, he said, not to take his re-election for granted. To that end, he has written a book, "In Praise of Public Life," a sentimental ode to the life of a career politician that is in equal parts patriotic and self-promotional. The book, published by Simon and Schuster, is now in stores.
He has also amassed a considerable $3.1 million war chest. "I do feel fortunate now, having put this amount of money in the bank," Mr. Lieberman said. "There is no question that it does give me more time to focus on my Senate work, and that's a blessing."
As expected, his re-election campaign will focus on his work on several issues, including economic growth, environmental protection and national security, as well as on the policy areas he hopes to continue tackling: improving education and cultural values, increasing federal financing of scientific research, closing the wealth gap and protecting the state's defense industry jobs.
"If you are an incumbent, you are running on your record, so hopefully you have been doing your job aggressively since the first day that you got it," he said. "A campaign is a way just to go back and talk to people about what you have done and what you hope to do if they are good enough to re-elect you." He said he had slowed his fund-raising efforts.
Mr. Giordano, a 36-year-old Republican serving his third two-year term as mayor of Waterbury, has formed an exploratory committee to begin raising money and has been traveling the state to gauge his level of support. He said he understood why the governor and other Republicans might not be too optimistic about his chances.
"When you are running against someone like Joe Lieberman, who has $3.5 million in the bank, I wouldn't expect the governor's comments to be too encouraging," Mr. Giordano said. But he questioned the effectiveness of Mr. Lieberman and the state's senior senator, Christopher J. Dodd, who is also a Democrat. "I believe we have been ill represented up in D.C.," he said in a telephone interview.
"I believe our senators have gotten too global," Mr. Giordano added. "They have lost touch with the local folks." He said he thought that Mr. Lieberman was vulnerable to a challenge, especially in the areas of defense and education. Mr. Giordano said he did not know when he might formally declare his candidacy.
Mr. Lieberman, for his part, said he would continue his work in Connecticut and in Washington, paying little heed to any talk about his joining the national ticket.
"It is surreal," he said of the speculation. "Because unlike most political experiences, this is not something one creates. This is, you know, the Grand Mentioner, and you get mentioned and you know it's an honor to be mentioned, but I consider myself to be fortunate to be a senator from Connecticut. It's what I dreamed of doing. I love my work and I don't expect or seek anything else."

HEADLINE: OPEC Divided On Increase In Production

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 24

 BODY:
After watching oil prices triple over the last year to their highest level since the Persian Gulf war, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is groping toward agreement on a modest increase in production.
But OPEC ministers preparing for a crucial meeting here Monday still appeared divided today on the extent and timetable of any production increases despite intense lobbying by the United States, where soaring gasoline prices have created a political uproar. 
 It is widely expected that OPEC ministers, who control about 40 percent of the world's oil supply, will agree to increase production. But few outside experts think the increase will be big enough to cause more than modest price reductions at the gasoline pump.
Officials from Saudi Arabia, the world's largest producer and the most powerful OPEC member, have quietly endorsed the goal of reducing oil prices to about $25 a barrel from its peak of $34 on March 8.
Indeed, OPEC production is already running more than a million barrels a day over its stated limit of 23 million barrels, and most experts believe the bulk of this extra oil is coming from Saudi Arabia.
Since March 8, the benchmark market price for oil has dropped about 18 percent and as of today was trading at about $28 a barrel. Much of that reflects an expectation among oil traders that OPEC will raise production by about 1.5 million barrels a day. It also reflects an unofficial increase in production that has already occurred.
But even if oil does settle at about $25 a barrel, analysts say that would probably knock only a few pennies off the price of gasoline in the United States, where a gallon of unleaded regular costs an average $1.60.
In the meantime, countries like Iran and Libya were still fighting against a big production increase and their positions have hardened in recent days.
"OPEC is divided," said Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, Indonesia's oil minister, to reporters in Jakarta today. "I think it's going to be a heated debate during the meeting."
With oil officials already descending on the Intercontinental Hotel here today, the stakes and the uncertainties about Monday's meeting are both usually high.
"The only thing we know is that OPEC is going to increase production," said Peter Ginoux, who oversees petroleum trading at Salomon Smith Barney in London. "We don't know how much of an increase. We don't know how it will be divided between countries and we don't know the timing."
It was OPEC's surprisingly unified and disciplined decision to cut daily production by 2.1 million barrels last March that sent prices soaring and ignited protests from American drivers and politicians.
In the House of Representatives, lawmakers passed a largely symbolic bill this last week that would require the Clinton administration to determine whether OPEC nations were colluding to fix prices and punish any deemed to be doing so. There is also growing pressure on President Clinton to provide relief by selling oil from the federal government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
Bill Richardson, the Secretary of Energy, has waged an intensive lobbying campaign with the leaders of oil-producing countries, and spent much of this last week meeting with officials in Norway, Nigeria, Algeria and the United Arab Emirates.
American officials have been pushing for an increase of as much as 2.5 million barrels a day, the amount that oil analysts believe is necessary to stabilize prices at about $25 and allow oil companies to rebuild their depleted reserves.
Saudi officials are believed to support an increase of about 1.5 million barrels a day, and they appear to have support from countries like Venezuela and Mexico. Though Mexico is not a member of OPEC, it joined in last year's production cut and is a formidable producer.
But analysts say the real issue is not the nominal increase in amount countries pledge to produce. More important is whether those increases come on top of the current cheating on restrictions.
If oil-exporting countries increase their formal commitments by two million barrels a day, but eliminate the roughly one million barrels a day in noncompliance, the net increase would be only about one million barrels and its market impact would be limited.
"The biggest question is how they handle compliance," said Gary N. Ross, chief executive of PIRA Energy Group, a petroleum industry consulting firm. "How much do they raise the pledge volume, and does noncompliance come down as a result?"
Robert Priddle, executive director of the International Energy Agency, a Paris-based research group, estimated that world output will need to increase by 500,000 to 1 million barrels a day just to bring supply back in line with demand.
Oil producers are understandably anxious, having experienced both an unnerving plunge in prices and an almost equally unexpected ricochet back up -- all in the last two years.
The 1997-98 Asian financial crisis, which deeply depressed demand for oil, and a Saudi decision to step up production helped contribute to a supply glut in 1998 that pushed prices down to about $11 a barrel, inflicting severe financial pain on OPEC nations and other big exporters. Analysts estimate that decline cost OPEC nations $65 billion in revenue.
The severity of that crisis finally imposed discipline on OPEC nations, particularly chronic cheaters like Venezuela, and persuaded non-OPEC producers like Mexico and Norway to join in with production cuts last year.
Now prices have shot up even more dramatically than they declined two years ago, leaving consumers as well as producers almost shell shocked by the turbulence.
"They have never really been in this situation before," said Paul Horsnell, assistant director of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies in Oxford, England. "This is the first time they have ever had to add more than a million barrels a day on the market in a coordinated way."
The last time prices shot up so much was during the Persian Gulf war, when oil producers cranked up their output to compensate for the cutoff from Iraq and Kuwait. But that case was simpler, because all producers simply produced as much as they possibly could.
Iran's OPEC governor, Hossein Kazempour Ardebili, said on Thursday that he had become more skeptical about production increases in the aftermath of the price retreat since the March 8 peak.
"Two weeks ago it may have been justified to call on OPEC to increase production," Mr. Ardebili said. "But now we have a different situation in that during the past three to four days oil prices have fallen by $4 to $5 and this is expected to continue."
Mr. Ross, of PIRA Energy Group, argued that OPEC has extraordinary leverage at the moment because production growth has been slow in non-OPEC areas and global economic growth is accelerating. A 1 percent increase in global economic growth increases oil demand by an estimated 700,000 barrels a day.
"The momentum is with OPEC," Mr. Ross said.

HEADLINE: Indian Bureau Recommends Federal Recognition for Two Pequot Tribes in Connecticut

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
The Bureau of Indian Affairs recommended yesterday that the Eastern Pequot and Paucatuck Eastern Pequot tribes of Connecticut be granted federal recognition, a step that would provide new government benefits and economic opportunity for tribe members and perhaps bring more casinos to Connecticut.
While formal recognition might take a year or more, ecstatic leaders of the Eastern Pequots and the Paucatuck Eastern Pequots, who share a 224-acre reservation in North Stonington near the Rhode Island border, voiced confidence that their decadeslong quest for tribal sovereignty was at last in sight. 
 "This is truly an historic day," said Mary Sebastian, 64, chairwoman of the 770-member Eastern Pequots, in a telephone interview last night. "After 20 years of waiting, we are pleased the Bureau of Indian Affairs agrees that our tribe has maintained its social, cultural and political identity as a sovereign nation."
In another interview, James Cunha, 37, chief of the Paucatuck Eastern Pequots, said his 150 members had "wept tears of joy" at the news from Washington and were gathering to celebrate and to plan work on a final comment on the tribe's petition, which must be filed in 180 days. "We are very happy," he said.
Ms. Sebastian and Mr. Cunha noted that recognition would make tribe members eligible for a wide range of federal assistance in housing, education, health care and other benefits, and that economic opportunities for members would undoubtedly follow.
Both declined to say whether their tribes planned eventually to establish casinos in Connecticut, but Mr. Cunha expressed gratitude to Donald Trump and the Trump Organization for supporting his tribe's efforts.
Only two tribes in Connecticut have federal recognition, and they have been able to use their status to open highly successful casinos: the Mashantucket Pequots, who operate Foxwoods, one of the world's largest and most prosperous gaming establishments, and the Mohegans, who run the Mohegan Sun Casino in the Uncasville section of Montville.
"What we plan to do at this point is still a ways away," Mr. Cunha said. "We're taking this one step at a time."
Ms. Sebastian said that her tribe, if recognized, would make "housing, education and health care for our members No. 1 on our agenda." As for people leaping to conclusions about casinos, she said: "Let them leap. Right now, I'm not going to focus on anything else."
She expressed gratitude to the Connecticut congressional delegation and to state and local officials who supported the tribe's petition.
Joy over the bureau's recommendation masked a long, bitter dispute between the Paucatuck and Eastern Pequots about whether the groups constitute two tribes or different factions of the same tribe, and about which group was truly descended from the original Pequots, who were given the reservation by 17th-century colonial leaders after a war that nearly wiped out the tribe.
The Eastern Pequots began pursuing federal recognition in 1979, a complex process to show that the group had been continuously identified as a tribe since colonial times, that it was a distinct community, that it had maintained authority over its members and that current members were proven descendants.
In 1990, 150 Paucatuck Eastern members began pursing federal recognition separately. The Mohegans supported the Paucatucks and the Mashantucket Pequots supported the Eastern Pequots, who have contended that the Paucatuck Pequots were part of the Eastern tribe.
Both applications had run into trouble in the last decade. In 1990, the bureau said the Eastern Pequots had skipped generations in their attempt to show historic links to ancestors. In 1994, the bureau said the Paucatuck tribe had not proved it was a distinct community since historic times.
While their applications for recognition have been pending, the Paucatuck and Eastern Pequots have avoided talk of plans to establish casinos, but that possibility and its enormous impact have prompted concern among officials.
The Town of North Stonington has hired an anthropologist and a genealogist to monitor both federal petitions, and town officials have said that federal recognition of even one group would probably result in land claims and casinos that would bring drastic change to the area. State officials, too, are monitoring the situation carefully.
Mr. Trump, who has a casino in Atlantic City, has indicated an interest in working with the tribes.
Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said the state had been notified of the bureau's decision, but had not immediately received a copy of the 40-page ruling. "We will review the decision and will consult with the governor's office as well as our congressional delegation and the affected towns," Mr. Blumenthal said.
Ms. Sebastian said, "We are proud of our tribe's long and impressive history of attempting to work with its neighbors in North Stonington, Ledyard and Preston, as well as the surrounding communities."

HEADLINE: Annan Exhorts U.N. Council on 'Oil for Food' for Iraqis

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 24

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan warned today that the United Nations was in danger of losing a propaganda war with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq if the "oil for food" program intended to help Iraqi civilians suffering under sanctions is not made more effective immediately.
"The humanitarian situation in Iraq poses a serious moral dilemma for this organization," Mr. Annan told the council. "The United Nations has always been on the side of the vulnerable and the weak, and has always sought to relieve suffering, yet here we are accused of causing suffering to an entire population." 
 He was speaking at a special daylong Security Council session to review the organization's work in Iraq, during which the United States was on the defensive against criticism that it is blunting the positive impact of the program by blocking more than 1,000 import contracts.
Responding to such charges, James B. Cunningham, the deputy American representative at the United Nations, announced today that the United States was lifting its holds, in the committee on sanctions against Iraq, on 70 contracts worth at least $100 million. The United States also formally introduced its resolution doubling to $600 million the value of oil equipment Iraq may import every six months. The amount of oil Iraq can export has not been limited since December.
Richard C. Holbrooke, the American representative, was not in the Security Council today. He has played down the Iraq issue since his arrival in August, showing little interest in a long-running Clinton administration policy that has drawn rebukes against the United States. He has turned the Iraq file over to Mr. Cunningham, who is more familiar with the issue, having been posted here when Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, an invasion that led to the imposition of international sanctions.
Today, Mr. Cunningham offered several proposals for better supervision in Iraq, so that American suspicions about the ultimate use or destinations of certain imported goods, including electrical, scientific, telecommunications and oil equipment, could be reduced.
Even with current Iraqi problems, Mr. Cunningham said, Iraq's oil exports and food imports are reaching the levels that prevailed before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
In a long speech accompanied by statistical material circulated to council members, Mr. Cunningham continued to place much of the blame for shortcomings in the oil sales plan on Mr. Hussein's government, which, he said, refuses to expedite orders, share information or allow inspections at many sites.
Mr. Annan also took the Iraqis to task, saying people living under sanctions are "often victims both of their own government and of the measures taken against it." The only way to end that, he added, is for Iraq to comply with council decisions.
The council is waiting to see whether Mr. Hussein will allow the return of weapons inspectors, the key to ending sanctions.
But Mr. Annan expressed anguish over the position the United Nations now finds itself in, with an uncooperative Iraq on one side and an intransigent United States on the other.
"We are in danger of losing the argument, or the propaganda war -- if we haven't already lost it -- about who is responsible for this situation, President Saddam Hussein or the United Nations," he said.
During today's debate, several council members tried to shift from past blame to future efforts to make the "oil for food" program work.
Sir Jeremy Greenstock of Britain, speaking to reporters before this afternoon's session, said there were numerous things the council could do without further debate.
"We can speed the procedures in the sanctions committee," he said. "We can inject more cash into the U.N. program in Iraq. We can start to stop the smuggling that is going on, the illegal oil sales. We can increase the number of monitors looking at the program's delivery in Iraq, and if we do that, we can bring down the number of holds."
The Russians, French and Chinese were most critical today of the American and British positions on Iraq. Sergey Lavrov, the Russian representative, accused the United States and Britain of killing more than 140 people and wounding hundreds in attacks in the no-flight zones in northern and southern Iraq.
"Any explanation that these strikes were not directed at civilians does not hold water," Mr. Lavrov said. He called for an early suspension of sanctions.
Peter van Walsum, the Dutch representative and chairman of the committee on sanctions against Iraq, said that despite differences, there was a council consensus that Iraq still has to convince the world that it does not have dreams of creating prohibited weapons.
"Iraq is the only country in modern history that has not only attempted to develop all categories of weapons of mass destruction -- nuclear, biological and chemical -- but has actually used such weapons, both against a foreign enemy and against its own citizens," Mr. van Walsum said. "In doing so, Iraq has placed itself in a league of its own."
Until today, two issues lying at the heart of the debate on Iraq had rarely been raised. One is the scarcity of verifiable information beyond what is physically visible to United Nations officials in Iraq -- whose appointments Baghdad can control in the sense that it can reject nominees for relief positions, and whose movements are frequently circumscribed.
All health and poverty figures the United Nations has to work with are provided by the Iraqi government. Journalists cannot report freely in the country, and the international news agencies there must use Iraqi citizens for day-to-day reporting, which usually amounts to no more than repeating what officials say in the state-controlled press.
Iraqi government decisions are often opaque, some United Nations officials say. In some ministries, there appears to be little planning for social development using what funds are available to the government from its own resources.
The second issued seldom raised before now is that in the virtual absence of independent information-gathering in Iraq, critics of Mr. Hussein say, the effects of sanctions can be manipulated to influence public opinion inside and outside the country, as a few speakers noted today.
Richard Butler, a diplomat in residence at the Council on Foreign Relations, who was chief arms inspector in Iraq from 1997 to 1999, argues that sanctions worked when they were first imposed.
"Sanctions might work initially, depending not on how severe they are or how the leadership reacts to them," he said in an interview on Wednesday. "They did, in the Iraq case, concentrate their minds for a while."
But the longer sanctions are applied, Mr. Butler said, "the less and less effective they become, to the point where they invert in their effectiveness for two reasons. One, they get busted through a black market, and two, the leadership is able to parlay this into a reason for staying in power.
"I think that's exactly where Saddam is now," he said. "He's saying, 'Only I can protect you from all those bad people out there, and that's why you've got to stick with me.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft Said to Offer Plan
To Settle Antitrust Case
Microsoft presented a proposal in an attempt to settle the antitrust case filed by the Justice Department and 19 states against the company. Lawyers were studying the plan to decide whether it was promising enough to warrant weekend negotiations.
Representatives of the government said Microsoft agreed to restrain some of its business practices but the document contained so many technical details that they could not analyze it quickly. Judge Richard A. Posner, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals in Chicago who is acting as a mediator in the case, has urged the two sides to resolve the case quickly. Page A1.
 
Dow Falls, but Nasdaq Rises Again
A volatile week on Wall Street ended quietly, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell slightly and the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index crept closer to the record it set earlier in March. The Dow was down 7.14 points, to 11,112.72, while the Nasdaq rose 22.42 points, to 4,963.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.11 point, to 1,527.46. The real action yesterday was in bonds, with the price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond falling, sending the bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, up to 5.99 percent from 5.91 percent on Thursday. C3. 

European Beer Prices Investigated
European investigators looking into the retail price of beer made surprise visits to five breweries, including Grolsch and Heineken in the Netherlands and the Italian brewer Peroni, to investigate documents that may shed light on how the industry sets prices. C2.
 
Steel Maker Bids for Car-Parts Unit
The British mobile telephone giant Vodafone AirTouch said it had received an unsolicited offer from ThyssenKrupp, Germany's largest steel maker, for the car parts and engineering unit of Mannesmann, which Vodafone recently agreed to acquire for $183 billion. Analysts said a deal for the unit could be worth $10 billion. C2.
 
Clinton Lauds India's Tech Industry
India's information technology industry, the core of the country's steady economic growth, was saluted by President Clinton, who, on the final full day of his visit to the country, was promoting trade between the two countries and more American investment in India. A4.
 
Durable Goods Orders Decline 2.3%
Orders for durable goods declined 2.3 percent in February, the second consecutive monthly decline and the largest in 10 months. The figure was lower than analysts had expected, but was still 7.3 percent higher than a year earlier, indicating that the recovery by the manufacturing sector of the economy from the global financial crisis of 1997-99 remained on track. C3.
 
Exxon Mobil Challenges ARCO Sale
Exxon Mobil said that it sued to block the sale of the Atlantic Richfield Company's Alaskan oil fields to Phillips Petroleum, contending it had the right of first refusal to purchase some of the assets. The lawsuit seeks a preliminary injunction that could delay BP Amoco's proposed $33 billion purchase of ARCO. C3.
 
South American Auto Trade Pact
South America's two largest countries, Brazil and Argentina, reached an agreement on the trade of automobiles. The five-year accord will establish an equal balance of imports and exports between the two nations, in addition to a shared tariff of 35 percent on imports from outside the Mercosur trade bloc, which includes Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay. C2.
 
I.B.M. Developing TV Internet Chip
International Business Machines said it was developing technology to provide Internet access on television sets. C14.
