HEADLINE: An Enigmatic Pianist Reclaims Her Stardom

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
Few people who have heard the tempestuous Argentine-born pianist Martha Argerich play ever forget it. She is a colossal technician, a powerfully intuitive musician and an electrifying performer. Just last week at Carnegie Hall, as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra in a concert conducted by Charles Dutoit, Ms. Argerich vanquished the formidable challenges of Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3. Her fiery, ecstatic performance elicited a frenzied ovation, including 10 curtain calls, from a sold-out house.
Though she inspires cultlike devotion among ordinary concertgoers, her admirers include many of the world's most respected musicians. Mstislav Rostropovich, the great cellist and conductor, recently called her "a pianist with no limits at all, none whatsoever." 
 But Ms. Argerich, who will perform again tonight at Carnegie Hall, is the most enigmatic figure in classical music today, by turns passionate, disarming and chaotic. Beset with inner demons and insecurities, she can be an erratic performer and has been famously prone to canceling concerts precipitously. "Martha is an unguided missile," as one close friend of hers has memorably put it.
For years the reclusive pianist assiduously avoided giving interviews, even as adoring fans worried about her and flocked to her concerts, hoping that she was well, hoping she would play. Ms. Argerich kept her silence even as rumors spread that she was fatally ill.
But on one recent night, close to 11 o'clock, Ms. Argerich (pronounced AHR-gur-itch) sat in the lounge of a midtown hotel for the first extended one-on-one interview she has given in nearly 20 years and talked openly about her work and her health.
Some weeks earlier she had allowed a statement to be released confirming that she had been treated for melanoma, cancer of the skin, at the John Wayne Cancer Institute in Santa Monica, Calif. But now she revealed the extent of the problem: the melanoma had spread to her lymph nodes and lungs. "I was afraid of my own body," she said of the trauma she faced. "I was afraid of myself for the first time; afraid to be me."
So far the treatments appear to have been successful. She is in remission. Indeed, out of gratitude Ms. Argerich's concert is to benefit the institute. All tickets were scooped up weeks ago. Her program tonight is also significant because, for the first time in 19 years, she is performing solo repertory in a major American concert venue.
During the wide-ranging 90-minute interview, Ms. Argerich, who is 58, also spoke of musical matters and her tumultuous career: her beginnings as a pint-size prodigy; her early triumphs; her crisis of confidence when she felt "out of order," as she put it, "like an elevator or a telephone;" her practice habits, which can be "not very systematic and not very disciplined;" and her "contradictory type of relationship" to the piano. "I can be obsessive" when there is music to be learned, she said; but at other times "I don't touch the piano at all."
Pinning the unpredictable Ms. Argerich down to a time and place for the interview proved difficult. When she finally arrived as promised, she had just finished practicing in an upstairs studio at Carnegie Hall and was in work mode: dressed in slacks and a long sweater, her sleek mane of black hair a bit disheveled. Ms. Argerich, barely 5-foot-4, is a striking woman with bright brown eyes and a sturdy build. Her hands are surprisingly small, and on this night a few finger tips were protected by band-aids.
In 1981, Ms. Argerich announced that she was giving up solo recitals entirely, and, with occasional exceptions for special, usually hush-hush events, she has kept to her word. Why?
"It's really a very obsessive situation, when you are alone onstage playing on your own," she said. "I have a tendency to be a very obsessive person. It makes me very . . . I don't know." Of course, the solo repertory is wonderful, she added. But she prefers playing chamber music and concertos, which is more stimulating and less lonely.
Her insecurities as a performer long predate her health crisis. The daughter of two university-based economists in Buenos Aires, she began piano lessons at 5. When she was 8 she played a difficult Beethoven piano sonata (Op. 31, No. 3) for the renowned pianist Walter Gieseking, who proclaimed her a phenomenon. At 16, within the space of three weeks, she won both the Busoni and the Geneva International Piano Competitions.
When she was 21 she suffered a crippling bout of depression that lasted over two years. After studying in Europe, she moved to New York and "didn't do anything," she said. "I just sat in an apartment watching the late late show." Even getting married and having the first of her three daughters, each by a different man, did not lift her from the depression.
"I felt I could not play any more," she said. "Since I spoke several languages, I thought I would just become a secretary." She credits a former teacher, the Polish-born pianist Stefan Askenase, and his strong-willed wife with helping to lift her out of this hole and back into music. Their intervention clearly worked, for in 1965, at 24, Ms. Argerich won first prize in the Chopin International Competition in Warsaw, and her career took off. Among the colleagues who helped was Mr. Dutoit, to whom she was married from 1969 until 1973 and with whom she remains good friends.
She was quickly acclaimed for her rhapsodic playing, particularly of the Romantic repertory. But as her career developed, she began missing concerts, quite often. "I don't know why I had this very scandalistic reputation," she said, coyly. "I played more concerts than what I canceled." In early 1968 she was scheduled to play Beethoven's First Piano Concerto for her debut with the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Leonard Bernstein. She withdrew on short notice.
"It was terrible I did this," she said. "It was not for health reasons. It was some other problems I had. So Bernstein played the concerto himself. The manager at the time was very funny. He said: 'Lennie played. He had a great success, so he loves you!' " Ms. Argerich burst into hearty laughter and grabbed a handful of the sesame crackers she had just discovered on the snack tray.
Of course, some real crises compelled her to miss performances in some cases, like two recitals scheduled in Tokyo early last month. Ms. Argerich had been hoping to try out there the solo works she will play tonight. But a former teacher, the pianist Friedrich Gulda, a deeply spiritual musician ("my most important influence"), died, plunging her into distress. After attending his funeral in Vienna, Ms. Argerich flew that same day to Tokyo, and within two hours of landing performed, as scheduled, the Chopin Piano Concerto No. 1 with Vladimir Ashkenazy conducting. "It was the best Chopin E Minor I ever played," she said. "I don't know why." But she developed a fever and had to cancel two eagerly anticipated solo recitals.
Not getting this trial run has added pressure to tonight's concert. Half of her program will be solo repertory, works by Bach, Chopin and Prokofiev's daunting Seventh Sonata. Ms. Argerich is looking forward much more to the concert's second half, when she will have some company onstage: the Juilliard String Quartet for a performance of Schumann's Piano Quintet, and an old friend, the pianist Nelson Freire, for a performance of Ravel's "Valse" in its arrangement for two pianos.
She has been practicing hard. A night owl, she prefers to work late. When not availing herself of Carnegie Hall's studios she has been at the Metropolitan Opera House, where a young friend, the tenor Kamel Boutros, arranged for access to a studio.
"Once I start practicing I can stay," she explained. "But I don't start," she added, laughing again. "O.K, if I am in trouble, I need to practice. But that kind of obsessive practicing is not good. Ideally, I would like to practice very little, just two hours and then not more."
Obviously, health concerns have contributed to her anxiety. Though enormously relieved by her medical progress, Ms. Argerich delayed the appointment for her annual checkup until after tonight's concert. "I was too nervous," she said. "Let's hope for good news," she added, tapping on the cocktail table.
Her first melanoma appeared 10 years ago, at a very difficult time. "One year before, my mother had died of cancer," she said. "Then, the same day I was diagnosed, my best friend died from another type of cancer. She was 49. It was like a nightmare."
Ms. Argerich underwent treatment in Europe, but five years later another melanoma appeared. Within a year it had spread. The condition was now life-threatening.
Through friends Ms. Argerich learned of a surgical oncologist, Dr. Donald L. Morton, the medical director of the John Wayne Cancer Institute, a nonprofit organization in Santa Monica, Calif., supported by the National Cancer Institute and private funds. Since 1960 Dr. Morton had led a research team seeking to develop a vaccine that could be used to fight melanoma by simulating the body's immune system.
In addition to recommending the experimental vaccine, which Ms. Argerich is taking, Dr. Morton explained that she would have to undergo surgery to remove cancerous tissue from her lungs.
"This was March 1997," Ms. Argerich said. "Just before the surgery, I felt, 'This is dangerous.' You see, to play the piano you use these muscles here." She pointing to the areas below her arm, on her side and back.
Dr. Morton, speaking by telephone from California, said he had not realized until then how important those muscles were to a pianist. "Thank God we were able to accomplish the procedure without doing damage to the muscles," he said. The recovery was grueling for her, said Dr. Morton, who is in New York to attend the benefit. "But the same characteristics that make her a world-class pianist also make her a survivor," he said. "She is a very brave lady."
While leaving her practice room at Carnegie Hall on the way to the interview the other night, Ms. Argerich was approached by a young usher who is a big fan. She wound up confiding her nervousness to him. "So, he told me, 'You must learn the wisdom of uncertainty,' " she recalled. "That's nice, no?"
Uncertainty is something Ms. Argerich has learned to live with.

HEADLINE: Budget Rift, Not a Chasm

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
This year's partisan battle over the federal budget, which lurched forward early today when the House narrowly passed a Republican tax-and-spending blueprint, has a familiar ring.
Republicans want a big tax cut, more money for the military and reductions in just about everything else. Democrats are trying to expand or at least protect spending on a wide array of domestic programs. Each side is attacking the other in apocalyptic terms. The policy and political repercussions could be substantial. 
 But it is worth noting that prosperity has brought the parties closer on fiscal policy than either usually admits.
Without debate or rancor, Republicans and Democrats have more or less agreed that the surplus being generated by Social Security -- $1 trillion over the next five years and $2.3 trillion over a decade -- should go to pay down the portion of the debt held by the public, currently about $3.5 trillion. (The fine print could theoretically also allow the money to be used to help create private investment accounts within Social Security. But that Republican goal has been put on the back burner at least until after the election.)
There is common ground on other issues as well. Republicans are proposing a substantial increase in spending on education, seeking to neutralize an issue that long played to the advantage of Democrats. Both parties want to provide money to add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare, though they differ on the scale any such program should have.
And the unanimous votes this month in both the House and the Senate to repeal the earnings limit on Social Security recipients provided some hope that compromise might be possible on other tax issues, like the marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples.
"We should be doing a little bit more celebrating for what we have been able to achieve as Republicans and Democrats alike," said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee.
Still, the differences, in both ideological and dollar terms, are more than enough to create political friction on the campaign trail this year as well as in Washington.
The House budget blueprint, passed by a largely party-line vote of 211 to 207 early today after more than 12 hours of often rancorous debate, would cut taxes by at least $150 billion over five years and perhaps as much as $240 billion. It would also raise total government spending authority by 3 percent, to $1.85 trillion.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who has locked up the Republican presidential nomination, wants a $483 billion tax cut over five years -- more than his party is willing even to try getting through Congress this year.
Vice President Al Gore, who will be Mr. Bush's opponent in the fall, says that the approach taken by Republicans in Congress would risk a return to budget deficits and imperil efforts to shore up Social Security and Medicare -- and that Mr. Bush's plan is even worse.
The Senate will soon take up a budget plan similar to the one passed by the House, though it has been bottled up for the past week in the Senate Budget Committee by conservatives who are pressing for bigger tax cuts and less spending.
Once both chambers have settled on and reconciled their budget plans -- nonbinding resolutions that provide a framework for the development of specific spending and tax bills -- the really difficult work will begin.
At that point, the appropriations committees that set spending levels for everything from fighter planes to farm aid and school lunch programs will start drafting their bills. If the past few years are any guide, they will find it difficult if not impossible to remain within the limits set out in the budget outline.
The budget provides for a 6 percent increase in military spending, to $307.3 billion, but essentially freezes nonmilitary spending at $289 billion, requiring cuts in most programs once inflation is taken into account. Most of the rest of the budget goes to pay Social Security and Medicare benefits and interest on the national debt.
In each of the past several years, the Republican-controlled Congress has approved nonmilitary spending increases well above the inflation rate. In part, that is because of pressure from President Clinton. But it is also because Republicans themselves have found it hard to vote for spending cuts or freezes in popular programs at a time when the budget surplus is swelling.
The result has been to make it difficult for Republicans to pass the appropriations bills needed to keep the government operating, leading to an end-of-session rush to cut deals and get out of town, even if it requires using budgetary gimmicks to make the numbers add up. Such a prospect looms again this year, when members of Congress will be particularly eager to get home to campaign.
The failure by Republicans to set realistic spending targets "has delayed, rather than expedited, action on appropriations bills and other fiscal legislation," Jacob J. Lew, the White House budget director, said in a letter sent to Congressional leaders on Thursday night.
The problem is exacerbated by a split within the Republican Party. House leaders had difficulty rounding up the votes they needed to pass the budget early today because a group of conservatives had threatened to vote against it on the ground that it did not have enough safeguards against last-minute deals to increase spending.
Yet moderates and members of the appropriations committees warned that the spending levels in the budget plan were already unrealistically low, and that passing appropriations bills would become even more difficult if conservatives insisted on further cuts or more debt reduction.

HEADLINE: US Airways and Union Talking as Strike Deadline Passes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Negotiators for US Airways Group and its flight attendants union continued talking early this morning as the 12:01 a.m. deadline for the talks passed.
The airline and the union had reported modest progress earlier in the evening and at about midnight, Jeff Zack, a union spokesman said that the two sides had agreed to continue talking beyond the deadline. 
 Lawrence Nagin, US Airways's executive vice president and general counsel, said the chairman of the National Mediation Board had asked them to extend the talks past the deadline and the two sides agreed to do so. The airline's management repeated yesterday that if no agreement was reached by the deadline, US Airways would suspend operations beginning today to avoid being whipsawed by the attendants' planned partial strike.
Adopting unorthodox tactics, the union's 10,000 flight attendants have warned of a partial strike that would disrupt 49 of the airline's busiest routes. Company officials fear that the partial strike, which the union calls Chaos -- Create Havoc Around Our System -- would tie the airline in knots and strand thousands of passengers during a busy time when many schools have spring break.
At a news conference yesterday in Washington, Patricia Friend, president of the Association of Flight Attendants, said the union was continuing preparations for a strike, adding, "We've been able to settle a large number of issues, mostly the smaller issues, but the larger issues of pay and pension remain unresolved."
The union's leaders and Rakesh Gangwal, the airline's chief executive, were still negotiating late yesterday in an undisclosed Washington hotel with the assistance of Ernest W. DuBester, chairman of the National Mediation Board. Officials from both sides said the talks were difficult because the airline was intent on reining in its operating costs, the highest in the industry, while the attendants want a large raise because they have not had an across-the-board pay increase in four years.
The flight attendants have been bargaining with the airline since 1996 and they became free to strike at 12:01 a.m. today when a federally mandated 30-day cooling-off period expired. Under federal law, President Clinton has the power to order the airline and attendants to continue normal operations for 60 days, but officials for each side said they doubted he would do that because neither side has requested such intervention. Several labor experts said they doubted he would intervene because it would upset the A.F.L.-C.I.O., in an important election year. The labor federation complained bitterly in 1997 when Mr. Clinton intervened to cut short a pilots' strike at American Airlines, saying his action weakened the pilots' leverage.
The threat of a shutdown of US Airways, the nation's sixth-largest airline, whether through a strike or the company's pre-emptive action, was sowing tension and chaos in airports around the nation yesterday as thousands of passengers rushed to change their reservations or seek refunds on their tickets. On a typical day, US Airways operates 2,200 flights carrying a total of 150,000 passengers.
"There's a considerable amount of nervousness out there," said Michael Pingrey, owner of Act Travel, a Washington-based travel agency. "We're working hard to get people on other flights, but it's getting tougher and tougher. Everyone has been trying to get onto other flights, but all the other flights are booked up now."
A shutdown would do the greatest harm on the East Coast, where US Airways has hubs in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C., and holds 36 percent of the market.
Delta Air Lines has said that if US Airways' New York-Washington-Boston shuttle is suspended, it would add several planes to the Delta shuttle, while Amtrak said it would add 1,500 train seats to carry on the New York-Washington-Boston routes.
US Airways has arranged for other airlines and Amtrak to honor its tickets if its operations are shut down. The airline advises customers holding electronic tickets to call US Airways or a travel agent, or to go to a US Airways counter, to get their tickets reprocessed so those tickets can be accepted at other airlines.
Philip Baggaley, an airline analyst at Standard & Poor's, said a shutdown would cause the airline $15 million to $20 million in losses a day. But he said the airline had more than $1 billion in cash to help weather a shutdown, including a $500 million credit line it recently drew down. To control costs, US Airways is pressing the attendants to accept a formula, known as parity plus one, similar to that accepted by its other major unions. That formula would link attendants' pay to the average of their counterparts at the nation's four largest airlines plus 1 percent.
But US Air's attendants have bridled at this, egged on by union leaders who say the formula put forward by management would cut their pay and benefits. Resistance to the formula has been fueled further by resentment toward the compensation received by US Airways' top executives. Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman, received $34.2 million last year in salary, bonus and stock option grants, several times that of his counterparts at the top four airlines.
"It's outrageous that when they receive their large salaries and bonuses and when the airline continues to prosper in a strong economy, they expect us to take a pay cut and accept concessions," said Christopher Spangler, a $32,000-a-year flight attendant based in Pittsburgh. Attendants' pay starts at $17,145 and rises to a maximum of $36,918 after 14 years.
Company officials assert that their pay offer is generous because it links the attendants not to their counterparts at struggling companies, but to their counterparts at the industry leaders: United, American, Delta and Northwest.
US Airways officials added that if the union accepted the parity formula it would go far to restrain the airline's costs. These officials added that if the attendants were to receive a higher formula, then the airline's other major unions might demand to have their contracts reopened.
"This is not about who is right or wrong or who wins or loses," said Nagin, the airline's general counsel. "It's about this company being competitive and doing what's right for our employees."
One sticking point has been the attendants' assertion that management was pressing them to accept the same version of the parity formula as the pilots did.

HEADLINE: Holy Wars

BYLINE: By Chris Hedges; Chris Hedges is a reporter in New York for The Times.

 BODY:

The Battle for God
 By Karen Armstrong.
 442 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. 
 Dr. JAMES LUTHER ADAMS, my ethics professor in seminary, used to tell us that we would end our careers fighting an ascendant fundamentalist movement, or, as he liked to say, "the Christian fascists." He was not a scholar to be disregarded, however implausible such a scenario seemed, and still seems. But it is clear that as we enter the new millennium the traditional versions of the three monotheistic religions have failed to fill the huge spiritual void of modernity -- one Jean-Paul Sartre called "a God-shaped hole." We lie on the cusp of a great religious experiment, one similar to the upheaval that led to the decline of paganism and the rise of reformers and prophets during the so-called Axial Age (800 B.C.-200 B.C.), when the most important thoughts worth thinking were first thought. Regretfully, for the moment, all innovation, passion and energy lie with the adversaries of secular, democratic society.
Whether or not you see fundamentalism as a threat, as Karen Armstrong does in "The Battle for God," hers is one of the most penetrating, readable and prescient accounts to date of the rise of the fundamentalist movements in Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Rather than make sweeping pronouncements, she wisely focuses on the fundamentalist strains in the United States, Israel, Iran and Egypt. She displays, as she should, sympathy for the plight of those who turned to fundamentalism after being shunted aside by forces and states that have little patience with the quest by the poor and the dispossessed to find meaning and purpose.
But what has evolved as a response to modernity is also tainted, Armstrong points out, with the doctrines and mores of the 20th century, including the support for liberation movements, the requirement to fashion messages to suit the confines of the electronic media and the disturbing belief that the rational world can be applied to the mythos of religion as if it were a science. Protestant fundamentalists read the Bible, she writes, "in a literal, rational way that is quite different from the more mystical, allegorical approach of premodern spirituality." Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was not, as she aptly reminds us, a throwback to the Middle Ages: "in fact much of his message and developing ideology was modern. His opposition to Western imperialism and his support of the Palestinians were similar to other third world movements at this time; so was his direct appeal to the people." Even the ultra-Orthodox Jews, who try to turn their back on secular Israeli society, have founded yeshivas that are recognizable, voluntarist institutions. "They adopted a novel stringency in their observance of the Torah and learned to manipulate the political system in a way that brought them more power than any religious Jew had enjoyed for nearly two millenniums," Armstrong notes.
These movements are struggling to define, often in disturbing ways, an ethic in a world whose landscape has altered dramatically. They are a product, although they do not recognize themselves as such, of the culture they hope to vanquish, and all "have a symbiotic relationship with modernity." Like other uncompromising movements -- fascism, communism and nationalism -- fundamentalist sects fester. "The West has developed an entirely unprecedented and wholly different type of civilization," Armstrong, the author of three previous books, including "A History of God," writes, "so the religious response to it has been unique." She is unsure how to vanquish or tame these movements, pointing out that each attempt to crush them has resulted in more virulent strains. The problem may be that such vindictive intolerance, racism and homophobia simply have no place in a civil society. Much of fundamentalism is an ideology of rage, a product of the worst elements of the society it condemns. The Gush Emunim in Israel, the forces grouped around the Iranian clergy, the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt and the constituencies of Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson "have absorbed the pragmatic rationalism of modernity, and, under the guidance of their charismatic leaders, they refine these 'fundamentals' so as to create an ideology that provides the faithful with a plan of action," Armstrong writes.
The fieriest and deadliest battle, however, is not between the sacred and the profane, but between the anointed and the apostates masquerading as believers. The assassinations of Anwar Sadat and Yitzhak Rabin illustrate, Armstrong says, the two wars being fought in the Middle East, one between the Arabs and the Jews and the other "between secularists and religious." It was the internecine fighting between the powerful television evangelists, not the liberal establishment they set out to topple, that saw the collapse of the empires of Jim Bakker and Jimmy Swaggart. The Christian right consumed itself.
But as Armstrong's narrative, which traces these movements back to their roots, makes plain, there has long been an ebb and flow. In a pattern they share with all fundamentalist groups, including those who fought the shah of Iran or the Egyptian leader Gamal Abdel Nasser, the sects, each time they are wounded, regroup, redefine their mission and return again to assault modern society. "Protestant fundamentalists in the United States became more reactionary, intransigent and literal-minded after their humiliation at the Scopes trial," she writes. "The most extreme forms of Sunni fundamentalism surfaced in Nasser's concentration camps, and the shah's crackdowns helped to inspire the Islamic Revolution."
None of this is a defense of modernity. Armstrong, who spent seven years as a Roman Catholic nun, recognizes that for many people modern society means "an emptiness, a void, that rendered life meaningless; many would crave certainty amid the perplexities of modernity; some would project their fears onto imaginary enemies and dream of universal conspiracy." Scientific rationalism, while discrediting myth, has nothing, she says, to offer in its place. And it has led, in its perverted forms, to the creation of the most effective totalitarian states and ideologies in human history, along with two world wars, the gas chamber and the gulag. "Without the constraints of a 'higher,' mythical truth, reason can on occasion become demonic and commit crimes that are as great as, if not greater than, any of the atrocities perpetrated by fundamentalists," she says.
For those who feel battered and perplexed by forces they cannot control and cannot understand, especially Muslims under the boot of the shah, Jews reeling from the annihilation of the shtetl and the Holocaust, poor peasants ground down by the pro-Western government of Hosni Mubarak in Egypt and American Christians who resent the arrogance and ethos of the Eastern liberal establishment, the retreat into fundamentalism offers refuge and hope. But ultimately, like all ideologies that eschew compromise, fundamentalism is utopian and accepts the morally corrosive proposition that the ends always justify the means. Disturbingly as it is to accept, the inquisitional nature of the early church seems closer to these new Jeremiahs than the soft universality of mainstream religion.
Already mutant splinter groups, many of which have retreated from the tainted, profane world, have left more temperate fundamentalists far behind. The organization known as Christian Identity, which has swung so far out of orbit that it disapproves of fundamentalism, rails against the Christian right's support for Zionism. It is angered that the Jews have usurped the title of Chosen People from the Aryan race. The ideology of Christian Identity is the kind of poison ingested by Timothy McVeigh before he blew up the federal building in Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995. It bears a striking similarity to the fringe Muslim and Jewish groups who see any target, including children and the innocents, as the regrettable cost of holy war.
History is awash with beleaguered revolutionaries and lunatic extremists who were endowed with enough luck and enough ruthlessness to fill power vacuums. The danger is not that fundamentalism will grow, Armstrong's analysis suggests, so much as that modern, secular society will wither. Already mainstream Christianity, Judaism and Islam lie defeated and emasculated by the very forces that ironically turned them into tolerant, open institutions. "The chances of this theology's achieving much popularity in the United States are, to be sure, remote; but it has been suggested that in the event of an environmental or major economic catastrophe, an authoritarian state church could replace the liberal polity of the Enlightenment," she writes. "Christianity, after all, was able to adapt to capitalism, which was alien to many of the teachings of Jesus. It could be used to back a fascist ideology that, in drastically changed circumstances, might be necessary to maintain public order."

LENGTH: 711 words

HEADLINE: Biz.Com

BYLINE: By Rob Walker; Rob Walker is a contributing writer for Money and the Internet magazine Slate.

 BODY:

The Cluetrain Manifesto
 The End of Business as Usual.
 By Rick Levine,
 Christopher Locke, Doc Searls
 and David Weinberger.
 190 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Perseus Books. $23. 
 Perhaps the current Slogan Era of business thinking began in 1995, with the appearance of Fast Company magazine. The distressed type on the cover introduced "The New Rules of Business" in the form of catch phrases like "Work Is Personal" and "Knowledge Is Power." The slogans seemed vaguely political, and that was the idea -- the editors announced a "business revolution." Of a piece with this rhetoric was the appearance, about a year ago, of a "manifesto" at www.cluetrain.com. The site, put together by a small cadre of tech-oriented thinkers, came to the attention of a Wall Street Journal writer, and now we have a book -- already creeping up on some best-seller lists -- that consists of the original document plus seven related essays.
Although there are 95 points to the manifesto, most are refinements of a few underlying ideas, which are of course reducible to slogans: "Markets are conversations," and the murkier but equally important "Hyperlinks subvert hierarchy." What these statements mean is that, in a networked world, workers and consumers can share information far more easily than ever before. The loser is "the company," which the authors dismiss as being "a metaphysical construct" in any event.
So you, the person who works for a company, have or will have extraordinary communication with fellow employees, from subversive e-mail about how stupid that meeting was to comments about your latest project from co-workers you've never even met. With the right kind of intranet, the right idea will always emerge, possibly from someone you would never have asked (and thus does a hyperlink subvert a hierarchy). Meanwhile, you, the consumer, can cross-check those companies' claims and ask for or give advice about any product or service. Ultimately, advertising proves futile. "Word of Web will trump word of hype, every time," the authors write.
That, needless to say, is itself hyperbole. So is much of the authors' view of business, which they often express with about as much sophistication as Holden Caulfield. Basically, people who run companies are venal phonies, and they are foolishly trying to bend the networked economy to their cynical ways with disingenuous corporate Web sites and boring intranets.
But that's O.K. A manifesto should be full of hyperbole, and while this one often strains credulity in the particulars, the general thrust is on the mark. Certainly at the large companies I've worked for, the intranet was no more populist a forum than the bulletin board in the lobby. And as a reporter I have dealt with enough corporations to applaud the chapter on the banality of public relations. "The Cluetrain Manifesto" suggests that even companies that see themselves as "getting" the Internet are actually in denial about it, and that's probably true.
What's strange -- but ultimately revealing -- is how the authors frame their broadside. "Burn down business-as-usual," Christopher Locke writes in the opening chapter. "Bulldoze it. . . . Topple the statues of heroes too long dead into the street. Sound familiar? You bet it does. And the message has been the same all along, from Paris in '68 to the Berlin Wall, from Warsaw to Tiananmen Square: Let the kids rock 'n' roll!" Whether that was the ultimate message of these events is debatable, but it emphatically is the message that "The Cluetrain Manifesto," and the culture it emerged from, have for society. What the Slogan Era's "business revolution" is really about is not borrowed from politics; instead, it's a phenomenon that offers middle-aged managers a second chance to sound a barbaric yawp and imagine a new significance to their lives. This message is popular because no one wants to serve the public, but everyone wants to feel like a rock star. "There's a huge opportunity here," Locke declares, "for individuals to keep their day jobs but at the same time indulge their natural human bent for self-expression." And if you buy into that, then, gee, it turns out that business and rock 'n' roll -- why, they're practically the same thing after all!

HEADLINE: Steve Phillips's Winter of Content

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber; Bruce Weber is a theater critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:
In the wee hours last Oct. 20, Kenny Rogers threw his last pitch for the New York Mets, ball four to Andruw Jones of the Atlanta Braves, walking in the winning run in the 11th inning. It was a moment of startling anticlimax, bringing to an abrupt, pallid end an otherwise nerve-jangler of a ballgame, the equally vivid National League Championship Series and, just short of a consummating subway World Series against the Yankees, the Mets' whole preposterously titillating and melodramatic season.
"I remember seeing it, and my first thought was, 'This just isn't right,"' says Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager. 
 Phillips is speaking at a moment of relative calm, in his office at the Mets' spring training complex in Port St. Lucie, Fla., with players limbering up nearby for a morning workout. Renewal is in the warm, breezy air, as it always is in baseball at this time, but for Phillips, a rising executive in a transforming business, a climax is imminent. Now entering his third full season -- which begins this week with the Mets traveling to Tokyo for two games against the Chicago Cubs -- as the team's chief architect, Phillips has earned a reputation around baseball as something of a shopaholic, and a gifted one. Only eight of the major-league players he inherited when he assumed his post in July 1997 are still in the organization, and the core players of last year's team -- the catcher Mike Piazza, the third baseman Robin Ventura, the starting pitcher Al Leiter and the power relief pitcher Armando Benitez, who led the Mets into post-season play for the first time since 1988, are all Phillips acquisitions. Still, his contract expires at the end of the year, and before they renew it, the owners are waiting to see how the Mets, with Phillips's latest renovations, perform.
This winter, in a frenzy of trades and free-agent signings -- some completely unforeseen, like the trade with Houston that brought Mike Hampton to New York, a No. 1 starting pitcher (an ace, in age-old parlance) -- Phillips has redesigned last year's near-miss team. Seven players from last October, more than a quarter of the roster, are gone.
It has all been in the service of an iffy proposition that illustrates the increasingly pressurized dynamics of the general manager's job -- making sure that the Mets' fortunes this year will not hang on a single errant pitch. And it has all taken place amid a lingering buzz of organizational tension and in the shadow of the crosstown Yankees, whose three world championships in four years have made them the sporting kings of New York.
"As dramatic as everything was for us to get to that point, and for a bases-loaded walk to end the season, it wasn't right," Phillips says again, only to discard the past with his next breath. "At that point it was, 'O.K., what's the plan, Steve?"'
In the 1960's and early 1970's, when artificial turf and domed stadiums began to appear, when the pitcher's mound was lowered and the umpires began their steady shrinkage of the strike zone and when the designated-hitter rule took effect in the American League, baseball's evolution, for good or ill, was on the field. Since the advent of player free agency and salary arbitration in the mid-1970's, however, the game has changed far more significantly in the front office.
The economic advantages enjoyed by large-market teams, provided mostly by local broadcast rights, has widened the divide between wealthy and penny-pinching franchises. At the same time, soaring payrolls have made each big-ticket player's signing more of a risk and made owners more attentive to the operations of their ball clubs. Five years ago, the Mets' player payroll was about $13 million; this year it is close to $90 million. That the business of baseball is a dicey one, dependent more than ever on winning, is evident in that although the Mets drew 2.8 million fans last year, the most in a decade, the club made a profit with only the revenues from its post-season games.
Now just 36, Steve Phillips is representative of a generation of executives who have emerged in response to these developments, refining the role of the general manager; it is their job, simply put, to allot the owners' resources wisely. It is a less powerful post than it was but more accountable, less wide-ranging but in the minutiae of wheeling and dealing with 29 other general managers and dozens of player agents more complex and indisputably under more scrutiny by fans and reporters, especially in New York.
In 1986, the year of the last Met championship, the general manager at the time, Frank Cashen, who oversaw not only the team's player personnel dealings but also the marketing of the club, the stadium operations and the legal affairs, said that with his generalized skills, he could run a dairy as well as a baseball team. No general manager in baseball could say the same today.
"I remember when I was an administrative assistant on the club and I'd be in the general manager's box during the game," Phillips says. "And Frank and Al Harazin" -- Cashen's former assistant, who was, briefly and disastrously, his successor -- would be reading books. And they'd be talking about them and about things going on in the world. The guys today, I don't think we could do that. We know about baseball. We talk about that. And about our families."
Well spoken and reporter friendly, Phillips looks his age -- young, that is -- in spite of the frost that has begun to sprinkle his light hair. A compact man who carries himself with the ease of an ex-athlete, he is a former infielder who reached the Double A level in the Met organization before hitting the ceiling of his talent and reluctantly leaving the game to go into business. But he has no formal business training; his undergraduate degree, from the University of Michigan, is in psychology. Ten years ago, just before he was hired by the Mets as an assistant to the team's scouting and minor-league directors, beginning a rapid rise through the ranks, he was working for the Maritz Motivation Company in St. Louis, designing and selling worker-incentive programs to American corporations.
"I thought too much, overanalyzed, changed my stance every at bat," Phillips says, explaining his limitations as a player. (It was Yogi Berra who most succinctly expressed baseball's delicious mind-body problem: "You can't hit and think at the same time.") "When I struck out, it wasn't just that out, it was the 50 before. My temperament is better suited for the front office than for playing." Player-gained savvy is an obvious advantage in his current post, and in that sense he is a descendant of one line of traditional baseball executives. But it is Phillips's apprenticeship in the front office (he has also served as the Mets' minor-league director and assistant general manager), essentially a business degree that baseball as a whole is only just beginning to offer, that makes his resume so contemporary.
His first job included keeping detailed inventory of all the costs associated with running the Met farm system, from player salaries to new pitching machines; he has learned baseball value, both on the field and on the bottom line, which is how value is measured today. Players aren't just players anymore; they're also money. A long-term player contract can amount to a mortgage on a franchise. "I get buyer's remorse after every deal," Phillips says. But even so, he has a reputation for guts, which has, among other things, endeared him to players who don't ordinarily deal with the general manager except at contract time.
"He's not afraid to make a deal, and that's big," says Leiter, who was displaced by Hampton as the leader of the starting rotation. "A lot of G.M.'s are afraid to pull the trigger, because it's their neck on the line."
Guts are only half of it. Here, for example, is Phillips on the recently concluded contract for Armando Benitez, a powerful relief pitcher entering, at 27, the prime of his career. Benitez had filed for arbitration for this year's salary -- meaning the team and the player submit salary proposals, and an independent official chooses one, based on an estimation of what players of similar value are making -- because negotiations for a four-year agreement had stalled.
The problem was that during the first year of the four, the so-called arbitration year, the salary was to be based on his past accomplishments; for the following three years, which would be his free-agent years if he did not sign now, the Mets had to negotiate based on speculation of his future market value. "They're two different animals," Phillips says. "So we started by trying to agree on his value for the three free-agent years, assuming he has good seasons as a closer, and worked backward from that, and negotiated the arbitration year. Then, once we agreed on the total package, we negotiated how we could slice it up in a structure that satisfied both sides."
The result was a $22 million deal over four years, with salaries of $3.25 million, $5.625 million, $5.625 million and $6.75 million, plus a $750,000 signing bonus, a third of which will be paid out each of the next three years.
"There are some tax breaks for guys who take a signing bonus instead of a salary," Phillips says. "And in 2002 there is some question about a strike or a lockout, and he wanted some money coming in just in case."
Compared with, say, Mariano Rivera of the Yankees, a top closer who lost his arbitration case this spring but still received $7.25 million, Benitez is, from the Mets' perspective, a reasonable risk who could develop into a great bargain. "If he gets 40 saves this year and helps us win the World Series, imagine what his free-agent value would be," Phillips says.
And here is Phillips on horse-trading, discussing a complicated deal from the fall of 1998, meant to unload a declining outfielder, Bernard Gilkey, and his two-year, $11 million contract. That season the Mets had acquired Mike Piazza from the Florida Marlins, and in the weeks before the Gilkey deal had signed the All Star catcher to a seven-year, $91 million contract.
"We thought Gilkey was going to be tough to trade after the season he'd had," Phillips says, "but we found a place to send him, Arizona, where we could get two players for the same money. We got Willie Blair, a pitcher, and George Fabregas, a catcher, and we thought we could get lucky with one or the other."
In the end, instead of overpaying Gilkey, the Mets wound up with two inexpensive minor leaguers. "We traded Blair to Detroit for Joe Randa, and we didn't want Randa," Phillips says. "We just wanted out from under Blair's money, so we traded Randa to Kansas City for Juan LeBron, a prospect. Then we traded Fabregas to the Marlins for another prospect because they needed a front-line catcher. It was all about moving money."
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' president and with Nelson Doubleday the team's co-owner, is unequivocal in his support of Phillips, in word if not yet entirely in deed. "I respect his responsibility; I don't tell him who to pick as a baseball player," Wilpon says. In fact, the owners have never nixed a deal Phillips proposed to them. But Wilpon and Phillips speak nearly every day -- I try to help him in terms of framing the business situation," Wilpon says. Asked if he and Doubleday are more hands-on owners than they used to be, he responds: "Yes, that's fair to say. We have someone who is young chronologically who is running our team. On the other hand, he had seven years in our system as a player and seven more coming through the ranks. Practically all of his working life has been in this organization."
Most pointedly, both Phillips and the Mets' on-field manager, Bobby Valentine, have contracts that expire after the 2000 season, and the owners have explicitly declined to extend them. That nonvote of confidence has inspired much speculation. One theory is that the owners, partners for 20 years but winners of only one World Series, now feel they have spent enough money and expect their manager and general manager to deliver a championship. Another is that a sale of the team is imminent and the owners do not want to saddle prospective buyers with contracts for leaders they haven't chosen. While denying that he is planning to sell, Wilpon does acknowledge that he and Doubleday have entertained offers for at least part of the team.
On baseball's organizational turbulence meter, the mets are not quite the Bronx Zoo Yankees of the Billy Martin-Reggie Jackson-George Steinbrenner era, but compared with the smooth and staid Yankees of today the Mets are a veritable riot. And indeed, the Braves' final 10-9 victory in October -- a game that saw the Mets fall behind 5-0, recoup and eventually take the lead in the top of the eighth only to lose it again in the bottom -- cemented the Mets' image as baseball's leading melodramatists.
Last year's loopy and improbable events included the firing of three coaches in midseason that launched a swivel in team fortunes; a late-September seven-game losing streak that threatened a seemingly assured playoff spot, followed by a four-game winning streak to close out the year, including a one-game playoff with the Cincinnati Reds; and an authoritative whupping of the Arizona Diamondbacks in the first round of playoffs, which was followed by three consecutive losses to the Braves, followed by two heart-stopping wins and the final heart-rending loss.
In the meantime, two players -- Bobby Bonilla, now gone, and Rickey Henderson -- irritated management and fans alike with their seemingly selfish indifference in the heat of battle. Valentine courted personal disaster by declaring, in the midst of the September losing streak, that he should be fired if the Mets didn't make the post-season.
And then there were rumors that Wilpon and Doubleday were at odds. And that Valentine, a tightly wound, ego-driven man, was chafing under the younger Phillips, particularly after Phillips's decision in June, with the team floundering, to dismiss two pitching coaches, Bob Apodaca and Randy Niemann, and a batting coach, Tom Robson. Many had expected Valentine would be the one fired, and though Phillips's surprising move saved the manager's job, there was, both men acknowledge, a tense confrontation over it -- I had gone to battle with those guys," Valentine says -- and it is hard to argue with the results. The Mets won 40 of their next 55 games. (And Robson, oddly enough, was rehired in the off-season.)
"I can look back now and understand it a lot more than I could that day," Valentine says. "We won a lot of games after that, so I won't play the village idiot and say it was the wrong thing to do."
The two men still assess each other warily; you could see it on the Port St. Lucie practice field, as each man strolled about on his own, never quite crossing paths. "When you're getting the job done, which is your first concern, the friendship thing doesn't quite equate," Valentine says. But they are not without mutual respect. Phillips praises Valentine's gifts as a teacher and game strategist, while Valentine appreciates Phillips's preparation and attention to detail in personnel matters. "I wouldn't be a G.M. with a bag of gold and a gun held to my head," he says.
Phillips, who is married with two children, was himself at the center of a bizarre team crisis. In November 1998, he took a "voluntary" leave of absence after admitting to adultery in the wake of a threatened sexual harassment charge. His return was announced in a news conference that included a confession and apology by Phillips. It was all an extraordinary spectacle that still strikes many as an unnecessary public flogging. Phillips, who has undergone counseling and by all accounts has begun to repair the damage to his family, declines to talk about any of it.
Wilpon says that Phillips was never in danger of being fired, provided he followed through on a promise to seek help, and he reinstated Phillips after only eight days. Asked why he has not extended Phillips's and Valentine's contracts, Wilpon gives a baseball answer. "People sign a contract and they get a certain amount of security for a certain job. There's a beginning and an end to that. Maybe it's going to be helpful to Bobby and to Steve -- to all of us -- to be accountable. I expect us to be a contending team."
One observer who would be very surprised should the Mets jettison Phillips is Scott Boras, the powerful player agent who at the end of the year will be seeking a contending team and a stable organization for his free-agent client -- Seattle's shortstop, Alex Rodriguez, who may be the game's brightest young star. "I think Steve has a dynamic about him that is really important to the Mets," Boras says. "He's experienced in three ways. First, he has pursued the big deal and landed it, and he has the confidence to do it again. Second, he has dealt with New York, professionally and personally, and has come out on top. Third, he knows what he's doing; he's credible."
Phillips's credibility is precisely what the Mets' season will measure. This winter, his plan was to augment the pitching staff, which is almost every team's priority every off-season, and to mend a hole in baseball's best infield after the team's stylish, free-agent first baseman, John Olerud, signed to play in his hometown, Seattle. "We also wanted to add a little more thump to our outfield," Phillips said. "We had pretty good production, but we had three guys out there -- Henderson, Hamilton and Roger Cedeno -- who didn't drive the ball as much as they got on base."
Unlike the Atlanta Braves, with their great starting rotation, or the Cleveland Indians, with their potent offense and stingy bullpen, the Mets have been stellar in neither their starting pitchers nor their closers. SaysPhillips: "The strategy is that the game isn't necessarily won in the first innings or the last, but over nine innings. So we've tried to maintain a high level of consistency, 1 through 12, among our pitchers. But now Benitez has come on and made us better at the back end, and Hampton makes us stronger at the front, without compromising the consistency we'd built."
Indeed, the Mets' collection of midgame relievers, including John Franco, Pat Mahomes, Turk Wendell and Dennis Cook, is probably baseball's most effective group. "Starters used to get you to the eighth, and you'd bring in a closer, a guy who could go two innings," Phillips says. "Then there really weren't any two-inning guys any more, and now it's more specialized still. In my opinion, you need a seventh-, an eighth- and a ninth-inning guy now."
Still, even with the acquisition of Hampton, the starting staff has questions. Only three of the five starters -- Leiter, Rick Reed and Bobby J. Jones -- remain from last season. Rogers, a free agent who was seeking a four-year, $8-million-a-year deal, is gone.
"We considered it," Phillips says. "That wasn't the best use of our $8 million, in my view, and it would have been tough to bring him back to start a multiyear deal when you know the first time he takes the mound he's going to get booed." (Rogers eventually signed with Texas for three years at $7.5 million annually.)
Masato Yoshii, another starting pitcher, is also gone, traded to Colorado for a lesser pitcher, Bobby M. Jones. This was a money trade -- Yoshii, at 34, was making $3 million. But Phillips was working on another deal for a younger pitcher whom the Mets liked for his sinker and the modest contract he already had signed for the next two years.
If that deal had gone through -- it didn't, and for that reason Phillips could be in violation of baseball's tampering rules if the player's name were publicly revealed -- there would have been no room for Yoshii on the staff, and he would be more difficult to trade for significant value in return because other teams would recognize the Mets' desperation. Meanwhile, Phillips was busy acquiring four other pitchers -- Bill Pulsipher, Jesse Orosco, Glendon Rusch and Rich Rodriguez -- overstocking the larder with baseball's rarest commodity, left arms. The Mets have nine lefties with major-league experience, too many to squeeze onto the roster but potentially useful as bait for a future trade.
In any event, it was easier to part with Yoshii after Hampton was signed. In this case, Phillips took advantage of the Mets' willingness to spend for a championship and the leverage that star players now wield in shaping their own careers. And he still needed a little luck. Hampton, entering the last year of his contract -- he'll be paid $5.75 million this year -- was afraid that if he signed an expensive, long-term contract with Houston, the team, with its midrange budget, would be unable to afford to pay the other quality players needed to win a title, so he asked to be traded to a contender.
At first, the Mets were not in the running; Houston wanted a shortstop as part of the deal. But then the Astros landed a young shortstop, Adam Everett, in a deal with Boston. It finally worked, however, because the Mets were willing to relieve the Astros of Derek Bell, an outfielder who slumped last year but was nonetheless earning $5 million annually. In exchange, the Mets gave up Octavio Dotel, a promising but unproven pitcher, and Roger Cedeno, a speedy outfielder who will replace the center fielder Houston gave up in the deal for their new shortstop.
"We took $10.75 million and gave back about $2.5 million," Phillips says.
The off-season's other key development was the departure -- not unexpected -- of Olerud. He and his wife had had their first child since he signed his last contract, in 1998, and though the Mets matched the Mariners' initial salary offer and offered to fly both sets of grandparents to New York several times during the year, Olerud defected. "John was our No. 1 priority, but we knew it was 50-50 and we knew it wasn't going to be about money," Phillips says. "That was refreshing. It would've been more refreshing if he'd chosen to come back."
Still, Phillips had already been shopping and within a week signed Todd Zeile, a free agent from the Texas Rangers. Other first basemen were available, and Zeile, a third baseman by trade, is not likely to be the anchor of the Mets infield that Olerud was. But Phillips liked the way Zeile fit in the Met lineup. Olerud hits for better average; Zeile hits more homers. But that is just a shard of the comparison.
"We are a work-the-count kind of offense," Phillips says. "We take pitches deep into the count, so we focus on pitches per plate appearance, which translates into on-base percentage, which translates into runs scored. Olerud is a significant loss, because of his on-base percentage, which was .427 last year. Zeile's isn't that high -- he was at .354 -- but the interesting thing is he actually sees more pitches per plate appearance. What that means is that at 3-1, 3-2, he's swinging. He's an R.B.I. guy -- he drove in 98 runs last year hitting sixth or seventh in the order.
"John was an on-base percentage guy. He drove in 96 with two guys in front of him with over .400 on-base averages. He walked 125 times. One of the things I think is that even without John, we're going to have a significant number of guys on base, and that a guy who swings more will drive in more runs. So we've changed our offense a little that way, but without letting the opposing pitcher off the hook by letting him do less work."
The loss of Cedeno has cost the Mets their leading base-stealer; and unlike Olerud, Zeile hits right-handed, leaving the Mets with a starting lineup lopsided to starboard. To solve those problems, Phillips wanted to secure a left-handed-hitting outfielder. Ken Griffey Jr., their notorious first choice, snubbed them and then forced his old team, Seattle, to send him to Cincinnati, where his father is a coach.
It remains to be seen whether the addition of Hampton will compensate for the loss of Yoshii, Rogers and Dotel, and Phillips still wouldn't mind trading for a proven starter from a weaker team that is seeking to unload salary: Brad Radke of the Twins, for example. Still, the Braves have lost John Smoltz, a leading starting pitcher, to injury, and the lingering ill will from the racist comments of their closer, John Rocker, will not help team chemistry. Barring injuries of their own, the Mets are well positioned to unseat Atlanta as the long-reigning champions of the National League and to challenge the Yankees for primacy in the world -- and even more important, the city. As the games begin, Phillips says he is content with his winter.
"We're ready to go with the guys we've got," Phillips says. And if he feels any pressure at all, it wouldn't be like him to let on. Asked if the Mets are a championship-caliber team, he is unequivocal. "No question," he says. "There's no doubt about it."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1396 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Impresarios Working on the Fringe

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE; Eric V. Copage, a reporter for the City Weekly section of The New York Times, writes about culture.

 BODY:
LIMOR TOMER, a Juilliard-trained pianist and former music history teacher at New York University, descended into the dim light of the basement of Two Boots, an East Village pizzeria. For the last two years, the owners of the pizzeria had used the basement, called the Den, sporadically for video nights and private parties. But now Ms. Tomer, walking around the 500-square-foot space, was evaluating it for her own use.
She looked at the size of the sound board, the size and quality of the speakers and the postage stamp-size stage in the corner, then smiled. "The room holds 50 people, but it has a comfortable vibe," Ms. Tomer said recently. "It is completely open. It doesn't say drum-and-bass or jazz or classical. So anything could be played in it." 
 These days, in the brave world of new music in New York, versatility is the key word. Ms. Tomer is one of a small but avid group of advocates who are presenting music that falls between the cracks of genres. It is music that won't fill 600-seat auditoriums but may be the wellspring for mainstream music to come. Call Ms. Tomer and her ilk downtown Diaghilevs, mini-impresarios, or settle for a less grandiose term, music curator. Regardless, while they usually work on a small scale, what they do is hugely important to the artistic soul of New York. In an environment in which culture is straitjacketed and niche-marketed at warp speed, they are keeping in circulation its most precious artistic currencies: experimentation, risk taking and innovation.
Some of these edgy impresarios have a steady venue; some are peripatetic and, like sonic Johnny Appleseeds, move from church to cafe to bar to basement, as well as smaller traditional venues throughout the city, to find places for unfamiliar, often challenging, music. They differ from nightclub bookers in that they are not primarily trying to fill up a space. They differ from the typical concert producer in that they are not merely signing up an artist. They are on a personal mission: exposing others to the music about which they are enthusiastic. Even when the music is not hard to classify -- like German lieder or chamber music -- they are putting that familiar music in unfamiliar places, and thereby cross-pollinating audiences.
George Steel, who is the executive director of the 685-seat Miller Theater at Columbia University, also uses smaller venues downtown. "It's a wonderful period of transition in terms of instrumentation, in terms of the amount of improvisation," he said. Mr. Steel recently presented a concert by the chamber group the Absolute Ensemble at the Flea, a 75-seat theater in TriBeCa. It featured a chamber transcription of the Mahler Fourth Symphony with a part for a Yamaha DX7 electronic keyboard.
He presented the concert at the Flea because, he said, "you can grab a beer and go into the theater."
"The social pressure is off the audience to behave in the usual prom-night fashion."
Mr. Steel's next downtown adventure will be in July, when he presents contemporary classical music at the Cornelia St. Cafe in Greenwich Village.
David Linton, a composer specializing in electronic music, has a somewhat different approach to curating. His idea is that presentations should be a cross between a party and a concert, a kind of aswitched-on Lilith Fair, without the feminist slant. The artists in his shows specialize in electronically generated sounds, ranging from techno to Morton Subotnick-like sheets of sound. Mr. Linton has put on shows in places like Context Studios, a performance space, and the basement lounge at CBGB's, both in the East Village, as well 168 Bar in Chinatown. His SoHo loft was the original home of Sound Lab, an underground club for electronic music. His latest curatorial project, Unity Gain, a series of freewheeling works by composers, will be presented the first Wednesday of every month at Galapagos, a bar and gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Some of the composers will show up at virtually every presentation, and others will participate less frequently, resulting in a mix of new and old music so that audiences will never know exactly what to expect.
This mixing and blending of musics and audiences stems from several factors. An increasing number of musicians feel at home in more than one musical genre. Even a musician devoted to classical music, for instance, cannot escape the dissonant harmonies that are frequently found in movie soundtracks or the African music played in the background music at an upscale coffee shop. Yet audiences seem increasingly segmented, as record companies and concert promoters stream performers into a given niche. "People into one thing tend not to cross over into another thing," said Ms. Tomer, who also curates three nights a week for the BAM cafe at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and organizes a monthly series of classical music at Joe's Pub at the Public Theater in the East Village.
Another reason for the growing segmentation is the price of tickets. When $20 to $25 tickets are the cheapest seats, everybody, musician, curator and institution alike, can feel the creeping conservatism higher ticket prices might inspire. Conversely, when the entrance fee is about the same as a movie ticket, musicians and curators feel freer to experiment. Of course, artists dedicated to their art will eventually find places to perform, especially in today's New York City, where a booming economy has put a new performance nook on nearly every block. But through their passion, these music curators facilitate exposure. Many are performers or former performers who see their role as advocating and nurturing colleagues rather than merely pushing acts.
The phenomenon of music curating in New York can be traced back, if not to the prewar Copland-Sessions concerts, then at least to 1960, when the composer La Monte Young ran a series of concerts in Yoko Ono's Chambers Street loft. In 1971, Rhys Chatham became the first curator at the Kitchen, an alternative performance space then in Soho. And while curators like Phill Niblock, who runs the Experimental Intermedia concerts, Thomas Buckner of the Interpretations Series and Jim Staley of Roulette have been active for decades, today's curators face vastly different challenges. For years, there was little interest from the uptown crowd. But today happenings downtown travel uptown at warp speed. NBC recently opened a theater space called P.S. NBC at the Here Arts Center in SoHo, one of the city's leading alternative theatrical spaces. The purpose? To scout talent for the network.
Similarly, over the last several years mainstream music institutions have noted the increased openness of their audiences and taken steps to exploit it. Lincoln Center has used its summer festival to explore fringier territory like "The Electronic Ordo Virtutum," a new interpretation of Hildegard von Bingen's 12th-century proto opera. Likewise, it has turned to smaller venues -- the 600-seat John Jay College Theater and the 500-seat New Victory Theater -- to present more experimental productions during its regular season. Carnegie Hall is also building a more flexible setting for music, the Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall, to expand the kinds of programming it presents.
Will today's music curators and their close relationships with artists be ennobled by alliances with larger institutions, given greater budgets and more freedom? Or will they be made virtually obsolete, gobbled up by mainstream venues? The betting is that there will always be lofts, bars and living rooms where people working in what will always be the no man's land of experimental music will gather. There will always be those who take joy in seeking out relationships with fringe artists, and midwifing a musician from obscurity to an appreciative audience.
It's late after a performance at Ms. Tomer's Saturday Balkan Cabaret at the Den at Two Boots. The musicians are packing, but the audience is still lingering -- talking, basking in the reverberations of the music. Asked what she would do if the music she is so passionate about suddenly went mainstream, Ms. Tomer knitted her brow and offered an idealistic response: "If what I am interested in becomes popular enough to support itself, if it creates enough momentum to garner bigger institutions, then I am gone. I will go on to the next uncharted area."
