PUB-DATE: March 26, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2474 words

HEADLINE: A Great Orchestra Dancing Past the Graveyard

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
DVORAK HALL in the Rudolfinum, the home of the Czech Philharmonic on a crook of Smetana's Moldau River, is, like this city itself, a small treasure. The stage, below a commanding pipe organ, projects into an auditorium mutedly colorful in grays and tans. Magnificent columns, beginning at balcony level, tower above on three sides, giving a sense of height and grandeur. That upper chamber provides light, from high windows during the day and chandeliers at night, and a rich, reverberant acoustic.
But the overriding impression occurs at orchestra level, where the room seems a jewel box, with elegantly decorated walls snugly enclosing most of the 1,000 seats, and that impression is one of smallness and intimacy. (Alice Tully Hall, by comparison, has 1,100 seats.) One of fragility, even, for how can a historically great international orchestra continue to function in the highly charged world economy of a new century from such a tiny, antiquated base? 
 In fact, the size of the hall, which was completed in 1885, used by the Parliament of Czechoslovakia from 1919 to 1939 and beautifully reconstructed from 1989 to 1992, may be the least of the orchestra's problems. For one thing, the Philharmonic spends relatively little time there. Like many other financially challenged performing-arts institutions in the emerging capitalist nations of Eastern Europe, the Czech Philharmonic has found the grass greener abroad. It performs about half of its 100 or so concerts a year on the road.
This afternoon, led by its chief conductor, Vladimir Ashkenazy, the orchestra gives the first of three concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, having just completed two weeks of touring in Florida and California. These concerts, the Philharmonic's first in New York since 1996, present mostly Bohemian or Czech music and are part of Lincoln Center's Prague Festival, which celebrates the 10th anniversary of the Velvet Revolution, a few months past. The festival began yesterday with a symposium on Prague's rich cultural history.
Touring is far from the whole solution, however, and not only because of the wear and tear it exacts on players and staff. As a state institution in a nation embroiled in an awkward transition to a market economy, the Czech Philharmonic has suffered a drastic reduction in subsidies in recent years but still labors under burdensome restrictions on how it can raise money and spend what it raises. It cannot, for example, unilaterally increase the salaries of players, who by any reasonable standard are cruelly underpaid.
Crisis, to be sure, is nothing new to the Czech Philharmonic, which was formed by members of the National Theater Opera Orchestra and gave its first concert in 1896, conducted by Antonin Dvorak in the Rudolfinum. Indeed, the second chapter in a published history of the Philharmonic is titled "Krize," with reference to a strike that resulted in the dismissal of the players by the theater in 1901 and the establishment of a shaky independent organization.
Yet through it all, including artistic misdirections compounding the financial woes of the last decade, the orchestra has maintained not only an excellent standard of performance but also something of its local character: a particularly rustic, woody cluck in the woodwinds, incisive playing from the brasses, a dark depth to the strings. The woodwinds are notable more for the individuality of their colors than for their blend. If any orchestra dances better, it can only be the Vienna Philharmonic, which may at the moment have more reason to do so. All this, at least, to judge from limited recent experience: two concerts and a rehearsal in Dvorak Hall, including repertory to be performed in New York.

THE characteristic sound of an orchestra, in many instances already a casualty of the jet age and the resultant interchangeability of players as well as maestros, is something that seems to worry critics and connoisseurs these days more than conductors. Engaged around the globe and at least marginally influenced by recent notions of period performance practice, conductors tend to prefer versatility: a shifting sonority appropriate in weight and coloration to the composer or work in question rather than a sound boasting local color. Mr. Ashkenazy is no exception.
"They are aware of their sound," he said of the Czech players. "But the repertory requires a certain type of sound. That's why more and more orchestras sound the same. Maybe there's some kind of margin where you can retain a certain sound and still play the repertory as it should be played."
Mr. Ashkenazy, at 62, is the ultimate musical cosmopolite. He left Russia in 1963 as an acclaimed pianist and now lives near Lucerne, Switzerland, with his family. After stints as principal guest conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, music director of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London and chief conductor of the Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra (now the Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester Berlin), he took over the Czech Philharmonic in 1998, picking up after a series of podium misadventures.
In 1991, the players, newly free to elect their leaders, voted to hire Gerd Albrecht as principal conductor rather than extend the contract of Jiri Belohlavek, who had taken over the year before. Mr. Albrecht, a German, thus became the first non-Czech maestro in the Philharmonic's storied history. The orchestra's fame was built and sustained during the long, successive tenures of four conductors, each a major figure internationally: Vaclav Talich from 1918 to 1934, Rafael Kubelik to 1950, Karel Ancerl to 1968 and Vaclav Neumann to 1990.
Part of the players' thinking about Mr. Albrecht, apparently, was that with his international contacts, he would attract more recording projects for the orchestra. But as it happened, the classical-record business was on the verge of a worldwide meltdown. Mr. Albrecht, who took over in 1993 after Mr. Belohlavek's angry exit, himself resigned in a fit of pique in 1996. Although no one would say much about Mr. Albrecht's term or his departure, the circumstances were obviously not happy.
"There were two camps," said Petr Kristian, a veteran violinist, "half and half." Mr. Albrecht, who had done much Czech music with the orchestra before, including Dvorak operas, suddenly seemed less interested in it, and some players are said to have found him highhanded in manner.
"It was destructive for the orchestra when he left in the middle of his contract," Mr. Ashkenazy said. After Mr. Albrecht's departure, the gap was filled jointly by Vladimir Valek, Sir Charles Mackerras and Ken-Ichiro Kobayashi. Mr. Valek, as permanent guest conductor, led tours celebrating the orchestra's centennial, including one in the United States in 1996. Mr. Ashkenazy first conducted the orchestra in 1997.
In his own conducting career, Mr. Ashkenazy ran into a situation in 1994 somewhat like Mr. Belohlavek's. Without consulting Mr. Ashkenazy, the Royal Philharmonic, which he had led since 1986 and with which he had open-ended plans extending to 1997, made an offer to a successor, Daniele Gatti. Mr. Ashkenazy resigned immediately.
Though widely experienced by now, he has not yet achieved the universal respect as a podium technician or interpreter that he enjoys as a pianist. (He will be heard in both functions tomorrow evening, playing and conducting Mozart's great D minor Concerto.) But many players respond to his innate musicality, evidently the Czechs among them.
"He is a good musician," said Jaroslav Halir, a young trumpeter. Mr. Kristian seconded that opinion, adding that Mr. Ashkenazy, because of his Slavic Russian roots, is sympathetic to the orchestra's tradition and style. (Mr. Ashkenazy rehearses the orchestra in English, when, that is, the musical terminology itself is not Italian.)
And he offers advantages beyond his musicianship. "With his connections, he can bring in many soloists and good conductors," Kr. Kristian said. "The level has improved in the last two years.
Another invaluable asset, not unrelated: Mr. Ashkenazy has brought along his powerful manager, Jasper Parrott, who is based in London. Mr. Parrott, a longtime friend and collaborator of the conductor's, wrote the biography "Ashkenazy: Beyond Frontiers" in 1985 with Mr. Ashkenazy's help. Mr. Parrott's father, Cecil Parrott, was the British ambassador to Czechoslovakia from 1960 to 1966, a writer about music, the author of a biography of Jaroslav Hasek and a translator of Hasek's "Good Soldier Svejk."
Mr. Parrott has been using his own diplomatic and managerial skills on the orchestra's behalf. For one thing, he is working with Mr. Ashkenazy for changes in legislation and governmental regulations.
"The Czech Republic is in some ways worse off, because it started out better," Mr. Parrott said of the various Eastern European countries still adjusting to life after Communism. "The attempt to liberalize after the revolution was largely a fraud. It sort of avoided problems and made things look good. Five years ago everything hit the buffers, and it became clear how little fundamental reform there had been. The Poles made much more rational reforms, and now Hungary has, too.
"It is difficult for institutions in the Czech Republic to benefit from entrepreneurial activities. Museums and performing-arts institutions are treated in the same way as everybody else, and they've all done badly. It's sort of equal misery for everybody, so nobody has gone bust."
Mr. Parrott has also been helping the orchestra's administration -- the managing director, Jiri Kovar, and the new intendant, Eva Sedlakova -- develop a modern management style based on Western models. The Czech Philharmonic administers the Rudolfinum as a whole, with its performance halls and art gallery. Mr. Kovar was said to be occupied with legal matters during a reporter's brief visit and thus unavailable. Ms. Sedlakova was put forward as the one who runs the orchestra day to day.
For an American, nosing around in the Czech Philharmonic's finances is depressing business. The overall institution's annual budget amounts to less than $4 million. The players' average salary, Ms. Sedlakova said, is 12,000 Czech crowns a month, which comes to about $4,000 a year. Although comparisons at such a level are almost beside the point, the average salary in the Vienna Philharmonic was said last year to be $59,000, and the starting salary in top American orchestras hovers near six digits.
The Czech players' average salary corresponds to that of the citizenry as a whole and is regulated to do so. "The budget for salaries is fixed," Ms. Sedlakova said. "It is not possible to increase salaries even for very good players."
State subsidies have declined steadily to about $1.3 million a year. "The subsidy now covers one-third of the budget," Ms. Sed lakova said, "and we still have the same regulations as if it were subsidized 100 percent." Sponsorship from corporations like the Investment and Postal Bank and Skoda Auto amounts to perhaps $300,000. The rest has to be earned through ticket sales and tours.
At least the players do not have to buy their own instruments. They may use those of the institution, and Ms. Sedlakova said the majority do. The players stand to make additional money by moonlighting, playing chamber music or recording film music, and Mr. Kristian said all do. A few, he added, also teach.
Still, the sums are pathetic, and even given a relatively low cost of living in Prague, such a scale puts the orchestra at a clear disadvantage in the international market for top musicians. Of the 120 players, Mr. Ashkenazy said, only one is not Czech, and that one is Slovakian. Here, to find a silver lining, is a reason the orchestra has been able to retain some of its old character.
And its old habits. Only five players are women: three violinists, who joined the orchestra in recent years, and (the classic dodge) two harpists. "It totally changed the atmosphere of the orchestra when women came in," Ms. Sedlakova said, declining to elaborate much. "It just changed. The building is not built to separate men and women. There are few rooms."
The difficulty in attracting players from outside the Czech Republic has by no means been killing, obviously, since native players have been good enough to lift the orchestra to its present level. The worse problem is the converse: keeping the best Czech players from accepting foreign opportunities, which are sure to increase when the Czech Republic enters the European Union, perhaps in 2003. Mr. Ashkenazy cited the case of a young Czech horn player who eluded the orchestra's grasp, which he fears may become typical.
"It is not yet destructive, but it might be," he said. "The playing itself is still at a very high level, but the morale is not so good. The players sit there with their arms folded, thinking we will do something for them, because that's the way it was under Communism."
Mr. Ashkenazy seems to be trying his best to help. "It takes a lot of time and energy meeting with important people to find solutions, meeting with this minister, that minister," he said. "But if we ever get to the point where we can do with our money what we like, then we'll be all right."

ALTHOUGH no one would specify Mr. Ashkenazy's salary, Mr. Parrott said that "his fees are substantially below his international level, but they are at least honorable." He is maintaining most of the busy schedule to which he was already committed elsewhere before coming to the aid of the orchestra. He spends six or seven weeks a season with the Czech Philharmonic in Prague, he said, and another six or seven weeks on tour.
"It would be nice if he could be here more," Ms. Sedlakova said. She pointed out that although he had not yet taken part in player auditions, in which he is supposed to have a vote, she hoped he might make one next month for an opening in the horn section.
"But when he is here he does his utmost," she added. "The time of conductors like Ancerl and Neumann is another world. Even if we had a very good Czech conductor, he would mostly be abroad. The main thing is to be in touch."
Mr. Ashkenazy says he hopes to spend more time in Prague, and he is not in any case trying to drum up new business. "I don't like to guest-conduct so much," said this most self-effacing maestro (if that is not in fact an oxymoron). "I'm too shy. I like to establish relationships." His contract with the Czech Philharmonic runs until next year, and an extension is being negotiated, doubtless with understandable caution on both sides.
"We mustn't be too pessimistic," Mr. Ashkenazy said of the many difficulties still ahead of him and the orchestra. "We can't predict everything. But it would be a shame to lose a great orchestra, because you might lose it."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 17; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1543 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Exploring the Farthest Edges of French Society

BYLINE: By NANCY RAMSEY; Nancy Ramsey's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the Iranian director Majid Majidi.

 BODY:
DRESSED in a leather jacket and jeans, the director Claire Denis, whose latest film, "Beau Travail," opens on Friday, has a casual sophistication. At 49, she is petite, intense, reticent and, on occasion, disarmingly honest. Her voice is raspy but energetic, and in conversation she is at once very quick and very thoughtful. The daughter of a French civil servant, Ms. Denis grew up in Cameroon in West Africa during the final days of the colonial empire.
"Beau Travail" ("Good Work"), the story of a troop of French Foreign Legionnaires, is set in present-day Djibouti, in East Africa. "When I was a child, I was living in a landscape that I knew was not mine," Ms. Denis said one evening last September over a glass of red wine near Lincoln Center, where her film was screening as part of the New York Film Festival. "People have written that my being raised in Africa, growing up in a different culture, forever a foreigner, made me solitary. But I never suffered not to be raised in France. I liked this sharing of cultures. Of course it's an imposed sharing, but it opens your mind. My parents were teachers, and my father was militant for independence. One of my small memories of when I was a child was somebody immediately clearing away my plate at the table as soon as I was finished. My parents told me that wasn't normal." 
 "Chocolat" (1988), her critically acclaimed first film, is set in Cameroon and combines a spareness with a rich sensuality and texture. A shy little girl is tended to and served by a kind, strappingly handsome houseboy. Father is often away on business; sexual tension builds between mother and houseboy. Slow, languid days in the hot African sun coexist with the racial tensions about to explode under the harshness of colonial rule.
"In 'Chocolat,' I was trying to say something about the perversity of the colonial situation," said Ms. Denis, who now lives in Paris and who as a young filmmaker worked as an assistant to Wim Wenders, Jim Jarmusch and Costa-Gavras. "French colonialism was a little better," she said, and smiled. "Well, you know how French people are, they're always better." Her next features, "No Fear, No Die" (1990), "I Can't Sleep" (1993) and "Nenette and Boni" (1996), were set in France but on the margins of French society: the outskirts of Paris, the port city of Marseille. Populating the films are African guest workers, West Indian immigrants, disaffected adolescents, black-market businessmen who prey on the illegal immigrant community, all thrown together in rich tapestries. They move in and out of the street's night shadows, Ms. Denis's camera glancing off them at oblique angles, a visual metaphor for their tangential relationship to mainstream society. Sultry soundtracks are punctuated by the rhythms of reggae and disco. In describing "I Can't Sleep," in which a transvestite and his lover are killing old women in Paris, Caryn James noted in The New York Times that "it calmly lures viewers into an ordinary world where the sinister and the benign wear the same face."
Lives on the edge, moral ambiguity: making a film whose main characters are legionnaires seemed a logical next step. "When you join the legion, nobody remembers the past, even if you were in prison," Ms. Denis said. "It's a hard life, but it's also a protected life." With outposts in remote corners of the world, where strict discipline ruled, the legion developed a reputation as a haven for criminals and misfits.
"Remember Gary Cooper in 'Beau Geste'?" she asked. " 'Where would you go if you wanted to disappear completely?' " Ms. Denis first encountered the Foreign Legion not in Africa but in Paris, on the Champs-Elysees during a Bastille Day parade, and for her it was not the legion of criminals and misfits but of Edith Piaf's "Mon Legionnaire." ("He was thin/ He was fine," she trilled. "And the desire for his skin consumes me.") "The legionnaires' parade was very beautiful," Ms. Denis said. "They were very solemn and proud, they never mixed with the other soldiers."
Shortly before Christmas 1998, Ms. Denis, the cinematographer Agnes Godard (who has worked with her since "Chocolat" and is no relation to the director Jean-Luc Godard), and a small crew arrived in Djibouti and stayed five weeks. "We shot from morning to evening," Ms. Denis said. "Bringing along a generator would have meant bringing it by boat, so we used only natural light." The crew's equipment was spare: a truck, two tents and, for protection, 15 guns. Assistance came from Djibouti's Ministry of Culture and Army; according to Ms. Denis, the French Army was none too happy about the project.
"It was rather difficult to convince them that I was not going to make fun of the legion," Ms. Denis said.
"Beau Travail" is beautifully filmed, the dialogue is minimal and the military training sequences, under the scorching African sun with the sparkling blue Gulf of Aden in the background, are elaborately choreographed, often to the backdrop of Benjamin Britten's opera "Billy Budd." The story line, in fact, is based loosely on Herman Melville's allegorical novella, set in 1797 in the British Navy, in which an innocent sailor, Billy Budd, is destroyed by a petty officer, John Claggart.
In "Beau Travail," Sentain, a new recruit played by Gregoire Colin, arrives in Djibouti; he is young, fit and brave, and his sergeant, Galoup (Denis Lavant from Leos Carax's "Lovers on the Bridge"), becomes consumed with jealousy over him. Vowing to destroy Sentain, Galoup ends up destroying his own career.
On the surface, Galoup's story is not a sympathetic one. "It was up to me to make him someone I would like," Ms. Denis said. "I needed to be somewhere inside that character. I cannot be the one to judge. I always consider a character to be as anxious and fragile as I am. My link with Galoup, I suppose, is some kind of pathetic obligation to do well, to be loyal, to work hard as opposed to the search to be happy." Critics have noted Ms. Denis's striking empathy with her characters. "Some directors make films that are clearly for the elite," said Jean-Michel Frodon, who writes about film for Le Monde. "But Claire Denis does not make films from a superior position. She's also not somebody who lives only with her brain. She reacts to feelings and sensations.
"Many directors take a big red pen and draw arrows on the screen so that you know who is who and what is what, where it comes from, where it goes," he continued. "But Denis doesn't design characters that way. She does not twist the way things are just because it's more attractive. I think that the word that would define her is ethical."
Outside of directing, she was active in a movement launched by French film directors in early 1997 that worked on behalf of "sans papier," people without documents who were being threatened with deportation by the authorities. "She kept working on it after the media attention went away, when most of her colleagues went back to their usual business," Mr. Frodon said.
Ms. Denis's sense of justice applies as well to her casting choices. For the role of Bruno Forestier, the commander who presides over the troops in "Beau Travail," she chose Michel Subor. One of Mr. Subor's first roles as an actor was in Jean-Luc Godard's overtly political and seldom shown "Le Petit Soldat" (1960), a film made shortly after "Breathless." Its existentialist hero, Bruno Forestier, a young man trying to find his way in a Europe where good and evil were not so clear as during World War II, was an army deserter who was coerced by right-wing forces to assassinate a man fighting for the cause of Algerian independence.
" 'Petit Soldat' is one of my favorite movies ever, and I always considered Michel Subor's performance one of the best performances in a film," Ms. Denis said. "At the end, Forestier has killed a man, and he knows he cannot return to France."
And so Forestier, again played by Mr. Subor, appears, 40 years later, in Ms. Denis's Africa. "Working with Michel Subor was so moving, it's something I'll never forget," she said. "It was almost as if he had disappeared as an actor. Did you know he was the voice-over in 'Jules et Jim'? I hadn't seen him since he had a part in Hitchcock's 'Topaz.'
"As a young actor with Godard, he had such strength, and that's still with him. And Denis Lavant has this whole physical world within him."
"Beau Travail" begins and ends in Marseille, with a solitary Galoup recounting his tale in a narrative voice-over similar to Forestier's in "Petit Soldat." The last scene is set in a disco to the pulsing "Rhythm of the Night"; Stephen Holden, in The Times, called it "a frenzied Dionysian release." It is ambiguous, like much in Ms. Denis's films. "It was like an emotion I couldn't stop," she said. "The best explanation is that I wanted that scene and that's why it's there. The whole film is a kind of stew, a cuisine. 'Le Petit Soldat' is always in my mind; whenever I don't know what to do in a film, it's like a light for me. And I took from Melville what interested me.
"The innocence of Billy Budd, the role of law, that didn't interest me the most. I always found Claggart more interesting; he represents neither power nor innocence like me."

PUB-DATE: March 26, 2000

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 16; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1361 words

HEADLINE: Korea to Syosset: A 2-Generation Bridge

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

DATELINE: SYOSSET

 BODY:
THE manicurist at the first table in the busy nail salon remembers everything: the names of her regular customers, what colors they choose, whether they prefer their nails long or short, shaped square or round. As manager and a partner of Pinky Nails, she is known as Jane.
But after work every evening, during her 10-minute drive to her Hicksville apartment, she resumes her role as Jung S. Yoo, Korean immigrant, who even after 15 years living in the United States is still only comfortable when speaking Korean. 
 While customers at the salon insist she is fluent in English, Ms. Yoo does not share their confidence. "When I want to say something, it's hard for me to explain it in English," she said. "Sometimes I hear a new word and look it up, but by the next day, I forget it."
For Ms. Yoo, a new life in America began in 1985, when she moved from South Korea to Flushing with her husband and their nine-year-old son, Jong, who quickly became Americanized as "Dennis Kim" (his father's surname).
"I am part of what we call the 'one-point-five generation,' " said Mr. Kim, now 23 and a New York City police officer, who had stopped at Pinky Nails recently to take his mother to dinner for her birthday. "We call ourselves 1.5 because we are both Korean and American.
"My mother, coming from Korea as an adult, is part of the 1.0 generation. My mother understands the English of her customers, but if she watches the news on TV, she only understands part of it. Members of the 1.0 generation don't integrate that much with Americans."
As for the 1.5 generation, Mr. Kim explained: "Coming here as a kid, I had a tough time in the beginning, but I've found myself. I've learned to assimilate in both cultures and to distinguish which parts of me should be Korean and which American. I look Korean, but I'm American. When I'm with my Korean friends, we speak Korean; when I'm with my American friends, we speak English. My children, who will be born here, will be part of the 2.0 generation."
For the 1.0 generation, the decision to come to the United States was often motivated by enticing stories from friends and family already here. "My husband's family has been in New York since 1978," said Ms. Yoo. "But he was not as interested in coming here as I was. I couldn't wait to come to this exciting country."
But while her husband was greeted with a job at the midtown Manhattan deli where his brother worked, Ms. Yoo had to figure out what she could do in her new home. For Korean immigrants, the typical pattern is to follow in the footsteps of family or friends who have already found jobs, frequently in dry-cleaning, fruit and vegetable markets and nail salons.
While there are no Korean associations listed in the telephone directories for Long Island, there is a Korean Community Service Center in Flushing that helps Korean immigrants with problems ranging from language barriers or confusion over local laws to job searches.
For Ms. Yoo, the path to a nail salon came through a friend. As she remembered, "My friend told me that it was very hard to find work, but giving manicures was quick to learn and would be an easy job."
Following a crash course, Ms. Yoo found her first job at a salon in Manhattan, two months after arriving in the United States. For four years, she worked in New York City. But in 1989, when Dennis was starting eighth grade, she was not satisfied with the education he was getting and decided to move to Long Island. Following a friend who told her schools were good in Locust Valley, the family rented a house there.
Thus Ms. Yoo came to the Island at the very beginning of a surge in Asian residents. The Census Bureau put the number of Asians and Pacific Islanders in Nassau and Suffolk at 63,000 in 1990, and estimates that their number shot up 52 percent by July 1998, to 96,000.
The year she arrived on the Island, 1989, brought two other major changes to life in America: Ms. Yoo and a relative became partners in their own salon, and she learned to drive. "When we lived in Korea, most women didn't know how to drive," she said. "Even in Queens, I never needed to drive. But on Long Island there was no choice. So I went to a Korean driving school."
For Dennis Kim, life also became increasingly Americanized. After graduating from Locust Valley High School, he continued to college, first at SUNY Farmingdale, then at SUNY Albany.
"Like most kids, I really didn't know what I wanted to do with myself," he said. "A friend of mine convinced me to take the exam to become a police officer, and right after graduating from college, I was hired by the New York City Police Department."
He is now one of 40 Koreans on the force, he said, "but half are Americans who don't even speak Korean."
In 1996, when the family became eligible for American citizenship, Ms. Yoo and her husband immediately started studying for the exam, which included a test on the Constitution and American government. Of the decision to apply for citizenship, Ms. Yoo explained, "We had been here for more than 10 years, and this was my home."
But for Dennis Kim, at 20 years old, contemplating the decision of where his permanent home should be was more difficult. "I realized then," he said, "that if I went back to Korea, I would no longer fit in."
Preparing for the citizenship exam was overwhelming, Ms. Yoo said. "There was so much to remember," she said. "We had to know about the three branches of government and what each color of the American flag stands for. We received a manual and a tape, and every day I took the tape in my car and studied the material. Today, four years later, I forgot it all."
Now an American citizen and entrepreneur, Ms. Yoo has become a familiar and friendly face to hundreds of steady customers at Pinky Nails who appreciate her interest in their personal lives. "Many mothers and daughters come to get their nails done together," she said. "We've celebrated with them many bar mitzvahs, weddings and new babies."
While comfortable chatting in English with her customers, Ms. Yoo still switches to Korean when conversing with her co-workers, all of whom are also Korean.
Since a Seinfeld comedy routine in which Korean manicurists were apparently gossiping in their own language about their American customers, Ms. Yoo has been asked countless times if the manicurists do in fact talk about their customers.
"Of course not," she insists. "When we discuss what color polish a customer wants, or which nails need to be repaired, it's just easier to explain it in Korean than in English."
And Mr. Kim, who saw the Seinfeld episode, challenged its authenticity. "That's not the way we speak," he said. "They imitated the sounds, but it was not our language. If I was younger and more into defending our culture, I would have been offended, but now I think it's funny."
Outside work, Ms. Yoo's social life centers around membership in a Korean church in Bethpage. She often spends days off with friends in Flushing, where there is easy access to Korean groceries and video.
"My mother likes her life very simple," Mr. Kim said. "She refuses even to get a beeper."
And as a true 1.0, she still insists on speaking only Korean at home. "I don't want my son ever to forget the Korean language," Ms. Yoo said. "And I never want him to forget that while he is American, he is also Korean."
She is even more Korean, and travels back to South Korea every other year to visit her parents and other family members, but her real home is now on the Island, she said, with her son and husband.
"I don't know how long I'll continue working, or if one day I might return to Korea," Ms. Yoo said. "Right now, this is my home, but the truth is, nobody really knows what tomorrow will bring."
 
A Diverse Island
Articles in this series are looking beyond the stereotypes that sometimes taint relations between immigrants and native-born Long Islanders. Future articles will examine immigrants' lives and how they are being woven -- or not -- into the social and economic fabric. The first article, on March 12, examined the lives and aspirations of Muslims on the Island.

HEADLINE: The View From/Dobbs Ferry;
Ballroom Dance Pizazz From Russian Emigres

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY

 BODY:
WHEN she was a little girl in the city of Baku in what was then the Soviet Union, Lilia Borovski told herself stories about becoming a dancer and a princess. The princess part did not materialize, but she and her husband, Ilia Borovski, could be seen as royalty of sorts. Still in their early 20's, they are well known in the world of competitive ballroom dancing, having won dozens of international competitions doing everything from the stately waltz to the flashy Argentine tango.
Last year, they moved from Moscow to the United States to broaden their opportunities. Earlier this winter, they became teachers at Royal Ballroom, a studio that opened here this month. Their reputations in Russia had been solid, they said, but here in America, they felt they could soar as far as their fancy footwork could carry them. 
 "In America, if you have an idea, you can grow," Ms. Borovski, a petite woman with huge almond-shaped eyes, said. "In Russia, it is more fatalistic; there are limits."
Her husband added: "Here, too, everyone feels safer. Nobody worries about tomorrow, about the car breaking, about one day waking up and having no money at all."
In recent years, many ballroom dancers have left Russia and come to the United States, the Borovskis said. Those who left while Communist rule still prevailed generally did so for political and ideological reasons; those who came after the breakup of the Soviet Union were usually fleeing precarious economic conditions. But whatever the reason, they found a welcoming environment, where they can pursue their dancing and teach it to amateurs at studios like Royal Ballroom.
Indeed, Royal Ballroom alone has nine Russian teachers, including the Borovskis. The company Royal Ballroom Inc. is owned by Alex Koulik, a former neurologist, and his wife, Tanya, an English teacher, who left Moscow seven years ago and now live in Millburn, N.J. The Kouliks, who have earned several championship titles, run Royal Ballroom Studios in Millburn and New Brunswick. Their most recent venture, the one in Dobbs Ferry, is franchised to Barbara Antes, an American nurse, entrepreneur and dancer from Pleasantville.
The Kouliks, the Borovskis, two other Russian couples and a 29-year-old dancer and aerospace scientist, Vlad Kalyuzhny, rotate among the New Jersey and Dobbs Ferry studios, giving lessons and exhibitions.
On Friday evening the public can see some of them dance at Royal Ballroom on Ashford Avenue here. (The cost is $10 a person; the number to call for more information is 479-9090.)
For those who want to work with Russian dancers, there are individual and group lessons.
On a recent night at Royal Ballroom here, the Borovskis and Mr. Kalyuzhny led students around the blond wood floor, past mirror-lined walls, giving instructions. (Mr. Kalyuzhny, who is also highly proficient in computer and accounting, helps with the financial end of the business operation as well.) In their liltingly accented voices, they counted out beats -- "cha-cha, cha-cha-cha" -- and gave directions to students ranging from highly skilled to visibly self-conscious. If they felt frustrated by some pupils' lack of innate ability, they never let it show.
"We love to help everyone, to show them the better, more professional way," Ms. Borovski said.
They also talked about their own lives. Mr. Borovski, 23, was born in Iranteevka, a suburb of Moscow; his wife, 24, is from Baku, near the Caspian Sea. Both remember growing up in an era where anything American was considered forbidden, therefore desirable: "Even bubble gum from America, it was a brighter shade of pink," he said.
Both began dancing at an early age. Ms. Borovski, who said, "My first word was cha-cha," remembers being allowed to compete virtually anywhere but America. "Smooth" dances, as they are known -- fox trot, waltz, and the like -- were favored in Russia over livelier, more suggestive Latin ones, although the rhumba was allowed because it came by way of Cuba. Costumes, while elaborate creations of sequins and silk, could not be as revealing as their American counterparts.
In 1993, Ilia and Lilia met at a competition in St. Petersburg. "I have another partner, he has another partner," Ms. Borovski recalled. "First two dances, samba and cha-cha, I win. Second two, rhumba and pase doble, he wins. In competition, I'm thinking about dancing, not romance."
Five years later, however, they met again. This time they clicked instantly and within two days were talking about spending the rest of their lives together. They soon married, moved to Miami Beach and, after that, to Dobbs Ferry. They are "extremely happy" living in America, and with each other: they never have to explain anything, they said, verbally or on the dance floor. "We feel the same things, we think the same things, we move the same way," Ms. Borovski said.
As for Mr. Kalyuzhny, he does not yet have a professional dance partner or a spouse. A native of Moscow, he said he was a straight-A student, first in grade school, then in high school, then at the Moscow Aviation Institute, where he studied to be a cosmonaut. "By education," he said, "I am a designer of space stations."
When the Soviet Union broke up, financing of the space program was cut off, and he got temporary work as a translater. Soon he was offered a job with an American-based construction company. While living in Staten Island (he now lives in Edison, N.J.), he obtained a green card and decided to stay.
"Dance lessons are so much cheaper in Russia and, for professionals, the competition has no big prizes," he said. "Here one can teach ballroom dancing for much more money and can win money in competitions. I would like to also be in aerospace, but I do not know if I can ever be in that profession here."

HEADLINE: The Guide

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

O'Neill Seminars
On Tuesday at 7 p.m. David Hays, designer of the original production of Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night," will talk about the play in the house where it is set, Monte Cristo Cottage, the O'Neill summer home at 325 Pequot Avenue in New London.
This will be the first of two seminars on O'Neill. The second is scheduled on April 11 at the same time and place. The speaker will be Ted Mann, founder of the Circle-in-the-Square Theater in Manhattan, and producer of numerous O'Neill plays. 
 The seminars are precursors to a ceremony on April 28 when honorary doctorate degrees will be conferred on Arthur and Barbara Gelb, authors of the definitive biography of the playwright, "O'Neill," published in 1962. The couple has written a second three-volume work titled "O'Neill: Life With Monte Cristo," to be published by Applause Books in May. Mr. Gelb, formerly managing editor of The New York Times, is director of The New York Times College Scholarship program.
Presentation of the honorary degrees will take place at 4:30 p.m. in the Cummings Art Center of Connecticut College, 270 Mohegan Avenue, New London. Included in the ceremonies will be talks about O'Neill, his background and his work, by the Gelbs and others.
The event will kick off a series of symposiums, lectures, performances and exhibitions to be presented through December of this year under the umbrella title "Eugene O'Neill's New London: The Influence of Time and Place," a tribute to the only American Nobel Prize-winning playwright.
All events are open to the public free of charge. Call (860) 439-2787 for more information.
 
Before Jeans
Before the fashion-bereft 60's and the subsequent elevation of the blue jean and T-shirt to a thousand-dollar plateau, there were real clothes by Schiaparelli, Mainbocher and Chanel as well as Trigere, Norell, McCardle and other Americans.
Fashion has moved along, smartly or not, through the 20th century, and at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford it is documented in an exhibition that points up its erratic trajectory. From haute couture paper dresses to beaded extravaganzas, from Seventh Avenue to Hollywood, custom salon to ready-to-wear, changes in silhouettes, fabrics and concepts are displayed on 25 mannequins. Adjuncts to the clothes are also on view, including perfume, underwear, accessories, photographs and advertisements.
"The Fashion Follies: A Look Back at the 20th Century" may be seen through Sept. 10, on Tuesday through Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is $7, $5 for students and people 62 and older, $3 for children 6 through 17, free under 6, and free to everyone on Thursdays and before noon on Saturdays. Call (860) 278-2670 for more information.
 
American History
A three-day Conference on Native American Studies will be held for a third year at Yale in New Haven, beginning on Friday at 5 p.m. with an address by Arthur Lazurus. The former Yale law professor represented the Sioux Nation before the Supreme Court in a landmark effort to redress the government's appropriation of the Black Hills in 1876.
A panel discussion on Saturday morning on the historical perspectives of legal sovereignty will be led by Alan Trachtenberg, professor of English at Yale. The afternoon session will open with a talk by Oren Lyons, a chief and faithkeeper of the Onondaga Nation, to be followed by a panel on contemporary sovereignty in political, economic and environmental matters. Judith Resnik, another Yale law professor, will lead that discussion.
Saturday evening will be filled with a reception and dinner at the Beineke Library, where Gerald Vizenor, Native American poet and writer, will read from his work. And on Sunday morning, Carol Rose, Yale professor of law and organization, will be moderator for a panel on intellectual sovereignty.
The weekend will culminate in a powwow on Sunday at 12:30 in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium, featuring a dance contest, drumming performance and crafts in a variety of Native American idioms. All events are open to the public and do not require reservations. Call (203) 432-2956 or send an e-mail message to george.miles@yale.edu for more information.
 
Tallulah Bankhead
"Tallulah Tonight!" -- called "Southern Comfort" when it was presented in New Rochelle earlier this month -- has been developing over many months of traveling around the country as a vehicle for Tovah Feldshuh. It was first performed a year ago at Odette's, a cabaret in New Hope, Pa., and it is expected to be booked into an Off Broadway house later this year.
The Tallulah of the title is the legendary actress from Alabama. The show, based on an episode in Ms. Bankhead's tumultuous life, opens at Theater Works in Hartford on Friday, running through May 7. Ms. Feldshuh, winner of Obie, Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle awards, will portray Ms. Bankhead.
Ms. Feldshuh, who wrote the script with Linda Selman, has given herself an opportunity to exercise her vocal talent by interspersing the script with songs by Cole Porter, Noel Coward and Johnny Mercer.
Performances are Wednesday through Saturday at 8; Sunday at 2:30 and 7:30. Additional Tuesday performances are scheduled on April 4, 18 and 25 at 8, and a Saturday matinee will be given on April 29 at 2:30. The theater address is 233 Pearl Street and tickets at $20, $25 and $35 may be reserved by calling (860) 527-7838.
 
Puppet Artistry
Saturday, April Fool's Day, is also the National Day of Puppetry, and it will be celebrated at the Charter Oak Cultural Center in Hartford with a full complement of puppet arts from 9 to 4:30. There will be workshops and demonstrations as well as performances of interest to novice puppeteers, polished performers, educators -- and to children and grown-ups who just enjoy puppet shows. One of the workshops will be devoted to Punch and Judy, conducted by Don Wonderlee, and one of the performances will be "Shadows 'n' Light," by Jim Napolitano of Nappy's Puppets.
The day was organized by the Connecticut Guild of Puppetry. The center is at 21 Charter Oak Avenue and admission to all events for the entire day requires registration at $40. Admission to the 2 p.m. performance by Mr. Napolitano is $3. Call (860) 693-4129 for more information.
 
Whistler's Influence
James McNeill Whistler is the subject of three lectures organized by the Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington. The first two are to be held at Miss Porter's School, 60 Main Street in Farmington, on Wednesday and April 5. The third will take place at Hill-Stead on April 12.
Linda Merrill, curator of American art at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, will present the first lecture, called "Whistler in America," appraising his influence on American art as an expatriate American. (Whistler left the United States at the age of 21.) The second lecture, "Patron and Friend: Charles Lang Freer and James McNeill Whistler," will be given by Kenneth Myers, assistant curator of American art at the Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery of the Smithsonian Institute.
Freer, a Detroit industrialist, was a prodigious collector of Whistler's work -- some 130 paintings, 174 works on paper, and 946 prints. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: For Fairness, Metro-North Takes Over Lots

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
IN Pelham, out-of-towners pay a premium to park at the train station: $390 a year compared with the $350 it costs villagers. It is a similar story in Port Chester, where commuters from nearby towns like Rye Brook and Greenwich pay $470 annually, compared with the $256 that local residents pay.
All that, however, is likely to change as the Metro-North Railroad takes over parking lots in places along its lines. 
 With Westchester's rail commuters lining up for parking permits like Giants fans for season tickets, Metro-North has decided to enter the parking lot business and level the playing field for all customers.
"It's a fairness issue," Marjorie Anders, a spokeswoman for the railroad, said, explaining why the railroad is taking over some of the parking lots it owns, instead of leasing them to the municipalities. "The goal is to improve access to our stations for all people, regardless of where they live."
She added: "Not everyone realizes that we don't control all the parking lots. They assume that if it's our station, it's also our lot. So we've decided that what we can control we will." An estimated 79,000 customers commute on Metro-North's lines every weekday during the morning rush.
Metro-North has already taken back 19 of 83 parking lots in New York State. On March 1, it took control of the spaces it owns in Mamaroneck, and next month it will do the same in Pelham. It has not announced which stations are next.
Once Metro-North takes over the spaces it owns next to the Pelham station, the resident rate will prevail for all. Justifying Pelham's policy up to now, Mayor Joseph E. Durnin Jr. said that if his village had not given preference to residents, "It would have been open season for anyone to use our station."
In Port Chester, where Metro-North also owns part of the lot but leases all of it to the village, Richard A. Falanka, the village clerk, agreed with Mayor Durnin, saying that "parking spaces are like gold" and municipalities should make sure their own residents are served first.
But Ms. Anders said the railroad wants an impartial party -- not the towns and villages -- to issue permits and maintain waiting lists. Metro-North has hired Allright Transit Services of Poughkeepsie to run the lots. She said that the company will take over the existing waiting lists and maintain them.
The railroad also plans to increase the amount of available parking for commuters, "even if that means literally repainting lines to eke out another space," Ms. Anders said.
In addition, Metro-North will assume responsibility for landscaping, striping, snow removal and lighting, among other things -- the duties formerly carried out by the municipalities that leased the slots and shared the revenue with Metro-North.
Michael S. Blau, Mamaroneck's village manager, said that from an economic perspective, Metro-North's re-entry into the parking lot business in his municipality turned out to be a good thing. Mamaroneck did not charge out-of-towners more to park. "The village initially resisted, but once we looked at all of our costs versus the revenues generated, we realized there was no benefit to our running the lot," Mr. Blau said. "We weren't making enough money to justify keeping it because we were anticipating major costs to maintain it."
Meanwhile, at stations where Metro-North owns relatively few parking spaces, out-of-town commuters may continue to fume.
In Tarrytown, for example, Metro-North owns only 77 of the 909 parking spaces next to the station. Those 77 spaces are metered, open to all. In an effort to keep cars from Rockland from crowding out local residents who park during the early morning commuter rush, Tarrytown raised its rates for nonresident commuters to $950 a year, a $325 increase. By contrast, Tarrytown residents pay $150 a year.
"Our goal is to encourage people from Rockland to take mass transit across the Tappan Zee," Richard Slingerland, the village adminstrator, said.
Out-of-town commuters in Croton-on-Hudson will also have to put up with the village's rate structure, said Richard F. Herbek, village manager and clerk. The village, which owns 2,000 spaces in the parking area, charges $1,008 a year for one of 50 preferred parking spaces, which are right next to the tracks and are guaranteed to be available. Other permit spaces are oversold on the assumption that not everyone will be commuting at the same time. Permits are $648 a year for nonresidents and $432 for residents.
Mr. Herbek said Croton's rate structure is intended to discourage commuters from Rockland, Orange and Dutchess Counties and other Westchester communities. The Croton-Harmon station, the largest in Westchester, generates more than $1 million in annual income for the town.
Other municipalities in Westchester where Metro-North owns at least some of the parking spaces are Scarsdale, North White Plains, Mount Kisco, Hastings-on-Hudson, Irvington, Ossining, Peekskill, Larchmont and Rye. And at many of those stations, the Metro-North spaces are metered.
Besides Mamaroneck, Allright already oversees parking lots in Harrison and Mount Vernon East. In parts of Connecticut up to New Haven, where Metro-North also operates, the state's Department of Transportation oversees the parking lots.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Helmetta, N.J.;
Middlesex County's Version of Mayberry

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
AT regular intervals each day, the Helmetta Police Station is locked up so that the sole officer on duty can go out on patrol. Generally, he's back at the station within an hour. Crime is virtually nonexistent in Helmetta, a Middlesex County borough that measures all of 0.9 square miles.
Wedged between the towns of Spotswood and Jamesburg, Helmetta is truly a sleepy little town. It has four police officers, fewer than 800 homes and just a handful of businesses -- among them, a 19th-century general store, a flower shop, a gas station, a post office and a landscaping supply store -- all on Main Street. But the commercial activity in the borough is about to double, with the impending completion of a small strip mall at the corner of Main Street and Old Forge Road. 
 Alluding to the town portrayed on "The Andy Griffith Show," Mayor Frank Hague said, "People say we're like Mayberry, U.S.A., a small town where people gather for coffee at the general store and watch out for each other."
The one thing that rattles Helmetta, literally, are the Conrail freight trains that chug through several times a day, shaking the nearby houses. The line was built by the Pennsylvania Railroad before the turn of the century to haul tobacco from the South to the Helme Tobacco Company mill, which was the world's largest snuff producer and the borough's main employer until it closed in 1993. Now, the deserted 21-building, 14-acre mill complex looms over Main Street as a reminder of the borough's proud industrial past and as its hope for the future.
The mill is the heart of the 220-acre G. W. Helme Snuff Mill Historic District, which is listed on both the National and State Registers of Historic Places. The district is bounded by Manalapan Brook to the south, Lake Avenue to the East, Ericson Avenue and Helmetta Pond to the north and Railroad Avenue to the west.
"It's the center of our town and needs to be redeveloped," said Mayor Hague, who has not been able to determine if he is distantly related to the longtime Jersey City mayor of the same name. "We would like to see the owners sell the mill so that it can be reused to provide jobs and more tax revenue. It could be used for light industrial lofts or even be outfitted as an assisted-living facility."
The mill is now owned by Swisher International of Wheeling, W. Va., and is for sale for $1.25 million. Stephen M. Segal, the owner of Segal Commercial Realty, which is representing Swisher, said that the best use for the property would be a converting it to housing for the elderly. "It is a multibuilding site where the buildings are of different ages, some 100 years old, which makes it complicated to redevelop," he said. "However, a number of developers are looking seriously at the property now." He would not name them.
Started in 1825, the snuff mill was sold to George W. Helme in 1879. In 1888, the borough split from East Brunswick in a dispute over services. It was named in honor of Mr. Helme's daughter Olivia Antoinette Helme, who was known as Etta.
Today, about a quarter of Helmetta's residents still have strong ties to the mill. Janice Mondoker, the vice president of the Helmetta Historic Society, recalls picking her father up at the mill entrance when the whistle blew for lunch every day. Her father was employed by the mill for half a century, and her parents, Emil and Margaret Mondoker, still live in one of the 105 houses that the company built for its workers at the turn of the century.
Many of those homes, on John Street, Railroad Avenue, Old Forge Road and Main Street, still have outhouses in their backyards. But with the installation of indoor plumbing in the 1940's, they were converted into storage sheds.
Peggy Gandy, the owner of Gandy Realty in neighboring Jamesburg and a lifelong resident of the area, recalled that until the tobacco company sold them to the workers in the late 1960's, the houses were all painted white. "That was the only color the company used," she explained.
Mrs. Gandy said the sturdy houses -- 16 feet wide, two stories tall, with two bedrooms and one bath -- are the most affordable ones in the borough, selling for $115,000 to $135,000, depending on condition and improvements. Occasionally, a house in need of updating sells for under $90,000, and recently one with an additional bedroom on Old Forge Road went for $149,900.
T HE borough also has 1940's ranches, a few postwar Cape Cods and a row of 1920's Sears prefabricated two-story houses that still have assembly instructions etched into their rafters. Those homes sell in the $115,000-to-$135,000 range.
The most expensive single-family homes in the borough are three- and four-bedroom colonials in the Sutton Place development, 60 houses built two years ago just off Main Street. They originally sold for $180,000 to $245,000. The first resales are just coming on the market, Mrs. Gandy said.
Helmetta has one major condominium complex, 340 two-bedroom units at Heather Glen, in a wooded setting off Lake Avenue, about a quarter mile from Main Street. Sandra Bohinski, the borough clerk, said that when Heather Glen was built in the late 1980's, it virtually doubled the borough's population.
Last year, 24 Heather Glen condos were sold at prices ranging from $74,500 for a one-bath unit to $104,000 for a two-bath end unit.
Among the people who recently moved into Heather Glen was Rocco Mazzio, a divorced father of three, who bought his condominium in January because it provided enough space for his children to sleep over and wooded trails for them to hike on.
"I was looking for an affordable home in a family-oriented community," Mr. Mazzio said.
Two other complexes are in the early stages of development: Regency Manor, with 70 single-family houses for people 55 and older, and Lakeview Commons, with 30 town houses. Both are just off Maple Avenue, behind the old mill complex.
The borough has about a dozen one- and two-bedroom apartments with monthly rents in the $650-to-$700 range, Mrs. Gandy said.
In mid-March, just seven houses and eight condos were on the market in Helmetta. "It's impossible to build up inventory because the houses in Helmetta are selling almost as quickly as they are being listed, often for more than the original asking price," she said. "The economy is good in all of Middlesex County, and Helmetta has the advantage of that small-town feel."
Young families with children are moving in, replacing older residents who are dying off. Empty-nesters from neighboring towns are also drawn by the small mill houses and affordable prices. Some longtime residents complain that Helmetta is becoming noisy because children play field hockey and soccer on its narrow streets, partly because there are no public parks. But others see this as a revival of a community tradition that existed when they were children.
Helmetta's 250 public school students attend classes in the neighboring Spotswood School District. With a total of 1,550 pupils, Spotswood has two elementary schools, Memorial Middle School for grades seven and eight, and Spotswood High School.
The G. Austin Schoenly School, with kindergarten and first grade, was recognized in 1997 by the United States Department of Education as a Blue Ribbon School, an honor given to 263 schools nationwide that year.
Dr. Anthony E. Vaz, the school superintendent, said that the district emphasizes literature and writing, starting in kindergarten. Each classroom in the system has at least one computer, he said, and all schools except Schoenly have computer laboratories. The middle and high schools are connected to a computer network, and by the end of the year Dr. Vaz expects to have the other schools connected to the network.
Although 83 percent of the 138 students who graduated last year went on to college, the district's seniors have scored at or below the state average on College Board tests for the last five years. Last year, Spotswood High seniors had combined verbal and math scores of 992, 15 points below the state average. Because of budget limitations, the school offers no advanced-placement courses, a policy that is being re-examined in light of the test scores, Dr. Vaz said.
The Spotswood School District is grappling with both a rising population and budget constraints. In the last seven years, the school population has grown by 7 percent. And in the last 18 years, only two budgets passed on the initial vote, the last time in 1993.
"Some of our classes have as many as 28 students, which is way too high," Dr. Vaz said. "We are currently examining our facilities, and we will decide whether we need to restructure the system or build."
Dr. Vaz believes construction will be difficult because the three municipalities that make up the district -- Spotswood, Helmetta and Milltown -- are all primarily residential, with few businesses to share the tax burden with homeowners.
ANOTHER price that Helmetta residents pay for the small-town atmosphere is the lack of shopping. The closest supermarket is five miles away in Spotswood, and the closest mall is Brunswick Square, six miles away in East Brunswick.
The residents do have Bo's General Store, the former company store directly across the street from the snuff mill. The proprietor, Roger Bohinski, the husband of the borough clerk, worked in the mill during his youth and displays his collection of antique snuff tins, packages of chewing tobacco, tools and other mill memorabilia. Along with groceries and liquor, Bo's General Store offers lots of atmosphere, with half a dozen tables and a four-stool counter called the "gossip corner," where old-timers and newcomers alike gather over coffee.
"This town will never change," Mr. Bohinski said, pointing out that because mill and the company houses still dominate the landscape, Helmetta looks much the way it did 100 years ago. "We may get a couple hundred more homes," he said, "but we are and will always remain a factory town."

THE RIGHT SNUFF: During the Great Depression, Helmetta was one of the few factory towns that received no federal assistance, according to a history published for the borough's centennial in 1988. Despite the hard times, Americans continued buying snuff produced by the Helme Tobacco Company's mill. Although hours were cut back at times, there was always work at the mill, and during this period of bank failures, the mill paid its hands in cash.

HEADLINE: A Way to Get More Money for Their Milk

BYLINE: By JAMIE MONAGAN 

 BODY:
CONNOISSEURS rhapsodize over products from the great cheese-making capitals of the world such as Asturias in northern Spain and Franche-Comte in the French Alps. Can raves for Colchester and Falls Village be far behind?
Six farmhouse cheese-making operations have opened across Connecticut over the past three years, each producing small quantities of hand-made "boutique" goat, cow or sheep cheeses. 
 Though the quantities are less than 1 percent of the state dairy production, according to a state Department of Agriculture estimate, these businesses reflect a new survival strategy in the face of fluctuating milk prices and unrelenting development pressure.
"If farmers can't make a living, no way are they going to hold onto land that's worth a million dollars, especially with development going on around them that makes farming more difficult," according to Liz MacAlister.
During the past 20 years at the 75-acre Cato Corner Farm in Colchester, she has tried various schemes to turn a profit, none very lucrative.
"I like my cows a lot and I really wanted to keep them, so I came up with cheese as a 'value-added product.' I no longer sell my milk wholesale, so I'm not at the mercy of fluctuating prices and minute profit margins."
Bill Hopkins, marketing representative for the agriculture department, helped spark the new businesses with a 1996 seminar, "How to Save the Farm and Keep the Cows," which offered alternatives to merely sending milk out to be bottled. Three of the current generation of cheese-makers attended, including Ms. MacAlister.
"At that time the price for fluid milk was about 20 cents a gallon, so we tried to offer dairy farms an alternative so they could get more money for their milk," Mr. Hopkins said. "The more creative, entrepreneurial ones headed off in this direction."
Ms. MacAlister estimates she has spent $50,000 in equipment and barn renovations during the two years she has been in the cheese business -- a relatively small investment, she said, since she already owned the land and animals.
She sells most of her cheese at green markets in New York City, successfully enough that her 30-year-old son, Mark Gilman, quit his teaching job to help full-time with the cheese-making operation.
"With an English degree you can do anything, even make cheese," she joked.
This year they will milk 35 Jersey cows, which give the high protein and butterfat milk needed for cheese.
Adhering to traditional European methods, Ms. MacAlister's production is dictated by the seasons.
"In France and Italy certain cheeses are made only in the spring, for example, when the animals are eating a certain kind of pasture," she said.
"It's a very refined way of thinking. We keep the cows on pasture almost the entire time we're making cheese so they only eat what's seasonal. If I were to feed them silage, which is essentially a fermented product, it would affect the taste of the cheese, particularly as it ages and the flavors intensify."
"The appeal of farmhouse cheese, assuming it's well-made, is its rusticity, as opposed to the garishness of big budget, mass-produced cheeses," said Steve Jenkins, author of "The Cheese Primer" (Workman Publishing) and head of the cheese department at Fairway Market in New York. "The whole experience is predicated on memorability. You remember a cheese when you're struck by its rusticity and hands-on attention and taste of the land. When you close your eyes you can almost envision the lovely fields the animals graze in. It sounds like hyperbole, but it's absolutely the case."
Joan Lamothe finds she does well selling her goat and cow's milk cheese straight from her Rustling Winds Creamery, a 200-acre farm on Canaan Mountain in Falls Village. She tends two Jersey cows and 23 goats, "counting papa," to produce a variety of hard and soft cheeses, including Cheshire, a type of cheddar which Steve Jenkins said is "among the most satisfying, simple, hearty and rustic cheeses known to man."
Mrs. Lamothe, a 58-year-old widow with calloused hands and a no-nonsense manner, says she has invested $250,000 in equipment and a new barn, and isn't sure she will ever make her money back.
"Depends on how long I'm here," she said.
Most of the 50 pounds of cheese she produces each week is made from raw, unpasteurized milk, all of it "all natural."
"When I order feed, I tell them just what I want in it and how I want it mixed -- no pesticides, herbicides, hormones or additives of any kind," Mrs. Lamothe said. "I put in my own minerals and vitamins that the animals need. I usually do that with herbs, which is better for them anyway.
"Nettles are very good for goats. They love them -- eat the prickers and all, great big thistles. All that stuff is tonic for them."
Mrs. Lamothe dotes on the "weird personalities" among her flock, especially 14-year-old April. "She follows me around like a dog. She'd come in and help me make cheese if I let her."
The agriculture department dairy division wouldn't appreciate April's presence in the cheese house, however.
State inspectors make frequent unannounced visits at all the creameries to make sure that sanitary conditions, especially concerning raw milk, are strictly maintained.
Paul Trubey, who tends a herd of 18 swiss dairy goats at Highwater Dairy in Glastonbury, has been licensed commercially only since June, though he had been experimenting with different cheeses for years. His fledgling business got a boost last year when he won first place in the fresh non-herbed goat cheese category at the American Cheese Society's national competition in Shelburne, Vt.
Highwater Dairy is already turning a small profit, but Mr. Trubey intends to "keep his day job" as a hospice program administrator and part-time instructor at Central Connecticut State University.
"People are really interested in small, local, artisan produce," said Mr. Trubey, who is the only man among Connecticut farmhouse cheese-makers. When all his goats are lactating, Mr. Trubey makes up to 100 pounds of fresh goat cheese a week, which he sells to local stores and restaurants and at green markets in Kent and Storrs.
Another Connecticut cheese-maker with academic ties, Elisa Santee, makes cheese from the milk of 11 Jersey cows at her 140-acre Foxfire Farm in Mansfield. She is also an adjunct math professor at Three Rivers Community Technical College.
"For a farm this size, cheese-making is a better source of income than selling fluid milk," said Mrs. Santee, who has a master's degree in business administration. "There's better cash flow, and it's more easily managed, but like any start-up business, you have to get out there and do the legwork. If you don't pound the pavement promoting your product, very few people know about you.
"Connecticut has a huge agricultural base that I think the public is not generally aware of, from our oyster beds to maple sugaring to cattle to cheese-making," she said. "We have a great deal to offer agriculturally, but we seem to be very quiet about it."
Foxfire Farm is the only certified organic producer of cheese in the state. She makes cheese from a family recipe -- her husband is a fourth-generation dairy farmer -- from March through December.
"Our cows are always dried off before Christmas so that we can have some family time when milking is not the focus," said Mrs. Santee, who also raises organic lamb and vegetables with her husband and two daughters.
Beaver Brook Farm in Lyme is a sheep dairy, one of about 100 across the United States. Suzanne Sankow and her husband, Stanley, whose family has farmed the 175 acres since 1917, raise 600 sheep, about 150 of which are milked for cheese. In only her third year, she sold more than $30,000 worth of cheese, the same amount grossed from the wool and meat operations.
Her total output of 3,000 pounds of yogurt, feta and other cheeses sold easily last year, despite prices starting at $16 a pound. "I have people from New York who call me ahead of time to reserve their yogurt, and then drive over to get it," Ms. Sankow said.
Ms. MacAlister of Cato Corner Farm said it is a sophisticated population who appreciates boutique cheeses and they don't object to the higher prices.
"If you're willing to market yourself," she added, "making and mongering cheese is a great way for dairy farmers to survive."

LENGTH: 1297 words

HEADLINE: E-Sales Drive Need for Warehouses

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
AT his first Internet-based grocery operation, Allen MacCannell relied on supermarkets in New York City to deliver the goods that his customers ordered online.
But the costs were high and the delivery service was not reliable, so Mr. MacCannell helped form a new company with its own fleet of trucks and a warehouse in a dusty industrial complex here near the Connecticut border. 
 Taking advantage of its proximity to New York City and its northern suburbs, the company, YourGrocer.com, saw its business take off, and it has already added a second warehouse, in Elmsford.
"We chose Westchester because of its free access into Manhattan over the Third Avenue Bridge," Mr. MacCannell said. "The warehouse space you can get here is convenient and really inexpensive."
Mr. MacCannell's company is among dozens in the New York City suburbs that have entered the online delivery business in recent years, generating economic growth by providing consumers with a variety of products, from books to chocolates to wines. But these fast-growing companies have also created a surge in demand for warehouse space across the region.
In Westchester, real estate agents say, demand is so strong that a shortage of warehouse space has developed.
Paul Jacobs, a consultant for Insignia/ ESG, a real-estate broker, said the shortage has many potential buyers looking to New Jersey and Rockland County.
Insignia does not keep statistics on warehouse rents and vacancy rates, he said. But in one recent example, a client seeking industrial space chose a site in New Jersey over Westchester because he could not find a block at a reasonable price.
"Industrial space is very tight," he said. "There is not a lot of product because Westchester County has not historically developed industrial space because land values have been so high, and it has really gotten tighter in recent years."
Nearly a dozen e-commerce companies have set up shop in Westchester and just across the Connecticut line in Fairfield County.
For example, Eglobalshop.com, a startup company that plans to sell apparel, household products and other items, intends to set up a warehouse in Larchmont. TradeOut.com, a company that sells excess inventory, is based in Ardsley. Wrenchead.com, which sells auto parts, and Camdens.com, which sells gifts geared to executives, both have their headquarters in White Plains and operate warehouses there.
Driven by the growth in e-commerce, warehouse space in North America has grown by about 20 percent a year for the last two years, according to the International Warehouse Logistics Association, based in Park Ridge, Ill. Westchester County has proved particularly attractive to e-commerce companies that want a presence in the most densely populated area in the nation.
"It is exciting; it is like the industrial revolution of the last century," said Kevin L. McNulty, the association's membership services director. "I have never seen anything quite like it."
While government officials and those at the Chamber of Commerce say that no major studies have been done on e-commerce warehouse demand in Westchester, if it follows regional trends in neighboring suburban counties, it accounts for about 40 percent of the demand.
Less than a decade ago, experts predicted that Internet ventures would no longer need actual stores, drastically reducing the amount of space used for commercial storage.
But experts have learned quickly that while the world of e-commerce may be a great place to buy wine or books, cyberspace has no shelves or storage space. And the products sold by Internet companies must be stored someplace.
This has led to the construction of more warehouses in surburan counties -- in proximity to technology-savvy high-income communities -- across the country.
Westchester is particularly popular, Mr. MacCannell said, because companies can easily deliver to customers in New York City without having to pay tolls, and they have easy access to Westchester, Rockland and Fairfield Counties, as well as northern New Jersey.
YourGrocer.com, which serves Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx, Manhattan, Westchester, Rockland and western Fairfield, is considering an expansion into northern New Jersey, Mr. MacCannell added.
The county's shortage of warehouse space has been compounded by a general shortage in commercial space, which experts trace to small business growth even before the e-commerce boom.
In the early 90's, the county had experienced a weak commercial real estate market, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage company. But last year, Westchester saw leasing activity jump and the overall vacancy rate fall to 15.2 percent from 17.6 percent in 1998.
The shift was being driven, Cushman & Wakefield officials said, by a growth in demand for warehouse, industrial and office space. In one example of the growing shortage, Drinks America, an Internet alcoholic beverage company, was looking for an 8,000- to 12,000-square-foot building, which would include a warehouse to serve the New York region.
The company looked at three potential sites in Westchester, but then chose Long Island, despite reservations about logistics, because two of the Westchester sites were under contract before company officials had a chance to make any decisions.
In its infancy, e-commerce companies, like Amazon.com, tried to provide goods by serving as the middle man between consumers and wholesale businesses. They relied on vendors to make deliveries on time.
But after facing problems fufilling orders, especially around the last two holiday seasons, many companies decided to set up their own warehouses so they could keep items in stock and more accurately predict when items would arrive.
Mr. MacCannell's first e-commerce company was NYCGrocery.com, which relied on vendor supermarkets to make deliveries. But the Manhattan-based company was limited by the high prices for goods in the city supermarkets and the unreliability of their delivery services.
So they decided to move to the suburbs, where real estate was cheaper and bulk groceries were too, Mr. MacCannell said. The old company was purchased by YourGrocer.com, Mr. MacCannell said.
Dwarfing the original YourGrocer.com warehouse in Port Chester, the new one in Elmsford is about the size of four football fields and took some time for a real estate agent to find, said Mr. MacCannell, 36, the founder and vice president for sales at the company. The company is leasing the 20,000-square-foot warehouse for $100,000 a year.
At the Elmsford warehouse, the company's more than 20 mid-size delivery trucks and one large rig can be heard loading and revving up each afternoon to make trips throughout Westchester and surrounding communities.
YourGrocer.com requires customers to make orders of at least $50 by 5 p.m. Mondays through Thursdays and by noon on Fridays for delivery the next day. The orders are processed in the corporate offices in Port Chester, and then the goods are loaded onto the trucks. The company makes about 100 deliveries a day, Mr. MacCannell said.
The trucks, Mr. MaCannell said, "basically go straight from the warehouse into the surrounding communities, including Manhattan, and on heavy days we have to send in the large tractor trailer to Central Park, where we split the goods onto smaller trucks."
Over the border in Fairfield County, Shoplink.com has also launched an online delivery service for groceries. Officials at the Massachusetts-based company recently opened a warehouse of more than 83,000 square feet in Stratford.
Officials from Shoplink said that they looked for space in both counties and eventually settled on the warehouse in Stratford because it could serve communities in Westchester and Fairfield.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 3; Real Estate Desk
