HEADLINE: Suburban Home Prices: Upward, Ho!

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
WITH 1999 standing as the fourth straight record-setting year for home prices throughout the nation and the New York metropolitan region, and with older baby boomers ensconced in their homes of choice while younger ones seek a place to finally fit their families, it has come to this:
One day last month in Westchester County, a desperate young woman knelt on the porch of a four-bedroom home in Hastings-on-Hudson and slipped photographs of her children under the door. 
 "They wanted the house so badly," said Robin Friedman, the manager of the Houlihan/Lawrence brokerage office in nearby Irvington. "They obviously were hoping to pull at the seller's heart strings. Unfortunately, they did not make the highest offer and did not get the house."
The home, which Ms. Friedman described as a "nice split-level," sold for $450,000.
All across the region, because of a confluence of mostly propitious economic forces, the squeeze is on -- and what spurts up are prices.
In the suburban arc around New York City, according to data collected by the National Association of Realtors, the median price for existing single-family homes hit $208,000 in 1999, an 11 percent rise over 1998 -- and nearly triple the nation's 3.9 percent rate of increase. "Virtually every area around New York City was close to double digits in increases," said Dr. Fred Flick, the association's vice president for economic research.
The median price for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, for example, rose by 9.7 percent in 1999, to $197,000. Westchester County's average price ascended to $458,981, a 15.1 percent increase. In New Jersey, the median price for Middlesex, Hunterdon and Somerset Counties, computed together by the National Association of Realtors, jumped to $221,000, a whopping 23.3 percent increase over 1998 -- nearly six times the national rate of appreciation.
And while that New Jersey statistic was certainly the extreme, it was also the point of the arrow for the region. For the second straight year, according to another measure of the market, the Case Shiller Weiss repeat-sales survey, every one of the 576 ZIP code areas in 14 counties that constitute most of New York City's suburban ring saw prices appreciate in 1999 -- 396 of them by at least 8 percent. (Statistics for several areas, including all of Rockland County, were incomplete.)
That boon -- for sellers -- rides atop a historic boom.
January was the 107th month of the nation's economic expansion, the longest ever, surpassing the 106-month period from 1961 to 1969. "So, 31 days into the 365,250-day-long millennium, we break the record," said Dr. James Hughes, the dean of the Rutgers University School of Planning and Public Policy. "What a way to start a millennium!"
"We used to think 3 percent was the maximum growth rate for the gross domestic product," Dr. Hughes said. "But we closed out the millennium, the fourth quarter of 1999, with a G.D.P. growth of 6.9 percent."
"And housing certainly went along for the economic ride," he said.
Not only did the national median price for existing single-family homes set a record last year, so, too, did sales volume. There were 5.19 million resales in 1999, said Dr. Flick of the National Association of Realtors, breaking the record of 4.97 million sales set in 1998.
At the same time, national sales of newly built homes also set a record last year, breaking the 1998 mark. "In the last four years," said Steve Berman, a statistician in the residential construction branch of the Census Bureau, "we have had four of the best six years ever for sales of new homes since the beginning of time -- which for us is 1963, when we started the survey." There were 907,000 new homes sold in 1999, topping the record of 886,000 sold in 1998.
"So don't be surprised," Mr. Berman said, "that given last year's numbers, when combined with the record for existing-home sales, that the nation's homeownership rate hit an all-time high." The old record, set in 1998, was 66.3 percent of all households owning their own homes, he said, "and it hit 66.9 percent in '99."
Obviously, sales activity has been feverish throughout most of the country; regional records were set in the Midwest and South, and the West enjoyed its third-best year ever. Less obviously, sales volume has been somewhat dampened in the Northeast, and in the metropolitan region in particular.
Part of the reason, as Rae Rosen, senior regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, sees it, is that "in some sense, we're landlocked -- in the city, but also in many older suburban areas."
And in the view of Patrick O'Keefe, the executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association, the dearth of development is attributable to stringent zoning regulations and open-space preservation. In New Jersey, for example, Mr. O'Keefe said, "housing production is down 36 percent, decade to decade," from 37,900 units a year during the 1980's to 24,000 in the 90's.
All of which, given the resurgence of the regional economy, has acted as a pincer, pushing up prices.
HOUSING demand has been fueled, in large part, by job growth. In the 31-county New York-Northeastern New Jersey region, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, 205,000 private-sector jobs were created last year, raising the job total for the region's private industries to 8.3 million. "The 1999 growth record comes in as the best for any year in the region's current recovery, which began in 1993," said John L. Weiting, the bureau's regional commissioner. Between 1989 and 1992, the regional economy suffered through a major downturn, with 715,000 private-sector jobs lost during that period. In 1992, Mr. Weiting pointed out, the region's unemployment rate stood at 8.4 percent; at the end of last year, it was 4 percent.
So the underlying forces of the housing market, Dr. Hughes at Rutgers said, "have been job and income growth, the wealth effect from the stock market and consumer confidence, all reinforcing the other force -- the baby boom still trading up at a furious pace."
This year, the baby-boom generation will range in age from 36 to 54. "The older boomers are locked into the houses they want, so they are not selling," Dr. Hughes said. "The younger boomers are trying to settle into the communities where they can finish raising their families. So we're short of product."
There are no overall regional statistics on inventory, but the national numbers offer a hint of the crunch. In January 1999, Dr. Flick said, there were 2.04 million listings available around the country; in January 2000, there were 1.15 million. Locally, by way of example, the Westchester County Multiple Listing Service reported only 3,141 listings available at the end of 1999, down 32 percent from 4,619 in December 1998.
ONE consequence -- directly observed by Ms. Rosen of the Federal Reserve Bank -- is a phenomenon called the "teardown" or "knockdown." "They buy the house for the value of the land, at fairly impressive prices, knock it down and rebuild -- large houses, sometimes right to the property line," she said. "It's happening in Connecticut and northern New Jersey, and it's true on Long Island, too."
"I live in Connecticut," she said, "and there's five knockdowns on my block."
Conventional wisdom has it that rising mortgage rates stifle demand, and interest costs for the standard 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage have certainly risen recently.
"Currently, we are at four-year highs for the 30-year fixed mortgage, hovering near 8.3 percent," said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage statistics company in Butler, N.J. "There's been a long, steady climb since October of 1998 when we achieved 31-year lows of 6.68 percent." During 1999, the low mark for a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage was 6.84 percent on Jan. 31; the high was 8.31 percent on Aug. 13.
Rising home prices and mortgage costs do, of course, take "some of the marginal home buyers out of the market," Mr. Gumbinger said, but house-hungry, thick-walleted buyers have, literally, adjusted.
"The steady rise in fixed rates," Mr. Gumbinger said, "has given some resurgence to adjustable-rate mortgages" -- or ARM's -- a mortgage product that, at least to begin with, offers a lower-cost alternative to traditional fixed-rate financing.
Currently, Mr. Gumbinger said, about 30 percent of mortgages being originated "have some form of adjustable rate, up sharply from the 10 percent in January '99."
"That is one of the reasons home sales have not cooled too much despite the climb in interest rates," he said.
Certainly, the ardor to buy, often at any price, has not cooled. "There's a house in Hartsdale that was listed at $399,000, and there were so many offers within 24 hours of the listing that the owner instructed the agent to get everybody's best offer in writing," said Ms. Friedman, the Houlihan/ Lawrence broker in Westchester. "My agent just phoned to say she got a call advising her that none of the written offers were being accepted and the owner was raising the asking price to $429,000 and starting over again."
Tracking real estate trends by the numbers defies absolute precision. Although single-family house sales are reported by local realty boards, not all real estate agents are members of the boards and not all sales are made through agents, so not all sales in a given area are recorded. At the same time, while one board may use median prices -- meaning half the sales are above that figure and half below -- others calculate an average. Still, the numbers serve as barometers of market patterns.
In Westchester, according to the New York State Association of Realtors, the average price hit $458,981 in 1999, up 15.1 percent from $398,727 in 1998. But with inventory low, sales volume slipped by 5.1 percent, from 6,907 in 1998 to 6,553 last year.
The upward price spiral was reflected in the findings of the Case Shiller Weiss repeat-sale survey. The survey is based on a table showing the average price for all single-family homes sold in most ZIP code areas, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1999, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price the house brought the last time it sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the previous purchase price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1998. The 1999 sales prices for homes within each ZIP code area were then compared with the estimated 1998 prices to compute the average change.
Of Westchester's 65 ZIP code areas, the survey indicated, 10 saw prices increase by up to 4 percent last year, 14 rose by 4 to 8 percent, 35 by 8 to 12 percent and 6 -- Eastchester, Hastings-on-Hudson, Larchmont, Rye, Tuckahoe and Wykagl-- jumped at least 12 percent.
Ms. Friedman's anecdotal evidence bore out those findings. In North Yonkers, a four-bedroom split-level was purchased in December 1997 for $225,000. "In January '99," she said, "the owner put it on the market for $305,000, got bids over the asking price and then decided she didn't want to sell because she could get more money. She re-listed three months ago at $349,000, and it's in contract, close to asking price."
In Rockland County, according to the Greater Hudson Valley Multiple Listing Service, the median price in 1999 was $238,000, up 9 percent from $220,000 in 1998. But sales volume was down 3.4 percent, from 2,009 in 1998 to 1,940 last year.
Ann Garti, the executive officer of the Hudson Valley service, said: "One community that was heretofore very affordable is Stony Point. In 1998, the average price was $215,660, and in 1999 it was $258,618, a 20 percent jump. We have a community in the far reaches of Rockland, the northwest corner -- Sloatsburg. There you had a 1988 average of $153,284, and in 1999 it went up to $175,416, 14 percent."
T HE situation was similar on Long Island. In Nassau County, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors, the median price in December hit $230,000, up 12.5 percent from $204,500 in December 1998.
The Case Shiller survey showed that of Nassau's 64 ZIP code areas, 1 saw prices increase by up to 4 percent, 6 appreciated between 4 and 8 percent, 47 by 8 to 12 percent and 10 -- Atlantic Beach, Cedarhurst, Hewlett, Lawrence, Long Beach, Oceanside, Rockville Centre, Woodmere and two in Valley Stream -- rose by 12 percent or more. At the same time, the number of Nassau sales dropped 9.9 percent, to 7,389 from 8,199.
"The brokers are stressed because of the inventory shortage and buyer's demand," said Joseph Mottola, the executive officer of the Long Island board.
Mr. Mottola offered several community-specific examples: "In Baldwin, the median went to $188,600, up 6 percent from $178,000 in 1998. Glen Cove saw an increase from $252,750, up 12.2 percent to $284,500. And Levittown had a 14 percent increase, $158,000 to $180,000."
In Suffolk County, the median price for homes sold in December was $168,000, 1.8 percent more than the $165,000 in December 1998. And the number of sales throughout the county was 11,265, virtually the same as the 11,244 transactions in 1998. Of the 86 ZIP code areas in Suffolk, 29 appreciated by 4 to 8 percent and 57 by 8 to 12 percent.
"While the overall increase was less than Nassau's, in these three towns, the increase was significant," Mr. Mottola said. Brentwood rose 15 percent, from $113,000 to $130,000; Northport jumped 12 percent to $325,000, from $290,000; and in tonier Cold Spring Harbor, the increase was 27 percent, $530,000 to $675,000.
Measuring the market in Connecticut is complicated by the fact that the state does not indicate property type on deed transfers. Yet, by far, most transfers are residential, said Vincent Valvo, the editor and publisher of The Connecticut Law Tribune, which tracks the state's economic trends.
Citing data compiled by Warren Information Services, a real estate statistics company, Mr. Valvo said that in Fairfield County the median price was $220,000 in 1999, up 4 percent from $211,500 in 1998.
Bucking the sales-volume trend, Fairfield showed an increase last year with 20,074 transactions, a 2.4 percent rise over the 19,598 recorded in 1998.
According to the Case Shiller survey, of Fairfield's 45 ZIP code areas, 1 saw prices rise by up to 4 percent, 12 by 4 to 8 percent, 29 by 8 to 12 percent and 3 -- Westport and two in Norwalk -- by at least 12 percent.
It is all indicative of the Connecticut rebound. "In 1993, Connecticut was absolutely anemic," Mr. Valvo said. "We had massive layoffs, high commercial vacancy rates. Fairfield faired better than other counties, but it still suffered."
Over the last two years, however, "it's completely turned around," Mr. Valvo said. "Technology has been strong, and that's allowing workers to afford the higher prices for Fairfield homes. It's causing some firms to expand outside the county. You're basically pushing people, business and wealth up the Merritt Parkway."
Randi Hutton, a broker at Tilghman & Frost Coldwell Banker in Westport, concurred: "The midrange customer, $500,000 to $600,00, if that's midrange -- well, maybe it is in Fairfield -- they want the large kitchen, nine-foot ceilings, but they can't afford that in this price range. So they're willing to go north, where they can get more space and land for their money."
"They say, 'We don't want to be more than an hour from the city,' " Ms. Hutton said. "Then when they see the reality, they make the commute 15 minutes longer."
Officials of the New Jersey Association of Realtors did not respond to repeated requests for information. But some indication of price shifts in the northern New Jersey area -- all of them up -- was offered by the National Association of Realtors.
In Bergen and Passaic Counties, the median was $218,400, up 4.9 percent from $208,200. In Monmouth and Ocean Counties, it was $161,200, up 14.2 percent from $141,100. In Newark, there was a 9.2 percent rise, from $192,000 to $210,500.
And, of course, there was that 23.3 percent vault in Middlesex, Hunterdon and Somerset Counties, from $179,000 to $221,200.
Of the 316 ZIP code areas in the 10-county area of northern New Jersey surveyed by Case Shiller, 16 saw prices rise by up to 4 percent, 91 by between 4 and 8 percent, 201 by 8 to 12 percent and 8 -- Milburn, 1 in Newark, South Orange, Chatham, Passaic, 2 in Paterson, and Summit -- jumped by at least 12 percent. (The 10 counties are Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Passaic, Somerset and Union.)
In the view of Mr. O'Keefe of the New Jersey Builders Association, "housing prices are going through the roof -- pun intended."
The median price for a new home in New Jersey, as of last September, was $231,125, Mr. O'Keefe said, "up 14.9 percent from $201,137 in 1998."
"And in northern New Jersey's Bergen County, for example, it was $379,900, up 12.7 percent from $336,950," he added.
There has been a "significant increase" in residential construction in Hudson and Bergen Counties, Mr. O'Keefe said, "but it's mostly rental."
WHICH is why some buyers go to great lengths -- and designs -- to get what they want. Ric Martel, the manager of the Coldwell Banker brokerage office in Spring Lake, N.J., told the tale of one family's unusual twist on the teardown phenomenon.
"They bought the original house in the $600,000 range," Mr. Martel said. "Then they donated it to Habitat for Humanity, picked it up and towed it to Neptune, and put it on a lot that was donated there.
"Then they built themselves a 4,800-square-foot home, side to side, setback to setback, for another, I'd say, $600,000."
"I guess they got a tax write-off for giving away that old house," he said.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
The Noose Is Tightening For Smokers in New Jersey

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
John Burns sat at the bar at Triumph Brewing Company on Nassau Street, his Newport 100's and Bengal Gold pale ale forming a cozy universe along with his copy of "The Turning Point" by Malcolm Gladwell about crucial moments in social trends.
"It's a reading room," Mr. Burns, 45, said of the pub, across the street from the university's FitzRandolph Gate and populated last Sunday by a harmonious blend of tobacco lovers and others. "It's a place where I can sit down and interact with a Nobel laureate or a guy who pumps gas." 
 So Mr. Burns -- who works at a health food store here -- said he was alarmed by one of the state's budding trends: smoking bans on private property.
Amid a growing intolerance toward smokers and medical findings about the harmful effects of second-hand smoke, state legislators have introduced bills aimed at banning smoking in restaurants, shopping malls and -- if a building owner wants -- in leased office space.
Since 1994, 172 of New Jersey's 566 municipalities have adopted restrictions of some kind, from bans on cigarette vending machines to smoke-free school zones, according to New Jersey Group Against Smoking Pollution, or GASP. But in what supporters and opponents say would be a first for New Jersey -- and the entire New York region -- the Princeton Regional Health Commission is moving to ban smoking in bars as well as almost all public places.
"I believe in the public and the private, and I think that the sense of public entitlement has crossed the line to the point where --" said Mr. Burns, pausing in midsentence to light another Newport -- "freedom is being directly threatened. And to have something like having a drink and smoking a cigarette be infringed upon is almost fascism."
In a bastion of intellectual freedom like Princeton, that is an indictment almost as strong as a freshly lighted Camel, and one the commission rejects.
"This is a smoke-free ordinance, we don't think of it as a ban," said Katherine Benesch of the 10-member commission. "The fact that there is so much research now that talks about the effects of second-hand smoke definately had an impact."
So far, none of the proposed state legislation has been approved in committee, much less survived votes in the full Senate and Assembly. Moreover, Governor Whitman, who received an award from the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids in October for an anti-smoking campaign, is reserving judgment on the measures. Her spokesman, Pete McDonough, said that she preferred to "try to use market forces" to dictate smoking policies for businesses.
"As a rule, the governor tries to avoid restaurants where people are allowed to smoke," said Mr. McDonough. He noted that the current state budget included $30 million for programs to help smokers quit and to keep children from starting.
For now, Mrs. Whitman's commissioner of health and senior services, Christine Grant, has invited the New Jersey Restaurant Association, which represents 1,000 of the state's 10,000 licensed retail food vendors, to discuss voluntary restraints. A 1985 state law requires restaurants to post signs if smoking is permitted, and Francis Schott, an association spokesman, said members did not want to change things.
"We'd propose that private restaurants continue to post their policy and that consumers continue to have the right to chose whether to patronize the smoky little jazz club or patronize smoke-free environments," Mr. Schott said.
Yet in an interesting twist, teachers have expressed concern about a measure introduced by State Senator John Lynch, Democrat of New Brunswick, that would prohibit smoking on school property. "Sometimes they confuse the adult staff with children," said Karen Joseph, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association.
As for the proposed ordinance in this university town, the health commission, which ministers to the borough and the surrounding township of the same name, voted unanimously on Feb. 15 to introduce its far-reaching ban; it can adopt it at a meeting scheduled for April 18.
Proponents of the ban, which exempts the local smoke shop, say it could help New Jersey catch up with other states, citing a statewide ban California has imposed on smoking in workplaces, including bars. "We're not doing anything radical here," said Ms. Benesch.
But Richard Ryan, manager of the Ivy, a bar on Nassau Street, said 85 percent of his customers smoke, and the ban would hurt business. "I don't think they considered the ramifications," Mr. Ryan said.
Among the 16 restaurants and bars in the borough with liquor licenses, only three do not have nonsmoking sections. As William J. Cleary, executive director of the New Jersey Licensed Beverage Association, put it, "There's not been one case ever recorded where someone was forced into a restaurant and wasn't allowed to leave if they didn't want to be there."
Regina Carlson, executive director of GASP, noted that three-quarters of the public did not smoke, and would drink and eat out more often people did not have to think twice about where to go.
Michael Marlow, a professor of economics at California Polytechnic Institute in San Luis Obispo, who has tracked the effects of smoking bans, said the results were not surprising. Some restaurants see an increase, most experience little change, and bars tend to lose out.
More interesting, Professor Marlow said, are the unanticipated results: Maine's ban on smoking in bars that serve food has prompted some owners to scrap their menus. "You also see more purchases of take-out food by smokers," he said.
If anyone seemed likely to support the ban here, it would be Alice Rogers, 25, a student at Westminster Choir College.
"I'm sensitive to second-hand smoke," Ms. Rogers said after emerging from the Triumph. But she added: "About the ordinance, I'm against it. I think it takes away a freedom."

HEADLINE: ART;
Tableware as History: You Are Where You Eat

BYLINE: By JENNIFER OLSHIN 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
FROM the Fairmont markets to antique fairs around the country, private dealers to eBay, Charles Venable has been collecting dishes. In under a decade, Dr. Venable, the deputy director and chief curator of decorative arts at the Dallas Museum of Art, and his staff have assembled an encyclopedic collection of ceramic and glass tableware used in America over the last century.
The culmination of this collecting adventure is the exhibition "Tabletop to TV Tray: China and Glass in America, 1880-1980," on view at the Newark Museum of Art. Presenting more than 500 examples of ceramics and glassware, period advertisements and archival photographs from both the Newark and Dallas permanent collections, the show traces the history of America's love affair with dishes. 
 With Steven G. Harrison, assistant curator of decorative arts at the Dallas Museum of Art, as co-curator with Mr. Venable, and Ulysses Grant Dietz, the Newark Museum's curator of decorative arts, as director, the show is a radical undertaking. It is a documentary of the dishes that ushered middle- and upper-class Americans through their daily lives. The 500-page exhibition catalog, written by Dr. Venable, Ellen Paul Denker and Dr. Katherine C. Grier, is a trove of reference material.
The exhibition is introduced to the visitor through a "great wall of china" -- a dazzling array of plates mounted on dozens of square, white-painted boards arranged in rows on a wall. Beneath each board, a shelf carries matching cups and saucers. A display technique used by department and specialty stores starting in the early 20th century, the great wall of china allowed potential buyers to assess a store's entire selection. At the Newark Museum, the recreated wall resembles a giant game board or puzzle and the viewer is invited to identify and relate individual pieces based on historical hints, personal memories or familial possessions.
Within this enormous genealogy of plates, Rockwell Kent's iconic image of the New York skyline is illustrated in a red-and-white design from 1937, derivations of the American Op-Art movement are captured in a frenetic Wedgwood design of 1968-69, and the German modernist aesthetic is portrayed in an abstracted pattern made by J. Uffrecht and Company around 1935. These wide juxtapositions reflect the influence of the complex and ever-shifting economic, political and social landscape on the American tablescape.
"Most people forget that very few Americans bought all white, pristine, high-art glass and ceramics; they wanted pattern and color, they wanted warm and cozy, the conservative and the balanced," Dr. Venable said. "We tried to put a different perspective on these objects by placing them side by side."
The exhibition presents the consumer as the dominant force driving foreign and domestic retail strategy in this country.
Throughout the 19th and early 20 centuries, the growing appetite for refinement at the table resulted in an increasing demand for large numbers of matching ceramics, glassware and specialized items like pressed glass pickle jars and asparagus tongs. Looking to their 18th-century English and Continental ancestors for stylistic inspiration, Victorian Americans consumed vast numbers of traditionally shaped, floral-painted services with gilded rims. The oyster plate, made by the French Limoges factory, Haviland and Company, for the Rutherford B. Hayes White House service, exemplifies these trends. So to does the enduring popularity of conservative motifs and revival styles marketed by Spode, Wedgwood and other 20th-century Staffordshire potteries.
Though traditions persisted, new players were gaining inroads into the dinnerware market in America. The war, the Depression and casual living contributed to new trends in dining. In the 1930's, table services contracted in size, practicality was emphasized and the color palette changed dramatically.
Furthermore, American producers gained their own constituency. Homer Laughlin China Company's sturdy and brilliantly colored Fiesta line, introduced in 1936, was an immediate commercial success. Fiesta shapes, with sturdy talc bodies and semireflective finishes, echoed the streamlined designs of Art Deco while its characteristic concentric circles suggested a traditional potter's wheel. Also selling by the millions were Russel Wright's sets of American Modern. Wright's pieces, many on view at the museum, were rimless, easy to stack and carried such innovative colors as sea foam blue, coral and chartreuse.
The 1930's were filled with new American pastimes, including card parties, and mah-jongg parties and ladies' luncheons, and the end of prohibition in 1933 had spawned the cocktail party. Magazines in this jazz age taught the public how to drink in the home, at country clubs and at hotels. The cult of the martini provided makers like A. H. Heisey and Company with boundless opportunities, such as elaborate ensembles of cut-glass decanters, stainless-steel shakers, glasses and swizzle sticks, while drinking Champagne inspired innovations like the champagne pitcher.
Not all modern experiments appealed to Americans. Eva Zeisel's boldly shaped Museum line from 1946 (hailed at the time by the Museum of Modern Art as "good design") is exhibited as a design that did not sell well. Summing up this phenomenon, Dr. Venable said, "Most museum curators in the past have been more fascinated by the avant-garde but this is not always in step with the culture at large."
While aesthetic preferences fluctuated, Americans were enamored of new materials if they facilitated the process of cooking, serving and storage. In the 1950's, manufacturers targeting this new wave of consumers became household names; Pyrex, the continuously improving shock-resistant glass, was ubiquitous by the 1940's and 50's, Moderne carafes kept coffee hot at the table, and "casserole dishes," encouraging oven-to-table service for buffet-style dinners, became the norm. Plastics, introduced in the 1930's exploded in the marketplace as Tupperware, Boontonware and even traditional manufacturers like Lenox and Fostoria, began producing millions of plastic wares. Examples of all these wares can be seen in the exhibition.
With the emergence of the barbecue and the TV dinner, expediency at the table became a dominant trend. Gerald Gulotta's Chromatics from 1970 were fantastically popular. With their alternating concave and convex components, they fit snugly on a shelf. But casual entertaining did not preclude the emergence of zany and theatrical designs based on broader decorative and fine-art movements. The giant sunflowers in Day-Glo colors seen in a Wild Poppy chop plate and coffeepot (made 1969-71) are influenced by both Scandinavian and indigenous American design initiatives and Mikasa's Millennium plate reflects Italian Memphis design.
Again and again, this exhibition surprises with its elevation of the everyday. As Ulysses Dietz put it, "It crosses the line into real life, not just curatorial life." Installed around the museum's rotunda, the exhibition seems to have no beginning and no end; one could just keep going in an endless circle of dishes.
 
FROM TABLETOP TO TV TRAY
Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, Newark.

HEADLINE: Expensive Sport Utilities Fall Short of Expectations

BYLINE: By CHERYL JENSEN 

 BODY:
LUXURY sport utilities built on the underpinnings of trucks, as most are, tend to disappoint owners more than luxury cars -- and also more than a new breed of carlike "crossover" S.U.V.'s, according to two recent studies.
The consumer satisfaction studies -- by Strategic Vision and J. D. Power & Associates, two California-based research companies -- suggested that high expectations might be a factor in buyers' dissatisfaction. 
 "Luxury cars tend to provide some of the industry's highest-quality offerings," said George Owens, manager of product research at J. D. Power. "People who are coming from luxury cars are continuing to bring with them luxury-car expectations."
While most sport utilities, including luxury models like the Cadillac Escalade and Lincoln Navigator, have bodies fixed to truck frames, crossovers like the Lexus RX 300 and BMW X5 use one-piece unit bodies like most cars'. Crossovers also have suspensions and steering systems much like those of cars, compared with the rugged, often less sophisticated, systems of trucks.
 In a report comparing the RX 300 with traditional sport utilities and luxury sedans, Daniel Gorrell, vice president of Strategic Vision, said old-style S.U.V.'s did not deliver the attributes buyers sought and fell short of meeting owners' emotional needs. These buyers want a luxury vehicle that makes them feel in control, is able to handle anything, adds to the fun in their life and gives a sense of freedom, he said. "Yet these vehicles deliver less well on these dimensions than luxury cars or the RX 300," he said.
These truck-based luxury sport utilities scored lower than luxury cars in quietness, engine performance, ease of entry and exit, and particularly on fuel economy.
The 1998 and 1999 initial quality studies by J. D. Power indicated that consumers liked their luxury cars better, in general, than their luxury trucks.
One group in particular -- those who traded in luxury cars -- is even less happy with their fancy trucks. These consumers' complaints mostly related to the quality factors that the industry calls "fit and finish."
Several manufacturers have crossovers in the works, including Buick, Pontiac, Porsche, Saab and Volkswagen. Mr. Gorrell said crossovers "represent the birth of a significant new segment that can offer customers the best of both worlds."
One person who has also seen some disenchantment, but doesn't think it is a big problem, is George Petersen, president of AutoPacific Inc., another consulting firm. Luxury S.U.V.'s provide outstanding satisfaction, Mr. Petersen said, adding: "But it's not the same level of satisfaction as a luxury car, and it's a different kind of satisfaction. They are still based on trucks and don't have the same level of finesse as luxury cars." Owners take that into account, he said, "because, by golly, them are trucks."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM;
Buses May Return to 101st Street, and Neighbors Are Riled

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
It is hard to find space in Manhattan for eight macaws. But Esther Sirol, a retired contractor, found a three-story brownstone on East 101st Street that could comfortably accommodate her and her grown daughter, Sonia, as well as the birds.
When Ms. Sirol moved there from East 65th Street in 1998, the large bus municipal bus depot a block away on Lexington Avenue was vacant. But in January, the Metropolitan Transit Authority began demolishing the depot, creating plumes of debris and dust. The agency plans to build a new $90 million structure. 
 But what has lingered in the air for her, Ms. Sirol said, is the sense that her investment in the neighborhood was for naught. "There are going to be buses going in and out, and who's going to want to stay here?" Ms. Sirol said.
Demolition should be completed this week. On Tuesday, the city plans to award a design and construction contract to the Perini Corporation of Framingham, Mass., to build a four-story building for storage, administrative and cleaning. There will be space for 133 articulated buses, the long ones with accordionlike middle segments. The project is expected to take two years.
Local officials and residents say the city has ignored their pleas to consider the depot's possible impact on a neighborhood struggling for economic rebirth.
But Albert W. O'Leary, a spokesman for New York City Transit, said, "Space is a premium in New York, and we are pretty much stuck with the space we have."
The 81,000-square-foot plot of land has been municipal property since 1895, when it was used for a trolley barn. The city had planned to rebuild the bus depot on 100th Street since it was closed in March 1998, Mr. O'Leary said.
But Councilman Philip Reed, whose district includes East Harlem, said: "The depot has never really been a very good neighbor. Historically it has really polluted the neighborhood."
Mr. Reed has urged the governor and the city to halt construction. In January, his office suggested that the transit authority consider expanding a depot at East 126th Street, but Mr. Reed said that idea was rejected.
Meanwhile, a competing vision for the land has emerged. Henry M. Calderon, president of the East Harlem Chamber of Commerce, said investors had shown serious interest in a plan to turn the site into a retail center with office space or middle-income housing.
"If we go ahead with the M.T.A.'s plan, we're throwing away and misusing valuable property," Mr. Calderon said. "East Harlem isn't a dumping ground anymore. It's part of an economic renaissance." NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: A Strange Brew's Buzz Lingersin Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
IN June 1975, a solitary computer hacker slipped quietly into a van in the parking lot of a local hotel, Rickey's Hyatt House, and "borrowed" a copy of Microsoft BASIC, the first commercial program from a tiny Albuquerque, N.M., company started by two other young hackers, William H. Gates and Paul G. Allen.
The van was on a nationwide tour to show off the MITS Altair 8800, one of the world's first personal computers. The program -- stored as a set of punched holes in a long paper tape -- was "liberated" to be shared by a rag-tag group of Silicon Valley computer hobbyists who that March -- 25 years ago this month -- had banded together as the Homebrew Computer Club. 
 The tape was handed to Dan Sokol, then 31, a semiconductor engineering manager who did what he thought was right.
"I made convenient copies for the members of the Homebrew Club, because I was the only one who had easy access to a paper tape reader," Mr. Sokol recalled recently.
The act outraged Mr. Gates, who saw nothing in the stunt but the outright victimization of his company, which then spelled its name "Micro-Soft." He wrote an angry letter to the computer hobbyists. "As the majority of hobbyists must be aware, most of you steal your software," the letter said. "Hardware must be paid for, but software is something to share. Who cares if the people who worked on it get paid?"
This initial confrontation between Mr. Gates, then 20, and an anarchic cadre of programmers and hardware tinkerers was the forge of a basic tension that is still shaping the computer industry.
On one hand, the valley has long been motivated by what the author Michael S. Malone called "The Big Score" -- or more simply put, greed. Indeed, it was not long after the Homebrew Club's first meeting in Menlo Park that it began spawning companies -- with names like Apple, Osborne, Cromemco and Northstar -- owing their roots, directly or indirectly, to the enthusiasm that was captured in the initial club meetings.
On the other hand, the valley also continues to be driven by a more ethereal and in many ways purer motive -- what is called "the hacker ethic," a reference to the values of passionate programmers, and not, in a more modern definition of "hacker," to an outlaw subculture.
That ethos finds its clearest expression today in Linux software -- a freely available operating system that has been developed and supported by volunteer programmers and now has about a 25 percent share of the computer server market. It is also evident in the commitment of the so-called open source movement to the shared ownership and development of computing tools, and in the patent protection and copyright issues facing the music and e-commerce industries.
The PC industry "began with people who had a passion for computers," said Paul Freiberger, co-author of "Fire in the Valley: The Making of the Personal Computer" (McGraw Hill, 1999) "They were followed by people who had a passion for money. It's the mixture of those passions that defines Silicon Valley."
On a rainy night in March 1975, it was the original hacker spirit that captivated a small group of young men who were drawn early on to the potential of powerful personal computers. One of them, a Hewlett-Packard technician named Stephen Wozniak, has long maintained that he had no intention of creating a company when he built his first computer, but that he rather was intent on building a machine he could show off to the members of the Homebrew Club.
By happenstance, Mr. Sokol sat next to Mr. Wozniak at an early club meeting. "He bemoaned the fact that he couldn't get any parts to make his computer from H-P," Mr. Sokol remembered. "So I told him to come by my company, and I found a shoe box full of parts that became the components used in the first Apple I computer."
 There was no initial-public-offering gleam in either man's eye.
"We were interested in playing with toys," Mr. Sokol said. "People looked at our hand-wired computers and laughed at us and asked, 'What are you going to do with it?' "
THIRTY-TWO people showed up at the first meeting after a peace activist named Frederick Moore Jr. rode his bicycle around Palo Alto and Menlo Park, tacking up small 3-by-5-inch notices on bulletin boards and telephone poles.
"I slipped Fred $5 and he went to the copy store and printed up a bunch of fliers," recalled Gordon French, an engineer who along with Mr. Moore is considered a co-founder of the group and who held the first club meetings in his Palo Alto garage.
The tiny flier read in part: "Are you building your own computer? Terminal? TV Typewriter? I/O device? Or some other digital black magic box? Or are you buying time on a time-sharing service? If so, you might like to come to a gathering of people with like-minded interests. Exchange information, swap ideas, help work on a project, whatever . . ."
One person who saw the flier on a telephone pole was Alan Baum, who became an early employee of Apple Computer. He called his friend Mr. Wozniak, and the two agreed to attend.
In fact, Mr. Wozniak had already heard about the meeting from another friend, John T. Draper, even then a legendary figure in the Bay Area. Mr. Draper had been nicknamed "Cap'n Crunch" after he discovered that the whistle prize in the cereal box would unlock the AT&T long-distance system by generating a specific tone; he was considered a pioneer "phone phreak," part of a subculture of hobbyists who explored the inner workings of the telephone network in the 1960's and 70's.
Mr. Wozniak and his friend Steven P. Jobs had met Mr. Draper several years earlier, in Mr. Wozniak's dormitory room at the University of California at Berkeley. From him, they learned about devices called blue boxes that could be used to make free telephone calls.
Briefly, Mr. Wozniak and Mr. Jobs sold blue boxes. But after Mr. Jobs realized from the Homebrew Club meetings that there might be an enthusiastic market for PC's, the two men founded Apple Computer.
By the third meeting, the Homebrew Club was bursting at the seams and had outgrown Mr. French's garage. It ultimately settled for many years at the Stanford Linear Accelerator auditorium, where as many as 750 computer enthusiasts would gather twice a month.
Neither graphics nor sound were common computer features in those days, so when a hobbyist, Steve Dompier, demonstrated at the fourth meeting that he had laboriously programmed his new MITS Altair computer kit to play the Beatles' "Fool on the Hill," the assembly gave him a wild standing ovation.
TYPICAL Homebrew meeting began with a "mapping" session. The moderator -- for many years Lee Felsenstein, a political activist turned computer hardware engineer -- would point to people around the room, and each would describe what they were working on. A formal presentation would follow. The meeting would conclude with a "random access" session in which people with similar interests would cluster to share information.
It was at one such meeting, in the fall of 1981, that the transition from the hobbyist era of computing to today's booming world of corporate computing took place -- though virtually no one in attendance realized the shift.
Mr. Felsenstein pried open the case of the first I.B.M. PC, examined its motherboard and pointed with glee to three "blue lines" -- wires that were evidence, he proclaimed, of a hastily patched-together computer that had been rushed to market.
 It was a sweet -- if momentary -- vindication for the assembly that blended several hundred computer hackers with the vibrant counterculture and antiwar movement that had come to define the San Francisco Bay Area in the 1960's and 70's.
I.B.M., of course, overcame whatever early assembly problems it faced, and the broad sale of its PC's gave rise to an industrial explosion unmatched in American history.
The advent of the I.B.M. PC also marked the birth of the commercial software industry. Until its rise, software had been largely developed in the image of the Homebrew Club -- as a freely shared resource used to breathe life into computer hardware. Now it was being converted into a powerful economic force that would swiftly transform society. And Mr. Gates's software, in particular -- the operating system of I.B.M.'s machine -- secured a controlling position that it still has not relinquished.
So even today, an uneasy tension remains between the get-rich-on-Internet-time fever that has swept the valley and the original hacker ethic.
"Information wants to be free," said Stewart Brand, the author and social commentator who coined the term "personal computer" in 1973, "and information also wants to be very expensive."
Many of the new Linux start-ups -- companies like Red Hat and Corel -- are grappling with precisely that paradox by creating businesses in which new software is shared and free, while service and support are for sale.
MR. SOKOL'S career has mirrored the same tension. Shortly after the birth of Homebrew, he decided that it was time to get out of the semiconductor industry, which was then under assault from foreign competition.
"I could read the handwriting on the wall," he said. "I couldn't tell what it said, but I could see it was written in Japanese."
Although Mr. Sokol kept his passion for computers and continued to tinker with them, he left the industry and worked in the video business in Texas for a number of years. But he remained a close friend of Mr. Wozniak -- the two men have always found time to explore the latest computer technologies -- and in 1987 he was lured back to the valley as a software consultant.
Seated in his office recently in San Francisco's South of Market district, surrounded by three computer screens and three Macintosh computers, Mr. Sokol was the very image of the computer hacker, bearded and wearing a Hawaiian print shirt, baggy army pants and running shoes. But that also made him all but indistinguishable from most any Silicon Valley chief technology officer who had just closed the $9 million second round of financing for his start-up.
Indeed, with his partner Kirk Knight, Mr. Sokol has had a string of start-up ventures over the last decade -- a company to create interactive movies, for example, and a Web infrastructure company with technology to speed up the Internet. Neither was a success.
THEIR latest venture may have a much better chance of taking off. Called Cobaltcard, the company is marketing an Internet debit card for teenagers; it has solid financial backing and a tie-in with Visa, the credit card association.
If it succeeds, it will be because Mr. Sokol has managed to straddle the contradictions between the world of the hacker and that of the entrepreneur.
As in the Homebrew Club's early days, it remains an uneasy balancing act. Twenty-five years after Mr. Gates's broadside, Mr. Sokol is still righteous about those days of software anarchy.
"Bill Gates owes his fortune to us," he said. "If we hadn't copied the tape, there would never have been an explosion of people using his software."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK LANDMARKS;
The Lower East Side Seeks Honor for Humble Tenements

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Landmark designations typically reflect history's grandest aspirations: Grand Central Terminal, the Chrysler Building and Trinity Church are but a few examples.
But now several groups are seeking to bestow the honorific on the Lower East Side, an area better known for tenements that housed waves of working-class immigrants. 
 The proposed historic district would include the narrow corridor between Allen and Essex Streets from East Houston to Canal Streets. The district would also extend five blocks along East Broadway and include parts of Seward Park and its adjoining library. In total, it would encompass 31 blocks comprising more than 500 buildings, the oldest of which date back to around 1827.
The district already includes several official landmarks, including the Orthodox Eldridge Street Synagogue, built in 1887. But most of the structures are nondescript tenements from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, often built without private toilets.
The Lower East Side Business Improvement District, which submitted the proposal, says the designation is a way to honor the area's rich history and boost its economy.
"So many groups got their start here," said Andrew Flamm, the organization's executive director. "It was their first stronghold on American soil. Whether it's Park Avenue or this area, it is important to recognize that history."
Protestant families first developed the neighborhood in the 1820's, followed by German and Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe. By the early 1900's, the area was considered the world's largest Jewish community. The district began to diversify in the 1920's as tides of Italians, Sephardic Jews and others settled into the tenements and took over the shops.
Renee Epps, vice president of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, said that the area has continued to attract new immigrants, and today included recent arrivals from China, Malaysia, Russia, Puerto Rico and India.
Some community groups, however, expressed concern that the historic status could cause problems for current immigrants.
"Would it hinder the area or benefit growth?" asked Huey-Min Chuang, director of business outreach for the Chinatown Manpower Project. "I'm in favor of historical value, but I'm more interested in how it will help the area grow."
In response, Mr. Flamm pointed out that his group was not seeking designation as a city landmark, which would require approval for building changes, but rather recognition under the National and State Registers of Historic Places. It is "another means for us to promote this whole area," he said.
The proposal has the support of State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and several groups interested in New York history. Others, including Community Board 3 and Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, remain undecided.
"Now that the area is becoming prosperous, many of the old stores are getting kicked out," Ms. Freed said. "This could guarantee more of the same. In one sense, you are keeping the facade but changing the tenants." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: Personal Business;
Apply Now. But Learn The Interest Rate Later.

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
IN recent years, consumers have found plenty of reasons to complain about companies that issue credit cards. High interest rates. Less time to pay bills (and hefty penalties for being a day late). Fees for exceeding credit limits. Balances computed in new ways, to the customer's disadvantage. New, sometimes more onerous terms when accounts are sold to another company.
Now there is another: difficulty in shopping for the best deal. 
 Since 1989, federal law has required that issuers disclose interest rates and other key conditions to potential card holders. But recently, various companies have taken to listing a wide range of rates for one or more of their cards and not committing to one until a credit check is made. It is akin to a rental car company asking for all sorts of information before it tells you how much it costs to rent a midsize car in Phoenix -- but then making you wait two weeks to find out.
No one is saying that the practice is illegal; indeed, it seems patently reasonable to base the cost of credit on a borrower's creditworthiness. But critics contend that listing multiple potential rates -- a practice called risk-based, or tiered, pricing -- is not what Congress intended.
"We are seeing a radical shift" in card marketing, said Ken McEldowney, executive director of Consumer Action, an advocacy group based in San Francisco. "Banks don't quote rates until it's clear whom they are dealing with. It looks like the free marketplace is being shuttered, replaced instead with targeted offers based on your credit history."
Some experts say that tailoring rates to creditworthiness may be a result of a welcome democratization of credit, in which consumers with black marks like garnishments or liens on their records are no longer necessarily rejected. "Even people like that now can get a credit card," noted Janis Smith, spokeswoman for the Comptroller of the Currency. The rise of the Internet, which brings applications from people who have had no pre-screening, has added to the incentive for lenders to keep offers vague.
Federal regulators say they have not received enough complaints for this issue to register; the 1,620 complaints last year over national banks' disclosures of credit card terms were mostly about rate increases on existing accounts.
Still, a consumer is at a disadvantage when applying for a card without knowing its exact terms. Comparison shopping becomes difficult.
Consider the Aria cards, Visa cards that Providian Financial offers only via the Internet. "You apply -- and then we tell you what you qualify for," Laurie Cole, a spokeswoman for Providian, said of the four types of Aria cards, which have interest rates of 7.99 to 23.99 percent. "In order to offer credit to such a broad spectrum of people, we need to know something about them."
Ms. Cole said that Providian's direct-mail solicitations, to people who have been at least minimally screened, offer only one rate, but that balance transfers still need to be, as she put it, "customized."
Wells Fargo also bases rates on its judgment of risk. Current rates for its three main credit cards are 12.75 percent, 16.15 percent and 18.15 percent. It typically takes two or three weeks after applying to learn which rate will be imposed.
The lesson, Ms. Smith said, is that consumers cannot assume that all issuers are alike -- or that they can skip reading the fine print.
"More and more banks are setting individual terms," she said.
A consumer who is stuck with an unattractive rate, however, has an option: canceling the card. He should not let it sit in his wallet; besides accumulating possible annual fees, the card represents potential borrowing power that could give other lenders -- say, for a mortgage -- distinct pause.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Children of the Killing Fields

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
HE would try to catch some sleep between the press of bodies, sometimes 20 of them packed into the van. In winter, the windows fogged up with their heat. In summer, he couldn't distinguish the smell of other people's sweat from his own. On most mornings, someone squeezed onto his lap.
His name was Phalla Huoth (pronounced pa-LAH HOOTH). His Cambodian parents had brought their eight children to the Fordham section of the Bronx in 1985. They were fleeing a country in which nearly two million people had died at the whims of a dictator, a land where human bones jutted from the earth. 
 Whatever Phalla Huoth had once imagined about America, it certainly didn't entail getting up at 6 every morning, waiting for the factory van and sleeping on the 45-minute trip to New Jersey. The same van took him and his Cambodian co-workers back home at midnight. During the trips, he would slouch down in his baggy jeans and untucked shirt, a Yankees cap pulled over a face lightly scarred with acne.
Mr. Huoth, now 18, has gone through five minimum-wage factory jobs since dropping out of high school in 1998. Packaging bottles of body lotion. Placing eggs into a carton. Stocking shelves with boxes of pet food. It was all a blur.
"It's hard to survive here," he said. "I went through my childhood and didn't have any fun. I regret it. I never went through my teenage life."
He is one of thousands of children of Cambodian and Vietnamese refugee families who came to New York starting in the early 1980's. Most of the families gathered in the northwest Bronx, transforming the neighborhoods of Fordham, University Heights and Bedford Park into the city's largest concentration of Southeast Asians.
From 1983 to 1999, about three-quarters of the 2,000 Cambodian refugees who came to New York, and more than half of the 6,000 Vietnamese arrivals, were resettled in that area, according to the United States Department of Health and Human Services. (Nearly 40 Laotians were also relocated there.) Unlike most landlords in other boroughs, many in the Bronx kept rents cheap and allowed families of up to a dozen people to crowd into one- or two-bedroom apartments.
Today, after calculating births and recent migrations, the City Planning Commission estimates that 2,000 Cambodians and 5,000 Vietnamese live in the borough. And they are young. With families averaging six to eight children apiece, the 21-and-under generation makes up the bulk of the population.
For the most part, the teenagers deal with the same issues that other young immigrants do. Most of their families depend on welfare, they often encounter discrimination and they are sometimes hobbled by language difficulties, all as they confront the travails of adolescence.
But these young people also face a host of distinctive problems. Their families, uprooted from their tropical homelands, have farming skills that are useless here. Few community groups exist to help out new arrivals. And even if schools and workplaces offer bilingual programs or translation services, the Southeast Asians are so few that their language needs are seldom addressed.
Moreover, the parents, who have suffered greatly, often hide their past from their children, creating unspoken tension in the family.
Like many immigrant parents, they bristle when their children start doing things like dating, collecting Pokemon cards and listening to hip-hop music. But those same parents often refuse to talk about their history, even when their children witness their nightmares, insomnia and depression.
"For a lot of parents, it's not easy to express their feelings to their children," said Sarah Phok, a Cambodian mental health worker at Montefiore Medical Center in Fordham. "They hide their pain, and it's not easy to talk to your children about that unless you have support or someone to sit down with you."
 
The Terror of the 70's
If the Cambodian parents do discuss their past, they might begin with the Communist revolutionary named Pol Pot. After seizing power in 1975, he ordered his followers, the Khmer Rouge, to kill intellectuals, clear out cities and eradicate religion. By the time the Pol Pot regime collapsed in 1979, nearly a quarter of the country's seven million people had died. Hundreds of thousands of survivors fled to refugee camps in Thailand, just west of Cambodia.
Meanwhile, the North Vietnamese Communists triumphed in their war to unite the country. Saigon fell in 1975, the United States withdrew its military forces and hundreds of thousands of South Vietnamese went into exile, many on makeshift boats.
Most of the Southeast Asian refugees who made it to New York arrived wearing slippers and carrying a single bag stuffed with clothing. Many young people came without fathers, who had been killed. Most of the adult survivors had the equivalent of a third-grade education. They had left behind verdant fields and slow-flowing rivers for a concrete labyrinth.
Phalla Huoth and many of the other children who boarded planes for the United States were too young to understand why they were being juggled from bombed-out villages to refugee camps to low-rent apartments halfway across the world. Others were born here shortly after their parents arrived, or came under the sponsorship of relatives.
Unlike Chinese and Korean immigrants, these Southeast Asian refugees landed in a city where their people had yet to build an infrastructure of neighborhood organizations, churches and other institutions that typically aid new arrivals. They had no enclaves like Chinatown or Koreatown, and no tradition of entrepreneurship. Even today, there are only two Cambodian grocers in the northwest Bronx.
Many Asian-American advocacy groups say that the "model minority" stereotype of Asian immigrants as hard-working overachievers has blinded society to the harsh conditions under which Southeast Asian refugees are living.
Those families are more dependent on welfare than are most immigrant groups. About three-quarters of 250 families polled in the northwest Bronx received some form of public assistance, according to a 1998 survey by the Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence, a Manhattan group that works with young people in the Bronx. A 1994 study by two research groups in Los Angeles found that nationally, Southeast Asians had the highest welfare dependency rate among all ethnic groups, with more than 30 percent of such households relying on welfare.
Many of the Bronx children have grown up working long hours in the garment industry, in nail salons or at factories in New Jersey. While this country may have provided their parents with a haven, the young people often say it has yet to meet the American ideals of economic and racial equality.
"America didn't give my parents what they expected," said Rom Chy, 17, a senior at DeWitt Clinton High School in Norwood. "It gave them a minimum. It gave them freedom, support from the government and the opportunity to live. They were satisfied with those, but I know this country has so much more to give."
 
Rats, Roaches and Reality
When Narin Prum and his Cambodian family first moved into their one-bedroom apartment in Fordham in 1984, rats and roaches scrambled across the floors. Pipes dripped water through the ceiling of a closet. Mr. Prum's baby brother became ill from eating peeling paint.
Their parents bought a sewing machine and set up shop in the living room, getting up at 7 a.m. and shutting down 14 hours later. Because space was tight, the family came to an arrangement. For two years, the parents would sleep in the bedroom and their five sons in the living room. Then they would switch.
"We still weren't as bad off as other families," said Mr. Prum, 17. "They had a lot of terrible stuff, like rusty water out of pipes. But that's reality."
His home was typical of those in which many Southeast Asians grew up. In the late 1970's, during a wave of white flight from the Bronx, one-bedroom units rented for under $200 per month. Landlords jumped at the chance to lease cramped and dingy apartments to refugee families.
In these mostly Hispanic neighborhoods, the Southeast Asian families have claimed a few spaces as their own. In Fordham and University Heights, there are two houses that have been converted to Cambodian and Vietnamese Buddhist temples. In warm weather, the swath of green known as Devoe Park becomes a meeting place for refugee families. Old men play cards, food vendors sell shish kebab, and parents and children unfurl picnic blankets a world away from their crowded apartments.
"If you were poor in Cambodia, you still had your own land," said Leang Kulen Lang, founder of the Cambodian temple in Fordham. "You had your mango trees and banana trees. Here, poor is really poor."
The young people quickly discovered a world outside their apartments. Narin Prum said his older brother, Sokhon, began skipping school and hanging out with two dozen other teenagers on the block. Flaunting baggy jeans and gold chains, they sat on doorsteps and smoked cigarettes.
"They saw school as boring," said Mr. Prum, who often wears the shirt-and-tie uniform of the Roman Catholic high school he attends on a scholarship. "They thought everything they needed was on the block. If they needed money, they could sell drugs or get a job at McDonald's."
The other boys made fun of Mr. Prum, taunted him for wearing glasses and not having $200 sneakers. He found comfort in family outings to Orchard Beach and the Bronx Zoo. He studied hard, determined to become the son who would make his parents proud.
His older brother moved to Philadelphia at 18 to make a clean break and take college classes. Mr. Prum stayed home, but he carved out his own niche away from his apartment and his family. He hung out with classmates from school. He joined a community outreach program called the Youth Leadership Project. And he began meeting several dozen other Southeast Asian teenagers for a football game every Sunday at Harris Field, near the Bronx High School of Science.
Sometimes boys got hurt when they slammed each other into the ground. Sometimes they formed rivalries. (One team dubbed itself the Factory Workers in an expression of blue-collar pride.) But it was their game, a game they started despite everything else that went on in their world. That was what mattered.
"Without this game, there would be no unity among the people who play," Mr. Prum said. "The game keeps us together, to make sure we stay as friends. The game represents a bond with all of us."
 
Thrust Into Adulthood
If being the oldest child affects one's destiny, then Linh Duong's fate was altered when an older brother she never knew died in infancy on the boat trip from Vietnam. He fell ill, and there was no medicine. His mother sat helpless among the waves, as torn up inside as the country she had just left.
Ms. Duong, 17, quiet with flowing black hair and a quick smile, was born the year her parents arrived in the United States. Perhaps being thrust into the role of eldest child made her more willing to watch out for those around her.
For the last few years, she has listened as other Vietnamese parents talk anxiously to her mother about being dropped from welfare rolls. Because the adults speak little English, Ms. Duong often calls their caseworkers for them. "No one ever picks up," she said. (A spokeswoman for the city said that the welfare center might have had telephone problems.) Ms. Duong has also heard other stories, such as the one about a woman who visited a local welfare center and was forced to wait for hours.
For refugees, welfare issues became more pressing after changes to federal and state benefit laws in 1996 resulted in many immigrants losing food stamps, cash assistance and health benefits. Those Southeast Asians who scrambled to apply for citizenship found few English-language and citizenship classes geared toward them. Add to that the chaos created by the state's welfare-to-work program, and the result was a population in turmoil.
Like many Southeast Asian children, Binh Ly, 18, and her five siblings grew up working alongside their parents to supplement the family's welfare check. The clatter of sewing machines was the music of their childhood.
From 1992 to 1997, the Vietnamese family used part of their two-bedroom Kingsbridge Heights apartment as a scrunchie factory, churning out the elastic hair bands seven days a week. The mother's feet swelled up from sitting at the machine until midnight, sometimes until dawn when a shipment was due.
The pay was not a fortune, but it was at least enough to survive on. When the family started, a Vietnamese contractor paid them $2 per dozen scrunchies. By the time the parents moved to Texas five years later to join relatives, they received half that.
Ms. Ly said her mother cooked only chicken because other meats were too expensive, and she forbade her children to go to the movies because the family could not afford the price of a ticket.
"I didn't like working all the time," said Ms. Ly, a Fordham University freshman who wears tortoise-shell glasses and speaks in energetic bursts. "On the weekends, my friends would go out, but I couldn't go with them."
"But I'm really good at making scrunchies now," she said with a grin. With nimble fingers, she showed how she used to put the fabrics together into a loop and then string a rubber band inside. After a few seconds, she held up the imaginary product. "There, you have a scrunchie."
 
Turning Off and Dropping Out
When Rom Chy was 11, he and a dozen other Cambodian youngsters spent a summer playing in the weed-infested backyard of a nearby apartment building. The boys joked with one another in Khmer, the Cambodian language. They built fires to grill hot dogs and raw meat. They boasted that they were a gang, and a gang had to have a name. They called themselves the Cambodian Connection.
Then summer faded, and Rom Chy returned to school. He knew his mother would punish him if he ever cut class. But he also knew the sacrifices his parents had made for the family. He had heard stories of the corpses they had stumbled across in Cambodia. Once, his father went to a lake to get water, only to find it filled with blood.
But the boy watched as seven of his friends from that summer dropped out of school.
"They felt socializing was better than school, where you've got racist kids and bad teachers," said Mr. Chy, 17, in a soft voice. "They thought school was nothing. Drugs would come into their lives. Then they would get stuck."
Keeping Southeast Asian teenagers in school is one of the biggest challenges facing teachers and community workers. Although there are no statistics on school attendance among Southeast Asians, there is general agreement that cultural hurdles, household stress and poverty have contributed to high dropout rates. The temptation to hang out with friends in pool halls and on street corners is always there, as are opportunities to earn money through low-wage labor.
"For some of the kids, their self-esteem was affected when they first came to this country," said Sister Mary Burke, who runs an after-school tutoring program at Theodore Roosevelt High School in Fordham. "They're in a new environment with a new language. Some of the parents, they need to support their children, but they might be overwhelmed with other things."
More than a decade ago, the principal of Theodore Roosevelt, which has 3,000 students, sought help from St. Rita's Asian Center, a group that helps refugees in the Bronx. Teachers had found that many Southeast Asian students were not adapting well to school.
In response, the center started a daily tutoring program. These days, the program helps young people from all backgrounds, but Vietnamese children are still the largest ethnic group, making up more than a fifth of the 133 students.
Even with such services, some community organizers say that School District 10, which covers the northwest Bronx, should try harder to provide interpreters for Southeast Asian parents. In the grades up to high school, Southeast Asians are the third-largest group in the district's English classes for non-native speakers, according to the Board of Education.
Last November, the Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence accused school officials of reneging on promises to print Khmer and Vietnamese flyers and to hire interpreters for parent-teacher conferences. Local youth staged a protest. School officials recently agreed to translate fliers and print a directory of interpreters for teachers to use.
Binh Ly said having interpreters at school might have helped her parents realize sooner that her older brother was dyslexic. Her mother would berate him for being "lazy and stupid," Ms. Ly said, but she never attended parent-teacher conferences because she couldn't speak English. Not until Ms. Ly interpreted for her mother at a meeting did her mother realize her son had a learning disability.
"It was really discouraging for my brother," Ms. Ly said. "He would get mad at himself. And I'm sure he's not the only one who's fallen through the system."
 
A Moment in the Spotlight
As the host this particular day, it was Phalla Huoth's job to work the crowd. He strutted across the stage of a former convent in Fordham, flashing the audience a smile as he announced the break-dancing show. He leaned over and clicked on a strobe light. The speakers thumped. The walls shook. Three of his friends began twirling on the floor.
Mr. Huoth had recently quit his latest factory job and was working a few hours each week at the Youth Leadership Project, an outreach group. On this bright, chilly afternoon, the members were giving a community party to celebrate 15 years of Southeast Asian history in the Bronx.
The menu included chicken curry and noodles. A show featured traditional Vietnamese and Cambodian dances. About 50 people, mostly teenagers, sat at tables in the cavernous meeting hall.
At the youth program, Mr. Huoth said, he had met "good people, people who go to school, different than the friends I hang out with." He swore never to go back to the factories. Maybe he would get a high school equivalency diploma. Maybe he would find another job soon.
But for now, there was the stage, the music, the crowd. The beat ended. Applause thundered through the room. Someone cut the strobe light, and he swaggered off the stage.
"I was waiting for this day," Mr. Huoth said after slapping a friend's hand. "I wanted to take part in something I could have fun in. And I wanted everybody to be involved. This is something special for me."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk
