HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Will Chinese Food Go the Way of Pizza?

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

 BODY:
IT is a long way from any kind of Chinatown to the Fashion Square Mall in this upscale Phoenix suburb. But to Richard L. Federico, the usually-packed flagship restaurant in the P. F. Chang's China Bistro chain, nestled close to Nordstrom's and convenient to the multiplex, is more representative of Chinese food's future than are the tens of thousands of mom-and-pop Chinese restaurants that pepper the Main Streets of America.
If he is correct, mass marketing, Wall Street financing and professional management will finally have broken through in what has long been a chain-resistant segment of the retail economy. Like independent department stores, local burger joints and dozens of other entrepreneurial businesses, the independent ethnic restaurant may soon find itself, if not headed for extinction, well on the way to marginalization. 
 In many ways, Chinese food has been one of the last redoubts. Donna Gabaccia, a historian at the University of North Carolina who examined the mainstreaming of ethnic food in her 1998 book, "We Are What We Eat," said Chinese food presents unique obstacles to mass marketing compared with, say, Italian or Mexican cuisine. Individually owned Chinese restaurants were among the first to offer fast orders, takeout and delivery, she noted, leaving little room for a franchise fast-food approach to take hold, as it did in hamburgers, chicken, pizza, tacos and other categories. And the complexity of Chinese food preparation, whose tools and techniques have little in common with European cuisine, makes it less susceptible to standardization.
Mr. Federico, president and chief executive of P. F. Chang, dismisses those concerns. "In this business, the attitude was that there was a Chinese restaurant on every corner, and the idea was you could not penetrate the Chinese segment," he said. "But they said the same thing about Italian 20 years ago."
Professionally managed companies made inroads long ago into other ethnic food categories, with mass chains like Chili's (Mexican and Tex-Mex, 637 restaurants) and Olive Garden (Italian, 464). In many suburban and Sun Belt communities, chains like these often became the standard-bearers for their categories, sometimes by default. Their success told Paul M. Fleming, founder of P. F. Chang and now a consultant to the chain, that "authentic" roots were far from a prerequisite for success in ethnic food.
Mr. Fleming, 45, had a background in chain restaurants, notably as owner and operator of several Ruth's Chris Steak House locations. On a business trip to Los Angeles, he once enjoyed a meal at the swank Mandarin Restaurant in Beverly Hills, but afterward could not find similar quality food in Phoenix, his hometown. He got in touch with Phillip Chiang, owner of the Mandarin, in 1992 and asked him to lend some culinary expertise to a new chain.
Mr. Fleming started with Mr. Chiang's recipes and ingredient-buying instructions, but he made some adjustments that he hoped would enhance the food's appeal to a more mainstream market. He concentrated on the most familiar menu selections, lowered the oil content a bit and aimed to hold prices to an average bill of $17 a person. He also developed an extended wine list, unusual in Chinese restaurants, and chose a sleek modern decor that avoided Chinese cliches.
Mr. Fleming believed that starting in a suburban mall rather than in a cosmopolitan urban setting would be a better way to test the concept for an eventual national rollout. "Phoenix may not be a recognized center for Chinese cooking," Mr. Fleming said, "but it is a good barometer for the rest of the country."
Opened in 1993 with a name that melds Mr. Fleming's initials and a version of Mr. Chiang's surname that Middle America could readily spell and pronounce, P. F. Chang's took off, and soon expanded to Southern California, the Boston area and to Westbury, N.Y., on Long Island. There are now 39 open nationwide and 13 in development. In 1996, with the chain growing and more managerial expertise needed, Mr. Fleming brought in Mr. Federico, 46, a veteran of the Bennigan's and Macaroni Grill chains of Brinker International, to run the operation with a new chief financial officer, Robert T. Vivian. Mr. Fleming remains on the board, and Mr. Chiang continues as a consultant and minor shareholder. The new executives took the company public in December 1998 at $12 a share; the stock closed on Friday at $32.75.
As Prof. Gabaccia might have predicted, the toughest challenge in expansion was transmitting cooking expertise to new chefs and staff members, especially because the chain had no intention of restricting itself to places where native Chinese workers could be recruited.
The responsibility for maintaining chainwide food quality falls on P. F. Chang's executive chef, Paul M. Muller, a German-American native of Oakdale, N.Y., with experience in the kitchens of the distinctly non-Asian Waldorf Astoria Hotel in Manhattan and the Old Ebbit Grill in Washington. Having been schooled in Chinese cuisine under Mr. Chiang's direction, Mr. Muller puts new chefs through six to eight months of training before giving them restaurants to run.
Only 8 of the 39 head chefs at P. F. Chang's restaurants are Asian. "The skills can be taught to gwei-lo's for sure," Mr. Muller said, using a Cantonese slang expression for Caucasians. "It just takes a different mentality and a kind of passion."
Critics of the chain approach say the mentality and passion are not so easily cloned, just as knowing how to daub paint doesn't make someone a pointillist. Theresa Lin, a of Chinese-food critic and a restaurateur based in Los Angeles, said P. F. Chang's and ventures like the New York-based China Grill could compete effectively only where mainstream diners have not been exposed to the work of native Chinese chefs.
"These kinds of businesses are good at marketing, but when the mainstream people discover the real authentic food, they will go for it," said Ms. Lin, who was born in Taiwan and now owns three upscale restaurants in Las Vegas, Miami and Santa Monica, Calif.
MR. FEDERICO concedes that at the luxury end of the spectrum, Ms. Lin may well be right. P. F. Chang's may never be the first choice of sophisticated diners who enjoy sampling Chinese fare in meccas like Manhattan, San Francisco, the Flushing neighborhood of Queens or the San Gabriel Valley east of Los Angeles. But as his chain expands across the country, Mr. Federico said he believes the great majority of consumers will come to think of the food at places like P. F. Chang's, not the traditional, mom-and-pop eateries, as setting the standard.
"In the future, for a lot of people of my kids' generation," he said, gazing out at the crowd in the Scottsdale dining room, "this will be the real definition of a Chinese restaurant."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Action Plan For a Reluctant Greenspan

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
FOR all those who doubt that a speculative bubble hangs dangerously over the economy -- and the doubters number in the tens of millions -- Robert J. Shiller's new book is sobering. He describes a market so out of control that the run-up in the Roaring 20's looks like a molehill, compared with the Mount Everest of the 90's.
Mr. Shiller, a Yale University economist, called his book "Irrational Exuberance," borrowing the phrase coined by Alan Greenspan in December 1996. The Federal Reserve chairman has tried ever since to soften stock prices, but investors -- that is, nearly half the population -- have laughed in his face. The Fed notches up interest rates and stocks rise anyway, as if they were an addiction like cigarettes or liquor, just as much in need of a warning label. 
 Posting such a label -- in this case, coming right out and saying that we are in a stock market bubble -- would be the sort of government intervention that Mr. Greenspan resists. But stocks today are greatly overvalued -- perhaps by more than $7 trillion, Mr. Shiller says -- and even free-market economists wonder about the efficacy of the Fed's interest rate strategy.
"Some of us believe that the speculation has gone so far that there is no easy or painless way out," said one such economist on Wall Street, Albert Wojnilower. "The question is whether to acknowledge this and open the floor to other solutions. That is what Greenspan would be doing if he declared that speculation is driving up stock prices."
Mr. Greenspan said in 1996 -- and he continues to say today -- that irrational exuberance might be driving up stock prices. But he has never stepped over the line and bluntly stated that it is. Instead, he has kept one foot firmly planted in the camp of those who regard the market's performance as rational. Rising productivity and the prospect of rising corporate profits, he says, bring investors tumbling sensibly into stocks in anticipation of future gains.
Mr. Greenspan has acquired enormous prestige for his astute nurturing of the economy in recent years. But he is in danger of dissipating that prestige by insisting on rational monetary policy -- the notching up of interest rates -- to discipline an irrational situation. Why should investors be deterred from borrowing money at 6 or even 10 percent, Mr. Wojnilower asks, when they believe that stocks bought with the borrowed money will go up 20 percent by year-end? Getting interest rates high enough to stop that fervor would bust the economy.
What would happen if Mr. Greenspan declared bluntly that irrational exuberance controls the market and is running roughshod over all the sensible reasons for owning stocks? For one thing, such frankness would encounter resistance. The Clinton administration, in an election year, prefers to view the market as reflecting corporate America's strength and profitability. And most Wall Street traders like Mr. Greenspan's current ambivalence.
But public recognition of the bubble might finally propel America into vigorous debate about ways to control the market fever.
THERE are a half-dozen remedies besides higher rates. On everyone's list is tightening margin requirements. Investors could be required to put up 60 or 70 percent of the purchase price of a stock, instead of the present 50 percent. Mr. Greenspan objects that small investors, the biggest users of margin debt, would be forced more than big investors to pull back. But they would also be saved from painful losses in a market sell-off.
Bank regulators could put up another obstacle to the purchase of securities on credit. They could require banks to increase the capital that backs such loans, which by one measure rose to $23.4 billion in February from $18.1 billion just last November. The government, in effect, would be allocating credit, a role shunned in Washington today.
A transaction tax on all stock trades, of the sort once proposed by James Tobin, the Nobel laureate in economics, would slow trading. So would an old Warren Buffett idea: a 100 percent capital gains tax on stocks held for too short a term, say less than a year. That would encourage people to invest for the long term, more cautiously.
The so-called suitability rules could also be extended. These require brokers to check that a customer's investment goals are in line with his income, net worth and the like. A broker is bound by the rules to discourage a grandmother from sinking all her savings into a profitless Internet company. Suitability rules do not now cover day traders and online investors, though formal proposals already exist to extend them.
Remedies like these might sap the speculation without bringing down the economy. But even proponents worry that it is already too late to prevent a damaging market crash or a painful sell-off -- the denouement in the past of speculative bubbles that have gone unrecognized for so long.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
The Idea That Almost Got Away

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
NINE years after patenting a helicopter-deployed fishing net, Kent Thomas finally went fishing last month in New Zealand's Bay of Plenty.
Mr. Thomas, a veteran helicopter pilot, used a specially designed net to encircle a cloud of fish called trevally. The fish had little to fear, though, because the net's closure mechanism failed. Mr. Thomas had been waiting six months for the right fishing conditions while his net sat idle at an airfield; unknown to him, grass had grown through some of the lines and snarled them. 
 Disappointments and delays don't faze Mr. Thomas, an entrepreneur who has nursed his idea for an environmentally friendly fishing net with persistence, self-sacrifice and a willingness to change course.
Even though it failed to capture any fish, the "drop net" developed by Mr. Thomas's Ocean Friendly Company of Signal Hill, Calif., is described by some people in the fishing world as a breakthrough. Moreover, fishing regulators, who helped finance the net, consider it an economically and environmentally promising alternative for an industry facing restrictions on more and more declining species.
"This is the first real innovative fishing technique in decades," said James M. Meehan, a tuna biologist for the National Marine Fisheries Service, which imposed curbs last April on coastal catches of shark, Atlantic tuna and marlin.
When dropped from a helicopter, the net forms a sort of mid-ocean aquarium. A 38-foot-wide hexagonal ring of floats supports a strong, light cylindrical net weighted at the bottom. Five tons of fish may be caught when the three-story cylinder is twisted closed.
In earlier tests, the net had closed properly, but in empty water. The latest test failed to trap fish permanently, but it did show how they would react inside the enclosure.
"It was an unknown," Mr. Thomas, 54, said in a telephone interview from New Zealand. "They were just swimming; they didn't have a clue!"
As a boy growing up on California's Santa Catalina Island, he saw firsthand the collapse of sport fishing as commercial fleets depleted the waters of bait fish. After serving in Vietnam as an Army helicopter pilot, he flew commercially, spotting fish for tuna boats. Wasteful methods -- the indiscriminate killing of juvenile fish and protected species along with the desired catch in mile-long purse seine nets -- galvanized him.
He designed a net to improve a boat's yield of a single species. Traditional nets kill the fish they snare, but the drop net keeps them alive, allowing unwanted fish to be sorted out and returned to the sea.
And though the net's potential volume is less than that of traditional nets, its live catch is suitable for aquariums, sea farming or demanding sushi chefs, and thus has higher value. The concept was endorsed by the executive director of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission in La Jolla, Calif., which sets fishing limits in the eastern Pacific.
Ocean Friendly got a $170,000 federal research grant for the project, one of the few backed annually by the Commerce Department. Reducing the "bycatch" -- unintended netting of dolphins, sea turtles and other species -- is a top concern of the agency's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
"We're just funding the best of the best," said Joseph M. Bishop, a Commerce official. "Japan is at the cutting edge," using infrared imaging devices to seek the birds and dolphins that are a telltale sign of tuna, he said.
Ocean Friendly's prototype nets, finished in September 1998 by Ocean Spar Technologies, a Seattle maker of sea cages, met a chilly reception from American fishermen.
Mr. Thomas thinks that an unwillingness to try new methods unraveled a pledge by a Tacoma, Wash., shipowner to permit a crucial sea trial of the drop net from one of its tuna trawlers. When the company stopped returning his calls, Tom Meneghini, an Ocean Friendly vice president, met the boat as it pulled into dock in Guam in December 1998. "There's no way that drop net is coming aboard," the boat captain told him, according to a report Ocean Friendly filed with the Commerce Department.
The fishing company's president, Joseph S. Martinac, said the test was aborted because of potential liability issues as well as the skipper's reluctance.
AS Ocean Friendly scrambled for another option, and the money to pay for a demonstration, Commerce officials agreed to let the net be tested outside American waters. Mr. Thomas settled on New Zealand, where migrating fish often school close to land; he calculated that a helicopter could carry a net a few miles from shore to the fish; no reluctant boat captains would be involved.
Tangled lines did not figure in his thinking, however. Nor did running out of money. When the grant ended in September, Mr. Thomas tapped some of his 28 private investors. For his personal needs, his sister lent him $400. He raised $4,000 by selling his Volkswagen van.
"I'm always concerned he's going to starve to death," said Leon La Porte, a Commerce official. "We funded him as far as we can," he said, adding that Mr. Thomas has resisted fresh rounds of venture capital to avoid ceding control.
Other governments may help. The Green Party of New Zealand wants the minister of fisheries to consider support for Ocean Friendly and has scheduled a presentation. Indonesia, which granted Ocean Friendly fishing licenses, has also asked for a presentation from Mr. Thomas.
But none of this is certain. "I'm having difficulty getting a read on the potential for support from the governments of New Zealand and Indonesia," Mr. Meneghini said. "They are long shots, in my opinion."
During the years that Mr. Thomas has been proving his concept, new methods for managing fish resources have been emerging -- a change that could benefit his company. Besides the familiar Norwegian salmon farms, aquaculture is taking hold in countries like the Philippines, Australia and Japan.
Gary F. Loverich, chairman and senior engineer of Ocean Spar, says the drop net -- which his company made for $18,000 -- is a reasonable fit with aquaculture, particularly for countries short of cash. "You don't have to buy big boats," he said.
Mr. Loverich figures that Ocean Spar will soon be making Ocean Friendly nets. "This would not have happened without Kent," he said. "He's got a Ph.D. in tenacity."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
For Putin and Markets, the Hard Part Starts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
BORIS G. FEDOROV, the former Russian finance minister and one-time head of the state tax service, knows an expatriate Russian couple who put a large chunk of their money into Russian stocks in December. Since then, they have doubled their stake and bought a house.
Unfortunately for Americans, who have probably been avoiding volatile Russian stocks, the couple's good fortune means that much of the easy money has been made. 
 The market rally has come as the Russian economy is rebounding from its plunge during the financial crisis of August 1998, when the ruble was devalued and the government defaulted on its foreign debt. The Russian economy grew 3 percent last year -- a pace that is expected to continue, if not accelerate, this year. The turnaround was spurred by a tripling of oil prices, which also bolstered government revenue, and the ruble's devaluation, which made domestic companies more competitive.
Investor interest is also perking up. For example, cash flow into the $68.6 million Lexington Troika fund, which invests in Russia, was a heavy $9.1 million for the first two months of the year, according to Lipper estimates. The Morgan Stanley Dean Witter office here, headed by Rair R. Simonyan, a Russian investment banker, will be host for a conference for foreign investors in mid-May. And last week, the head of the Russian Federal Property Fund, which controls the remaining government stakes in Russian companies, met with potential investors in London and New York.
This year's rally, however, may have more to do with the New Year's Eve resignation of the unpredictable Boris N. Yeltsin as president. The Russian Trading System Cash index jumped 17 percent in the wake of the announcement and is now up 39 percent for the year.The stability that people see coming with the expected election today of the acting president, Vladimir V. Putin, has also helped.
Some analysts here say the stock-market rally was powered by local investors just waiting to sell when foreigners piled back in. In any event, much of the good news is already in the market.
Once the election ballots are counted, a new uncertainty may emerge: Will Mr. Putin be a reformer, and, if so, can he make the changes he wants? The needed tax, regulatory and legal reforms are daunting. There is corruption to deal with, and the rich and powerful oligarchs. Mr. Putin has been difficult to gauge; no one can say what he will do about these issues.
Alexander Kim, Morgan Stanley's strategist for Russia, said people were still uncertain about who, precisely, the new policy makers would be and what reforms would be carried out. "It is always implementation that has failed," he added.
Mr. Fedorov, now an author, said, "Once oil prices go down and devaluation effects go away, things will be tough for Putin."
"More stability will not carry the market," he added, referring to investors' hope that Mr. Putin's strong hand will prove enough to keep stocks rising. "By the end of the year, there will have to be other actions."
Dmitri V. Vasiliev, the former head of Russia's version of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a long list of what the country needs, including laws and regulations that treat investors and companies equally, lower taxes and improved collections.
Now the head of a shareholders rights organization, backed by institutional investors with $10 billion in Russian stocks, Mr. Vasiliev said, "Today, rules are so unclear that there are so many opportunities for bribery."
Before the financial crisis, he said, investors looked at Russia through "rose-colored glasses" and bought everything; after the crisis, Russia was viewed through "black glasses" and nothing was bought. Now, he said, investors need to ponder opportunities here through "clear glasses."
That means "deep investment analysis" of companies is necessary, he said, especially concerning the honesty of executives and any links to the oligarchs or organized crime. Foreign investors face not only the risk of a tumbling stock market, but also of maneuvers by Russian executives that could undermine the value of a company or dilute the value of a stock.
That kind of analysis, he allowed, "is not easy, of course."

HEADLINE: Alleviating Famine

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Natural Born Killers" (column, March 22), Paul Krugman overlooks two important points when offering genetically modified foods as an "escape" from poverty and starvation in developing countries. 
 First, the economist and Nobel laureate Amartya Sen has demonstrated conclusively that famine does not result from underproduction of food, but rather from distribution problems. Second, the multinational companies developing these genetically modified crops have patented the crops, which drives up seed prices. Genetically modified food does not offer a solution to poverty.
 
DIAHANNA LYNCH
Oakland, Calif., March 22, 2000

LENGTH: 3066 words

HEADLINE: Merrill's Bull in China's Shop

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
ON a sultry Sunday evening earlier this month, Taiwanese death-metal rock music echoed from a party in a hillside apartment far above the ribbon of headlights snaking through the skyscrapers below. The living room was emptied of all but a couch, a table and a couple of pairs of socks balled up in the corner. Over the din, a dozen young Internet entrepreneurs swapped business plans and financing tips, gushing over the millions they hoped to make when their companies went public.
Such soirees were unheard of a year ago, as was Matei Mihalca, an Internet analyst from Merrill Lynch who was the host of these festivities. His unbridled enthusiasm, and his embrace of the Net culture, have quickly made him a favorite among Asia's new cyber jet set. That and the fact that he can help make them all very, very rich. 
 "Ehr-fei! You have to meet these guys!" Mr. Mihalca shouted across the room, charging toward Ehr-fei Liu, a Merrill technology banker, two Web design executives in tow. "They already beat their revenue forecasts for the year. This is a real growth story! Huge. I mean huge! This company is all about opportunity!" Then the cell phone in his pocket rang, and Mr. Mihalca walked away, lost in the next big opportunity, leaving the three men behind to exchange awkward hellos.
Asia is sick with dot-com fever. But no one has the bug so badly as American investment banks hoping to take Asia's new Internet companies public. Asian economies, left for dead two years ago when the tumbling dominoes of a currency crisis brought the region's growth to an abrupt halt, are being reinvented overnight. Or, at least, Asia's stock markets are. As many as 50 Internet concerns in countries like China, India and Singapore are likely to go public this year alone, more than double the number that did so last year. Fueling that boom is the rising number of people in Asia going online, projected to more than triple over the next four years.
Expectations like those attract opportunists. So for investment banks that largely missed the technology boom in the United States over the last five years, lagging behind the powerhouses Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Goldman Sachs, Asia has become a place to reinvent themselves, too.
Merrill Lynch is among them. The technology practice of Merrill, one of the world's biggest brokerage firms, pales when compared with its peers over that period. Merrill ranks seventh worldwide in the number of Internet businesses it has taken public, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. One reason is that Merrill has been slow to foster the oversized personalities necessary these days to attract high-profile, big-name clients. It has no technology analysts, for example, with the renown -- and entree -- of Mary Meeker, who helped put Morgan Stanley's practice on the map.
But with Asia awakening to the Internet, Merrill sees the possibility for a fresh start. "The idea was: It's a land grab, and we wanted to be there," said Adam Quinton, Merrill's former head of Asia-Pacific research, who now helps coordinate telecommunications research in New York.
So last year, Merrill began the task of grooming Mr. Mihalca into an Internet celebrity. He seems the unlikeliest of candidates -- a 30-year-old former Communist from Romania with no technology background to speak of and little finance expertise. Even his mother is surprised at the transformation. "It is something of a paradox that somebody who was raised in a Communist state went on to work for a Wall Street firm," said Doina Bochis, who still lives in Romania. "He was always so literary, like me, with a very strong, developed mind."
But he is eager, and willing, to avail himself of a public and a business culture chasing dot-com fantasies. Mr. Mihalca is a tireless traveler who visits as many as 25 companies a week and often takes the lead in wooing potential clients into Merrill's fold. If he is successful, it will mean millions of dollars in lucrative initial public offering fees for his firm, and a bigger salary for him.
His hunger to put Merrill Lynch and himself on the map, though, raises a fundamental question for investors in both Asia and the United States who rely on analysts like him to be their trail guides through the vast plains of the Internet's Wild Wild East: When does boosterism end and critical analysis begin?
Even in the United States, the line between research and salesmanship -- that is, between the traditional roles of stock analyst and investment banker -- has blurred. Here, it has all but been erased.
Mr. Mihalca has no quibble with that. "In many places, people think this is a conflict," he said. "I see it as working together." If he doesn't believe in a company, he added, he simply won't recommend taking it public.
Such boldness concerns those who see Asia's Internet market as immature and driven mostly by hype.
"I remember reading a report from a guy talking about philosophy and love, and that's because analysts are at a complete loss," said J. Mark Mobius, who as managing director of Templeton Asset Management has spent years searching the world for undiscovered companies.
It is more difficult finding sound investments in Asia, because there is little in the way of a venture capital community to ferret out the best ideas, he said. The danger is that untested businesses will be sold to a ravenous public, with only investment bankers as a buffer against speculative excess.
It is too early to tell if Merrill's gamble on Mr. Mihalca will pay off. So far, he has yet to make any headline-grabbing stock predictions like those of his American colleague Henry Blodget, who made his name more than a year ago by predicting that Amazon.com would hit $400 a share months before it did.
And it may not be long before Mr. Mihalca follows in the footsteps of other Merrill up-and-comers who have left for venture firms or dot-com companies. He has been approached by a handful of start-ups, and rivals say privately that in the past he has talked about making a switch.
Opportunism, after all, is not just for institutions. "Now that there is attention being paid to this one sector, there is a pedestal to step on," said Jay Chang, who competes with Mr. Mihalca as an Internet analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong. "So, why not?"
 
The Analyst as Salesman
It was 1:15 p.m. on March 8, a Wednesday, and the last day of a technology conference Merrill had put on for Asian investors. Mr. Mihalca was nowhere to be found. A dozen or so journalists were milling around the ballroom lobby of the Island Shangri-La Hotel, eagerly awaiting his arrival at a news conference. Mr. Mihalca, nicknamed "the mad scientist of Internet analysts" by colleagues because of his quirky ideas, was found napping on a couch. The reason? He had spent all night writing a research report on an Internet portal company that Merrill was hoping to take public.
"It is an experiment in selling," Mr. Mihalca said of the report after he showed up in the lobby, quaffing a cup of coffee as he rubbed sleep from his bloodshot eyes.
For an analyst, Mr. Mihalca talks a lot about selling: selling stocks to investors, selling companies on Merrill, selling himself to all of them. In February 1999, just when the cyberworld in Asia was beginning to take off, Merrill needed a bold and articulate spokesman to better its image among journalists and potential clients. "The objective I gave him was to raise his profile in the corporate world as quickly as possible," Mr. Quinton said. "If someone wanted to interview someone who was knowledgeable, he would be the person the media turned to."
Never mind that his relevant experience was limited. He was a fluent Mandarin speaker and well-versed in Asian culture and politics, a necessity in countries where government and business are so closely intertwined. And he showed an early affinity for writing; his father was a journalist in Romania.
After a brief stint at the United States Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan, Mr. Mihalca was hired by Merrill in 1997 as an analyst. He was not a natural fit at first, so was hired on a temporary basis, Merrill executives said. But he showed promise, particularly as a skilled networker. "He seemed to know more people in Taiwan in one year than I did in 10," said Peter Kurz, the director at Merrill in Taiwan who hired him. "He is disarmingly honest, and people trust him for that reason." After first covering the semiconductor industry, he was appointed head of Asia-Pacific Internet research last year.
Soon after that, Merrill began its Mihalca campaign. He was introduced to reporters at major media outlets, some of whom he knew already from his stint freelancing for The Asian Wall Street Journal. Merrill took out newspaper advertisements touting his research and included his e-mail address. He made himself a regular visitor to the CNBC studios on the 25th floor of the Asia Pacific Finance Tower in central Hong Kong, eight floors above his own humble cubicle.
"I promote myself," he said unabashedly in a recent interview. Last month, he moderated an hourlong panel on CNBC Asia about the Internet there. That was a result of an elevator conversation with a "Squawk Box" anchor, Bernard Lo.
And he always returns reporters' calls. When America Online and Time Warner announced plans to merge in January, for instance, he was disturbed at midnight by a reporter seeking comment.
"I was happy about that," Mr. Mihalca said. "You have to put yourself in the customer's shoes."
But who, in fact, are Mr. Mihalca's customers? Some may still think that analysts are the eyes and ears of investors, or at least their brokers. But in truth, analysts like Mr. Mihalca labor to suit the companies their bankers court.
Thomas Rosenthal, a fan and president of MeetChina.com, a business-to-business Web site in China, said of Mr. Mihalca: "I see him as a salesman. He is out there getting the business." Mr. Mihalca recently offered to broker an introduction between MeetChina executives and a potential partner interested in setting up a joint venture. He is also a trusted confidant; after an investor meeting, Mr. Mihalca said he gently suggested that a MeetChina executive refrain from talking about his colleagues' wives.
Mr. Mihalca connects with young entrepreneurs in tradition-bound Asia because he, like many of them, is an outsider. On a recent Sunday morning, Mr. Mihalca, along with his Taiwanese wife, Ching-Fang Hu, and Rajesh Jain, an Indian entrepreneur who recently sold his Internet company for $115 million, took the ferry from Hong Kong island to Kowloon for breakfast. The two men had met only once last October, but they greeted each other with smiles and a hearty bear hug.
"When I first met Matei, we talked for three hours at a Bombay hotel," Mr. Jain said over a breakfast of Egg McMuffins (a favorite of Mr. Mihalca's) and coffee. "I met someone who was as excited as I was and really understood what I wanted to do."
Such exuberance is rare on Wall Street. One colleague teased that David Komansky, Merrill's chief executive, would grow pale if he knew about the all-nighters Mr. Mihalca spent at the office. Mr. Mihalca waves goodbye with two hands, and the floor shakes under his gait as he runs down the hall.
"Personally, I think there is something neurologically wrong with him," joked Duncan Wooldridge, a Merrill senior economist in Hong Kong. "One of the great things is that his excitement and enthusiasm are contagious. He likes to talk about ideas. If you don't have free time, don't go by his desk."
But can Mr. Mihalca adapt his style to more traditional clients, particularly as the Internet sector matures? His discomfort with established society became apparent hours after his meeting with Mr. Jain. Mr. Mihalca and his wife were invited to the exclusive Hong Kong Jockey Club for a private party held by Champion Technology, a multibillion-dollar communications concern. It was Derby Day, the equivalent of the Kentucky Derby in the United States. Clearly Mr. Mihalca was not on familiar terrain.
"Nice carpet," he said sarcastically, pointing to the burst of purple and orange on one of the floors. The guest list was a who's who of Hong Kong's diplomatic corps and business society. They had arrived in private cars, while Mr. Mihalca took a cab because he missed the train. His khakis and tweed jacket looked pedestrian compared with other guests' tailored suits and dresses. And while Champion's chairman, Paul Kan, held court with older, more polished investment bankers, Mr. Mihalca was briefly introduced when he arrived.
To him, the business culture of the jockey club's patrons was a curiosity to be studied and understood. Theirs is a social structure being displaced by newer entrants. And to comprehend where society was going, one had to understand from where it had come.
"Sure, I felt more comfortable this morning with Rajesh," he said later, during the cab ride home. "But you have to understand this world, too. You can't turn your back on them just because it is not comfortable."
 
'I Am a Lone Cowboy'
Mr. Mihalca was born on April 5, 1969, an only child, and lived in the small Romanian mountain town of Baia Sprie, 100 miles from Bucharest. Food was scarce under the tyranny of Nicolae Ceausescu, and the lights in young Matei's house ran on a car battery.
He remembers his mother, a hospital psychiatrist, treating "depressed people who swallowed detergent and stuff." (His stepfather, Mircea Bochis, an artist, married his mother 24 years ago.)
"I am a lone cowboy," Mr. Mihalca said. And at times that has cost him.
"He had problems in school because he spoke against the system," his mother recalled. "He presented himself openly as an anti-Communist. I always said, 'Shut up! Be quiet!' "
Despite his views, Mr. Mihalca joined the Communist Party in 1988. If he hadn't, he said, he might have missed the opportunity that has defined his career: a chance to study Chinese in Beijing in 1989, as one of a handful of students plucked from the University of Bucharest for a summer exchange program.
Turmoil seems to chase him, or he, it. Then just 20, he arrived at the Beijing Language Institute on June 7, days after the massacre at Tiananmen Square. Armored vehicles rolled past his dormitory-room window. Many foreign students had returned to their embassies, and as their mail piled up in the dorm lobby, he spent his summer skipping classes, reading Western magazines and learning to ride a bicycle. Six months later, back in Baie Sprie, he and his family huddled around a television set and watched the Ceaucescu government crumble.
Mr. Mihalca returned to Beijing and was later accepted into a doctoral program at Harvard University to study history and East Asian languages. He spent five years there but never finished his dissertation. In Cambridge, too, he had a difficult time getting along. Nikolas Gloy, a Harvard friend and next-door neighbor, said Mr. Mihalca openly criticized the research of fellow students and corrected the grammar of native Chinese speakers.
When pressed to reflect, Mr. Mihalca acknowledges that those were not happy days. "Being a Romanian guy studying Chinese in America did not work that well," he said. He paused for a moment, deep in thought, the memory seemingly raw. "In a way I am like my father, somewhat cold. I do not feel the need to be sentimental about my past."
If anyone best understands Mr. Mihalca, it is probably his wife, Ms. Hu. The two met in Taipei in 1997, where she was editor in chief of Playboy Taiwan, for which she now consults.
Having a dialogue with society is important to her husband, she said. And at Merrill Lynch, he gets the attention he craves. "He has a childish side -- like a baby, naughty," she said. "He needs a lot of love. He is like a complicated child who is always thinking, and it is hard to get to the heart of where his mind is."
 
How Long Can a Star Shine?
It is still early in the race to take Asia's Internet industries public. Among investment banks, Lehman Brothers, an also-ran in the United States, has captured much of the attention here so far with two high-profile offerings last year. One was for Chinadotcom, the other for Pacific Internet. Ravi Sarathy, Lehman's chief Internet analyst and an early dot-com celebrity in Asia, played a key role in attracting that business.
Like many other Wall Streeters, he has since departed to create his own online start-up. But he remains a consultant to Lehman clients.
Other aspects of the banking business here are as peculiar. Some analysts are also entrepreneurs. Eric Gan, who works for Goldman Sachs Japan, is also co-founder of eAccess Ltd., an Internet service provider in which Goldman has invested, said a spokeswoman for the firm.
As long as Internet stocks keep going up, there seem to be few complaints about such arrangements. The real test will come when companies begin to stumble. Then, the true Internet stars will shine, the analysts and bankers who can separate the novas from the black holes.
Clients and investors say Mr. Mihalca's strength is understanding a concept -- and, even better, marketing it. But as the investing world comes to focus more on revenue and profits, the ability to sell a story will hold less appeal. Then the plodding, less glamorous, but more incisive analysis will prevail.
That may prove uncomfortable to Mr. Mihalca and others like him who are making young Asian entrepreneurs rich today, but will be duty-bound to chastise them if they fail to execute.
"If it were to happen, it would be a personal disappointment," Mr. Mihalca said. "You invest a lot of time and energy and personal commitment." But by then, he added, he may have a large-enough staff to help him work through the numbers. "How I delegate the nitty-gritty to our team members," he said, "is something I will have to learn."
He is acutely aware that if Asia's Internet companies fail to deliver, his 15 minutes in the spotlight are up. But in this market, where everything is a "buy," he does not seem to worry.
"If you pick companies that go up in flames, well, it is everyone who goes up in flames," he said. "Then it is not about you anymore. The story is fairly sound. If the Internet as a whole doesn't work out, it is not my problem."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: A Weapon for Consumers;
The Boycott Returns

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
NOT since the 1970's, when grape workers and the anti-apartheid movement were holy causes for millions of Americans, have so many groups embraced the boycott as a weapon.
In the most prominent boycott in years, the N.A.A.C.P. has called on tourists and conventions to shun South Carolina to pressure that state to remove the Confederate flag atop its Capitol. Also facing an N.A.A.C.P. boycott, the Adam's Mark luxury hotel chain agreed last week to pay $8 million, seek minority customers and give its employees diversity training to get the boycott dropped and to settle race discrimination lawsuits brought by some offended black guests and the Justice Department. 
 Gay groups have proposed a boycott of Paramount over a planned television show starring Dr. Laura Schlessinger, who has called homosexuals "biological errors" and "sexual deviants." Groups seeking to restore democracy to Burma are sponsoring boycotts against Best Western, Unocal, Suzuki and other companies that do business there. Among the companies that labor unions are boycotting is Kaiser Aluminum, which locked out 2,900 unionized workers 14 months ago. And the Southern Baptist Convention is pressing a boycott against Disney, charging that it is too sympathetic to gays.
"The times may be ripe for more consumer boycotts," said Jeff Faux, executive director of the Economic Policy Institute, a research group in Washington. "We have more of a consumer culture, and people see themselves more as consumers today. While people are participating less in the political process, as consumers they see that one way they can exercise power is by where they spend their money and where they don't."
The boycott takes its name from an economic war waged by Irish farmers in the 1880's against an English land agent, Charles Cunningham Boycott, who refused demands to cut rents during a time of poor crops. Their subsequent refusal to work his land or sell him goods forced him to return to England.
In the late 1880's American farmers were already shunning railroads charging exorbitant rates. In 1885 alone, American labor unions carried out 196 official boycotts.
One boycott that made a profound impression on 20th-century America was the Montgomery bus boycott, which came after Rosa Parks famously refused to sit in the back of the bus in 1955 because she was black. Since then civil rights activists have repeatedly embraced boycotts. Two months ago, the television networks agreed to increase minority hiring after the N.A.A.C.P. threatened a boycott, charging that few shows featured minority actors.
But sometimes boycotts, which require organization and consumer awareness, fail. Most Americans do not realize that the United Farm Workers' 1984 grape boycott remains in force. Begun when growers refused to sign new union contracts, it has largely failed because the union stopped promoting it when it failed to catch on. Union officials say it remains in effect because lifting the boycott would give a victory to the grape growers. In sharp contrast, the original boycott called by Cesar Chavez in 1967 persuaded millions of Americans to give up grapes and pressured California growers to recognize unionized workers and raise wages.
Boycotts can hurt the very people they intend to help. When anti-sweatshop groups threatened a boycott against apparel from Bangladesh in the mid-1990's because many factories employed child labor, the factories simply fired the children, pushing some into begging and prostitution. Anti-sweatshop groups now generally oppose boycotts.
The N.A.A.C.P.'s president, Kweisi Mfume, said his group never rushes into boycotts. "This is a trigger you don't want to pull until all else has failed," he said. "In the case of South Carolina, after 38 years of negotiating even the N.A.A.C.P. has a limit to its patience." As a result, the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce says, more than 100 conventions and other events have been canceled in the state, which has lost at least $18 million in tourist dollars.
BUT Howard Hunter Jr., the chamber's president, said the boycott might backfire because it has caused some lawmakers to dig in. "One group of legislators," he said, "has used the boycott very effectively for not taking action, saying: 'We're being blackmailed. If we succumb this time, what are they going to ask for next?' " The business community, Mr. Hunter said, has been working to resolve the problem.
LOOKING for less controversial tools than a boycott to pressure Paramount to drop its "Dr. Laura" plans, gay groups have deluged the corporation with calls and e-mail. "Paramount would never host a talk show where someone said such nasty things about blacks or Jews," said John Aravosis, who has organized the stopdrlaura.com Web site.
Companies react to boycotts with either compliance or defiance. After several groups boycotted Pepsi over its Burma ties, the company stopped doing business there. "When customers and consumers contact us, we definitely listen," said David De Cecco, a Pepsi spokesman, who added that the company's action was consistent with American foreign policy.
But Unocal has reacted differently to a boycott over its investment in a natural gas consortium in Burma. "We sympathize with the boycott's goals," said Michael Thatcher, a Unocal spokesman. "We want to see democracy and economic improvement in Myanmar. We feel that the way we're doing it is much more likely to bear positive results than their way, which is to pull out and isolate the country."
During the South Africa boycott, the apartheid regime made similar arguments, saying sanctions were hurting the nation's blacks in particular. But Archbishop Desmond Tutu rejected those arguments, saying: "You get all sorts of people saying all sorts of things about sanctions: That they will hurt the people you are trying to help. Twiddle! It's baloney of the first order! Because you are speaking about people already suffering, and you are saying you are trying to find some way that is a nonviolent strategy for bringing about the change that everybody says they want."

HEADLINE: Russia Votes: Will Democracy Win?

BYLINE: By Jack F. Matlock Jr.; Jack F. Matlock Jr., a former ambassador to the Soviet Union, is a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study and the author of "Autopsy on an Empire."

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
If enough people bother to vote today in Russia, Vladimir Putin is expected to be elected president by a wide margin. What then? Is he the inscrutable "black box" some observers have described, or even a Russian Pinochet determined to establish order by whatever means required? Or will he turn out to be a democratic reformer, eager to get on with the changes Russia needs to become a just and prosperous society?
Of course, neither Russians nor outsiders can be certain what Mr. Putin will do. But one guide we might consider is Boris Yeltsin's motives in setting him on the succession track. 
 In a meeting in Moscow last December, President Yeltsin's spokesman told me that his boss was determined to go down in history as the person who made the restoration of Communism impossible. By the spring of 1999, I was told, Mr. Yeltsin had become worried that Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov, his ostensible successor, had become "too close to the Communists." Mr. Yeltsin had therefore dismissed Mr. Primakov and named Sergei Stepashin as prime minister, only to be convinced within weeks that Mr. Stepashin probably could not win a presidential vote.
So he had replaced Mr. Stepashin with Mr. Putin, the spokesman told me, since he believed Mr. Putin was the man most capable of winning and preventing any return to Communist rule or other authoritarianism. Two weeks after the Kremlin aide told me this, Mr. Yeltsin resigned, which automatically made Mr. Putin the acting president and moved up the election by three months. There could hardly have been a more powerful assist to a candidate.
The aide's explanation may have been tailored for the listener. Nonetheless, the important question about Mr. Putin is whether he is capable of keeping Russia on the democratic track and devoted to doing so. In that sense, Mr. Yeltsin's purported judgment seems well founded.
Mr. Putin has condemned Communism, saying, "It was a blind alley, far away from the mainstream of civilization," and has described his goals as building a strong democratic state and encouraging growth. He has warned against "restoration of an official state ideology," adding: "Our people have accepted such values as freedom of expression, freedom to travel abroad and other fundamental political rights and human liberties."
His rhetoric on democracy has been unequivocal: "History proves all dictatorships, all authoritarian forms of government, are transitory. Only democratic systems are not transitory." He has also said, "The main threat to human rights and freedoms emanates from the executive authority."
His economic prescriptions include encouraging the growth of small and medium-sized business and reforming the financial system through realistic budgets, tax reform, monetary stability and the creation of "civilized" markets. He has called for "integration of the Russian economy into world economic structures" and, specifically, for membership in the World Trade Organization.
He insists that Russia must remain a great power, but he has specified that "ensuring a high level of people's well-being" is more important than military strength. He also emphasizes that Russia has nothing to gain from confrontation with the West and that development will be more rapid if Russia attracts foreign investment.
Not only has Mr. Putin said the right things; he has also shown a remarkable capacity for political maneuvering. After backing the hastily organized Unity Party in the December parliamentary elections, Mr. Putin turned around in January and arranged a surprise deal with the Communists that effectively prevented Mr. Primakov from being elected speaker. Although many Westerners attacked Mr. Putin for reaching out to the Communists, there is no evidence he made substantive compromises. The Communist committee chairmen will get their BMW's and their dachas while they may finally back the banking and tax reforms that they have long blocked.
Mr. Putin's record is not without blemish. A former K.G.B. official, his reliance on former agency colleagues as advisers raises legitimate questions. And he has gained much from the support of super-rich "oligarchs," particularly Boris Berezovsky, whose television network savaged the Primakov team before the parliamentary elections and last week attacked Grigori Yavlinsky, a liberal presidential candidate, saying that he was backed by Jews, homosexuals and foreigners.
Most worrisome is the brutality of the war in Chechnya, and the Russian government's efforts to block objective news coverage and cover up atrocities. But most Russians consider Chechnya unique. Russian popular sentiment has long considered Chechnya the most lawless and corrupt region in the country. No other province is suspected of sponsoring terrorism in the rest of Russia. Many Russians will condone actions there that would not be tolerated elsewhere.
Although Westerners may think the war is the sole cause of Mr. Putin's popularity, that is not necessarily the case. During recent trips to Moscow and St. Petersburg, most people I spoke to who supported him praised his youth, his "businesslike" manner and his reputation for getting things done. Few mentioned Chechnya.
Westerners have criticized Mr. Putin's reluctance to talk more specifically about his plans. (When a Russian magazine asked about his programs, he replied, "I won't tell you.") But his reasons are obvious. To carry out his goals, he will have to take on some powerful interests. Why provoke their opposition before the vote? No Western politician would do so.
The truth is, the changes in Russian society since 1991, including political decentralization, economic privatization and increasing independence of the courts, would make it very difficult for any leader to impose Soviet-style authoritarian control.
It is time we stopped making Russia the receptacle of either our dreams or our fears. We should congratulate the people on a peaceful and orderly transfer of power. We shall learn soon enough whether Vladimir Putin's supporters or detractors are correct. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1569 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: Flash Points;
Global Trade Meets The Lure of the Gun

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR seven years now, Bill Clinton has been chanting the mantra that countries that invest in education and focus on the Web are far more likely to prosper than those that measure their power in kilotons and argue over bleak pieces of real estate.
He made the case again last week in India and Pakistan while his top aides were delivering variations on the theme in Beijing. A third major flash point, the Middle East, was on his agenda for today.
But the argument that seemed so reasonable just a few years ago -- that plugging into a dynamic world economy will bring prosperity and tame nasty nationalistic tendencies -- is proving a hard sell as Mr. Clinton races around the globe in the last 10 months of his presidency. 
 The world's most economically isolated nations, like Pakistan and Syria, see no hope of catching up with their more economically advanced competitors, and those well on the road to global competitiveness, like India, China and Israel, believe more than ever that their economic potential must be married with military strength.
Take India's Parliament, which swooned when Mr. Clinton talked excitedly of the booming software houses of Bangalore and when he predicted that, as India makes the inevitable choice between "the hand loom or the hyperlink," its standard of living could sextuple in the next two decades. Yet as soon as Mr. Clinton suggested that India's economic progress is being undercut by its nuclear testing and territorial battle over Kashmir, his hosts got their backs up.
Just because our future is etched on a silicon chip, they shot back, in effect, don't think we're about to give up the Bomb.
In Beijing, meanwhile, hard-liners were using the election of an independence-leaning president in Taiwan to bolster their case that it was time for "economic integration" with the world to take a back seat to the assertion of China's sovereignty over what they see as a breakaway island. It is still unclear whether the generals will retake the upper hand from those who argue that the real business of the Communist Party is business.
Then there was Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, whose waffling on a peace accord with Israel prompted Mr. Clinton to schedule a face-to-face meeting today in Switzerland. For years now Mr. Clinton has been sketching out his vision of the Middle East's economic potential if only it could stop arguing over security and territory. But now a great deal of that vision hinges on his ability to persuade a reclusive and ailing Syrian leader increasingly preoccupied with creating a family dynasty.
Each of those disputes, of course, is driven by its own emotional history of ugly conflict. But they all serve to illustrate the dangers of too simplistic a faith in the lure of the market when nationalistic impulses flare up.
"We Americans often see a rigid tradeoff between economic success in an age of globalization and increasing your old-style military power," said Paul Bracken, a Yale professor whose book "Fire in the East" (HarperCollins, 1999) explored the growing nuclear threats in Asia and the Middle East. "The rest of the world doesn't see it that way. And in fact, their growing nationalism is a counterweight, in their minds, to the other strains they are feeling as their worlds are changed" by borderless competition.
NATIONALISM isn't the only factor at play. All three flash points are made more complex and unpredictable by the fact that nervous authoritarian regimes are facing off against some variety of democracy -- a mix that can produce political miscalculation when one side misunderstands how the other makes its decisions. Witness how China's heavy-handed threats, aimed at intimidating Taiwan's voters, backfired to the point that the Taiwanese elected the candidate who until recently had talked of asserting independence.
And in each dispute, Washington's own motives are suspect. Americans often view themselves as neutral arbiters, only seeking to spread peace. But from Delhi to Shanghai to the Persian Gulf, suspicions are greater than ever these days that the sole military and economic superpower is using its "neutral" role to create a world that plays to Washington's commercial and geopolitical advantage.
Why has a seemingly persuasive argument -- that it's wiser to invest in education and broadband networks than in nuclear reprocessors -- run up against such opposition both in unplugged nations and in the most plugged-in?
Pakistan and Syria are good places to start. Both are about as disconnected from the world economy as you can get.
But, while both countries harbor enormous reservoirs of native talent, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the leader of Pakistan, and Mr. Assad in Syria understand the nature of the poison pill: if they took Mr. Clinton's advice, the medicine that would be good for the country would eat away at their own holds on power. Among major authoritarian regimes at the turn of the century, only China's Communist leaders have made the bet that they can loosen controls on the economy, allow in the Internet and still exert iron control over the nation's politics.
So Pakistan holds on to nukes for the same reason that NATO did in Europe: as a guarantee against a much larger force across the border. Add to that nationalistic pride. But what about India? Doesn't it see that a nuclear arms race drains resources that could be better spent conquering new cybermarkets?
"It's exactly the opposite," says Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, who as a top Commerce Department official peddled a lot of Mr. Clinton's networks-not-nukes message. "In the first half of the 20th century, countries wanted well-rounded power. The cold war, though, created an odd sense that only a couple of countries would be both economic and military powerhouses. Now the pendulum is swinging back."
So India wants both. As does Israel, and both China and Taiwan. Indeed, countries look at the one nation that was supposed to exercise "soft power" through economic and technological prowess alone -- Japan -- and they see a pitiful excuse for a superpower. Once the economic magic went away, so did the global diplomatic influence.
The disconnect between analog and digital nations is worsened when the former are authoritarians and the latter are some variety of democracy. This has long been a problem in the Middle East. President Assad's rhetoric regularly frays the fragile coalition keeping Prime Minister Ehud Barak in power in Israel. Nothing new there. But Mr. Barak has long promised that any peace deal with Syria will be put up to a national referendum in Israel, and that means final adoption could be unpredictable.
But for real miscalculation, pop back and forth between Beijing and Taipei. China's leaders have what one senior American official last week called a "near-perfect ability to miscalculate" the effects of their words on the Taiwanese electorate. Yu Maochun, a professor at the United States Naval Academy who specializes in cross-straits relations, was sitting in a noisy Taipei restaurant earlier this month when the television broadcast a warning to Taiwan from China's premier, Zhu Rongji. The mainland, he said, was willing to "spill blood" to prevent independence. "People stood up and yelled" in the restaurant, Mr. Yu said, making vivid the backlash that was felt throughout Taiwan.
Why would a man as sophisticated about the world as Zhu Rongji, China's leading economic reformer, make such a blunder?
"The Communist Party, when it comes to big problems, is elitist," says Mr. Yu. "It is accustomed to sitting down behind closed doors with a Nixon or a Kissinger and solving a problem. Now it is faced with a whole different kind of foreign policy challenge. And they can't handle the politics."
DEMOCRACIES miscalculate, too. It was India that inflamed the long-running sore with Pakistan two years ago when it uncorked nuclear tests. Some Indian elites now concede that the nuclear grandstanding -- a great crowd pleaser at home -- paved the way for the rise of General Musharraf in Pakistan, who had engineered some of the horrors in Kashmir, then took command in a coup. Now, American officials believe, he figures that if the war at the top of the world gets splashed on enough front pages, India will be forced to accept what it has long rejected -- outside mediation from Mr. Clinton.
The general may be proved wrong, but maybe not. With not much to do at home, Mr. Clinton is moving from hot spot to hot spot, arguing that all involve areas in America's strategic interest. The problem is that Mr. Clinton envisions himself as an umpire, while the rest of the world sees Washington as a player with its own agenda.
There is suspicion in Beijing, for example, that America is using all its weapons -- from the Seventh Fleet to its influence over the World Trade Organization -- to contain China's power. The Indians share a similar suspicion, even as they flocked to shake Mr. Clinton's hand.
And so for all the happy talk, the Indians had no intention of signing on to Mr. Clinton's non-proliferation agenda. After all, they said, that other great symbol of democracy -- the United States Senate -- rejected the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty last year, proving that even the most powerful economy on earth wasn't willing to forgo its nuclear options.
So why, they asked, should they?

HEADLINE: RECKONINGS;
Deficit Attention Disorder

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
A long time ago, in an economic universe far, far away, people cared about the trade balance. When the U.S. trade deficit passed $100 billion for the first time, there was much wailing and gnashing of teeth. Doomsayers warned of an imminent "hard landing" in which a crashing dollar would precipitate economic crisis. Even calmer types regarded the unprecedented red ink as a warning sign.
But a funny thing happened on the way to the 21st century: people lost interest in the trade balance. In January, the Commerce Department announced last week, the United States set a new world record: the biggest monthly trade deficit ever. (Is this a great country, or what?) Measured as a share of G.D.P., last year's current account deficit (the broadest measure of the trade gap) was wider than ever before. But the markets couldn't have cared less. They were more interested in the accounts of MicroStrategy (a high-flying tech stock that lost two-thirds of its value in one day when it adopted a new accounting standard) than in those of the United States. 
 In some ways this lack of interest is a good thing. Obsession with trade balances has historically been a source of bad economic policies. It's probably for the best that state governments don't know whether their trade with other states is in surplus or deficit; their ignorance keeps them out of mischief. And not paying attention is almost as good as not knowing.
Still, perhaps we shouldn't be quite so indifferent.
At the moment the U.S. trade deficit is good, not bad, for our economy. It doesn't cost us jobs because we already have more than enough domestic demand. We aren't having any trouble paying for imports: the inflow of money from investors eager to buy into our miracle economy has easily matched the outflow to pay not only for all those Lexuses and BMW's, but for the suddenly more expensive oil they burn too. And this inflow of capital helps keep stocks high and interest rates low.
Besides, by any other measure the United States is performing superlatively compared with every other major economy. We have the highest growth, the lowest unemployment, the biggest budget surplus. To focus on the trade deficit, you might argue, would be like short-selling a rapidly growing company because it doesn't pay dividends.
But just as even the newest of new economy companies must eventually justify its existence by returning money to investors, even the most successful economy must sooner or later export enough to pay for its imports. Our current position, where we pay for many of our imports by attracting inflows of capital -- in effect by selling the rest of the world claims on our future exports -- cannot go on forever. And as the late economist Herbert Stein declared, "If something cannot go on forever, it will stop."
The most likely scenario is that the trade deficit will eventually be reined in by a decline in the foreign-exchange value of the dollar. The great dollar slide of 1985-87, precipitated by a trade deficit that was actually smaller compared with G.D.P. than the deficit today, reduced the value of a dollar by 40 percent in terms of German marks and Japanese yen. And there is no obvious reason why the same thing can't happen again.
But if that is the way it will play out, at least some of the money we are now pulling in is being brought in under false pretenses. Right now foreign investors are willing to hold 10-year U.S. government bonds, even though they pay only a slightly higher interest rate than their European counterparts. Those investors seem to believe, in other words, that today's strong dollar will persist for another 10 years. But the size of our trade deficit makes that unlikely. So foreign investors, and therefore the value of the dollar, are arguably doing a Wile E. Coyote -- one of these days they will look down, realize that they have already walked over the edge of the cliff, and plunge. And when they do it will come as a rude shock not only to them, but also to American financial markets that have become accustomed to big inflows of foreign money.
The trouble, you see, is that in economics, as in life, what you don't pay attention to can hurt you.

HEADLINE: New York City's New Dreams

 BODY:
The headlines nowadays are filled with ambitious proposals to transform New York City's landscape. One day, planners unveil a scheme to stage the Olympics in the city, with a new stadium on the West Side and apartment houses for athletes on the Queens waterfront. Another day, Albany debates plans to connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal or build a new Second Avenue subway. Clearly boom times are producing dreams for big projects, opening a potential new chapter in the city's self-renewal. But dreams also entail tough decisions. It is far from obvious how best to use limited resources for urban growth.
There is, of course, continuing pressure for New York City to use its regular capital budget to repair schools, bridges and the infrastructure. But the city's history also illustrates the importance of grand projects that spur economic growth and enhance New York's reputation as a cultural and business mecca. The need for planned expansion of existing public and private facilities is illustrated daily by crowded subways, high-priced apartments and squeezed commercial space. It is equally evident that there is room for quality development around rail yards, in old manufacturing areas and in underused waterfront districts. The problem for elected officials is how to sort through competing plans and find the best way to continue the tradition that has produced past successes from Rockefeller Center to Lincoln Center and Battery Park City. 
 Four overarching goals are already evident. The city government should try to open up Manhattan's West Side to development. It should also revise the city's residential zoning to protect the character of existing neighborhoods. The other two goals are the upgrading of transit links and development of the waterfront and other vacant areas. Shaping projects around these goals will involve complicated choices about the mix of public and private funds and the feasibility of various stadium proposals. Those choices, in turn, will be influenced by the outcome of the effort to recruit the Olympics. Here is a rundown on the major issues:
The West Side. The biggest opportunity for apartments and offices is in Manhattan, west of Eighth Avenue and south of 42nd Street, an area developers have eyed for years. The main impediment is a lack of transit access. The committee that proposes to bring the 2012 Olympics to New York has some imaginative suggestions. One proposal is to build a stadium over the rail yards near the waterfront, and link the site with the No. 7 subway line, the Long Island Rail Road, Metro North and the Amtrak trains to New Jersey.
The Olympic bid is supported by Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who also wants a West Side stadium for the Jets and the Javits Convention Center. Madison Square Garden is also said to be interested in moving west. A valuable new neighborhood could rise one day from what is now largely parking lots, warehouses and wasted space. The stadium proposals deserve serious study. But any new facility should have multiple uses, and no potential user -- whether the Olympics or a sports franchise -- should be handed a blank check.
The West Side is also being looked at by a team of business leaders put together by Senator Charles Schumer and former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin. They want to find room for high-tech and other business expansion in other parts of the city as well.
The Olympics. The Olympics do not always produce the economic activity that sponsors promise. But the Olympics group has laid out an intriguing scheme in which a stadium just might work. Its projections show that a public investment in a train stop and platform over the railroad tracks -- with or without a stadium -- could be paid for by tax revenues from new office, hotel and residential buildings. Over all, projected revenue from the Olympics would pay for more than $1 billion in new athletic facilities throughout the city. The Olympics proposal also calls for an athletes village to be built on the Queens waterfront and later converted to apartments. The entire proposal foresees improvements in housing, public facilities and transportation that would outlast the Games.
Transit. In New York City, of course, grand schemes often spark big squabbling. The state budget is now being held up by a fight over Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver's demand that more money be spent for a Second Avenue subway line. There is no question that the Second Avenue subway is a priority, but financing that line should not preclude bringing the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central or extending the No. 7 subway line to new West Side development.
Residential preservation. All these ideas for growth reinforce the city's responsibility to protect its neighborhoods. One initiative to accommodate construction of new apartments without destroying existing places is being put forward by the New York City Planning Commission under its chairman, Joseph Rose. It would revise the residential zoning code to encourage buildings on the scale of existing neighborhoods, and discourage blasting down existing street blocks for empty plazas and big towers like the one Donald Trump is constructing near the United Nations. This commendable proposal is going through a review with the city's community boards and should be adopted.
All these activities reflect New York's optimistic new spirit. Even in these affluent times, however, the public must spend its resources wisely. Recent proposals for Columbus Circle and a new Penn Station have proved that there still is a role for the government to facilitate and, in some cases, subsidize exciting new projects. The same attitude can create still more possibilities for the future. We intend to address the specifics of all these proposals in coming weeks. For now it is important to salute the promise of ideas for a new chapter in the constant journey of a city reinventing itself.
