HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Pinochet's Revenge: Oliver North, You'd Better Watch Out

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
IMAGINE that the year is 2005 and that Oliver North, the retired Marine lieutenant colonel and former National Security Council staff member in the Reagan White House, is on trial in Lebanon. He has been arrested while vacationing in Switzerland on an international murder warrant issued by Lebanon. The charge is that he helped direct the 1986 bombings of Libya that killed 31 people.
Libya had long sought his arrest, but in the end it was a Lebanese judge who obtained it, by joining the case and requesting that the Swiss authorities detain Mr. North and then extradite him to stand trial in Beirut on charges of crimes against humanity and aggression. 
 Imagine further that Mr. North is then convicted and the headline in one American newspaper roars: "Military Aide to Reagan Convicted of Murder for Official Act."
The events have not happened, of course, but international legal experts say that in the wake of the near-extradition of Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile to Spain, it is no longer so hard to imagine a situation in which a former high American official could be arrested while traveling and then tried in any foreign country, for crimes alleged to have been committed anywhere in the world.
Notwithstanding the notion, the likelihood that any nation would be so brazen is another matter. Issuing an indictment as a propaganda ploy is one thing; indeed, Libya has one out already on Mr. North. But these days, following through on it could subject the Libyans to far more than a writ of habeas corpus.
That is because a law of force still operates in the world, and it is not hard to imagine another set of headlines: "U.S. Demands Release of North; Economic Sanctions Threatened; Warships Maneuver."
Still, it is worth considering what might happen to someone like Mr. North when thinking about the recent rulings -- and precedents set -- in the Pinochet case by the British House of Lords. In 1998 General Pinochet, in London for medical treatment, was arrested after a judge in Spain issued an international warrant based on charges related to his actions while he was the leader of Chile. The Lords ruled that he was not immune from prosecution.
If the British home secretary, Jack Straw, had not freed General Pinochet earlier this year because of his deteriorating health, he would have had to face trial in Spain on charges of torture and political killings during his 17-year rule in Chile.
Widely praised by human rights organizations, the rulings have more quietly raised some eyebrows among former American officials who now wonder whether they too could some day be extradited -- let us say, if the United States lost its position as the world's sole superpower -- and tried any time any judge in the world accuses them of human rights violations.
In an interview, Mr. North said, "It limits my travel to certain countries."
It has some legal experts asking: Could Henry A. Kissinger be put on trial overseas as an architect of policy during the Vietnam War, which included bombings of Cambodian villages and intensive bombings of Hanoi?
What about President George Bush or his secretary of state, James A. Baker III? Could they be held responsible for deaths tied to economic sanctions related to the Persian Gulf war in Iraq? Or what about President Clinton? After he leaves office, could he face trial for the bombings of a factory in Sudan that was mistakenly believed to be a chemical weapons plant?
Some Congressional Republicans have argued against the expansion of international criminal courts, which they say could hamstring American leaders who fear being prosecuted after they leave office for official acts they committed. The legal rulings in the Pinochet case rejected an argument that the general was immune from prosecution by virtue of his official status, and legal experts say the case also expands the power to criminally prosecute certain human rights violations -- that occur anywhere -- to the courts of every nation.
"What we have done is restricted the travel opportunities for people like Henry Kissinger, Wesley Clark and Bill Clinton," said Michael Byers, a professor of international law at Duke University. "We have reduced their options in traveling to rogue states and their allies."
Robert Vieteretti, the managing director of Kroll Associates, the New York-based international security firm that provides personal protection, said his company is now much more concerned "with a country's laws, its alliances and anything our clients may have done to anger those nations."
Privately, some former American officials said that the F.B.I. has warned them not to travel to some countries, including some in Europe, where there is a risk of extradition to other nations interested in prosecuting them.
For now, Professor Byers says that former American officials do not need to worry "unless they are foolish enough to travel to some place like Iraq." Experts say that the reason is simple. If, as the saying goes, to the victor go the spoils, so too with history: the triumphant get to tell the story of what happened and to name the heroes, the pardonably mistaken and the villains when the conflict has ended.
"The political reality is that it is very remote," said Jonathan Charney, a law professor at Vanderbilt University and the editor of the American Journal of International Law. "Why? Because we are the superpower. It would be dangerous for another country to do that economically, politically and otherwise."
In an interview last week, Mr. Kissinger said he believed that the "very complicated" issues surrounding the Pinochet rulings needed further study. But he added that he was not concerned. "I don't think the well-known people are as much in danger," he said. "I certainly don't worry."
But Mr. North said that all it would take would be the slightest change in the political winds.
GENERAL PINOCHET was supported by the British when he was their ally in the war against Argentina over the Falkland Islands. "Here is this person who aided and abetted their cause, helped bring about democracy," Mr. North said. "And now because of this political sea change in Great Britain, now the country is going to turn him over to a third-party country to have him prosecuted. That's disgusting."
Patricia Derian, the first assistant secretary of state for human rights, said she could foresee the day when American officials would be prosecuted for acts similar to those that might be attributed to Mr. Baker, Mr. North or Mr. Kissinger.
"It is a stretch right now with the current rules of war and diplomacy, but I think it is going to come," said Ms. Derian, a Carter appointee. "It would be interesting to see what would happen if Kissinger went to Cambodia, or they just put out an international warrant for his arrest."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: MARCH 20-24;
Wall Street Shrugs Off Higher Rates Hike? No Problem

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
It was a winning week for both technology and industrial stocks after the Federal Reserve met Wall Street's expectations of a modest increase in interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average, adding to its recent gains, ended the week at 11,112.7, up 517.5 points. The Nasdaq composite index rose 164.9, to 4,963.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, meanwhile, moved into record territory every day last week, except Monday, ending at 1,527.46, up 62.99. 
 Investors have reached the conclusion that in time the economy will slow to a much more moderate, sustainable pace, a soft landing, " said Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist with the First Albany Corporation in Albany.
The Fed raised short-term rates an additional quarter-point last week, pushing up the key federal funds rate to 6 percent. It was the central bank's fourth rate increase since June.
Mr. Johnson said investors snapped up technology shares, taking advantage of a sharp decline in prices earlier this month. They're still not cheap, but they're about as good a bargain as you're going to get in the world of technology, he said. VIVIAN MARINO

HEADLINE: Business;
The United States, OPEC and Oil: A Snapshot

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
On Monday, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet to decide whether to open the oil tap and relieve the tight supply conditions that have driven up fuel prices worldwide.
The world oil market has become so integrated that the effects of its decisions would be felt in the United States even if it imported only 1 percent of its oil -- or even if it exported oil, in fact. But in industrial countries that export oil, like Britain, a price increase is a windfall for producers. For the United States, once a giant producer and now a giant importer, higher prices mean exporting more money. 
 The phenomenon is more pronounced today, because more than half the country's oil needs are met by imports; the figure was only one-third at the time of the oil shocks of 1974 and 1979.
 Most of the oil that the United States imports comes from the Western Hemisphere, not the politically turbulent Middle East. But another effect of global integration is that an interruption in pumping anywhere is an interruption everywhere -- that is, a disruption from any producing nation would be felt by all importers. MATTHEW L. WALD

HEADLINE: Mysterious Force Attacks Small Western Tribe's Young in the Womb

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SHOALWATER BAY INDIAN RESERVATION, Wash.

 BODY:
The tiny tribe that lives here on a wind-battered, rain-swept spit of land hard by the Pacific Ocean knows something about fighting for survival.
Members of the Shoalwater tribe fight the heavy erosion that over the decades has eaten more than half of the one-square-mile reservation created in 1866 when President Andrew Johnson signed an executive order removing the tribe from nearby villages. And they fight for economic survival, their latest battle a feud with federal marshals over the number and type of slot machines they may keep at a casino that is their main source of income. 
 But the most difficult battle is for the women who live here, who are up against an unseen foe, a killer that seems to come and go over the years, though no one can even prove it exists. For some reason, it is frighteningly difficult to give birth to a living child here.
The worst year was 1998, when all but one of nine known pregnancies on the reservation ended in a miscarriage or stillbirth. Since then, eight pregnancies have lasted 12 weeks or longer, and half of them have ended in miscarriage.
"You look around the village and you start asking yourself, 'Where are the children?' " said Lisa Shipman, who had a stillborn son in 1990 and whose sister-in-law, Vernita Norman, has miscarried three times and recently left the reservation, in fear, when she became pregnant.
Mrs. Shipman and her husband, Michael, finally had happy news last April when a healthy daughter, Kaylee, was born. "This was everybody's pregnancy," she said. "She is the community baby. Everybody dotes on her. But you still wonder, where are all the others? Where is the next generation coming from?"
It is a question that neither tribal leaders nor federal investigators can answer for sure. The national Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, called in after the 1998 calamity to study the alarmingly high rate of fetal deaths, issued a report this year that confirmed the fears of the tribe, one of the smallest, with 204 members, and poorest in the West.
The agency's study pegged the miscarriage rate after an established pregnancy at 50 percent to 67 percent, roughly three to four times the expected rate. But while such a cluster of health afflictions is disturbing, the study cautioned that it was dealing with such a statistically small sample that a definitive problem could not be proved -- nor, as is the case with other federal studies here, did it find a cause.
The killer could be lurking in the environment. Pesticides are routinely sprayed on cranberry bogs north of the reservation, on forestland to the east, and even into Willapa Bay, to control parasites that attack the oysters that are a big industry.
It could be a genetic flaw, though marriage among tribal members is rare and several of the miscarriages have been experienced by nontribal women married to Shoalwater men. It could stem from poverty and poor diet. Alcohol or drug abuse are often a factor in miscarriages, but the federal study found no evidence of either problem here.
And several women on the reservation talked of the meticulous care they took during their pregnancies, down to drinking bottled water and even avoiding any food grown here or plucked from the nearby sea. Still, there were miscarriages.
And, of course, it could be just an awful run of chance, though no one seems to believe that is the case.
"It would almost be easier to take if it was just a random occurrence, just a stretch of terrible luck," said Gale Taylor, the tribal health director, a non-Indian who had a miscarriage. "That would be nice because you think, well, it could stop. The fact of the matter is, though, every day I'm waiting for the other shoe to drop. One month here, we lost four pregnancies. It was like a war zone."
The tribal chairman, Herbert Madzu Whitish, who also owns a convenience store on the reservation, said he was frustrated by the lack of answers and worried about both "the generation that is missing here" and the women on the reservation who wanted to bear children.
"A lot of people are afraid of pregnancy," Mr. Whitish said. "Instead of it being the most joyous time of their lives, it's like they're on pins and needles, worrying that something is going to happen."
The tribe concluded there was a serious problem when its records showed that from 1988 to 1992, at least 10 of 19 pregnancies had ended in miscarriage or stillbirth. The miscarriage mystery has only been compounded, Ms. Taylor said, by the fact that those babies who have been born are generally healty.
A clinic was built, largely with federal dollars, to provide more immediate care and monitoring of pregnancies. State and federal environmental reports found high levels of three pesticides in the drainage areas of the cranberry bogs, but did not find the tribe's drinking water to be unsafe.
The problem slipped from public attention when the tribe had several healthy births from 1993 to 1996; by 1998, though, the level of miscarriage was at its highest in memory, and the fear returned.
"I did everything I thought I could possibly do to have a healthy baby," said Kim Zillyett, the business manager at the tribal clinic here, who has miscarried twice in the last two years and is expecting a baby in May -- an event she alternately views with joy and worry.
"It's not over till he's out," Ms. Zillyett said, referring to a boy whom she and her husband plan to name Teegan, an Irish name they found in a baby book. "It's not over until he's here and he's healthy."
The tribe, which was created a century and a half ago when several bands of Lower Columbia Chinook Indians were put together after refusing to sign a treaty with the United States government and live on a reservation with the rival Chehalis Tribe, "is not going down without a fight," Mr. Whitish said.
It has applied for federal money for more extensive environmental testing of reservation land and greater monitoring of all pregnancies. It has an extensive grief-counseling program, including a series of art projects in the log-frame tribal center here that allows the Shoalwaters to express grief over the tribe's mysterious affliction.
"These people are survivors," said Dr. Kristen M. Swanson, a professor of family and child nursing at the University of Washington, an expert on dealing with miscarriage who has been invited by the tribal council to study the community's response to the miscarriages.
"They've had a lot that they've had to survive," Dr. Swanson added. "And the chairman has been very clear whenever I've met with him that they will do all they can to get through this. In a lot of ways you have to stand in admiration as to how the tribe has not let this roll over them. They've gone to the Centers for Disease Control, they've gone to the universities, they've gone to the Indian Health Service, they're fighting for what they need."
And yet there remains enormous frustration that no one has a clear answer for why the problem has arisen. "When the recent report came out, I was glad that, yes, they recognized there were significant problems," Mr. Whitish said. "But they didn't offer much in the way of any kind of answers. I guess I got caught up in the TV version. I thought the investigators could ride in here and give us the answer."
Ms. Taylor, the tribal health director, is also dismayed that she cannot give certain answers when women ask how to improve their chances of a healthy pregnancy.
"When you have to tell people that maybe the water they drink is the cause, or just walking on the beach is a cause, or that maybe there's no cause at all, that's frightening," she said. "A lot of women feel, if you want to stay pregnant, get the hell out of the reservation. It's hard. We're losing our land on one side, and we're losing our babies on the other. It's not a great way to live."

HEADLINE: Deep Political and Religious Rifts Disrupt the Harmony of Nigerian Towns

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: ABA, Nigeria

 BODY:
In a corner of this city in Nigeria's Christian heartland, where every other car seems to affirm the driver's love for Jesus, Muslim migrants from the north had managed to become landowners.
The corner was known as Ama Hausa, or gathering place of the Hausa, who make up one of the country's three main ethnic groups, along with the Igbo and Yoruba. But after Igbo rioters destroyed this street corner in Nigeria's recent religious conflicts, graffiti scrawled on a wall of the gutted mosque reclaimed the land: Ama Igbo. 
 Thousands of Hausa have since packed up their belongings and left for the north. Many headed to Sokoto, at the country's geographic and cultural opposite end, where a similar exodus was taking place.
In Sokoto, the historic site from which a Muslim holy war succeeded in spreading the religion through West Africa two centuries ago, many Igbo were seen at the main bus station scrambling to buy the $15 tickets that would take them back to Aba and other cities in southeastern Nigeria.
Nigeria's recent politically driven religious conflicts have claimed hundreds, perhaps thousands, of lives and destroyed countless churches, mosques and houses. President Olusegun Obasanjo has described these clashes as attempts to undermine the nation's 10-month-old democracy, and many Nigerians from different parts of the country agree that several states' attempts to introduce Shariah, the Islamic penal and social code, have more to do with politics than religion.
But the conflicts are rooted in all-too-real hatreds and divisions, like the abyss between Sokoto and Aba. These hatreds and divisions are staggeringly complex, fueled by the misrule and corruption that have left most residents of one of the world's top oil producers in poverty. What is more, these rifts have been encouraged and exploited by the country's rulers, from the British to the military governments to the European and American oil companies that pump crude in the Niger delta, an area largely abandoned by the federal government.
Heaps of garbage, some of it on fire, littered the main road in Aba on a recent day. The garbage contractor had been dismissed for corruption, and a new contract had yet to be awarded. Nationwide, the unreliable national electricity system collapsed recently, plunging the Nigerians who could not afford generators into darkness and forcing Mr. Obasanjo to declare an emergency.
As Igbo were killed in the north and thousands returned here, the events recalled those leading up to the civil war of Biafra. Three decades ago, following massacres of Igbo in the north, the ethnic group tried to secede from the rest of Nigeria. The war was one of the most brutal in Africa's postindependence history -- a million died -- but a successful postwar reunification policy knitted greater ties among Nigerians. With the recent surge in hatreds, it is unclear whether those ties are stronger than the divisions.
"I cried when I heard what had happened to my people," the Rev. Prince Benny James, 29, an Igbo and associate pastor at the Living Church here in Aba, said of the recent killings of Igbo in the north.
Over the course of reprisal attacks against Muslim Hausa in Aba, Mr. James sheltered 10 Hausa who escaped eventually. But on the first morning, Mr. James said he was present at an attack against some Hausa. He did not participate, he said.
"But somehow I was happy these things were being done to them," he said. "In my heart, I was saying: 'Yes, do that to them! Go ahead! Go ahead! Right!' I gave my support by being there. If I had not enjoyed it, I would have returned to my house."
The locals began attacking the Hausa after corpses of Igbo killed in the north were brought back to Aba. But what began as a battle between Muslims and Christians in the north became an ethnic witch hunt here, as Igbo searched for anyone who might be a northerner.
At Mr. James's Living Church, the security guard, Andy Petei, 25, hid in a hole under the altar for three days after some youths came looking for him. Neither Muslim nor Hausa, Mr. Petei is a member of an ethnic minority from a north central state. He had nevertheless become a target because he was from the north.
"Some people said I may be Hausa," said Mr. Petei, a Christian. Religion is one of the great fault lines in Nigeria, an ambitious creation of British colonialists. Ethnicity is another. But Nigeria's divisions are so treacherous because the cleavages can shift from one region to another, from one day to another.
Almost all Igbo are Christian; almost all Hausa are Muslim. The Yoruba, on the other hand, are divided almost evenly between Muslim and Christian. And yet the Islam practiced by the Yoruba is a much more easygoing variety than that practiced by the Hausa.
"For the Hausa, Islam is a total way of living," said Julius Okolo, an Igbo and professor of political science at Usman dan Fodio University in Sokoto. "For the Yoruba, it's not a total way of living. The cultural aspects of the Yoruba are stronger than religion, whether it's Christianity or Islam."
Indeed, Yoruba Christians and Muslims marry each other without a second thought. It is not unusual for Yoruba to have members of both faiths in their families; some even practice both religions.
But among northerners, being a Christian Hausa, a closely related ethnic group, is considered a contradiction in terms.
"We're seen as people who have sold out," said Emman Usman Shehu, who heads an organization for Christians in Sokoto. "In the north, once we have left Islam, where the political, social and economic aspects are all tied up, we become classless citizens."
In Lagos, the commercial capital in the Yoruba southwest, deadly clashes between Yoruba and Hausa have occurred in recent months. But in the recent riots in the northern city of Kaduna, some Yoruba seemed to have escaped injury because of their religion or ethnicity.
Suraj Najimu, an 18-year-old student and a Yoruba Muslim, said he was surrounded by a group of Hausa youths ready to assault him. "But after I recited some Koranic passages, they let me go," he said.
On a Muslim street in the predominantly Christian slum of Kaduna, Christians destroyed all the houses except a few belonging to Yoruba. Most of the Yoruba were Christian. But even one who is Muslim, Shehu Garba, was spared, apparently because in this particular instance, ethnicity was more important than religion.
President Obasanjo has said that he wants to avoid taking the issue of Shariah to the Supreme Court, which would rule clearly on the matter. A political solution, he said, "will end up without any victor or vanquished."
"No victor, no vanquished" was the slogan adopted to reunite Nigerians after the Biafran civil war -- a policy regarded by many historians as one of the most successful reconciliation attempts in recent history. And indeed, over the years, despite all of Nigeria's fissures, the country has grown more interdependent.
The building of more roads, increasing urbanization and economic exchanges have all pushed ever more Nigerians to leave their historic home regions for other parts. Many of these Nigerians fell victim to the recent violence.
Mr. James, the associate pastor here, said he personally knew a Hausa man who was killed here. "He was married to an Igbo woman," he said.

HEADLINE: OPEC Gives Scant Signs That Oil Flow Will Increase

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 25

 BODY:
Despite unusually public pleas by the Clinton Administration for relief from high oil prices, there were few signs of support for a big increase in oil production as ministers from petroleum-exporting countries arrived here today for crucial meetings.
Two days before the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to consider an increase in output, members of the eleven-nation cartel remained divided and were girding for grueling negotiations throughout the weekend. 
 "I think it is too early to decide now," said Obaid bin Saif Al-Nasseri, the United Arab Emirates' oil minister, as he entered his hotel early this afternoon. "We have not discussed all the possibilities and all the options. My recommendation is to wait for some time."
Still amazed themselves by the extraordinary roller coaster in oil prices, from $11 a barrel one year ago to $34 three weeks ago and now back to about $28, many oil ministers are adamantly against moves that would trigger yet another plunge.
"I am worried about a decline in demand," said Chakib Khelil, the oil minister of Algeria, one of the more hawkish members of OPEC. "I am not sure we need an increase."But, he added, "if there is a consensus, we will support it."
As in the past, the most important disagreements are between Saudi Arabia and Iran, the two largest producers within OPEC. Saudi officials have been pushing for an increase in production of between one million and 1.5 million barrels a day.
Iran has repeatedly argued for much smaller increases, and its position has hardened as oil prices have retreated from their recent highs.
Iran has also lashed out at the United States, where Congressional lawmakers are pushing for sanctions against OPEC countries and whose Secretary of Energy, Bill Richardson, has lobbied OPEC producers on a whirlwind tour.
"OPEC should not opt for a big increase under political pressure," said Iran's oil minister, Bijan Zangeneh, on his country's state radio before departing for Vienna today.
Warning that a rash increase could lead to a "catastrophe," Mr. Zangeneh said OPEC nations "must move with the market and seek stability. We hope OPEC will make a decision based on economic justifications, not political."
Even boosting production by one million to 1.5 million barrels a daywould not necessarily have much impact on oil prices. Analysts say the crucial question is whether the increase comes on top of or merely substitutes for the cheating on oil quotas that is already taking place.
Industry analysts estimate that OPEC countries and the four nations that joined in the production cuts one year ago -- Mexico, Russia, Oman and Norway -- are already overshooting their target of 23 million barrels a day by about one million barrels.
If OPEC leaders agree to increase quotas by 1.5 million barrels but clamp down on cheating, the net effect would be negligible.
Even if the increase comes on top of the current over-production, most analysts believe the impact on oil prices were be modest and the reduction in gasoline prices could be no more than a few pennies a gallon.
Philip Verleger, a veteran oil economist at the Brattle Group in Newport Beach, Ca., noted that inventories of crude oil have declined to dangerous new lows at the same time that an acceleration in global economic growth is expected to increase demand.
The International Energy Agency, a research agency in Paris funded by oil-consuming countries, has predicted that worldwide demand for oil will climb by 4 million barrels a day, to 75 million, between now and December.
If worldwide inventories are not re-stocked, Mr. Verleger argued, consuming nations could find themselves under increasing pressure to turn to Iraq. Iraq, which remains under United Nations sanctions, is currently allowed to produce as much as it can under tight restriction on what it is supposed to buy with the revenue.
"If we don't increase inventories now, we may need Iraq's oil by Christmas," Mr. Verleger said.
But even non-OPEC countries are extremely worried that any big increase in production will send prices plunging back to the levels of a year ago -- $11 a barrel.
Olav Akselsen, Norway's oil minister politely rebuffed Mr. Richardson on Thursday after meeting with the American energy secretary in Oslo.
Although he acknowledged the need for some sort of increase, Mr. Akselsen said Norway did not support rolling back all of the production cuts that sent oil prices rising.
"Total suspension of today's production regulations will have a negative impact on the market and work against price stability," Mr. Akselsen said."Both too high and too low oil prices will lead to more instability."

HEADLINE: For Giuliani and City Council, Priorities Clash in a Battle of the Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
The bottom line figures are only 1 percent apart, but the $37 billion budget packages that have been served up by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council make clear the competing priorities -- and politics -- that divide the two wings at City Hall.
The Council's $37.2 billion spending plan, released last week, would direct income-tax cuts toward the middle class and the poor. The Council also proposes new tax credits for people 65 and older and working parents. On the spending side, it would add money to help defend tenants facing eviction, to expand library hours and book collections and to retrain city police officers. 
 The mayor's $36.8 billion spending plan calls for an income-tax cut that is about the same size as the Council's, but more than half of the money would go to the 13 percent of city taxpayers who make more than $125,000 a year. Mr. Giuliani, as in past years, has advocated cutting the library, parks and cultural budgets. His spending initiatives are directed at intensifying the police crackdown on aggressive driving and youth gangs and at hiring school safety officers. He also wants to offer some parents vouchers to send their children to private or parochial schools.
Council leaders call their budget proposal a step forward for the middle class. They say that if the city does not take steps to reduce the tax burden on the middle class, New York City will eventually become a city dominated by the wealthy and the poor as more moderate-income residents are forced to move out. They contend that the spending changes are essential to maintain the quality of life in New York.
"Anyone who uses a New York City public library, visits one of New York City's great cultural institutions, raises a child in New York City, pays taxes in New York City or has lost faith in the New York City Police Department will find our budget a welcome document," Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said.
The Giuliani administration says the Democratic-controlled Council is overestimating how much tax revenue the city will raise in the coming year. The projected figure is essential to the Council's plan to restore $159 million in program cuts advocated by Mr. Giuliani and to add $196 million in new programs, like hot weekend meals for the elderly.
"It is indicative of a philosophy," Deputy Mayor Robert M. Harding said. "Their approach is to be overly optimistic, and then they have to worry about the consequences about being overly optimistic."
The new budget does not go into effect until July 1, so the mayor and the Council have until June to resolve their differences. The next step is up to the mayor; in April, he must deliver a final budget proposal. Ultimately, compared with some past budget disagreements when the economy was not so flush, the differences between the mayor and Council this year are not that extreme.
Charles Brecher, research director at the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent fiscal monitor, noted that although the details still had to be resolved, both the Council and the mayor supported several major tax cuts in principal.
Both sides want to eliminate the 14 percent surcharge on the personal income tax imposed in 1991, a cut that will save taxpayers about $800 million once it is fully in place in 2002. They also both want to reduce and gradually eliminate the commercial rent tax, a levy that few, if any, other cities impose. The mayor and the Council also are both supporting a plan to rebate part of the unincorporated business tax, paid by people who are self-employed or work for law, accounting, advertising or other types of partnerships.
"All of those taxes contribute to the drag in competitiveness of the New York economy," Mr. Brecher said. "Getting rid of them should help further stimulate job growth in the city."
But even within these areas of agreement, differences pop up that point to the competing agendas.
Under the mayor's income-tax cut, all taxpayers would get the same percentage tax break, meaning the 14 percent surcharge would be wiped off every taxpayer's bill. For a filer earning $60,000 to $70,000 a year, the average savings would $230. Because the most affluent city residents pay much more in taxes, their savings would also be much higher. For example, taxpayers who earn $1 million or more make up only 0.8 percent of the filers, but would reap 27 percent of the savings, or an average of $14,856 a year.
The Council wants to restructure the tax rates so the savings would be weighted more to the middle and lower-income classes, meaning a taxpayer with an income of $40,000 to $50,000 would see a decrease of nearly 20 percent in the personal income tax bill, while those earning $1 million or more would see just a 2.9 percent drop. This plan would give those earning $1 million or more a smaller tax cut, averaging $3,401.
There is a similar distinction in the proposed reduction of the commercial rent tax and the unincorporated business tax. The mayor wants to cut the rent tax for every business that pays it, but the Council wants to direct the cut to smaller businesses that pay less in rent. The Council plan would give a rebate on the unincorporated business tax only to resident taxpayers with incomes of less than $150,000, while the mayor would provide the rate cut regardless of income and place of residence.
The proposals that would benefit older New Yorkers and working parents also reflect this split. The Council has proposed a tax credit for taxpayers 65 or older with a household income of $50,000 or less who live in rental units. The average credit would be $64 a year, costing the city about $19.2 million in the next fiscal year. To help working parents pay for child care, the Council wants to offer a tax credit worth as much as $96 or $492 a year, depending on a family's income, costing the city a total of about $25 million. The mayor has so far not backed either of these plans.
The deciding factor for many Council plans may be the final revenue estimates, which the mayor by law has the power to establish. The Council is estimating that the city will have about $1.2 billion more in available money next year than the mayor has predicted, mostly from higher tax revenue. Mr. Harding said that the Giuliani administration must decide whether to revise its revenue estimates before negotiations can formally begin. But he said he does not support restructuring the personal income tax rates as the Council has proposed.
Legislative approval from Albany is required for the tax changes, and officials there have made it clear that any changes must be supported by both the mayor and the Council.

HEADLINE: DaimlerChrysler Nears Deal To Buy 33.4% of Mitsubishi

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
In another big move toward the global consolidation of the automobile industry, DaimlerChrysler of Germany is to announce a deal tomorrow to acquire 33.4 percent of Japan's Mitsubishi Motors for about $1.3 billion, people close to the companies said yesterday.
The deal would make DaimlerChrysler the world's third-largest automaker, behind General Motors and Ford. All three will now have large shares of the three main markets: Western Europe, Japan and the United States. The other giants of the auto industry, Volkswagen, Toyota, Honda and the Renault-Nissan alliance, still are weak in at least one of these markets. 
 The agreement also marks the second time in the past year that a Japanese carmaker has ceded management control to a foreign competitor. Renault of France acquired a 36.8 percent stake last year in Nissan Motors. If the DaimlerChrysler-Mitsubishi deal is completed, Japan would be left with only two major independent car companies -- Toyota and Honda -- with the rest partly or entirely under the control of western manufacturers.
Mitsubishi has been in financial distress and is saddled with about $16 billion in debt. And though it has a presence in Southeast Asia as well as Japan, the company has only 2.3 percent of the Japanese market. Mitsubishi had been sought a partnership to shore up its capital position in the face of brutal worldwide competition in the market for small and medium-sized cars.
The Mitsubishi stake would give DaimlerChrysler the right to name several members of Mitsubishi's board and veto power over major decisions. And because the German-American carmaker would provide a crucial capital infusion, it expects to have the leverage to hammer out a strategy to bolster the two companies' presence in Asia and in the small-car market worldwide.
But the move poses plenty of risks for DaimlerChrysler. The automaker has already seen its stock pushed down in the past year, partly because of investor fears about the financial drain of taking command of a small-car producer and concerns about the lower profit margins of small cars in comparison with DaimlerChrysler's core businesses -- Mercedes-Benz luxury cars and Chrysler sport utility vehicles, light trucks and mid-sized American family cars.
People close to the talks between the two companies said Katsuhiko Kawasoe, president of Mitsubishi, was in Frankfurt yesterday to sign a letter of intent with Jurgen E. Schrempp, chairman of DaimlerChrysler.
Under the deal, DaimlerChrysler will take no stake in Mitsubishi's truck business, of which Volvo of Sweden owns 19 percent.
Cultural differences are often the biggest barrier to international auto mergers. But DaimlerChrysler and Mitsubishi may have an advantage, because Chrysler and Mitsubishi have worked together closely for many years. Mitsubishi makes the Dodge Avenger and Chrysler Sebring coupes for DaimlerChrysler at a factory in Normal, Ill.
For Mr. Schrempp of DaimlerChrysler, the Mitsubushi deal would appear to finally satisfy a goal he has had since engineering the takeover of Chrysler two years ago: to gain a major presence in Asia.
Though the Asian car market has been in disastrous shape for the last several years, thanks to the lingering effects of the financial crises in Southeast Asia and Japan's intractable recession, industry experts still believe it will be one of the biggest sources of growth in years ahead.
At one point last year, Mr. Schrempp was in advanced negotiations to acquire a stake in Nissan and was competing against overtures by Renault.
But after Daimler executives scrutinized Nissan's enormous financial and structural problems, Mr. Schrempp bowed out of the talks and Renault ultimately struck a deal with Nissan instead.
People close to Daimler said yesterday that Mitsubishi brings with it some good technology, including in the highly competitive area of direct-fuel injection diesel engines.
Mitsubishi also owns a stake in Proton, the Malaysian automobile company, and that stake in turn could give DaimlerChrysler improved access to the Southeast Asian market.

HEADLINE: Race Draws Unexpected Attention

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
A special election for a State Senate seat, especially one that comes just a few weeks after a high-profile presidential primary, rarely draws much attention. And if one candidate is a Democrat in a heavily Democratic district who has also been endorsed by the Republican, Conservative and Working Families Parties, the race would seem a sure bet for obscurity.
But not this race. Politicians and voters in a wide swath of southeastern Queens are paying close attention to the vote this Tuesday in the 10th Senate District because the Liberal Party candidate, Andrew Jenkins, is a convicted felon who is seeking to reclaim the very Senate seat he held for eight years and was expelled from in disgrace in 1990. 
 The race is a special election to fill the seat vacated by Alton R. Waldon Jr., a Democrat who Gov. George E. Pataki nominated for a judgeship on the State Court of Claims last summer and was confirmed by the Senate in December. Mr. Jenkins, an administrator at York College, is running against the Democratic candidate, Malcolm A. Smith, a real estate developer.
Mr. Jenkins was a well known politician in the district, which spans Cambria Heights and Hollis to the Rockaway Peninsula. But his incumbency came to an abrupt end 10 years ago when he was convicted on charges stemming from an F.B.I. sting in which he agreed to launder $150,000 in cash through a bank in Zaire. He was expelled from the Senate and served a year in prison.
Mr. Jenkins, 58, said voters would view his past legal problems as old news and most would recognize that the charges against him had been politically motivated and that he was innocent of the crime. Meanwhile, he said, his campaign has focused on the need for more housing for middle- and lower-income people and enhanced employment opportunities for people in the district. "The economy has improved, yet we are seeing high unemployment in the district," he said. "There is nowhere for our young people to find work."
Mr. Jenkins is inclined to talk about his achievements when he was in the Senate and the Assembly, where he held a seat in the early 1980's. He mentioned the work he did in bringing suits more than a decade ago to create districts that would be carved to include more black and Hispanic residents.
"I talk to people about the issues they care about," Mr. Jenkins said. "I talk about police brutality -- I was one of the first people to hold hearings on police brutality when I was in the Senate."
Mr. Smith, 43, said that in his campaign appearances, he has found that "the issues are education and economic development."
He added that he saw his endorsement by so many parties as a sign that he could forge relationships across broad ideological lines and that he would be an effective member of a Republican-controlled Senate. ' "I want to be viewed as someone who can bring people together," he said.
Mr. Smith has been closely affiliated over the years with several Queens politicians. Most recently, he managed the district office of the Rev. Floyd H. Flake while Mr. Flake was a United States Representative for the area.
Before that, he was chief of staff to City Councilman Archie Spigner. And in addition to being endorsed by the Republican, Conservative and Working Families Parties, Mr. Smith has secured the endorsement of nearly every politician in the southeast Queens community.
Tuesday's race will be Mr. Smith's third attempt at elected office.
He ran unsuccessfully for the same Senate seat after Mr. Jenkins's conviction in 1990 and in the following year lost a Democratic primary for City Council to Juanita E. Watkins.
While most politicians in the area expect Mr. Smith to prevail easily, he cautioned that anything could occur in a special election because turnout is typically low and the race is largely determined by the candidate that better organizes his core supports.
"This is a serious race," Mr. Smith said. "Andrew Jenkins is a former senator, and his name recognition is still out there. He has been out there and has been elected to office before, and I haven't. So for me, it's a very serious race."
Mr. Jenkins acknowledges that he is facing a difficult contest. "It's always a tough race when you're not the organization's choice," he said. "But I think that the people are smart enough to vote for the person and not the party."

HEADLINE: In a Replica of a Famed Slave Ship, Lessons From the Past

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: MYSTIC, Conn., March 25

 BODY:
A hand-built replica of the Cuban schooner Amistad, whose cargo of rebellious African slaves galvanized pre-Civil War abolitionists and made the ship an enduring symbol of freedom's triumph, was launched with great fanfare into the Mystic River today.
The vessel, reconstructed with painstaking attention to historic detail -- from the golden eagle figurehead on the bow, along its sleek black hull with a single white stripe, to the elegant lettering on its transom -- will be used as a floating classroom, traveling from port to port to teach the Amistad story. 
 More than 7,000 people attended today's festivities at Mystic Seaport, home to the nation's largest maritime museum and the shipyard where the Amistad was built over the last two years. Scores more spectators dotted the Mystic River in a colorful array of canoes, kayaks and other small craft.
"Today we have an opportunity to see a piece of history that has been recreated," Lt. Gov. Jodi Rell said at a ceremony that was punctuated by the music of traditional African drummers. "We are proud of the role Amistad will play in history not only today but for generations to come."
Shortly after 12:30 p.m., the launching ceremony began with the tolling of a bell 53 times in honor of each of the captives held on the Amistad. A ceremonial chain was cut, a bottle of water broken across the bow and six white doves released.
Then, with the push of a button, automated winches lowered the lift-dock holding the Amistad into the water. As it reached a depth of 10 feet, the wooden ship, flying the American flag but still without masts or sails, floated free, and the crowd erupted in loud cheers and applause. The HMS Rose, a tall ship anchored nearby, fired its cannons.
There was no such ceremony when the original Amistad entered Connecticut waters 161 years ago, carrying a cargo of slaves who had been kidnapped in Africa and sold at auction in Havana. Seized by a Navy brig off Long Island, the Amistad was towed to shore in New London, Conn.
The slaves, in a mutiny, had killed the ship's captain and chef but failed in an effort to return to their homeland in what is now Sierra Leone in West Africa. After 63 days at sea, they were charged with murder and jailed in New Haven, where they waited for American courts to consider their fate.
President Martin Van Buren hoped to extradite the prisoners to Cuba, where they would have been enslaved once again. But abolitionists took up the Africans' cause and organized a defense that eventually led to John Quincy Adams, the former president, arguing their case before the United States Supreme Court.
In March 1841, three years after the ship's capture, the court ruled that the Africans had been kidnapped illegally and ordered them freed. The 35 survivors eventually returned to their homeland, their saga fixed in American history.
The idea of recreating the Amistad grew out of a parade of tall ships in New York Harbor to celebrate the American bicentennial in 1976. The parade included a ship that had been temporarily renamed Amistad, which caught the attention of Warren Q. Marr II, then editor of Crisis, a journal of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
His interest led to the creation of Amistad America, a nonprofit educational foundation formed in 1996 to recreate the Amistad. The project also got a huge lift in publicity and interest from the 1997 Steven Spielberg movie "Amistad."
Construction of the $3.1 million replica, paid for by corporate sponsors and a $2.5 million grant from the State of Connecticut, began in March 1998 under the direction of Quentin T. Snediker, a captain and master shipwright.
Mr. Snediker, who has the look of a classic seaman, with a white beard and denim sleeves rolled up to expose an anchor tattooed on his left forearm, led the research into the details of the original Amistad that had been little noticed by historians interested in the ship's story, not its nautical design.
A research team scoured the National Archives and other historical repositories throughout New England. A treasure trove of information came from documents related to the sale of the ship after the court case was resolved, including details about the sails, rigging and fastenings.
In guiding visitors around the new ship, Mr. Snediker stresses that Amistad was a workaday cargo schooner, not one of the infamous Middle Passage slave ships that carried captives from Africa to the Americas. This, he points out, is one of the historical lessons to be taught about slavery in America.
"Amistad was just a freight vessel," he said. "But still she was so embroiled in this international incident that it shows how the whole economy was based on the labor of enslaved people. Every aspect of New World life was in some way complicit. Part of her power will be to help people understand the complexities of the past and how they continue to manifest in some of the issues of racism that we still face."
Mr. Snediker is also careful to point out that hidden behind the 85-foot ship's historic facade are all of the amenities of large modern sailing ships, including two 135-horsepower engines for auxiliary power and state-of-the-art navigational instruments. It meets all Coast Guard safety requirements.
When it is fully equipped to sail -- the masts and rigging will be installed by mid-April -- the Amistad will weigh about 136 tons. It includes 150,000 board feet of wood, including African iroko that was donated by Sierra Leone, and will feature 50 tons of ballast and 5,000 square feet of sail. The Amistad's inaugural voyage will be to New York Harbor to join a parade of tall ships called OpSail2000, July 3 to 9.
The ship, which is owned by Amistad America, will have its home port in New Haven, which is the reason for one of the visible differences between the reconstruction and the original. Regulations require a ship's home port to be printed on its transom, so the new ship has "New Haven" where the original showed "Principe," for Puerto Principe, its home port in Cuba.
Under an agreement with the state, it will spend half the year in Connecticut waters and the other half traveling. It will have classrooms as well as accommodations for overnight passengers. Captain Bill Pinkney, a yachtsman who in the early 90's was the first black man to make a solo trip around the globe, will be at the helm.
In the ceremony's keynote address, Samuel H. Pieh of Tennessee, a descendant of Sengbe Pieh, the slave known as Cinque who led the Amistad mutiny, told the crowd that the ship should be a symbol to combat the racism that still pervades society. "The same motivation that led people to enslave my ancestors are the same motivations today that are plaguing America and the world," he said. "We still have those kinds of leaders who will ignore the average man, the average woman, who will ignore the great strength in our diversity."
Other featured guests included the actors Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, and the Sierra Leone ambassador, John E. Leigh. Several praised the multiracial cooperation on the Amistad project, noting that the ship's name means friendship in Spanish.
Before today's ceremonial events, Elaine Warmsley of Middletown, Conn., a ninth-generation descendant of slaves, walked up the steps on the lift-dock and ran her hand over the Amistad's wooden rails, then looked up at the sky in a moment of prayer. "I hope it's really a learning tool," she said afterward. "People need to know. People need to see."

HEADLINE: Companies Try Dipping Deeper Into Labor Pool

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
Unable to find enough workers in the booming economy, American corporations are trying to expand the labor pool.
Until recently, employers had met their labor needs by hiring people who were already employed or at least wanted to work. But as this pool shrinks, they are increasingly recruiting from among the 36 million working-age people in the United States who had not sought a job, or even thought about taking one. 
 Conrad Bell is one of these new workers. Mr. Bell, a college junior, did not need a job. Living at home, he had enough pocket money, and the first payments on his school loans were still in the future. But when a notice went up on a campus bulletin board that H & R Block was hiring students skilled in computers to trouble-shoot problems called in from Block offices around the country, Mr. Bell applied and got one of the jobs. "Most of my friends now work," he explained.
The company has gone out of its way to accommodate the 23-year-old student, juggling schedules so that he can carry four courses at the DeVry Institute of Technology and still work 25 hours a week. Between semesters, he worked on Tuesdays, then switched to Mondays to attend Tuesday classes. Nearly 200 other students hired for the tax season get similar flexible treatment at Block's new technical center here.
In addition to students like Mr. Bell, companies are stepping up recruiting of the urban poor, retirees, homemakers, men and women mustering out of military service, the handicapped, women coming off welfare and illegal immigrants not already counted in the labor force. People with jobs are being recruited to moonlight in second jobs, and part-timers are adding hours more easily than in the past. To get workers, some companies even relocate to pockets of relatively high unemployment.
The recruiting poster and the promise of flexible hours were what landed Mr. Bell despite his mother's resistance. "She does not want me to work while I'm in school," he said. Aside from flexible hours, companies are offering subsidized transportation, child care, store discounts, free meals, family outings, tuition subsidies, and, in one case here, an $80,000 softball field -- everything, but significantly higher pay.
"We really are in uncharted territory," said Lawrence Katz, a labor economist at Harvard University. "The last time we had such tight labor markets, in the 1960's, the baby boomers were beginning to take jobs, and they fed the labor pool. We don't have them today, and we really don't know how many people we can draw."
The economy may ride, or fall, on the answer. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, argues that the pool of people still available to take jobs has dwindled to the point that employers will have to pay higher wages to compete for workers and then will push up prices to cover the higher labor costs. Citing this inflationary danger as one reason for their actions, the Fed's policy makers have moved interest rates up a quarter percentage point five times since last June to slow the economy, with the latest increase coming last Tuesday.
But Mr. Greenspan's estimate of the number of people still available for jobs relies on the Labor Department's monthly employment surveys, which do not count as available the people who say they are not interested in working. Many of these people are now being recruited, including Mr. Bell, who was busy being a student until he saw the H & R Block poster and popped into the labor force. In addition, the Fed chairman's concerns about inflationary labor shortages do not reflect the extent to which workers are settling for intangible benefits, rather than higher wages.
Certainly inflationary wage increases are not evident in national wage statistics or in the Kansas City metropolitan area, where the unemployment rate of 3.2 percent is nearly a percentage point less than the nation's 4.1 percent and employers are offering all the new lures, short of big raises.
That is especially the case at Block's recently opened technology center. A quarter of the 800 people working there in the tax season are students like Mr. Bell, who is earning $11.54 an hour, barely up from last year's rate. Another 200 are low-skilled customer call-center operators, some of whom commute by municipal bus from an impoverished neighborhood nearby. H & R Block has put the new center, and its jobs, near enough for the operators to get to a job, one that pays $8 to $9 an hour, good pay in their world.
"We have not been pressured to raise wages because of the labor shortage," said Frank L. Salizzoni, the company's chief executive.
Even some officials in the Clinton administration, despite its hands-off policy vis-a-vis the Federal Reserve, are challenging the Fed's view that an inflationary labor shortage is developing. Martin Bailey, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, said, "We don't see wage pressure coming from the labor market at this time." More bluntly, the labor secretary, Alexis M. Herman, declared in a recent interview: "I tell everybody Alan Greenspan is a wise man, and I don't comment on Fed policy. But this is a balanced economy that can continue to perform at a very solid and steady pace."
Part of the difference lies in how the experts tally the number of available workers. Ms. Herman counts at least 13 million people across the nation available for jobs, including 3 million part-time workers who have told surveyors from the Bureau of Labor Statistics that they would take more hours if they could get them.
Mr. Greenspan's more conservative estimate of 10 million people available for jobs leaves out the part-timers. He focuses on the nearly 6 million people who are listed as officially unemployed because they are actively looking for work, as well as 4 million others who tell the bureau's surveyors that they have not looked for work lately but would like a job or might like one in the right circumstances.
Mr. Greenspan's estimate of 10 million would-be workers has declined from 13 million in January 1996. But both his estimate and Ms. Herman's miss those who are not thinking about working but can be lured into jobs. Most of them are among the 36.3 million civilians between 16 and 64 who are busy in other activities and see themselves as not available for work, unless, like Mr. Bell, a company is able to change their minds.
In Kansas City's poorest neighborhoods, the statistics miss hundreds of families "who don't respond to surveyors or answer the door or any of that stuff, but want jobs," said Clyde McQueen, president of the Full Employment Council.
The council is a publicly subsidized organization that tries to get people in poor neighborhoods into jobs, mainly by training them and then paying for transportation, including bus fare to H & R Block's new center and similar job sites. "The first thing people here want to know," Mr. McQueen said, "is what is the shift time, does the bus get there and what happens if I have an emergency at home."
Nowhere in Kansas City is the sweep for new workers more on display than at Station Casinos, a Las Vegas-style hotel and casino complex that is the biggest of the four casinos along the Missouri River.
The casinos opened in 1997, and almost overnight 5,000 new jobs appeared in greater Kansas City, a considerable impact on a work force that then numbered 916,000 and now numbers more than 965,000. The casinos initially bid up wages, offering low-skilled workers $7.50 to $9 an hour. That drained people from other employers, including customer call- center operators at Sprint, then earning less than $7 an hour.
"We lost a lot of folks to the casino boats," said Mary M. Hogan, manager of Sprint's call center in suburban Lenexa, Kan., "but it is not an issue now."
Sprint has raised its starting pay to $8.25 an hour. It has also eased the wage pressure by employing more college students and offering them nonwage benefits like flexible part-time schedules and tuition subsidies of $5,250 a year if they stay at least that long. Station Casinos, employing 2,120 people, has also soft-pedaled wage increases.
"More and more we compete on the whole package," said John V. Finamore, president of the casino.
Apart from health insurance, that package includes a child care center, 10 percent discounts at local merchants, free meals once a month served by executives, gifts at Christmas, a talent show for employees and their families and, most recently, the softball field.
"These are soft labor costs that are much more easily absorbed than fixed wage increases and can be shed more easily," Mr. Finamore said.
To find workers, Station Casinos uses specialized employment agencies that recruit immigrants from Latin America, Africa, Russia, Vietnam, Cambodia and elsewhere. Ninety employees came out of retirement and 270 others work at the casino as a second job, often as weekend blackjack dealers earning $15 an hour, most of it in tips. For a while, the casino's vans brought people from poor neighborhoods to work in the hotel, but now a municipal bus -- known as the Casino Cruiser -- makes the run every half-hour.
"You cannot compete on wages," Mr. Finamore said. "All you do is raise the bar across the city."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Trail Blazers Trying To Regain Their Path

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., March 25

 BODY:
In Joe Kleine's 15-year career, he could not remember a regular-season game more hyped and anticipated than the one between the Portland Trail Blazers and the Los Angeles Lakers on Feb. 29.
Vying for home-court advantage throughout the playoffs, the teams came into the game tied with the National Basketball Association's best mark at 45-11. "The greatest regular-season game in the history of the N.B.A.," bellowed Bill Walton, the NBC analyst and the former Blazer center, before the matchup.
"I'd never seen anything like it," Kleine, Portland's reserve center, said of the buildup. "I don't want to blame that game on everything that happened, but obviously it had something to do with it. It was like everything just came to a standstill."
Including the beleaguered Blazers. They have not been the same since, going 5-5 since that defeat. They havelost four of six at the Rose Garden after winning 16 straight. They blew fourth-quarter leads to Minnesota and Detroit. Toronto recently beat the Blazers on their home floor by 19 points, their worst loss of the season.
As the Blazers prepared to entertain the Knicks on Sunday, the question was: could they find their rhythm and heart before the Lakers run away with the Western Conference championship?
"With the 82 games, it's inevitable that no matter how good you are, sooner or later you're going to hit a funk during the year," said Kleine, who has played on six teams, including a championship team in Chicago. "Very rarely does a team not go through one. You lose your way and eventually you find it again. But sometimes to find it, you need a good slap in the face."
Coach Mike Dunleavy added: "Certainly when you have a big loss, there is a residue to it. But more than that, we've really missed Brian Grant. Especially his toughness and rebounding."
Grant, a power forward, was activated last Friday after missing most of March with an injury in his foot. He also had off-season knee surgery. Instead of Rasheed Wallace being the anchor off the bench, he has been forced into a starting role.
The Blazers also lost Arvydas Sabonis last week after the center severely sprained his right foot. He is expected to miss two to three weeks.
Before the season, the Blazers were unanimously tagged as favorites to succeed the San Antonio Spurs as champions. In some quarters, the Spurs were picked to repeat, and the Lakers were seen as a greater long shot than any Eastern Conference team. But mostly, Portland was the team spoken of most highly.
The Blazers had the talent, experience and, most of all, the depth. Acquiring Scottie Pippen, Steve Smith and Detlef Schrempf during the off-season not only took oodles of Paul Allen's money but also the maneuverability of Bob Whitsitt, the team president.
After ridding themselves of Isaiah Rider and Jim Jackson, the Blazers' $50 million starting lineup was not as much about cash as it was cachet. And for the first four months, the Blazers seemed polished and poised, on the cusp of distinguishing themselves from the pack.
But gradually the problems began to surface. If it was not Wallace blowing a gasket and leading the league in technical fouls, it was poor decision-making on offense. Portland's lack of a genuine go-to player at the end of a game has also been raised.
Yet the biggest reason for their shortcomings is clear to see on the court: the Blazers are not mentally or physically strong enough to compete for a title. It's not just Wallace; many players think all of humanity is out to get them after a questionable call. They do not play through the whistles. Instead of saving their nasty disposition for their opponents, they direct it at the referees.
Having already won 50 games, the Blazers are the second-best team in the league. They are not in grave danger and have a few weeks to fix the leaks. But less than two months ago, Portland was considered a lock to wind up in the conference finals and dispatch the Lakers. Now, they are just another slumping N.B.A. team struggling to find its identity.
"We definitely still have a chance to get there and win it," Kleine said. "You can't say that about a lot of teams. But it's not going to be easy. The problems we have are fixable. We, as a team, complain too much. We've got to be a lot tougher, mentally and physically."
Dunleavy said: "My wish was to have us healthy by now. That didn't happen. So we just have to find a way to get it done."
 
The Carter Conspiracy
Less than a month ago, Vincesanity was the catchphrase used to describe the sweeping popularity of Vince Carter, and how the All-Star forward of the Toronto Raptors had made the casual fan again pay attention to the N.B.A.
But then Butch Carter invoked a number of conspiracy theories that could thwart Toronto from keeping his star player under contract. At one point this week, the Raptors coach accused both the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League of tampering and the N.B.A. of possibly trying to steer Carter toward an American city after he becomes a free agent.
The Toronto Sun actually spoke with a highly placed league official who essentially told the newspaper that the N.B.A. would be better off if Carter ended up on a team in the United States. It was an anonymous quote that a league spokesman referred to as "moronic" and "stupid" and not at all indicative of the league's stance.
Butch Carter apologized for his comments after he was chastised by General Manager Glen Grunwald. But he added, "I think there are forces out there that have been and will be destructive to our situation in Toronto. I don't think it will be anyone in the league office."
For simple economic reasons, the league needs high-profile players in its major markets. Yet the notion the N.B.A. wants Carter anywhere else than Toronto is a bit shortsighted.
The Raptors, regardless of their locale, are currently helping resuscitate NBC's sagging N.B.A. ratings. If Toronto could somehow negotiate its way through the Eastern Conference finals and into a championship showdown with the Lakers, neither the network nor Commissioner David Stern would fret. They would be overjoyed.
The immediacy of the Internet and television almost negate modern, big-market hyperbole. Witness the phenomenon of the Sacramento Kings over the past two seasons. In the old days, Vince would have had to go to Hollywood or Madison Avenue for maximum exposure. Now, they go to him.
Also, the N.B.A. is so concerned about its Canadian presence that the team owners recently unanimously rejected the ownership application of Bill Lurie, the St. Louis billionaire. After all the efforts that went into North American expansion, they did not want Lurie transplanting the Vancouver Grizzlies to the Midwest until that N.B.A. market was deemed a failure over a longer period of time.
If Carter's appeal could truly cut into the consciousness of a hockey nation over the long haul, would not investors in Ottawa or Montreal eventually give credence to N.B.A. teams in their own cities?
Finally, one of the main issues fought for and won by owners in the last round of bargaining was more restrictions on player movement. They want people to stay with their teams. Continuity -- Michael in Chicago, Larry in Boston, Magic in L.A. -- is still a valued asset in the N.B.A.
Unless Vince Carter -- and only Vince Carter -- wants to play somewhere else, he will remain a Raptor.
 
The Children of 76ers
Mike Dunleavy has been watching his son, Michael, play for Duke in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Harvey Catchings has been watching his daughters, Tamika and Tauja, play for Tennessee and Illinois, respectively, in the women's tournament.
Nearly 25 years ago, the two fathers were teammates.
"If you take all the players' kids off that team, you'd have a pretty good team right there," Dunleavy said.
Indeed, the 1976-77 Philadelphia 76ers fell to Bill Walton's Portland Trail Blazers in the finals, but they should also be an All-Genetic Dream Team.
Beyond Catchings and Dunleavy, that 76ers team featured Henry Bibby, whose son, Mike, starts at point guard for the Vancouver Grizzlies, and a reserve forward with a decent vertical leap, Joe (Jellybean) Bryant, father of Kobe Bryant.
There was also Doug Collins, whose son, Chris, starred at Duke, and Steve Mix, who has a daughter playing college basketball.
"It's one of those amazing coincidences," said Pat Williams, the general manager of that Sixers team. "I can't remember a team of players whose children turned out to be so good."
 
Teens Like Knick Trio
And you thought it was just fed-up adults who wanted Patrick Ewing to stop shooting so much and make way for the new generation. According to Inside Stuff, the teen magazine of the N.B.A., Latrell Sprewell, Allan Houston and Marcus Camby were named the league's top trio -- the three teammates who work the best together on the floor.
The three Knicks edged out Shaquille O'Neal, Kobe Bryant and Glen Rice; Ray Allen, Glenn Robinson and Sam Cassell; Chris Webber, Jason Williams and Vlade Divac; and Alonzo Mourning, Tim Hardaway and Jamal Mashburn.
The voting actually was not done by kids. Rather, the magazine's editorial board made the selections.
