LENGTH: 1411 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON ENTREATS PAKISTAN TO TREAD LIGHTLY IN KASHMIR

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 25

 BODY:
In an effort to defuse tensions in a region that he has described as the most volatile in the world, President Clinton today asked the military leader of Pakistan to show restraint in Kashmir, where Pakistan and India most recently battled last summer, and to reopen a dialogue with his Indian neighbors.
But after more than an hour and a half with Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Mr. Clinton received no assurances, said a senior administration official who participated in the meeting. 
 "We broke no new ground on Kashmir," the official said after the session. "We heard no new assurances from the general."
Administration officials had expected little if any immediate progress from the talks with General Musharraf. Pressed on terrorism, the spread of nuclear weapons and when he would return Pakistan to democracy at the national level, the general offered nothing new, the White House official indicated.
Pakistan and India, the world's two newest nuclear powers, regularly skirmish in Kashmir, which has been the main issue between overwhelmingly Muslim Pakistan and Hindu India since the two nations were created from the British Raj in 1947, leaving the status of the Himalayan territory unresolved. The Clinton administration believes that incursions by Pakistani-backed militants into Indian-held Kashmir have the potential to escalate.
Last summer, battles in the Kargil region of Kashmir were regarded as the first direct combat between two nuclear powers -- fighting that was halted after Mr. Clinton persuaded Nawaz Sharif, then Pakistan's prime minister, to back down. Three months later, Mr. Sharif was ousted by General Musharraf.
Mr. Clinton, who decided to come to Pakistan after intense disagreement within the administration, spent barely six hours in this country, arriving from an extensive five-day tour of India under some of the most elaborate security precautions ever devised for his travels.
After his meeting with General Musharraf, Mr. Clinton made a direct appeal to the Pakistani people in a live television broadcast in which he addressed them as friends of the United States. Instead of looking toward a future of economic collapse and potential war, the people should choose the path of economic security and peace, the president said.
"With the right vision rooted in tomorrow's promise, not yesterday's pain -- rooted in dialogue, not destruction, Pakistan can fulfill its destiny as a beacon of democracy in the Muslim world," Mr. Clinton said. If Pakistanis choose this path, he promised, "The United States will walk with you."
The administration official said the president had stressed to General Musharraf that there could be no military solution in Kashmir by incursions across the Line of Control, the de facto border between Pakistani- and Indian-held territory.
Mr. Clinton had asked specifically for "restraint, respect for the Line of Control, rejection of violence and return to dialogue," the official said.
There was not much movement on other issues, either.
Mr. Clinton asked the general to take action against terrorist groups operating in Pakistan and to help pressure the Taliban government in Afghanistan to bring to justice, Osama bin Laden, the terrorist whom the United States believes is responsible for the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa.
The general, as he has in the past, said he would work with the Taliban leadership on the Osama bin Laden case, the official said.
Speaking to reporters as Mr. Clinton was leaving Islamabad, General Musharraf said he and the American president got along very well.
There were, however, no photographs of the two leaders together, and the general -- as planned -- held a news conference alone.
When asked whether he had given Mr. Clinton assurances that Pakistani-backed infiltration into Indian-held Kashmir would cease, the general replied: "There were no assurances because there was no question. We are not involved in sending any kind of people across the Line of Control."
On the Taliban, the general said he assured Mr. Clinton "that I would like to engage the Taliban in Afghanistan and take up the issue of any sanctuaries for any terrorists or training that might be going on in that country."
On the question of nonproliferation, the general pledged Pakistan would not be a source for the export of nuclear technology, the administration official said.
As the official ticked off the list of items on the president's agenda, it was clear there was a recitation of long-held views on both sides.
Still, said the official: "We've made an effort to make our position clear at the highest level. We didn't expect to come in an hour and persuade the leadership of the wisdom of our position."
Indeed, one point of the hotly debated stop in Pakistan, White House officials said, was to try and keep the lines of communication open. Should the situation deteriorate sharply in Kashmir -- as the administration fears -- President Clinton is now in a better position to deal directly with General Musharraf, they maintain.
Mr. Clinton also brought up the trial of the former prime minister, Mr. Sharif, who is accused of hijacking, treason and attempted murder. If convicted, Mr. Sharif could face the death penalty, and Mr. Clinton today asked the general not to execute him. The general explained that he was not vindictive, but that the matter was up to the courts.
As he did in New Delhi, Mr. Clinton made clear to the general that the United States would not mediate in the Kashmir crisis, the White House official said. This was also a message that General Musharraf did not want to hear: unlike the Indians, the Pakistani leader would like the Kashmir dispute to be settled by international mediation.
The signals from General Musharraf in the days before Mr. Clinton's arrival were not promising. The Pakistani leader missed an opportunity to send a positive message on his national day on Thursday when he made a major speech.
Instead of announcing that local elections would be held this year, as he had indicated earlier, the general pushed the date back to next year.
Also, the general has consistently talked in recent weeks about the Islamic militants in Kashmir, who the administration says are backed by the Pakistani regime, as freedom fighters committed to a jihad, or holy war. The administration regards several of these groups as terrorist.
Pakistan asserts that Kashmir, with a large Muslim majority, should have the right to vote on whether to join India or Pakistan. Secular India claims Kashmir as one of its states.
The emotions behind the issue were vividly on display in some of the banners along the route taken by Mr. Clinton's motorcade. "You were fair in Kosovo," said one, referring to NATO's bombing campaign to deter Serbian repression against Kosovo's largely Muslim Albanian majority. "Be fair in Kashmir."
It is politically untenable for a Pakistani leader to appear as though he is bending to an American diktat. Mr. Sharif's decision to pull back behind the Line of Control last summer is thought to have been one factor behind his ouster. And behind the general stands another, perhaps even tougher, commander, Gen. Mohammad Aziz, the chief of general staff of the Pakistani Army, who Clinton administration officials assert was the brains behind the fighting in Kargil last year.
Mr. Clinton arrived from Bombay under elaborate security precautions. At the Bombay airport, he walked to the door of a military C-17 aircraft, shook hands with dignitaries as though he was going to board that aircraft, and then slipped around the front of the plane to board an unmarked, smaller white jet that was parked nearby. This aircraft, an Air Force version of a Gulfstream, known as a C-20, flew Mr. Clinton, his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, the secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, and several other advisers to Islamabad.
From the Islamabad airport, Mr. Clinton drove in a motorcade through deserted streets to the presidential palace.
Mr. Clinton's unmarked plane was accompanied by another Air Force Gulfstream, which was painted with the familiar blue and white of Air Force One and marked "United States of America." This was the decoy plane with Secret Service agents on board and arrived first, followed soon after by the president's plane. Many of Mr. Clinton's staff and reporters covering his trip were flown in on a military C-17 aircraft.

HEADLINE: Invasion of Laptops Spurs a Revolution In College Teaching

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.

 BODY:
During his economics seminar the other day, Sean Leary, a freshman at Wake Forest University, scanned stock prices, browsed basketball updates from ESPN, checked his e-mail, and perused pictures of "beautiful girls" on www.acewallpapers.com in search of a new backdrop for his laptop computer screen.
It seems Mr. Leary, who had already taken one economics course in the fall, was bored by the discussion of marginal benefit and cost. But no matter. This is a laptop classroom, where each student sits behind an open machine, sometimes posting answers to the professor's queries on a virtual chalkboard, sometimes, well, doing something else. 
 "I haven't skipped this class once," noted Mr. Leary, 18. "Even if there's something in class that's boring, there's other stuff you can do."
Wake Forest is one of more than 100 colleges and universities across the country where a computer is now required to matriculate. Not only has this created new forms of in-class distraction and revolutionized campus communication, but it has begun to transform teaching itself.
For example, Gordon McCray, a Wake Forest business professor, turned all of his lectures into a streaming video CD-ROM, essentially doubling his class time by forcing students to watch the lectures (or read a transcript) on their own. He thereby freed class time for group exercises.
Others have students do Web research in class to supplement discussion or use software for homework and quizzes that help tailor syllabuses to individuals. Professors say this way they are now serving a broader spectrum of learning styles.
The very hours of learning have also been extended beyond the classroom through online discussion groups -- often including experts in the field or alumni. Where only a handful of students typically take advantage of once-a-week office hours, instructors are now in constant contact with their students by e-mail, even in the wee hours.
"It's not just added on to the old curriculum -- it's a whole new curriculum," said Bill Moss, a professor of mathematics at Clemson University in South Carolina, where he started a laptop project for 250 engineering majors this year. "You've got old guys like me who've been teaching for 30 years who've got to throw out stacks of yellow notes and start a whole new pedagogy."
Arguing that computer literacy is now an essential part of a liberal arts education, small colleges and professional schools now scratch for spots on Yahoo's annual ranking of America's "most wired" colleges.
The first colleges to require computers were the military academies, which started putting a desktop in every cadet's room in 1983.
But the current wave began a decade later at the University of Minnesota-Crookston, an outpost of 2,464 students on the western edge of the state, and has erupted over the last five years, from Seton Hall in New Jersey to Sonoma State in California, from the University of Virginia's business school to the tiny Shepard Broad Law Center at Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
Now the trend is spreading to large public institutions: the University of Florida in Gainesville, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Michigan State University have all recently approved computer requirements.
Experts estimate that 80 percent of college students now bring a computer with them to campus. Making it a requirement means the cost can be factored in for financial aid; it also allows the university to impose uniformity, which makes technical support much simpler. (Some colleges, like Wake Forest, have raised tuition and mail the laptops to students shortly after acceptance letters.) In most cases, students pay about $3,000 for a laptop fully loaded with software specially designed for the institution, then trade it for a new model their junior or senior year.
Universities are also spending millions of dollars to upgrade classrooms so there are plugs and Internet connections at every seat -- though some are experimenting with wireless technology -- as well as laser disc players and video screens up front. There are added costs for expanded computer help desks, work-study jobs for students who provide emergency technical assistance in dormitories, and training for reluctant, old-fashioned faculty.
"The students believe we've given them an edge as they go out into the marketplace," said Joseph D. Harbaugh, dean of the Nova law school, where students use legal case-management software to file their assignments and mock-bill their time. "This has set us apart as we go out into the market for students and for faculty."
At Clemson, English classes keep their compositions in electronic portfolios posted on the Web. At Western Carolina University in the foothills of the Smoky Mountains, literature professors are able to use primary source documents in their lectures, displaying Web images of the handwritten notes of a minor British poet from an archive hundreds of miles away at Princeton University. In Jonathan Zittrain's class on Internet and Society at Harvard Law School, students respond each week to a question posted on the Web, and the answers are automatically routed to another student -- or, perhaps, the author of the pertinent article -- for comments.
At Oberlin College in Ohio, a class on the industrial revolution is using university-owned laptops kept locked in a newly wired classroom. One day they browse an online archive of correspondence between spouses in 19th-century Pennsylvania, another they analyze data from the 1870 census in Cleveland.
"We're experiencing something of the same sense of upheaval," said Gary Kornblith, the professor, aware of the irony of his technique and his topic. "I see a lot of parallels, and I hope my students will see parallels."
Here at Wake Forest, where the class of 2000 was the first to receive laptops, only a handful of professors regularly use computers in the classroom, but nearly all of them incorporate technology into their teaching.
Students in Patricia Dixon's Musical Protest in the Americas class consulted Pete Seeger himself in an online chat (and later corrected the professor by supplying Mr. Seeger's eyewitness view of events).
Rick Matthews, chairman of the physics department, said a circuit-maker program has elevated his electronics class. Before, students would draw a circuit, he would find a couple of mistakes -- probably miss one or two -- and give the paper, say, an 82. Now, students can test the circuit to see whether current would actually flow; everyone gets a zero or 100, because no one turns the assignment in until it works.
"The homework before wasn't teaching them anything -- it was merely documenting what they knew and didn't know," he said. "Now, they're putting four times as much time in as they did before, they're enjoying the homework more, learning 50 percent more electronics."
David G. Brown spearheaded Wake Forest's computer initiative while he was provost, and now is dean of the university's International Center for Computer Enhanced Learning.
"The computer is like the library," said Dr. Brown, an economist who uses laptops every day in class, having students type answers into a chat room rather than raise hands, or prepare an instant presentation doing Web research. "It's an intellectual resource. If you don't have it, you've got to dumb down your course, you've got to dumb down your research."
There are, of course, potential pitfalls.
There is the astronomy professor at Wake Forest who posted his lectures on the Web -- so most people stopped showing up for class. And there are the students at Columbia University School of Business who spend their time in class trading stocks -- occasionally interrupting the lecture with whoops of joy or sighs of pain over their trades. And there is the incessant clicking on campuses everywhere as students take notes on their machines or use them to write exams.
"It can't make up for a good teacher," said Heath Baumgarten, 20, a Wake Forest junior from Freeport, Me. "It has changed the social body. It's harder to meet people. A lot of people are inside a lot now."
As the first laptop class graduates from Wake Forest this spring, Mr. Baumgarten said he, for one, plans to leave his computer behind.

HEADLINE: Caution Ahead: The Mighty S.U.V.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Looking for the S.U.V. Vote" (Week in Review, March 19): While many economists would argue that the best way to improve fuel efficiency is to increase gasoline prices, such a move would disproportionately affect less affluent drivers.
The income gap between sport utility vehicle owners and sedan owners suggests that the way to encourage demand for more fuel-efficient vehicles is to impose a "gas-guzzler tax" on all new vehicles sold in the United States that exceed the average fuel economy of the American auto fleet by a certain percentage. 
 Such a targeted tax would encourage consumers to shop for more fuel-efficient autos, and manufacturers would seek to meet this changing demand over time. The tax is justified because the general public bears the environmental costs of those who choose to indulge their taste for fuel inefficiency.
 
BILL MOSELEY
Athens, Ga., March 19, 2000

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
Gas Prices the Talk Of State Campaigns

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
The steep rise in gasoline prices has mainly provided political fodder for Republicans going after Vice President Al Gore, who likes to boast that the country has never enjoyed better economic times. But more and more the gas issue is filtering down into Congressional and state races.
In Virginia, former Gov. George F. Allen, a Republican trying to oust Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, says Mr. Robb has to go because he once called for a 50-cents-a-gallon increase in gas taxes. 
 In Nebraska, George Grogan, a Republican businessman running for the Senate, is broadcasting advertisements in which he accuses President Clinton of knuckling under to OPEC and urges cuts in the federal gas tax and more oil exploration.
In Connecticut, the state's Republican Party recently ran advertisements in which Gov. John G. Rowland called on voters to press state legislators, particularly reluctant Democrats, to pass a 7-cents-a-gallon cut in the state's 32-cents-a-gallon gas tax. Democrats worry that this cut would cost the state treasury too much.
And in New York?
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says the blame for the price spike should be laid "completely at the feet" of Hillary Rodham Clinton's husband.

HEADLINE: On Park Bench, Another Jolt In a Bumpy Life;
Moved Along by the Police, A Soviet Emigre Vanishes

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Some Soviet dissidents became international symbols of human rights. Nikolai G. Tolstykh, like thousands of others, served his political imprisonment in obscurity. Confined for years in labor camps for anti-Soviet propaganda in the 1980's, Mr. Tolstykh was nearly 40 and estranged from his wife and son by the time a thaw in the cold war cracked open his cell door and sent him to America.
He had studied medicine, psychiatry and law in the Soviet Union. But in New York City, where his name became Tolstich, his broken English and bad health left him struggling in temporary jobs as a home health aide. He was depressed, friends said, and he drank. In late 1998, a decade after Mikhail S. Gorbachev ordered him freed, Mr. Tolstich entered a Manhattan homeless shelter. 
 By all accounts, he still cut a professorial figure on Dec. 6, when he sat down on a bench in a Chelsea park at noon in a light rain. A thin, neatly dressed man of 51 with short hair and a goatee, he had beside him a briefcase holding a Russian-English dictionary, a book of philosophy and a few personal items, including a hairbrush.
But two New York City police officers had reason to suspect he was homeless. His bench was one of a dozen in the park on Ninth Avenue and 28th Street across from the Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen, where 1,000 homeless people eat daily. Sure enough, when the officers demanded identification, Mr. Tolstich produced a homeless shelter ID card.
Mr. Tolstich said they ordered him to put his briefcase on the ground, stood him against a tree, frisked him and searched his pockets, according to an affidavit he signed on Dec. 29. Then they issued him a summons for a violation -- "obstructing park bench" -- because he had the briefcase on it. This month, lawyers for the homeless added Mr. Tolstich's affidavit and summons to a 1997 federal class-action lawsuit that has challenged the constitutionality of the Giuliani administration's crackdowns on the homeless.
But Mr. Tolstich himself has disappeared.
He was last seen at the 30th Street Men's Shelter in Manhattan on Jan. 7 -- three days before his court date to contest the violation. Letters from his elderly mother in St. Petersburg collect at the social service agency where he received his mail. And after fruitlessly searching the jails and shelter system, his lawyer and Soviet emigres who knew him say they are worried that Mr. Tolstich may have found the revival of old fears unbearable.
In his affidavit, he wrote: "I now associate that park not only with the experience I had on Dec. 6, but also with my experience in the Soviet Union. There, because it was a totalitarian state, the police could treat anyone the way the police treated me on that day. On Dec. 6, I felt treated like somebody in the Soviet Union, because I am homeless."
A Police Department spokesman, Lt. Stephen Biegel, would not comment on the incident because a judge has not ruled on it. But he said the police received many neighborhood complaints about homeless people spreading belongings on benches. Park regulations prohibit the use of a bench in a way that interferes with its availability.
Douglas Lasdon, executive director of the nonprofit Urban Justice Center, who met Mr. Tolstich at the soup kitchen's legal clinic, said that during the month Mr. Tolstich prepared his affidavit, he was sober and reliable, keeping three appointments. The former dissident, who studied in Leningrad at the prestigious Academy of Arts and at the Medical Institute before being sent to hard labor in prison camps, was in a workfare job at the time, records show, cleaning doors on Wall Street in exchange for weekly relief of $11.25 and $32 in food stamps.
Mr. Lasdon said he told Mr. Tolstich the park bench violation was likely to be dismissed, but warned that a failure to appear in court would generate an arrest warrant. He noted that the police had been raiding shelters to round up homeless people with outstanding warrants. For now, no warrant has been issued for Mr. Tolstich, because the clinic's lawyers have won three adjournments on his behalf.
To the fraying circle of former Soviet dissidents, Mr. Tolstich's case is an emblem of how the post-Communist world has forgotten their sacrifices. "A lot of them have come to no good end," said Edward Kline, the president of the Andrei Sakharov Foundation. "They haven't found a place for themselves in the West and they can't really go back -- they're unwanted in both places."
Is it likely, as Mr. Tolstich's Jan. 10 court date drew near, that memories of being locked up overwhelmed him? "Of course, yes, absolutely," said Yuri Fedorov, a veteran of Soviet political imprisonment and president of the Gratitude Fund, which helps Soviet dissidents. "He's not a very strong man," Mr. Fedorov added. "He used to be a very good man."
In 1986, Soviet exiles placed Mr. Tolstich's name on a list of political prisoners. Veterans of those days read volumes between the lines of his entry: 1980-83, imprisoned under fabricated criminal charge. Arrested spring 1985, Article 70. Publication of his works abroad. Tried December 1985-January 1986. Political camp. Mr. Yarim-Agaev said that fabricated criminal charges were especially commonplace in 1980, during a three-year campaign by the K.G.B. to eliminate dissent. After rounding up all the visible activists, he said, the secret police arrested little-known dissenters and put them with criminals. "That is part of the tragedy of Nikolai," he added.
The works that got Mr. Tolstich in trouble are long forgotten -- probably articles in the Russian-language press of Europe, experts say. But they were enough for charges under Article 70, which outlawed "anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda." Pretrial detention was harsh in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg), whether in a K.G.B. prison known as "the gray house," or in Kresty, the infamous czarist-era fortress with punishment booths that only had room for a man to stand.
His conviction under Article 70 meant punishment in a political labor camp, with even more severe physical conditions than in the criminal camp, said Mr. Yarim-Agaev, who called it "the second circle of hell."
Mr. Tolstich was one of 200 political prisoners released by decree of Mr. Gorbachev in late 1987, and among those expelled from the country, his affidavit said. Within days of arriving in New York, he came to the Center for Democracy in the U.S.S.R. in Manhattan, which Mr. Yarim-Agaev had founded in 1985. Later, Mr. Tolstich contributed articles to various publications including Novoye Russkoye Slovo, the major Russian language newspaper in New York, others said.
"He wrote a lot," Mr. Yarim-Agaev recalled. "He was -- he is a very cultivated and educated person, a person with humanitarian inclinations." But adjustment to a foreign country was difficult after years in a prison camp, he added. "A person after that hardly feels full of energy for new labors and new beginnings."
Many dissidents had imagined that coming to America would feel like coming home. Instead, they found what Catherine A. Fitzpatrick, executive director of the International League for Human Rights, calls "a constant disconnect" between their ideals and reality. And when the Soviet Union collapsed into economic chaos, gangsters and old K.G.B. hands seemed to get rich and powerful on United States aid, the former dissidents said, while their kind slid into impoverished irrelevance.
The Center for Democracy was disbanded in 1991. For a few years, Mr. Tolstich's acquaintances saw him at birthdays and funerals in the old circle, but eventually lost track of him. By the mid-1990's, the downward slope of his life steepened into a succession of unstable living arrangements and short-lived jobs he listed for his lawyer: mechanic's assistant, clerk, security guard.
At one point, acquaintances said, Mr. Tolstich roomed in a squalid ground floor apartment in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn with Boris Khurgin, a newspaperman described by former colleagues as a brilliant poet who drank himself to death at 48.
On a hot summer night a week after Mr. Khurgin's death in 1995, a colleague was sent to their apartment to look for poems to save. What he found was a wake without end in two tiny, barely furnished rooms where several men sat half-naked, sweating and drinking vodka with "terrible, bluish faces." One was Mr. Tolstich.
At the end of 1997, Mr. Tolstich entered the city's shelter system for the first time, returning in late 1998, Department of Homeless Shelter records show. But last year, when Mr. Fedorov encountered him again, he was pulling his life together. He said he had been living for months at the 30th Street shelter and attending an alcohol treatment and counseling program for Russian immigrants.
"He said he quit the drinking and tried to find a job," Mr. Fedorov said. "It was true. I asked him, 'Why didn't you call me when you had a problem with this?' But he said, 'I was ashamed.' "
Mr. Fedorov last saw him on Dec. 28, at a nursing home where they visited another former political prisoner, who was dying of cancer at 58. Friends say that they believe that Mr. Tolstich was shaken by that man's death a few days later, and that it might have contributed to his disappearance.
On a recent afternoon, a few worn-looking men rested in the part of Chelsea Park where the police had stopped Mr. Tolstich. There is a small patch of asphalt surrounding a World War I memorial to "the soldiers and sailors of Chelsea." The site of the former dissident's humiliation resonated with some.
"Dissidents are like soldiers," Mr. Yarim-Agaev said. "They're veterans of the war for human rights. Even Nikolai, I would not consider a failure -- he has already won his struggle. He deserved to live decently the rest of his life for what he already accomplished."

HEADLINE: Holbrooke's Campaign

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub is a contributing writer for the magazine, for which he has written about Kofi Annan, Rudolph Giuliani and others.

 BODY:
Richard C. Holbrooke has a taste for melodrama and derring-do that is practically archaic in the modern world of diplomacy. One epigram Holbrooke uses in "To End a War," a cliffhanging account of his role in the negotiations to end the war in Bosnia, is a quotation from Melville: "I am tormented with an everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts." Holbrooke has a whole stock of literary passages and phrases he likes to quote. Another one comes from Yeats, and has to do with "the fascination with what's difficult." Holbrooke, who since last August has been the United States ambassador to the United Nations, told me that he recited this one to his staff in November as his plane was landing in East Timor. Since the United Nations had authorized a major peacekeeping operation in East Timor, Holbrooke had a perfectly valid reason to fly halfway around the world in order to spend two days there. But East Timor was also the most barbarous coast he could find. Holbrooke has to go looking for danger these days. His current job calls for him to spend most of his time in Manhattan and Washington.
Holbrooke's central task on these two fronts is to end the antagonism that has grown up between the United States and the United Nations over the last six years or so. It is a job whose degree of difficulty is approximately equal to that of the Bosnian negotiations, even if it lacks forbidden seas. Perhaps the dramatic high point came in January when Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, addressed the United Nations Security Council, which Helms had spent years abusing as a threat to American sovereignty. Holbrooke, who had invited Helms, hoped that he would find it impossible to continue demonizing the institution once he encountered it in human form. On the other hand, he worried that the senator would launch an outrageous attack on, say, the Chinese, who would then respond in kind, precipitating some kind of awful incident. Many diplomats felt that a Helms visit would be insulting to the United Nations; some Clinton administration officials felt that Holbrooke was handing Helms a free pass to trumpet his views. Helms did, in fact, give a Helmsian speech, which included a threat that the United States would withdraw from the United Nations; but he didn't name names. 
 When I saw Holbrooke the next day, I asked him if the Helms speech had been a success. His chief press aide, Mary Ellen Glynn, happened to walk into the office with a sheaf of clippings. "Mary Ellen," Holbrooke said, "what's the lead?" Glynn looked at an Associated Press story on top of her pile and read the headline: "Helms Offers Hand to U.N. . . . " Holbrooke slapped the table gleefully. "That's the headline he wants," Holbrooke cried. Indeed, one of Helms's aides later told me that the visit brought "closure" to "the running battle with the U.N.," and later, in mid-March, Helms himself opened a new chapter by inviting the Security Council to visit the Senate.
Holbrooke had advanced the cause, as well as, perhaps, his own prospects. It is a virtual axiom of Washington life that Richard Holbrooke wants to be the next secretary of State, though Holbrooke himself professes to scorn any such ambition. Holbrooke is very close to Al Gore; in 1996, the vice president pushed hard to have Holbrooke nominated as secretary of State to succeed Warren Christopher. When Holbrooke invited the vice president to address the Security Council 10 days before Helms did, it was widely assumed that he was doing a favor for Gore and for himself. Should Gore become president and the Republicans retain control of the Senate, Holbrooke would need Jesse Helms's good office to ensure his confirmation. Several Clinton administration officials say that Holbrooke had not made it clear that the senator was to address the Security Council publicly, rather than in a closed session. "This was something Holbrooke did at the last minute," says one, "and he did it rather cravenly to curry favor with Helms."
Those are fighting words, and they afford some idea of the enmity, and perhaps envy, that Holbrooke routinely provokes. There is no other figure in the world of diplomacy who excites people's feelings the way Holbrooke does, or who so thoroughly incarnates the turbulence and glamour that once attached itself to the making of foreign policy. Leon Fuerth, who is the national security adviser to the vice president and a fan of Holbrooke's, says of him: "He's brilliant, imaginative, a strategic thinker. He's a very complex man who has a very strong impact on people -- they either love him or they hate him."
Not long after Holbrooke took up his new job last summer, he attended a budget committee meeting at which the British ambassador to the United Nations, Sir Jeremy Greenstock, remarked, "The United States has muffled its voice and stained its reputation" -- an intentionally stunning blow from America's staunchest ally. Nancy Soderberg, one of Holbrooke's top aides, says that when she proposed an extension of a peacekeeping project, the answer typically came back: "What do you care? You don't pay anyway." The United States was used to being resented in the United Nations, but scorn -- that was something new.
The main reason for this dismal state of affairs was that the United States had fallen so far behind in its annual payments to the United Nations that it was in danger of losing its vote in the General Assembly -- a fate that has never befallen a major Western nation. This was taken, correctly, as a sign of American nonchalance, or hostility, toward the United Nations. From the outset, Holbrooke said that nothing he did would really matter unless the Clinton administration could persuade Congress to pay the United Nations $926 million for the United States' arrears. (The United Nations put the figure at $1.6 billion, but Washington wasn't using that figure.) "We can't ignore it as it's been ignored in the past," Holbrooke told me early last fall. Then he heard the implied slight to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and corrected himself: "Or, not ignored, but not given enough emphasis. If we can't afford to lose we might as well throw ourselves body and soul into the effort, like a skier in a downhill race just going flat out -- you're either going to win or fall."
In October, Holbrooke started traveling to Washington to lobby Congress. The image that came to mind during these trips was not so much the downhill race as the full-court press. His staff kept a running tally of total Congressional contacts -- 23 one day, or 24 if you count the senator he buttonholed on the Capitol subway. One afternoon, when Holbrooke and the entourage that always seems to be trailing him tumbled out of the Capitol for a meeting in one of the House office buildings, Barbara Larkin, the State Department's Congressional liaison, whispered, "That's Steve Largent -- go get 'im!" Largent is a young conservative from Oklahoma. The man in the suit there on the sidewalk actually looked a little short to be Largent, a former National Football League wide receiver, and as Holbrooke closed on him, the man stuck out a hand and introduced himself as Bob Weygand, a Rhode Island Democrat. Holbrooke didn't miss a beat. He began talking about how many Rhode Islanders he had on his staff, and soon the two were trading gibes about the Brown University football team. As Holbrooke walked away, he started laughing, and then he turned to an aide and told her to set up an appointment with Largent.
Holbrooke never tried to defend the United Nations to a Republican in the United Nations' own language of mutuality and moral obligation. "It's about national security," he would say. It was precisely because the United States could not serve as the world's policeman that it needed the United Nations to intervene in crises around the world. Holbrooke invariably mentioned East Timor, where the United Nations had for once acted quickly in the face of mass violence. The multilateral force that the Security Council authorized involved, as Holbrooke never failed to note, no Americans and very few dollars. When he testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in early November, Holbrooke propped up a chart showing that only 36 American soldiers were serving in United Nations peacekeeping forces -- one-tenth the figure from the high-water mark of six years earlier. "We have learned the lesson of Somalia," he reassured the senators.
Holbrooke was able to exercise direct influence only on the White House. The Clinton administration had always favored paying the arrears, but never cared enough to force a confrontation on the issue with Congressional Republicans. Holbrooke's great fear last fall, which he would never express in public, was that the president's domestic-policy advisers would agree to barter away the arrears at the 11th hour to get in return something that actually mattered politically to them. Holbrooke spoke out constantly on the subject, and administration officials give him credit for raising the profile of the issue, though they give as much or more to Secretary of State Albright.
As for Congress, Holbrooke understood that the only figure who really mattered was Speaker of the House Dennis Hastert. And Hastert wouldn't return his calls. Holbrooke spotted Hastert one day at a White House ceremony and trapped him against a statue of Ulysses S. Grant. "I pinned the coach!" he told me exuberantly a few days later. (Hastert used to be a high-school wrestling coach.)
But Holbrooke knew that the only way he could influence Hastert was to persuade individual Republicans that the United Nations was too important to be held hostage to the abortion debate, which it had been since 1997. It was then that a New Jersey congressman named Christopher Smith saw to it that two pieces of legislation essentially having nothing to do with each other were linked: his bill prohibiting the administration from financing any foreign organization using its own funds to perform or lobby for abortions anywhere in the world, and legislation providing for the payment of United Nation arrears. (Smith's amendment was attached annually to legislation financing the United Nations, thus ensuring a stalemate.) And Holbrooke discovered that many of the people he talked to had never spoken even to a midlevel State Department official, much less a United Nations ambassador; he made an impression just by taking the trouble to visit. Holbrooke's predecessor, Bill Richardson, was a former congressman, but Holbrooke turned out to be by far the more effective lobbyist of the two. One American official who worked with both men says: "Richardson wasn't nearly so relentless; he stopped when he encountered resistance from the White House. Holbrooke made a pest of himself, as he also did on the Hill."
By early December, both the White House and the Republicans were ready to compromise. The original Smith amendment required foreign recipients of United States funds to certify that they would not use their own money for abortions or abortion lobbying. Negotiators from both sides agreed to narrow the range of prohibited activities and to allow the president to set aside the requirement, for up to a total of $15 million -- which is probably all the government would have spent anyway. When I went to visit Holbrooke in his office a few days after the agreement was reached, he was in a triumphant mood. "We got 90 percent of what we wanted," he said. On the other hand, he added, "the women have emphasized the 10 percent we didn't get." Holbrooke saw this as feminist purism. As we were talking, a call came in from one of Washington's most prominent women. Holbrooke picked up the phone, tried to talk and recoiled as if from a percussive shock. He made a wry face at me; we were complicit. "O.K., I don't know what I'm talking about," he said. "I've spent the last eight weeks talking to members of Congress I didn't know existed. . . . No, we beat Chris Smith. . . . Look, the United Nations is the biggest family-planning agency in the world. . . . You know I love you; otherwise I wouldn't scream at you."
All the while, Holbrooke was mugging for me and stealing glances at the TV, which was tuned to CNN. His chief of staff, Rosemarie Pauli, was whispering that he had to get off the phone for a meeting to thank his staff for its help, and then he had to go home and dress for a dinner he was giving for Gen. Wesley Clark, the NATO supreme commander. But Holbrooke couldn't, or wouldn't, end the conversation. Finally, he leaned into the phone with a seductive grin and said, "Are we going to have trouble getting the votes from you?" He listened for a moment, smiled and said, "Ahhh."
Holbrooke and I had lunch one afternoon in late January at the Ambassador Grill, the unofficial commissary of the United Nations elite. He drank a glass of white wine and began talking about his monthlong stint as president of the Security Council, which was just ending. Holbrooke has an oddly soft voice for so ebullient a character, and a confiding manner that is designed to seduce. Suddenly, apropos of very little, he said, "I hate personality-driven pieces." He had, he said, only agreed to talk with me because Mary Ellen Glynn thought he should do it. He probably wouldn't agree to pose for a picture. Holbrooke said that he had to leave in a minute. Until this moment, Holbrooke's manner toward me had been either flattering or bantering; now I wondered if I had committed some blunder. Then Holbrooke told me how much he had enjoyed an earlier article of mine. Had he mentioned it before? (Twice, actually.) Then he said, "No one has ever written about my refugee work," and he proceeded to shine a light on this overlooked corner of his career. Nor, he observed, had any writer properly described "the Wall Street part of my career." There was much to say on this subject. Holbrooke talked and talked and talked as a man vacuumed the carpet first to one side of us, then the other. We were the last customers left in the Ambassador Grill.
Holbrooke has had to endure a really remarkable amount of ridicule for a man with his record of achievement. Some of it is envy; but Holbrooke gives the envious ammunition by being so very transparent in his self-aggrandizement and so unconscious of the effect he produces. "I love Dick, but he is his own worst enemy," says one American diplomat who has known Holbrooke for a quarter-century. "We all spin, but Dick just can't stop. He hits a clean double, and then he wants to stretch it into a triple."
Holbrooke is notorious for looking over shoulders at cocktail parties, calling hosts at the last minute to cancel in favor of a better offer, shamelessly name-dropping, ladling praise on media stars and stepping on toes on his way to the top. His enemies consider him ruthlessly self-serving, while his friends speak of him with mordant irony, if also with genuine fondness. Most of them feel that he would make a truly great secretary of State, and they don't doubt that he feels that way himself. If Al Gore is elected president and does not choose Holbrooke as his secretary of State, says one, "That's when he'll need his friends." Holbrooke's cultivation of Gore is the stuff of legend. "He doesn't have a dinner party where he doesn't invite Karenna," says another friend. (For the record, Karenna Gore Schiff was invited to only one of the three dinners I attended.)
Mike McCurry, President Clinton's former spokesman, says: "It was amazing to behold how relentlessly self-promotional Holbrooke was. But it was never offensive. The president was wryly amused. He liked watching the Holbrooke show."
Holbrooke is a show. He is, at the age of 58, a big man, with big gifts, big foibles and the kind of big commitments that have fallen out of fashion, as domestic policy has supplanted foreign affairs. "There is a field of energy around Dick Holbrooke," says Fouad Ajami, a professor of Middle Eastern studies at Johns Hopkins University who has observed the man largely from a distance. "He harks back to an age when American power had great confidence about itself and a belief that America could do well and do good at the same time. He embodies the innocence and activism and hubris and nervous energy of that time. You compare him to Sandy Berger or Strobe Talbott" -- the national security adviser and the deputy secretary of State, respectively -- and they pale. They don't evoke in us that image of American grandeur."
Holbrooke speaks often of Henry Kissinger, and there is something in the way Holbrooke bestrides the world that can put you in mind of him. Like Kissinger, Holbrooke wants to be on the inside of everything -- every debate, every decision, every juicy secret and every desirable party. He is, like Kissinger, a social animal, equally sought-after as a guest and a host. Indeed, a Holbrooke dinner party is an exercise in seduction at the very highest level, not least for the journalist invited to watch. Almost everyone there is some kind of star -- a media star, political star, diplomatic star. The explicit function of these events, which are staged at the United States ambassador's official residence on the 42nd floor of the Waldorf Towers, is to introduce the elite of New York and Washington to what Holbrooke calls "the U.N. Village"; their distinguishing feature is the heady mixing of cultural and political power with moral glamour. Tom Brokaw, meet Nelson Mandela; Senator Rod Grams, meet Kofi Annan.
Everyone is flattered by everyone else. Forty people sit at four round tables; the guest of honor sits next to Holbrooke's wife, Kati Marton, a Hungarian refugee, journalist and herself a glittering presence. And Holbrooke delivers a toast that mingles high seriousness, flattery and wit. At a dinner earlier this month, he made gentle fun of Bernard Kouchner, the embattled head of the United Nations mission in Kosovo, for publicly begging for funds, and then he described him as the most talented figure in the United Nations and evoked the impossible conditions in which he worked -- as Senator Warner will have described to you, Barbara." Leave it to Holbrooke to offer a lollipop to Barbara Walters in the middle of a description of the Kosovar nightmare.
That quality in Holbrooke -- the lavishness of character, the theatricality -- seems a throwback in today's America. But Holbrooke often points to the fact that both of his parents were refugees, his mother from Germany and his father from Russia. Holbrooke's father, a doctor, was a cultured, Old World figure, but he fell ill when the boy was 7 and died when he was 15. During those years, Holbrooke's mother was preoccupied with caring for his father. This may help explain why Holbrooke sometimes seems semisocialized. As Kati Marton says: "Many of the things that we learn at home he didn't learn. He went out into the world, and the world was very quick to reward his brain, but the world was very put off by the man's lack of formality." This last phrase may be taken as a wifely euphemism.
It also may have been the loss of his father that led Holbrooke to look to much older and more powerful men for both guidance and sponsorship. His best friend growing up was David Rusk, the son of Dean Rusk, who was to become President Kennedy's secretary of State. The elder Rusk, the first of Holbrooke's mentors, persuaded him to take the foreign service test; he passed. This was in 1962, and Holbrooke, who has some sort of inner sense for where the action lies, asked to go to Vietnam. "There was a war going on, and it was the far end of the world," Holbrooke says. "It didn't interest me to be a third secretary in Europe or Asia."
Holbrooke began as an economic development officer in the field and then was assigned to Saigon, first as an aide to Gen. Maxwell Taylor and then as assistant to Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge. Holbrooke was immediately recognized as a junior member of the Best and the Brightest. Frank Wisner, a career diplomat who is Holbrooke's closest friend, says: "Dick loved the interaction of American politics. He loved matching wits with McNamara, Bundy, Lodge. And he worked with and came to know the next generation of foreign policy leaders" -- Cyrus Vance, Anthony Lake and others. Inevitably, Holbrooke got himself assigned to Averell Harriman's staff for the fruitless early stages of the Paris peace talks. Harriman became another mentor and guide, as later did Clark Clifford.
Holbrooke left the foreign service in 1969; he says that he couldn't work for Richard Nixon, but his friends from that time say that he simply found the foreign service too confining. During the years of Republican rule, Holbrooke went from the Woodrow Wilson Center at Princeton to the Peace Corps in Morocco to the editorship of Foreign Policy magazine. He came to know Jimmy Carter through the superestablishment Trilateral Commission, of which he was a member. Holbrooke left Foreign Policy to join the Carter campaign in early 1976 in what turned out to be a very nimble piece of political handicapping. When Carter became president, Holbrooke's entire Vietnam cohort rose a full notch; Holbrooke himself became assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. He was, at 35, the youngest assistant secretary in decades.
Holbrooke suddenly found himself in a very difficult position. Jimmy Carter had promised to moralize American foreign policy, and he created the new post of assistant secretary of State for human rights. His appointee, Patricia Derian, fought with all the regional assistant secretaries, but since right-wing dictators abounded in the Asia of the 1970's, she fought with Holbrooke most of all. The two tangled bitterly over President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, and Holbrooke would later be accused of serving as Marcos's chief defender in the Carter administration.
Holbrooke seemed offended when I raised this with him. He sees himself as a profoundly moral figure who at the same time scorns traditional American moralism as nave. Neither a Henry Kissinger on the one hand nor a Woodrow Wilson on the other, he is, in his own mind, a hard-headed idealist. "You have to deal with your responsibilities for the overall national interest," he said. "In 1978, to use our leverage in the Philippines to try to overthrow the president of the Philippines without any idea of what would follow, without any viable Philippine opposition, would have been very strange."
When the Republicans retook the White House, Holbrooke returned to civilian life. He had two sons from a first marriage, and he had gone through a second marriage as well. Now he made a tidy little fortune at Lehman Brothers while he played the social lion in New York. He also churned out a steady stream of op-ed pieces, testified before Congress and showed up at the big foreign policy events. Holbrooke had high hopes when the Democrats returned to power in the person of Bill Clinton. He had helped prep Clinton on foreign policy issues during the campaign. But he hadn't gotten in early enough. Worse still, the new secretary of State was Warren Christopher, the incarnation of the cautious, rulebound lawyer-diplomat, and back in the Carter State Department, Christopher had taken a dim view of Holbrooke. (Christopher had also served as chairman of the department's human rights committee.) Holbrooke was shut out of all three top jobs at State, while the job of national security adviser went to his old friend and rival, Tony Lake. It was, Holbrooke's friends say, a very bitter moment for him.
Holbrooke's temperament had, in effect, trumped his talents. Another man might have slunk back to Wall Street and contented himself with wealth and the company of beautiful women. But Holbrooke couldn't bear to be away from the action. What Holbrooke was finally offered was the ambassadorship to Germany; it was a small and rather distant perch, but he accepted. In the summer of 1994, after a year in Bonn, he was asked to return to Washington as assistant secretary for European and Canadian Affairs. This must have been yet harder to accept, for he would be returning to the same pay grade he had reached almost 20 years earlier; but again, he agreed (because the president personally asked him, he says).
Holbrooke would oversee NATO expansion, but it wasn't just about NATO. Nobody at State or at the White House wanted to take responsibility for the Balkans; Christopher had called it "a problem from Hell." And that was exactly why Holbrooke wanted it. Holbrooke's lightning dashes to the region, his all-night confrontations with Slobodan Milosevic, his shouting matches with the Bosnians, his virtuosity and almost comic machinations at Dayton and his ultimate success in getting the three warring factions to accept a divided country are all the stuff of legend by now, thanks in no small part to Holbrooke's own wonderfully superheated memoirs. Even Holbrooke's detractors concede that Dayton, which ended the violence in Bosnia -- though it scarcely brought peace -- was an extraordinary achievement.
The Dayton marathon was perfectly suited to Holbrooke's iron-man metabolism, as well as to his love of dizzying orchestrations. What is also true, however, is that Holbrooke took to the negotiations a historical consciousness and a sense of moral dimensions that had been missing before. He described the Balkans as "the greatest collective security failure of the West since the 1930's." And of course by invoking Munich, he was conjuring up the magnitude of the evil perpetrated by Slobodan Milosevic and by the Bosnian Serbs. Holbrooke hitched a ruthless pragmatism to a genuine moral imagination. Leslie Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations and a close friend of Holbrooke's, says: "To achieve truly important things you have to be willing to put your personal reputation on the line in a very skillful way, and Dick is one of the few people I've met in my life who has the courage to do that. It's not nutso ambition; it's courage." Gelb, Elie Wiesel and the Columbia historian Fritz Stern nominated Holbrooke for the Nobel Peace Prize.
According to Mike McCurry, President Clinton seriously considered nominating Holbrooke for secretary of State in 1996, though he wasn't sure how he would fit with the foreign policy team he planned. So Holbrooke was left out in the cold once again. The following year the president asked him to return to the Balkans to try to advance the peace process. In June 1998, Clinton named Holbrooke ambassador to the United Nations -- a job he finally assumed after a long confirmation process. Holbrooke insists that he would be perfectly happy if this were his last job in the government, and when I raised the subject of ambition, he bristled. "I can't do anything about the story line," he said, "and maybe some of my own actions contributed to it. But I can tell you if my goal in life was simply to be secretary of State, I would not have behaved the way I behaved over the last 20 years. I was interested in policy, and the people who got the secretary of State job were usually much more careful about policy."
That's a fair point. At the same time, no one is betting against Holbrooke now that Al Gore's electoral fortunes are rising. One State Department official says: "People have begun saying, 'That was a brilliant comment Holbrooke made the other day.' And then someone else will say, 'I can't believe how that guy is already sucking up to Holbrooke.' And then we spend the rest of the day chewing over that."
Of course, Al Gore may lose or look elsewhere, and we'll never get to know what kind of secretary of State Richard Holbrooke would have made. Holbrooke's private views are probably not far from Clinton administration policy on most matters, though he felt that a more deft negotiator -- himself, perhaps -- could have avoided a war in Kosovo. In broad terms, Holbrooke says, "My greatest concern is the gap between rhetoric and resources." Republicans generally argue that the United States should tone down its rhetoric to match its modest resources; Holbrooke takes the opposite view. 
But this view is also an implicit criticism of the Clinton administration, which has been known for using grand moral language without making solid commitments. International relations in this post-cold-war era have become increasingly technocratic and mercantilist. Holbrooke is saying that our commitments must be equal to our power.
Holbrooke has watched most of the great negotiators of the last few generations, and he has, he says, borrowed from all of them - Cy Vance's precision, Bob Strauss's use of humor, Kissinger's complexities and creativity, Harriman's tenacity." When Holbrooke describes his own style, he tends to talk about the difference between jazz and architecture -- which is to say, the difference between open-ended improvisation and being bound to a prior design. Holbrooke operates by feel and trusts to his instincts as much as to his analytical understanding. "He walks into a meeting with nothing -- no talking points," says one State Department official. "He's like Muhammad Ali -- he's yakking and talking; he's jiving. The first time you see it you think it's just bull; in fact, he's psyching out the other person and reading the reaction. He has this great talent of figuring out what the other person's bottom line is. His diagnostic skills are really remarkable. And when he sees the thread, he just goes after it. It's almost comical, it's so transparent. But it really works."
I had a chance to watch Holbrooke in action in mid-November, during a break he took from laying siege to Capitol Hill. He had invited the three Bosnian co-presidents to the United Nations to commemorate the fourth anniversary of Dayton. They had reluctantly agreed to negotiate several major issues that had not been settled in Dayton and that had since stalled in Sarajevo. And so at 5 p.m. on a Sunday, Holbrooke and his aides sat down on one side of a conference table in Holbrooke's official residence at the Waldorf Towers, while the presidents sat on the other -- the Muslim, Alija Izetbegovic; the Serb, Zivko Radisic; and the Croat, Ante Jelavic. They were joined by their aides and by Milorad Dodik, the prime minister of Republika Srpska, a Serb "entity" inside Bosnia. The presidents almost never met together; they sat stiffly side by side and spoke to Holbrooke even when addressing one another.
Holbrooke began by persuading an extremely grudging Izetbegovic that the Bosnian presidency couldn't function effectively without a staff, which Izetbegovic had blocked because he wanted the staff to consist mostly of Muslims rather than equally of the three ethnic groups. Izetbegovic agreed to a staff of six people -- two, two, two." Holbrooke got him up to 9, then 15. Holbrooke decided to quit while he was ahead, but he inserted the words "initially" and "at least" into the draft.
Another thing Bosnia lacked was a border service. Local police were guarding the borders, and black market goods were pouring through. This would be a much tougher issue. For one thing, Jelavic had to answer to Croatian black-marketeers, and Holbrooke's aides feared that he had been instructed to stall. Jelavic delivered a long and intransigent speech, and then Radisic delivered another speech. Then for an odd moment everyone appeared to agree, and then it became clear that no one agreed. Holbrooke rode it along for a while, then he abruptly shifted gears. He smacked the table good and hard and shouted, "Stop!"
Here, for a moment, was the fabled Sir Richard of Belgrade. Holbrooke looked hard at the three men and said, "Is this a misunderstanding about what the police do, or an attempt to prevent an agreement from happening?" That produced a sheepish moment, and then more bickering. The problem was somewhere else. Holbrooke motioned to Muhamed Sacirbey, the Bosnian ambassador and an old sparring partner from Dayton, who whispered to him that it wasn't Jelavic but Milorad Dodik who was blocking the agreement. Holbrooke summoned Dodik and a translator, and they left the room for 20 minutes. I don't know what Holbrooke promised him, but when Dodik came back, he no longer had a problem. Holbrooke, who kept passing me notes and beckoning me over during the talks, told me that he likes to walk out during negotiations to force the other parties to move forward on their own.
The three presidents ultimately signed a document strongly resembling the "New York Declaration" that the American team had drawn up in advance. Tom Miller, the United States ambassador to Bosnia, told me later that Holbrooke had come in from his weekend place in Bridgehampton (there's also a ski house in Telluride) an hour before the meeting and was basically winging it.
There is a widespread feeling in and around the United Nations that in the aftermath of the disastrous intervention in Somalia in 1993, Madeleine Albright, then the ambassador to United Nations, concluded that the easiest way to get her ticket punched to become secretary of State was to attack the United Nations. It wasn't hard; the United Nations had experienced one disaster after another, and the secretary general, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, was a highly unpopular figure in the United States. (A good deal of bitterness toward Albright still lingers in the organization.) Richard Holbrooke was hardly known as a friend of the United Nations; he had been brutal on the organization's dithering on Bosnia and had in fact banned the United Nations from Dayton. And so when he arrived, diplomats and United Nations officials were waiting to see if he, too, would take to bashing the organization. Holbrooke took a trip to Kosovo just before taking up his official duties in New York, and while there he made a point of praising Bernard Kouchner, who had been the subject of high-level sniping inside the Clinton administration. Then the East Timor crisis blew up, and Holbrooke played a small but critical role, calling around to Security Council members and insisting that the Council pass a resolution instantly to prevent further bloodshed.
And Holbrooke earned a lot of points inside the institution when Congress agreed to begin paying the money the United States owed. "It makes a difference to us to have an American figure who can operate at the highest level," says Sir Jeremy Greenstock. "He's able to project power to a point."
There is some grumbling about Holbrooke from some of the professionals in the United Nations Secretariat, but very little from the diplomats themselves, who seem to be less obsessed with matters of etiquette than you might think. "What I like about Holbrooke is that he's not very diplomatic," says Peter van Walsum, the Dutch ambassador. "He's willing to use the word 'evil' when it's appropriate."
Holbrooke also seems to have forged a very close relationship with the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, whom he praises as lavishly in private as he does in public. Annan returns the favor, giving Holbrooke major credit for the fact that "the standoff and the taboo have been broken." The Holbrookes and the Annans see one another fairly often, and a few weeks ago, at the end of a women's lunch that Kati Marton gave for Annan's wife, Nane, the two husbands suddenly popped out of the elevator on a surprise visit, having sneaked out of some high-level lunch of their own. They made an odd pair of conspirators: Holbrooke stood there beaming and cackling, his arm around various power females, while Annan stood by his wife's side with his typical air of serene and almost royal benevolence.
Nothing is more typical of Holbrooke than his decision to dedicate his entire month as president of the Security Council in January to Africa and to even give it a tag: "month of Africa." It was a public relations stunt with a profound message. The very idea of a "month of" was almost unheard of, especially for any of the five permanent members of the Council. So Holbrooke got credit for entrepreneurship. But Holbrooke also understood the special potency of Africa, a place that absorbed much of the United Nations' attention and resources and virtually none of the United States'. "The Africans," I once heard him tell a visitor, "are obsessed with their theory that we only care about Europe and Asia." Boutros Boutros-Ghali had described the Balkans as "a rich man's war." Thus the "month of Africa" was Part 2 of Holbrooke's mission of re-engagement: first, pay the arrears, and second, take an activist role. (Part 3 is to reform the organization to make it more effective, as Congress has demanded.)
Holbrooke's plan was to use the month to concentrate maximum publicity on the African continent, on the United Nations and on the United States' role in the United Nations. He arranged a series of star turns -- first Gore and then Nelson Mandela, who had agreed to come to brief the Security Council on his efforts to defuse a pending civil war in Burundi. Holbrooke instructed his aides to make sure that the galleries were packed for both men. He was just sitting down for a staff meeting to plan out the month when a phone was brought over. It was Mandela, who was calling with suggestions for the dinner party Holbrooke would be giving for him.
Holbrooke devises dinner parties with the care of a celebrity hostess, mixing and matching from his bottomless store of stars, wise men, experts and whatnot. Now he was writing down names -- the actress Alfre Woodard, the actor Denzel Washington. Holbrooke, who has developed a joshing relationship with Mandela, said: "Mr. President, you know HBO has bought my book on Bosnia, and I want Denzel Washington to play me in the movie. . . . I know what you're thinking -- he's too young to play me." Holbrooke knows precisely how much irony he needs to leaven his own vanity.
Throughout the early part of the month, Holbrooke met with diplomats and United Nations officials to plan negotiations over Congo. A peace agreement, known as the Lusaka Accord, had already been signed the previous summer by Laurent Kabila, the president of Congo, as well as the heads of six neighboring states. But the deadlines in the agreement proved meaningless. Holbrooke's inspiration was to bring the signatories together in New York, offer them a chance to make a statement before the Security Council and then induce them to sign a new and much more specific version of the accord's military annex, which dealt with the withdrawal of foreign forces. Both United Nations and State Department officials were skeptical of this grand venture, but Holbrooke argued that without Lusaka Plus, as he dubbed his hypothetical agreement, the United States Congress would never sign off on the United Nations peacekeeping resolution that the signatories themselves craved.
I heard Holbrooke explain this line of reasoning in a meeting with the ambassadors from the signatory nations. They all seemed very enthusiastic, and Holbrooke lavished his usual hyperbolic praise on them -- this is the most valuable group of any group I've met with" -- but as they went around the room, the Zimbabwean ambassador, Tichaona Jokonya, said that his president, Robert Mugabe, was coming to New York to get a peacekeeping resolution, not to renegotiate Lusaka. Holbrooke turned away in disgust. "Mugabe is indispensable to this process," he said to the group. And then he proceeded to dilate on Mugabe's greatness, as if that would help matters somehow.
Holbrooke began making the case for Lusaka Plus to journalists and diplomats in more and more fervid terms. Congo was becoming, in his mind, a crucible for the international system, as the Balkans had been before, and perhaps as Vietnam had been before that. "The Congo has been the graveyard of the United Nations, literally and figuratively," he said to me one day. Dag Hammerskjold, the sainted secretary general, died in a plane crash on a failed peace mission to Congo in 1961. "If we don't get it right in the Congo," Holbrooke said solemnly, "we're going to go down."
Holbrooke seemed to be getting carried away with his own melodrama. But Holbrooke always raises the stakes, both to flatter the reluctant and to make intransigence seem immoral. Working with Kofi Annan, African diplomats and American ambassadors, Holbrooke succeeded in persuading all seven heads of state to come to New York -- a highly improbable achievement all by itself. On Jan. 24, the Lusaka signatories made a magnificent entrance to the Security Council. Secretary of State Albright was there to introduce them, and Annan himself escorted each of them to a seat at the Security Council -- a bit of pageantry that Holbrooke had seen to personally.
Unfortunately, the private discussions were not working out as well as the public pageantry. Holbrooke and his staff drew up another New York Declaration for Kabila and the other heads of state to sign, but no one was in a mood to sign or even to negotiate. The discussions may have produced more harm than good, according to one person who was involved, since several of the heads of state experienced Holbrooke's rather brisk cajolery as bullying: "They viewed it as a bit of an insult to be asked to come to New York and be told to sign something when they got here. Mugabe, especially, just blew up like a Roman candle."
Mugabe was so angry that Holbrooke crashed a dinner party being held in the president's honor in the hope of mollifying him. When it became obvious that he was failing, he ducked out, called Secretary Albright, who was at the Waldorf, and she then came and calmed Mugabe down. Unlike in Bosnia, these heads could not be knocked. As Holbrooke's aide on African issues, Alex Laskaris, says: "Lusaka is one of the few things they've ever agreed on. They view opening it as more destructive than constructive, even though they're extremely frank about its limitations." The Congo negotiations exposed the dangers of a diplomacy of activism and hubris and nervous energy.
Kabila did, in fact, reiterate his willingness to engage in a "national dialogue" with all segments of Congolese society; and all the signatories rededicated themselves to the process of a negotiated withdrawal. At the same time, Kabila apparently did not feel particularly bound by whatever language he signed on to, since his army continued violating the cease-fire. The Africans, though delighted by Holbrooke's activism, were not very pleased by the outcome of the talks. Joseph Mutaboba, the Rwandan ambassador, describes the United Nations session as "yet another meeting" in which the signatories repeated what they had said elsewhere and accomplished little of substance.
When I asked Holbrooke what happened, he conceded that he hadn't gotten the specific timetable he had wanted, but insisted that "we got enough so that we didn't need that." Lusaka Plus, he said, was really about "going in the right direction" rather than about the particulars that he had not long ago considered indispensable. Here, truly, was Holbrooke's gift for improvisation; he was redefining success as he went along.
On the other hand, if you want to err on the side of caution, then you're wasting your time with Holbrooke. If there is such a thing as a Holbrooke Doctrine, it probably has less to do with an overarching theme of engagement than with a predisposition toward engagement itself. Holbrooke once expounded the theory to me as follows: "Henry Kissinger's view is that you don't get in these things unless your chance of success is 85 to 90 percent, because you're putting the American national interest on the line, and you can't pay the price of failure. I understand that view insofar as during the cold war any setback to the United States was a gain for the Soviet Union, but in the post-cold-war world, where the United States is the single leader and great things are expected of us, we should try even if our chances of success are less than 50 percent. When we went in to Dayton our chances were about 20 percent, maybe 30 percent. In the Congo today, they're less than 50 percent. The downside equation is different from the one Kissinger taught us to live by, and which many of my colleagues still live by."
In other words, tuck those ski poles under your arm, tug your hat down and head for the bumps. It's a nervy and rather attractive formulation. And the inference, of course, is that this is the moment to give it a try -- that is to say, Richard Holbrooke's moment.
