HEADLINE: The Awful Truth

BYLINE: By Jason Berry; Jason Berry's books include "The Spirit of Black Hawk" and "Lead Us Not Into Temptation: Catholic Priests and the Sexual Abuse of Children."

 BODY:

Under the Knife
 How a Wealthy Negro Surgeon Wielded Power in the Jim Crow South.
 By Hugh Pearson.
 Illustrated. 249 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $24. 
 THIS is the story of a search, a quest narrative in which the author follows a trail of research toward reckonings about himself. Such is the premise that Hugh Pearson, a former editorial page writer at The Wall Street Journal, holds out as he travels from New York to southwest Georgia, the land of his forebears, seeking to understand his great-uncle Joseph Griffin, a powerful and esteemed physician, long since dead. Pearson prepares us for shocks to come as he reflects on "the price of shoring up, providing a few more bricks to the facade we Afro-Americans construct to maintain our dignity rather than tell the world or even ourselves everything about who we are."
Pearson comes from a long line of doctors; his father left the South to practice in Indiana. Looming large in the family lore was Uncle Joe, who was graduated from medical school in 1915 and established a practice in the town of Bainbridge, where he built the largest hospital for black people in the state of Georgia. He also became a millionaire.
In excavating his uncle's past, Pearson discovers caves of moral ambiguity. Griffin was a philanthropist in his community, a man whose economic power exacted respect from whites. He amassed his fortune, at least in part, by getting clients to deed over property when they could not pay for medical treatment. "All told, over a 50-year period there were 268 property purchases by or collateralizations to Joe Griffin in Decatur County, to say nothing of the surrounding counties," Pearson writes. In many cases, "he foreclosed and acquired the property of those unable to meet their obligations."
He also performed countless abortions at his hospital. Many of the pregnant women where white, including students from colleges in Florida and Georgia. "The revelation about the abortions my great-uncle performed," Pearson writes in one striking passage, "was the principal reason my father decided not to go to Bainbridge to practice medicine, something he didn't tell me until I began investigating the abortion issue." He says little more about this; his father's moral concerns dissolve into a kind of spin on Uncle Joe: "He had no problem because that meant one less child who had to go through the hell of living in this world. . . . Who knew more about the hell of living in this world than a Negro physician in the small-town Jim Crow Deep South? . . . It was a hell that no doubt hardened him, made him cynical. . . . Or if it was an ambitious Negro girl or coed he was performing the abortion for, maybe he was only too glad to ensure she could become something more than another embarrassing, depressing poverty statistic ending up with a little dirty, naked, potbellied Negro kid among the many dirty, naked, potbellied Negro kids he had delivered and cynically watched grow out of infancy."
It is hard to imagine Griffin not being cynical; it is also easy, thanks to Pearson's reporting, to imagine Uncle Joe's cynicism as handmaiden to his greed. The man who weathered legal problems with people whose property he consumed ended up facing criminal charges in 1967 (six years before Roe v. Wade) for performing abortions. He was 79 years old.
The closer Pearson gets to the character of Uncle Joe, the more ambivalent his own self-searching becomes. Griffin was tried on three counts of performing abortions and convicted of one; the results of that nightmare are dispensed within half a page. The potential in a trial sequence, and all kinds of fireworks about Griffin's character, fade quickly. Instead, Pearson quotes those who knew him. Paul Kwilecki, a Jewish photographer whose family did business with Griffin, and respected him, reflects: "An abortion at that time was worse than illegal. It was considered a very heinous, unscrupulous act for a man who had taken the Hippocratic oath. . . . Dr. Griffin's life poses a question, this business of ambition driven by insecurity, or whatever it was driven by, versus principles and so forth and how we maneuver and skirt around obstacles like right and wrong to reach our destination. All of the elements of classic Greek tragedy are involved in his life."
Pearson extends this idea of tragedy by drawing memories from family members and neighbors who knew Griffin and comment upon his life as the action plays out. It is a measure of Pearson's honesty that he acknowledges his inability to put hard question to those he loves. At a crucial moment, he can't get the words out to Uncle Joe's daughter, now an elderly woman. He wonders if she feels she must atone for his life. "Does she pray for his soul, under the belief that your offspring must pray for you, asking God's mercy for the sins you committed during your life?"
As the question hangs, Pearson embraces the forgiveness so elemental to familial life. And so comes a poignancy transcending issues of race. "Some part of me was still proud of him, in fact, the lion's share of me," he reflects. "I felt bad for anyone who lost their land to my great-uncle. But the larger part of me thought of the robber barons and the legions of other millionaires who ruthlessly exploited or did something illegal on the way to their wealth. . . . I concluded that there aren't too many ways to become very wealthy, minus a certain ruthlessness and willingness to bend the rules."
In developing the biographical portrait, Pearson reflects on the lynchings, violence and economic deprivation that blacks suffered in the segregated South. There is an admirable candor in Hugh Pearson's weighing of of his own privilege -- an Ivy League education, access to reporting jobs -- against the harrowing experiences of his father's family in the South. These passages invest the narrative with a power and sense of urgency, and magnify Pearson's historical reportage on the struggle of early-20th-century black medical schools and physicians.
And yet, what might have been a graceful prose voice is marred by the author's relentless use of "Caucasian" and "Afro-American." The labels supersede words like "white" and "black" and come off as clunky, one page upon another, pounding the message that this book is about racial identity. Pearson's tendency to be preach weakens the strength of his message. A good literary scalpel would have improved the work. One closes this book with a curiosity about the author. "Under the Knife" is a moving passionate story that set Hugh pearson on a road to self-discovery. that search, that wrestling with his own identity, seems a beginning more than an end.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: Thinking Like a Town, Working Like a Region;
From Economic Development to Traffic Flow, Municipalities Learn to Join Their Neighbors

BYLINE: By EMILY BAZELON 

 BODY:
FOR hundreds of years, Connecticut government has been organized along town lines, often set by the distance of a comfortable Sunday horse-and-buggy drive to church on the central green. The result is that Connecticut still has 169 towns and no regional branch of government to link them.
So when a town taxes residents, sets up a fire department or just orders fertilizer for the green, municipalities tend to go it alone. Acting together as a region has been almost unheard of. 
 But towns are learning that such Yankee independence has a price. Planning experts say it results, for example, in traffic jams because of no coordination in planning roads, wasteful duplication of services and worse, makes it harder for towns to attract new businesses.
The latter problem has really gotten the attention of officials, and lately regional cooperation has begun to take root, with more and more towns working jointly on attracting new businesses, restoring river banks, police communication and even thinking about sharing tax revenue.
 "Businesses start to ask: 'What's the best and most efficient way to pick up trash, or run a police department, or collect taxes?" said Theodore Hershberg, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania. "Sometimes, efficiency will mean doing these things regionally rather than locally."
 Economic growth experts worry that the continued reliance on home rule by many states like Connecticut undermines the way they run and their future prosperity. The experts said the global economy is pushing businesses to search for lean government, which can often be found in younger parts of the country like Phoenix that have centralized decision-making over a metropolitan region.
Persuaded by such logic, some Connecticut towns are trying out a new form of collective problem-solving. In a series of big and small experiments, towns are cooperating to bring in new business, paying collectively for services and pooling resources to unsnarl problems like traffic.
What's happening is a patchwork throughout the state. Twenty-nine towns around Hartford save money by collectively buying goods like natural gas and grass fertilizer, and are jointly planning to train workers. Last year, 670 police cruisers in the region got laptop computers so officers from different towns could talk to each other.
A group that includes elected officials and business leaders from 15 towns around New Haven is pointing biotech business, a potential plum, toward a 70-acre West Haven site on Route 34.
"Attitudes have changed," said Tony Rescigno, first selectman of North Haven. "If a business comes to me, I have no hesitation saying you may be interested in what Madison or West Haven has to offer."
In the northeast part of the state, eight towns market themselves at trade shows as a regional package. "With so many people trying to get their attention, businesses don't have time for one small town. But as a region, they'll look at us," said Elizabeth Murphy, director of Putnam's economic development commission.
Out-of-state businesses said they've benefited from a nonprofit organization funded by 22 towns, including New London, Old Lyme and Stonington, in the southeastern part of the state. The organization handles inquiries from businesses interested in relocating to that area. "They made our job so much easier," said Nancy Tyrrell, director of business development for Medichem, a Chicago-based pharmaceutical research company that recently opened a New London office. "It was completely different from dealing with New Jersey, where we had to struggle just to get information."
The organizational tools for regional cooperation come in many forms, and what actually gets accomplished varies greatly. Towns threaded along the state's major rivers have tried to coordinate restoration of a shared waterway. For example, 30 towns in the northern part of the state are at work on a project to restore the Quinebaug River.
In the state's rural outposts, towns tend to be skittish about getting sucked into the orbit of the nearest big city, but they are beginning to join with neighboring small towns.
Then there are the regions around Hartford, New Haven, Bridgeport, and New London, in which suburban towns circle a core city. Elected officials work with business leaders on boosting economic development through a "council of government" and a "regional growth partnership." The idea is to get a region's major players behind a big plan, like Hartford's Adriaen's Landing, and to share responsibility for stumbling blocks like a bad highway interchange that prevents suburban employees from getting to work in the city.
"There's more understanding on the part of the wealthier suburbs that success for an urban center can mean success for the suburbs and that if the core city initiatives fail, some of the problems are necessarily going to move outward," said Marc Ryan, secretary of the State Office of Policy and Management.
Still, resistance to regional takeover runs deep. Connecticut was the first state to establish counties in 1666, and the first and only state to abolish them in 1959, after Gov. Abraham Ribicoff denounced county government as patronage-ridden and outmoded.
When the state legislature stripped the counties of all authority, with the exception of sheriffs' departments, towns started handling regional problems piecemeal. The result is a quilt of districts to manage water, sewage, public transit, and other services. Critics said the districts are inefficient and lack accountability.
"We have all these different shadow regional entities, and no one knows how much gets spent by all of them and who exercises the power," said Lawrence J. DeNardis, a former state senator and congressman.
Traditionally, towns cooperated on services like water and sewage when each clearly stood to gain and saw little threat to local autonomy. It's not hard to see why the towns of Weston and Wilton began operating joint emergency medical services last year. But that argument gets harder to make when the subject is which town gets to host a new business.
When towns compete for new businesses, their rationale is simple: While a company in Vernon may create jobs for some Manchester residents, it pays taxes only to Vernon. Pooling tax revenue has long been unthinkable in Connecticut, particularly to suburban towns that want to shield their better-off tax bases from poorer neighboring cities.
Yet with the support of the public-private growth councils, some towns are taking steps toward regional tax-sharing.
To raise $1.5 million a year for a riverside park system that runs through Hartford and East Hartford, the residents of eight neighboring towns agreed to small increases in water bills last year.
Such agreements could become more commonplace if the legislature passes a bill backing voluntary tax-sharing between towns. Supporters said the bill would help concentrate development in a region's most appropriate sites.
"If the small towns in northeast Connecticut could share in the property tax gain from a development in the Killingly industrial park, then they wouldn't have to change their rural character. And maybe their support is what keeps the development in Killingly," said Joel Cogan, director of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities.
The voluntary tax-sharing bill passed the State Senate in 1998, but never came to a vote in the House. Mr. Cogan is hoping for widespread support this year. But tax sharing has been on the legislative agenda before and gone nowhere. One often-heard concern is that allowing voluntary agreements now will open the door to compulsory ones later.
Some people who support regional cooperation see voluntary tax sharing as a litmus test. If Connecticut isn't ready to take this relatively easy step, they ask, how will towns ever cooperate on affordable housing and education, where the interests of small municipalities and larger cities clearly diverge? "On the really tough issues, the towns retreat to localism," said Emil Frankel, a former state transportation commissioner.
Others stress the importance of starting somewhere. "My hope is that we're building the trust that will allow us to tackle the difficult ones later," said John Crawford, chairman of the New Haven area's Regional Growth Partnership.
The modesty of many of the 900 cooperative examples on a state-compiled list -- for example, two towns jointly buying trash bags or training paramedics -- shows that in comparison to states with big metropolitan areas or well-established counties, Connecticut doesn't offer much in the way of regionally based services. Continuing ambivalence about the issue is expressed by Richard Lee, the mayor of New Haven in the 1960's: "Towns and cities are cooperating on a far greater scale now than they did 40 years ago, and that's good. But if I were mayor today, I'd be perfectly content with the existing structure."
Despite such skepticism, advocates are beginning to promote a more ambitious kind of regional thinking than Connecticut has tried before, one that cuts across state as well as town lines. They're shopping a map that expresses this new perspective. The map ignores town and state boundaries, and instead divides the region along three market roues with hubs in New York, Boston and Albany.
"The regional growth councils have been helpful, but they don't help you think about the relationship between Hartford and Springfield, or between New Haven and Bridgeport," said Mr. Ryan of the State Office of Policy and Management. "The new economic regions have nothing to do with cities or towns or states. That's really a unique thought in Connecticut, but it's where we need to get to."

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 686 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Cisco Takes Internet Phones to Next Stage

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
It was a year ago that John T. Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems, said he wanted the traditional telephone on his desk to be gone in 12 months.
That has not happened; the old phone is still there. But today, Cisco intends to announce an office telephone system based on Internet technology. 
 The system, which transmits voice calls in the electronic language of the Internet, could push the company to the top of the budding Internet-telephone market. Proponents say such systems bring new convenience, efficiency and cost-savings to corporate communications.
While North America's traditional office telephone powerhouses, Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks of Canada, are also developing Internet phone systems for offices, Cisco may have the early edge.
Merrill Lynch intends to make Cisco's the main phone system at a new campus in Hopewell, N.J., with 5,000 of the new phones to be installed over 18 months.
In addition, Texas Instruments is experimenting with about 500 of the new phones in an international test. Executives from both companies are giving the new Cisco system positive reviews.
For all of the ways in which technology has changed how people live and how companies do business, the final frontier of the first Internet revolution will probably be the humble telephone.
Many communications companies are promoting so-called Internet telephony as a low-cost long-distance alternative for consumers. But the sound quality of phone calls over the public Internet is generally inferior to that of calls over traditional telephone systems. The technologies and systems are not yet in place to allow the Internet to reliably transmit high-quality phone calls for millions of people.
Office networks, however, are in some ways much more stable than the public Internet, perhaps making them more amenable to early Internet telephone efforts.
Most offices now have two communications networks, one for computers and another for telephones. Many companies maintain separate staffs for each. Cisco's vision is to allow companies to use a common Internet-based network for both computers and telephones internally, reducing cost and complexity and adding new functions to the telephone.
"The networks that can't do data, voice and video are dinosaurs," Mr. Chambers said in an interview on Friday. "We're going to see open standards for any new telecommunications or computer product to connect to one network. This is the first gauntlet thrown down in that direction."
Cisco's new Internet phones connect to an office's Ethernet data network using a jack like those on the back of a standard office computer. One of the most attractive features of the system is that the phone can identify itself to a corporate network regardless of its location. A worker from New York, for instance, could take his or her phone to a corporate office in San Francisco and be reached as easily as in Manhattan.
"You can plug the phone into any connection, and it will keep the same number you had," Brian J. Bonner, chief information officer and a vice president at Texas Instruments, said. "You can take your phone and plug it in at a T.I. office in Germany, for instance, and I can dial your number, which looks like Dallas, and it rings in Germany."
When a worker changes offices at a company that uses a traditional phone system, a technician must generally reconfigure the phone system so that the worker's old phone operates correctly at the new location. An Internet phone system can eliminate that effort and cost, leading some of Cisco's customers to believe that the Internet system would be much cheaper to operate.
"There are some very compelling economics associated with I.P. phones relative to traditional phones," said John A. McKinley, chief technology officer and an executive vice president at Merrill Lynch, referring to Internet protocol, the language of cyberspace. "Ultimately, I think this represents the next stage in growth for Cisco."
Mr. Chambers must think so, too. The traditional phone by his desk shares space with one of his company's new creations.

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, a 21-day cash management bill being auctioned on Tuesday, and both a two-year note and a 19-day cash management bill auctioned on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Big Spring Seen for Art Sales

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
As news of the federal antitrust investigation of Sotheby's and Christie's broke at the end of January, these auction houses were right in the middle of trying to convince sellers that it was the time to put their prized works of art in the houses' big May New York sales.
"We did get calls from people asking how the investigation would affect the market," said David Norman, head of Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department in New York. "And I'm sure some people held back. But not many." 
 The investigation centers on allegations of price fixing between the two major auction houses and has resulted in the resignations of both companies' chief executives and biggest business getters: Diana D. Brooks of Sotheby's and Christopher Davidge of Christie's. But their departures have not hurt consignments yet, although no one is saying if any of the best paintings this spring were actually promised many months ago.
Now, as the catalogs for the Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions are about to go to the printers, experts say this spring's important sales are as strong as they have been in years past. (Sotheby's and Christie's will each be offering well over $100 million worth of paintings, drawings and sculptures in their Impressionist art sales alone.) All that is missing is a large estate.
"We haven't seen the major estates that we saw in 1995, '96 and '97," said Christopher Burge, Christie's honorary chairman in North and South America and its principal auctioneer. "But people are realizing that the market is strong and that it hasn't necessarily peaked. It's a good time to sell, especially for longtime collectors who bought years ago."
Rather than the usual tug-of-war between the two powerful auction giants, this season has been marked by the appearance of a new and rich presence that has aggressively invaded Sotheby's and Christie's turf: Phillips, the sleepy, 206-year-old auction house that was bought by LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton in October. Now, with the deep pockets and competitive instincts of its chairman, Bernard Arnault, officials at Phillips have been offering sellers huge guarantees -- an undisclosed sum promised to a consignor regardless of the sale's outcome -- in order to put together an auction on a par with Sotheby's and Christie's. As a result for the first time in its history Phillips will have $80 million worth of Impressionist and modern art to sell on May 11.
But those who have been around the auction business remember when a little-known Geneva-based auction house named Habsburg Feldman opened a Manhattan office in a grand town house on the Upper East Side in the late 1980's and began holding auctions of fine art. While the market was hot, so was Habsburg Feldman. But as soon as the economy hit the skids in 1990, Habsburg Feldman fell apart. 
While experts say Mr. Arnault, with his endless sums of cash, will not let that happen, the manner in which Phillips has been handing out large sums to sellers is staggering. In some cases when officials at Sotheby's and Christie's made offers to sellers, they said they simply did not feel comfortable trying to match the offers Phillips had made. Experts at both companies say Phillips is getting some material they would have liked to sell, but neither was prepared to risk the kind of money that Phillips has offered.
Both dealers and auction house experts are envisioning a number of outcomes. One is that with the scarcity of great material on the market, if things go well for Phillips, sellers will start demanding unrealistically high estimates that could artificially inflate the market. Another is that in today's market buyers are savvy enough to find out what things are worth and bid accordingly. And since in some cases Phillips is paying far more than the true market value, this could mean Phillips's sale could be a disaster.
Dan Klein, the international executive director at Phillips, declined to discuss either the estimates or the guarantees, saying only, "It will all become clear when the catalog comes out." (The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs requires auction catalogs to disclose any financial interest the house has in the works it sells.)
But Mr. Klein was happy to talk about some of the sale's top paintings. There will be a group of works from Japan that include a Cezanne landscape, "The Surroundings of Gardanne" (1886-1890). It is expected to sell for $8 million to $10 million.
Phillips's star attraction, however, is Malevich's "Suprematist Composition," an austere abstract composition that until recently has been hanging on the walls of the Museum of Modern Art. The artist's 31 heirs won a claim to get the painting back last year, and they have given it to Phillips to sell.
While the auction house says the painting dates from 1919, curators at the museum say it was painted later, from 1923 to 1925. The difference in dating is important, experts say. If it was made in 1919, it is far more valuable. Just how much it is worth is anyone's guess. Even Phillips refuses to say, but experts at other auction houses believe the company has given the heirs a $15 million guarantee.
Officials at Sotheby's and Christie's maintain they have been conservative about the amount of financing they have offered sellers this spring. Christie's star painting -- and what is expected to be the season's blockbuster -- Picasso's "Still Life With Tulips," a 1932 portrait of the artist's mistress Marie-Therese Walter, does have a guarantee, though no one will say how much. The painting, which will be offered on May 9, comes from a European collector who wishes to remain anonymous and who has owned it since 1957. Christie's estimates it will sell for between $25 million and $30 million.
Franck Giraud, head of Christie's 19th- and 20th-century art department worldwide said that this season he had been able to put together a stronger sale of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, but that 20th-century material has been harder to find. On May 8 Christie's Impressionist and Post-Impressionist auction will feature several big-ticket paintings.
There is a spectacular Caillebotte, "Man on the Balcony, Boulevard Haussmann" (1880), which depicts the back of a man who experts think was the artist's lawyer, Albert Courtier. It carries an estimate of $6 million to $8 million. The painting has been included in several major Caillebotte exhibitions in the United States and abroad.
A Gauguin that had been hanging in the Dallas Museum of Art as part of the Wendy and Emery Reves Collection, "Farm at Le Pouldu" from 1890, is also in the sale. Nicholas Maclean, head of Christie's Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art in New York, said it has been suggested that the painting is part of a triptych, with the other two in the National Gallery of Art in Washington. It is expected to sell for $7 million to $9 million.
Christie's sale also includes an unusual 1894 portrait by Renoir of the artist Berthe Morisot seated and painted in profile with her daughter, Julie Manet, standing behind her. The painting is being sold by descendants of Morisot and is estimated to sell for $9 million to $12 million.
Also carrying a $9 million to $12 million estimate is one of Monet's famous "Waterlily" series. This one, dated 1906, is a particularly luscious image. A similar one sold at Christie's in November for $22 million. Little wonder that Christie's has estimated this one could well sell for $20 million to $25 million.
Sotheby's is also selling a Monet "Waterlily," although a work done two years later and therefore less valuable. It, too, explores the visual effects on the surface of the artist's famous pond at Giverny and is expected to bring $7 million to $9 million. But another well-known Monet image, that of Rouen Cathedral, painted between 1892 and 1894, will be the top lot of Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art sale on May 10. Painted in the midday sun, it is expected to bring between $15 million and $20 million.
Sotheby's also has a 1932 Picasso, but rather than a portrait this is a still life, "Guitar and Fruit Bowl," which has imagery that suggests the body of Marie-Therese Walter. The painting belonged to Douglas Cooper, the collector whose works were sold at Christie's in 1992. Eight years ago the painting sold for $3.85 million. Now Sotheby's believes it will bring $10 million to $15 million.
Among the more contemporary offerings this spring there is a stunning Rothko, "Yellow Over Purple" from 1956, that is the star of Sotheby's contemporary art sale on May 17. Its canvas, a wash of yellows and oranges, is "everything you could possibly want in a Rothko," said Tobias Meyer, director of Sotheby's contemporary art worldwide. It is expected to bring $7 million to $9 million. The sale is filled with blue-chip artists: Warhol and de Kooning, David Hockney and Gerhard Richter from a mix of well-known European and American collectors.
"Buyers are hungry for great material," said Mr. Meyer. But he added: "In this strong economy no one is selling out of financial need. This material is coming from people who know the market is hot right now, and they're eager to take advantage of it."

HEADLINE: I.B.M.-Qwest Deal on Internet Data Centers

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
In a move to expand its ability to manage Web sites and software applications for corporate customers, I.B.M. intends to announce today that it has struck a multibillion-dollar deal with Qwest Communications International.
The pact calls for I.B.M. to build and help operate Internet data centers for Qwest across North America, executives from the two companies said on Friday. 
 One of the fastest-growing segments of the electronic economy is the so-called hosting business, in which information technology companies manage computer systems that run Web sites or internal software programs for corporate customers. The idea is that by allowing an outside concern to act as host for those computers, rather than managing them internally, companies can focus on their core business while receiving expert technical support.
"Customers are starting to get serious about using the Internet, about the use of e-commerce and about building the core processes that businesses run around what can be done on the Internet," said Douglas T. Elix, senior vice president of the I.B.M. unit involved in the effort. "This alliance expands our ability to meet those needs."
As basic communications lines become largely a commodity market, communications carriers of all sizes and descriptions are trying to expand into more sophisticated markets that can carry richer profit margins, like Web hosts. In recent years, Qwest, the upstart long-distance carrier, has announced alliances with companies including KPMG, the consulting firm, and Oracle, the database company, as it tried to expand its hosting business.
Now, Qwest has enlisted I.B.M. as perhaps its most significant partner. I.B.M. is already a leader among Web and computer-applications hosts, generating about $1 billion in annual revenue from those businesses. But managing complex computer systems -- I.B.M.'s forte -- often also requires managing complex communications networks.
"Keeping up with demand in this market is always a challenge, especially in finding qualified people," said Lewis O. Wilks, Qwest's president for Internet services. "Teaming with I.B.M. is a huge leap for us."
Under the deal, I.B.M. has agreed to build 28 North American data centers, each having at least 100,000 square feet of space, for Qwest over the next three years. The first four are to be in Dallas, Philadelphia, Sterling, Va., and near San Jose, Calif. Over the next seven years, Qwest intends to pay I.B.M. $2.5 billion in construction costs and management fees.
I.B.M. intends to lease about 25 percent of the space in the sites that it builds for Qwest. And over the seven-year life of their contract, I.B.M. intends to pay Qwest $2.5 billion for that space and for use of Qwest's fiber-optic communications network.
The two companies will generally continue to market their host services separately, but Mr. Elix and Mr. Wilks said that I.B.M. and Qwest would potentially collaborate and act as subcontractors for each other on certain projects.
The two executives declined to estimate how much revenue the deal would help their companies generate from outside customers.
In recent years, I.B.M. has appeared to ignore many other big communications carriers while announcing a series of strategic agreements with AT&T, whose chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, is a former I.B.M executive. By reaching a major deal with Qwest, one of AT&T's big competitors, I.B.M. may be trying to demonstrate that it is serious about forming partnerships across the telecommunications industry.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Uses Webcasts to Give Opinions Directly to Investors

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Interviews with analysts have been the stock in trade of financial television broadcasts for years. Now the large brokerage companies like Merrill Lynch, PaineWebber and others that have provided the analysts are putting them directly before clients, via their own Web sites.
Using streaming video technology, which is essentially broadcasting over the Internet, the financial service companies are experimenting with daily programs that resemble half-hour newscasts but feature the companies' own analysts, reporting on market trends and recommending hot stocks. 
 Wall Street Webcasting stands to further blur the line between financial service companies and the traditional media -- a process that began years ago when some of the big brokerage firms started sending television stations recorded interviews with analysts and video news packages featuring the firms' big clients. The self-generated Webcasts also raise questions about maintaining objectivity, when the primary purpose of the information being given is to attract clients and sell services.
The new Wall Street Webcasts are an example of how "the walls that have separated e-commerce from the media are coming down," said Mark A. Thalhimer, director of the Future of News project at the Radio and Television News Directors Foundation.
"What's happening now is that the news provider, to a much greater degree than before, has a financial stake in the transaction that is being presented to the public," Mr. Thalhimer said. "I wonder how consumers will view that, and how they will make the distinction between the news and someone so closely associated with selling something."
For their part, the financial service companies see no conflict. They consider what they are providing to be information that helps both their large investor clients and the typical individual investor.
"What we're providing is not just content, but context," said Frank Zammataro, first vice president of the Digital Business Development Group at Merrill Lynch.
Still, there is no question that the brokerage firms are competing with Internet stock-trading services like E*Trade for investors' attention. "If you understand how consumers are making decisions, then using the Internet this way presents an opportunity to shape those decisions," Mr. Zammataro said.
What Merrill Lynch provides is not really news, company officials say, but information and opinion to help investors. "What we feature can be newsworthy, but we are not a news organization," said Fred Yager, director of Merrill Lynch Global Broadcast Service.
Merrill Lynch is far ahead of the other financial service companies in Webcasting. Since last March the firm has put out two daily menus, one on its general Internet site (www.merrilllynch.com) for casual browsers and another just for clients.
"We were getting calls from clients asking, 'How come I've always got to see your analysts on CNBC -- why can't you get them to us first?' " Mr. Yager said.
The Webcast on the company's general Internet site, which is available starting at 11 a.m. each day the stock market is open, includes streaming video reports about industry trends. Securities regulations force Merrill Lynch to stop short of discussing particular stocks, because the audience is too broad.
At the end of the reports, however, viewers are told that if they want to know what Merrill analysts think about individual stocks in the featured industry, they should follow a link to the client site, askmerrill.com, which includes what is called the Global Investor Network. Once there, they have access to the complete Webcast. They can try a 30-day subscription, and get free permanent access by opening an account.
While the company has spent only an estimated $2 million on the Global Investor Network, it can put out a half-hour report using Merrill Lynch analysts on trading floors in New York, London, Hong Kong and Frankfurt. The heart of this Webcast is the summary of Merrill Lynch's morning call, the 7 a.m. meeting at which analysts discuss the most widely held and active stocks of the day. There are also segments on mutual funds, international investing and personal finances, all with Merrill Lynch analysts who talk about stocks they recommend.
With high-speed Internet connections, the Webcasts resemble television broadcasts, and once put on the site they can be downloaded by clients at any time. The connections tend to get clogged, which affects the video quality. At slower speeds, the images are hazy and movements quite jerky.
Mr. Yager, a former reporter and television producer, said that since the project began last March, viewership had increased from a few thousand a day to more than 100,000 daily hits.
In a few weeks, the site will be overhauled. Mr. Yager said that under the new format, clients would be able to switch from Webcast reports on one company to archived reports on other companies in the same field. They also will be able to download the text of complete research reports done by Merrill Lynch analysts on related stocks.
Merrill Lynch has long been involved in television production. Through its television network, it provides video interviews with Merrill Lynch analysts to hundreds of local television stations around the world that subscribe to the service.
Much of the production is handled by Bob Plunkett, a former Fox network television reporter who runs his own production company. Mr. Plunkett said the main difference between preparing a news segment for Merrill's Internet site and one for network television had to do with packaging. "When you're putting something out on the Web, you're basically giving it a lot more raw, straight objective data because we know who the audience is," Mr. Plunkett said. "If I was back at Fox, my audience would have been so broad that I'd have to present the material so that it could be understood by a big investment banker and the guy who shines his shoes."
Other financial service companies that do not have small clients do not have to put on separate Webcasts the way Merrill Lynch does. Goldman, Sachs, for example, plans to start a Webcast soon, but it will be directed toward its institutional investors.
PaineWebber expects to begin a trial of a daily Webcast this summer, according to Dennis M. McCann, the firm's director of marketing communications. Clients will also be able to pay bills and transfer funds while viewing the analyst report.
One of the biggest Wall Street firms, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, took a tentative step into streaming video earlier this month when it put on a widely publicized special Webcast about, appropriately, Internet stocks. The firm says it will follow up with other special Webcasts as warranted, but it is not ready to put out a daily report that includes video on demand.
Bear, Stearns & Company is already using streaming video to take the place of the investor roadshows it puts on in cities across the country to drum up support for new stock offerings. Peter D. Cherasia, head of e-commerce for Bear, Stearns, said he was discussing a deal with CNBC to use the firm's Web site to rebroadcast interviews done with its analysts after they appear on television. Once the company generates enough content, he said, it will revamp its Web site to include its own daily Webcast and other services.
"We want to make our site as sticky as possible," Mr. Cherasia said, using a term that refers to visitor retention, "so clients will have a reason to stay on or come back throughout the day."
Even as financial service companies seem intent on moving onto the terrain of the traditional media, broadcasters and news agencies are finding their way into financial services. In September, CNBC bought a 12.4 percent equity stake in Archipelago, a large electronic communications network that has applied to be registered as an Internet stock exchange. Other investors in Archipelago include Goldman, Sachs and Instinet, another electronic trading system that is part of the Reuters Group, the parent of one of the oldest news services in the world.
The president of CNBC, William L. Bolster, said there was currently no plan to take CNBC in that same direction. He noted that General Electric, CNBC's parent company, already has a financial arm -- GE Capital. "The CNBC business model doesn't envision that," he said in a telephone interview. "I'm saying no, but I can't categorically say that it will be no forever."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Liberty Media Plans to Take $130 Million Stake in IDT
Maintaining its drive into the telecommunications industry, John C. Malone's Liberty Media Group has agreed to invest $130 million for a stake of almost 10 percent in IDT, the communications carrier based in Hackensack, N.J.
Until AT&T's acquisition of Tele-Communications last year, Liberty was TCI's television programming unit. But over the last year, the company has shown interest in telecommunications. IDT regularly takes a leading role in creating communications niches. Page C8. 

OpenTV Plans to Buy Spyglass
OpenTV, which provides software that enables television viewers to go directly from TV shows to related Web sites, said that it would buy Spyglass, a pioneer in Internet browser software, in a $2.5 billion stock deal. C2.
 
Movie Systems for Deaf and Blind
Translucent screens that can carry text and images, but can also be seen through, are being introduced as a way to let deaf filmgoers view subtitles that are not visible to other patrons. The technology, along with a separate system that lets blind people use headphones to hear a description of the on-screen action, has been developed by the National Center for Accessible Media, which is trying to adapt existing systems to enable the deaf and the blind to go to conventional theaters. C13.
 
Cisco to Introduce Internet Phones
Cisco Systems intends today to announce an office telephone system based on Internet technology. The system could push the company to the top of the budding Internet-telephone market. Proponents say such systems bring new convenience, efficiency and cost savings to corporate communications. C4.
 
I.B.M.-Qwest Deal on Data Centers
In a move to expand its ability to manage Web sites and software applications for corporate customers, I.B.M. intends to announce today that it has struck a multibillion-dollar deal with Qwest Communications International. The deal calls for I.B.M. to build and help operate Internet data centers for Qwest across North America, executives said. C10.
 
A Drawback to Airline E-Tickets
The potential strike by flight attendants at US Airways, which was averted over the weekend, exposed one drawback of the electronic ticket not bought through a travel agent. While other airlines and even Amtrak said they would try to accommodate passengers with paper tickets, travelers with e-tickets could not expect such service. Computers at different airlines do not yet communicate well enough to share information on e-tickets. C15.
 
A Shift, Perhaps, in Online Vision
The only vision required to make zillions of dollars in the Internet economy is nearsightedness. The stock market remains so irrationally exuberant that almost every dot-com company can pick up $10 million or so in venture capital and make a bundle either on a quick initial public offering or acquisition, with nary a glance toward long-term viability -- or long-term investors. But the view may be shifting, with more emphasis placed on the creation of substantial businesses, common sense and ethics. Digital Commerce. C4.
 
Nonprofits Rely on E-Commerce
Nonprofit groups have begun to rely on electronic commerce to generate revenue and streamline their organizations. In so doing, these groups are not only finding new sources of money, they are also making better use of the money they already have. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C11.
 
Hollywood Joins Dot-Com Festival
The Yahoo Internet Life Online Film Festival, dedicated to the making and distribution of digital movies on the Internet, was a kind of coming out party, a faltering first date, for the worlds of mainstream Hollywood and online entrepreneurship. C13.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2127 words

HEADLINE: Through a Lens, Digitally;
Polaroid Girds for the New Era In Instant Photography

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
There is a paradox here somewhere.
Last year, Polaroid not only outsold its competitors in the growing digital camera field, it even turned a slim profit on those sales. Since analysts say that no one else is making money on digital cameras, it was a coup. 
 But talk to Polaroid executives and they shrug off digital cameras as simply Polaroid's way of marking time. They expect that a few years down the road, people will be snapping pictures with cell phones, Palm Pilots and the like -- and, they hope, printing them out on wireless Polaroid printers.
"The cameras are just another way of capturing images, many of which we hope people will want to print," said Gary T. DiCamillo, Polaroid's chief executive.
The accuracy of this forecast could determine Polaroid's chances for survival in a digital world.
Polaroid has always sold cameras pretty much at cost and made its money from chemical-and-paper film that develops itself in a minute or two. Since digital photography is essentially an electronic form of instant pictures, Polaroid is either in a special position to move into this field -- or specially suited to be rendered obsolete by it.
Of course, Polaroid executives stress the opportunities. "I laugh when people are surprised we're doing well in digital cameras," said Brian D. Poggi, senior vice president for North America. "After all, they're really the same as instant cameras: they provide an affordable and immediate picture."
But industry experts wonder whether the similarity will translate to sales. Many note that, even as film sales shrink, companies like Fuji and Kodak can still do a thriving business in sales of coated papers, which can be used to make high-quality prints of digital photos.
But a Polaroid customer who switches to digital photography is lost to the market for the company's self-developing film -- unless those customers use Polaroid printers or hybrid digital/instant cameras to make prints.
"It is not clear to me what long-term digital strategy can really replace what they are generating from film-based instant prints," said Steve Hoffenberg, a digital photography market analyst with Lyra Research in Newtonville, Mass.
Wall Street has similar concerns. Eastman Kodak and Polaroid have both had earnings problems that have driven their stock prices down in recent years. Kodak's stock remains mired in the $50's -- well below the nearly $70 it traded at a year ago. But many analysts say the company has cleaned up its digital portfolio and brought its costs under control, making its stock a good buy right now. Few are as upbeat about Polaroid, even though that company's stock closed at $25.1875 on Friday -- nowhere near the price of $60.25 it reached in July 1997, but a nice rebound from its low of $17.25 in December.
"Digital cameras, scanners, picture CD's, Web sites, they are all geared toward one thing -- driving output," said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "And the competitive picture for Polaroid in a digital world is a lot less clear than it is for Kodak."
Certainly, as the only instant photography company in the country, competition is not something Polaroid is used to. (The Fuji Photo Film Company sells instant cameras and film overseas, but when Kodak tried to do so here, the courts upheld Polaroid's patents.) But as the digital revolution is wooing many people from the 35-millimeter film camp, Polaroid could grab customers long loyal either to Fuji or Kodak.
"We used to be the only show in town for people who wanted instant gratification on their pictures, and yes, we've lost that," said Paul E. Lambert, Polaroid's senior vice president for research and development. "But for the first time, we can really tap into the conventional photography market."
Rather than try to capture a high-end digital market -- the strategy that Fuji and Kodak have pursued -- Polaroid has farmed out its production to overseas manufacturers, which make Polaroid-branded cameras that sell for as little as $99 and rarely top $300.
"Digital cameras are just their mechanism for building shelf space," said Michael Ellmann, an analyst with Schroder & Company.
True to its mass-market roots, Polaroid already is spewing forth products to fill those shelves. There is a portable scanner that can upload images to the Web. There is a digital camera with a built-in modem that can send pictures over the Web to Polaroid for transfer to prints, T-shirts or other items.
In February, Polaroid announced an alliance with PictureWorks Technology, a software company, to develop more Internet-related products. One on the drawing boards is a product to help dermatologists keep a digital-image record of a patient's progress during treatments for skin disorders and plug the pictures into insurance claims forms.
On the wireless front, Polaroid recently demonstrated a wireless printer that can receive images transmitted by radio waves from up to 50 feet away. "This makes the process truly portable, because digital cameras are no longer tethered to PC's," said Ulysses Yannas of Buckman, Buckman & Reid.
In fact, many of Polaroid's planned digital cameras will double as makeshift printers. The company already sells a combination instant-print and digital camera, aimed at teenagers, that is little more than two cameras glued together; the user cannot instantly print an image captured digitally. Within a year, though, Polaroid intends to introduce a hybrid camera that will collect images electronically, but will also generate an instant print with the press of a button.
And the company's chemists are working on a new type of paper for printing pictures that they claim will yield the same quality as the silver halide films that Fuji, Kodak and Polaroid now use, but at a much lower cost. By now, many inkjet printers can yield high-resolution 8 1/2-by-11-inch prints on photo-quality paper for less than a dollar each. Although conventional Polaroid instant film could be modified for use in a desktop printer, prints would cost several dollars apiece.
In the past, Polaroid's attempts to reduce costs were hamstrung by the need for a chemically treated paper that can both capture an image and print it; now, digital cameras take care of that first step. "If we don't have to worry about capturing the image, we can optimize how we print it out," Mr. Lambert said.
Polaroid is divulging few details about its research, and its new paper is at least two years from market. Still, what has leaked out excites analysts. "They're talking a few cents per print," Mr. Yannas said, "so they could capture a big share of the home print market."
That market promises to be huge. Indeed, photo processors already say digital cameras have increased, not decimated, their business. "Digital photography has created a whole new customer base for us," said Mitchell B. Goldstone, who owns 30 Minute Photo in Irvine, Calif. "People use less film, but they make more prints and enlargements."
But conventional photography companies will not give up market share without a fight. Kodak is researching non-silver-halide media for prints. Last week, it said it would soon begin selling lower-priced digital cameras. And it recently introduced a digital camera that can snap onto a Palm Pilot and transfer images to the device's memory.
Kodak also has a prototype digital camera that can e-mail images over a mobile phone. "The person receiving that e-mail image is likely to print it out, or send it to Kodak via the Internet to get prints," said Willy C. Shih, president of Kodak's digital imaging business.
Fuji, meanwhile, has been selling to photo processing labs a printing method that uses lasers and heat, rather than a wet process, to transfer images to paper. The company is now introducing a similar, scaled-down, dry-process photographic printer for home use. Unlike Polaroid and Kodak, Fuji is manufacturing its own digital cameras.
"Digital imaging is an industry unto itself, and we want to provide a cradle-to-grave solution in that space," said Manny Almeida, general manager of digital imaging at Fuji Photo Film USA.
There are still opportunities that no photography company has yet nailed down. B. Alexander Henderson, who covers the photographic industry for Prudential Securities, contends that all the photography companies should be promoting their corporate Web sites as places where customers can store their electronic photographs, with an eye toward making prints in years to come.
"Fuji, Kodak, Polaroid -- they could all generate repeat business in prints, and enough traffic to generate advertising revenue on their Web sites," he said. "The holy grail of the Internet is controlling content, yet none of them are doing it."
But then, all of the companies do have breathing space to get their digital acts together. Conventional photography is still growing fast in emerging economies like China. And the Photo Marketing Association says that amateur photography is a $15 billion annual market in the United States. Polaroid's own research shows that 90 percent of American households own cameras, but only 6 percent own digital cameras.
"Conventional cameras may get squeezed out within our lifetime," Mr. Almeida of Fuji said. "But in the next few years? No way."
Polaroid, too, says that sales of its conventional instant cameras and film are at a high. Last year, the company sold 9.7 million instant cameras, topping its 1978 record of 9.4 million. Its total sales hit $1.98 billion in 1999, up from $1.85 billion the previous year. And its net earnings were $9 million, a nice improvement from 1998, when weak demand in emerging markets combined with smaller orders from mass marketers in the United States to cause a net loss of $51 million.
Polaroid has been concentrating its marketing efforts on the youth market -- it just signed a sponsorship agreement with Britney Spears, the popular singer -- and its cameras have become hot sellers among teenagers. The company's I-Zone camera, a $25 item that yields postage-stamp-size pictures, was the best-selling camera in the country last Christmas season. "There's no question, Polaroid's instant cameras are going gangbusters," said Mr. Hoffenberg of Lyra Research.
But the excitement is clearly in digital products. "Instant photography will represent the majority of our business in the next five years," Mr. DiCamillo said, "but digital will be the fastest growing area."
That will probably be true in Polaroid's troubled commercial business as well. In contrast to its robust consumer sales, Polaroid's commercial sales, which in the past represented half its revenues, have been flat, and profit margins razor-thin.
Polaroid is banking that its mass market products will be used for commercial ends. A hospital in Canada, for example, uses Polaroid I-Zone cameras that yield sticky-backed prints to affix pictures to admissions records. "Half of our products are used in business, even if they're bought at Wal-Mart," said Stephen Golden, director of marketing for consumer electronics.
Of course, Polaroid does have strictly commercial products as well. Its digital microscopy camera, which captures what is seen through a microscope, is selling well to research labs, despite price tags that start at $6,000. Polaroid already is the world's largest supplier of photo ID cards, and it has its sights on becoming the company for digitally produced identification.
It is ready to introduce a system, particularly intended for the passport photo market, that would take and store photos digitally, but print them out on Polaroid film. Polaroid already produces the driver's licenses for 37 states, and it is testing a program in West Virginia for snapping and storing digital photos of children that police can use to help locate a missing child.
The company also has new technologies for incorporating fingerprints and facial recognition into ID cards. One system enables states to check whether someone has a driver's license in another name. And Polaroid just introduced a product, for sale to computer keyboard manufacturers, that would let people use their fingerprints in lieu of passwords and log-ons, by pressing their index fingers against a little window.
Polaroid also is using the Internet to expand its base of customers. It has begun accepting ID information and images via the Web, mailing back ID cards within 48 hours.
"This now makes us accessible to small businesses that don't want to spend thousands for an ID system," Mr. DiCamillo said. "I appreciate technology, but I'm a market-driven manager. And our strategy, now and in the future, will be driven by understanding what customers want."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 980 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Another Call for the Quarterback of Political Persuasion

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF William M. Daley ever needs to be reminded why President Clinton made him secretary of commerce, he need only hike across his office. On the far wall of the great rectangle, past the sofas, the generous hearth and the boardroom dining table, hangs a small photograph of the Oval Office with Mr. Daley and Mr. Clinton standing shoulder-to-shoulder inside. Inscribed across the bottom, in Mr. Clinton's curly scrawl, is a note of thanks to Mr. Daley for heading the Lazarus Project.
In the Clinton era, such biblical code is reserved for sensitive political missions. Mr. Daley headed one of Mr. Clinton's most successful: getting the North America Free Trade Agreement through a wary Congress in 1993. Mr. Daley, then working as a lawyer, was hired to salvage Nafta from what was seen as probable defeat. 
 "He thought I raised it from the dead," Mr. Daley said one recent afternoon, explaining how the project got its name and how he, a bit reluctantly, got his niche. "I enjoy the politics stuff, but you do get pounded with it."
Day to day, Mr. Daley oversees commerce duties like forecasting weather, counting how many people live in the nation, promoting United States goods abroad and collecting data on the national economy. But despite a self-conscious effort to thrive as a wonk -- as second son of the Chicago mayoral dynasty, he hopes to be remembered for something other than campaign savvy -- Mr. Clinton uses him as political offensive coordinator, especially when it is third and long.
So, in the twilight of Mr. Clinton's presidency as in its dawn, Mr. Daley is driving a White House legislative crusade. Along with Steven Richetti and a team of aides in every corner of the executive branch, Mr. Daley is trying to persuade Congress to grant China permanent normal trade relations. Mr. Clinton has called it his top remaining foreign policy goal. Mr. Daley, however he handles this year's census, has his reputation riding on a "yes" vote.
Like Nafta, it is an uphill struggle. Union pressure on Democrats, Republican loyalties to Taiwan and bipartisan concerns about human rights abuses have turned many lawmakers against extending permanent trading rights to China.
Mr. Daley calls the vote too "mushy" to predict.
The quarterbacking comes instinctively to Mr. Daley, who is 51. Like his father and his brother, the past and present Chicago mayors, politics runs in his blood. White House officials said Mr. Clinton trusts Mr. Daley's political intuition more than that of anyone else in the cabinet.
With brother Richard always first in line to fill the family shoes in Chicago, Mr. Daley practiced law at the Chicago office of Mayer, Brown & Platt and sought his fortune in national politics, working for Walter F. Mondale and Michael S. Dukakis before joining Mr. Clinton's presidential campaign.
The hoped-for payoff, a cabinet post, did not materialize in the first Clinton administration. But in early 1993 he was asked to move into the Old Executive Office Building next to the White House and mobilize support for Nafta. It was a paltry consolation prize -- his friend Dan Rostenkowski, then the Ways and Means chairman from Illinois, called him crazy for accepting -- but Nafta squeaked through Congress. And after the commerce secretary, Ronald H. Brown, died in a plane crash in 1996, Mr. Daley was offered the post.
IN an administration with many workaholics, Mr. Daley is known as an especially sober worker bee. His wife remains in Chicago, where their children are in school. He says it is easier that way because he is usually at the office when not on the road. He keeps the same long hours investment bankers do and dresses the way they used to. His close-cut blue suits and pinched shirt collars make him look prim even by Washington's atavistic standards of attire.
Mr. Daley would clearly prefer to enjoy the challenges and trappings of commerce secretary than the grind of a six-month legislative campaign. He said he is especially proud of little-noted achievements, like straightening out accounting practices in commerce's many units. With trademark deadpan, he said he hopes his legacy will be "getting out of here without hiring a lawyer."
Yet over a working lunch (chicken noodle soup in a plastic foam bowl, Diet Coke from a can) in his Olympic-pool-sized office, Mr. Daley says that shaping the China debate and cajoling members of Congress has become his new full-time job. His strategy: Link China trade to America's national security and the fate of China's reformers.
"The economics of this are great," he says. "But if this fight stays on economics, we lose. It has to be about Chinese politics, Taiwan and our position in the world. It's a big vote. Congress is just going to have to walk the plank."
To manage the process, Mr. Daley moved David Lane, his chief of staff, across the Mall to the White House. There, they set up a "war room" that monitors everything China and commands a remarkable chunk of Mr. Clinton's own schedule. He makes sure nearly every nanobyte of good news about bilateral relations -- a first-time export of oranges, China's decision to release the names of some political prisoners -- gets out to the press.
But Mr. Daley spends most of his time in one-on-one meetings with members of Congress. Some days he sees as many as six or seven members in their offices. He is taking 30 of them on an Air Force jet to China next month on a three-city, six-day lobbying tour that includes meeting with leaders in Beijing.
Will it work? Mr. Daley's efforts to get Congress to approve fast-track trade negotiating powers failed recently. But, having been through Nafta, he seems cautiously optimistic that he will prevail on China.
If not, he begs, only half in jest, please remember what he did to improve bookkeeping at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: ELECTION IN RUSSIA: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Washington Nail-Biting

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Monday, March 27

 BODY:
When Acting President Vladimir V. Putin met behind closed doors last month with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, he made an unusual appeal that Russia be considered a member of the Western club.
Mr. Putin said he liked to eat Chinese food, knew how to use chopsticks and regularly practiced judo. 
 "But that's exotic stuff," Mr. Putin said, according to aides who attended the session. "That's not our mentality. Our mentality is European."
The Clinton administration has a lot riding on a Putin victory and has been heartened by his remarks about the need to integrate Russia with the West.
Administration officials are not only anxious to get American-Russian relations back on track after a year and a half of drift since the collapse of the ruble in August 1998. In an election year, they also want to silence Republicans who have charged that Russia fell off the path of economic reform on President Clinton's watch.
And they would like to seal the Clinton presidency with a major arms control accord, one that would slash long-range nuclear arms and enable the United States to field a new network of antimissile defenses.
But Mr. Putin's autocratic instincts have cast a shadow over Washington's hopes. Setbacks on human rights or fresh reports of Russian atrocities in Chechnya would be major obstacle to closer relations, especially in an American election year.
"Clinton would like a strong leader he can work with but not one that is unleashed," said Toby T. Gati, who was a senior State Department official during the Clinton administration. "The hope is that Putin will turn out to be a reformer. The president and his advisers want to show Yeltsin left a legacy of reform that Putin can build on. They want to rebut the critics who say their Russia policy was a mistake."
With a complex agenda of overlapping and competing interests, there is no simple answer to what a Putin presidency could mean for Washington.
The prospect for closer ties is more favorable in the economic sphere, where Mr. Putin's goals overlap with Western interests, than in the area of security and human rights issues, where the two sides often collide.
On economics, Mr. Putin has signaled that he wants to establish the foundations of a modern capitalist state, not because he has a romantic infatuation with the free market, but because he understands that Russia must attract foreign investment and overhaul its rust belt industries to become a world power.
"A country where weakness and poverty reign cannot be strong," Mr. Putin wrote in an open letter to the Russian people.
To that end, Mr. Putin and his top aides have talked about overhauling the tax code, protecting the rights of shareholders, phasing out subsidies to money-losing enterprises and tackling politically dicey issues such as establishing the right to own land.
American officials have been impressed by Mr. Putin's talk of economic change, including his insistence that he wants Russia to be integrated into the world economy. They say he appears interested in achieving concrete results and understands that a boom in oil prices that has helped the Russian economy is not a substitute for reform.
Much will depend, of course, on Mr. Putin's willingness to challenge the tycoons who dominate much of the Russian economy so that he can level the playing field for business and investors.
Clinton administration officials are already discussing steps the West might take to demonstrate its support if Mr. Putin does undertake serious reform.
They include expanding assistance by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, rescheduling Russian debt and having the United States Export-Import Bank step up its efforts to encourage investment in Russia.
"I hope the 'Who lost Russia?' debate is behind us," Thomas R. Pickering, an under secretary of state and a former American ambassador to Moscow, recently told a business group in Washington.
But economics is just one part of the agenda. Arms control and foreign policy are also important. And while Mr. Clinton has said Mr. Putin is someone "we can do business with," Mr. Putin's nationalism, his background as a K.G.B. officer and his domestic constituency may make him less cooperative than Washington would like.
Administration officials are pleased that during his February meeting with Secretary Albright, Mr. Putin dispensed with diatribes against Washington's plans for a limited antimissile defense.
Instead, Mr. Putin said his goal was to preserve the principles of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. Administration officials hope that this vague formulation reflected a new, if cautious, sense of pragmatism -- one that might open the door to a grand bargain on offensive and defensive systems in which the treaty would be modified to accommodate the American antimissile program. Even if the Russians are willing to negotiate over the matter, though, the discussions may prove difficult.
The Russian military is strongly opposed to the antimissile program. And though Mr. Putin recently restored ties with NATO, the political climate in Russia is not conducive to wrenching compromises with the West.
The percentage of Russians who believe that Washington's hidden goal is to take advantage of their country's weakness is at a new high, the Clinton administration's own survey of Russian opinion indicates. The recent survey reports that 81 percent of Russians believe that the United States wants to reduce Russia to a second-rate power, up from 59 percent in 1995.
The mistrust stems from NATO's decision to expand eastward, the Western alliance's war with Serbia and the generally harsh indictment of Russia by Western politicians and the Western news media.
"Maybe the West thinks it knows what Putin will do on the ABM treaty, but it is wishful thinking," Georgi A. Arbatov, the veteran specialist on American-Russian relations, said about the arms control treaty. "We really don't know what Putin has in mind. The attitude in Russia is against building of antimissile defenses."
There is also Chechnya. The brutal war has been temporarily pushed out of the news by the Russian election, but it is still raging.
The West has denounced the indiscriminate attacks against civilians there but has been careful not to link the issue with the question of assistance from the monetary fund or other policy objectives.
But even with the best of intentions, a strategic alliance between the United States and Russia remains a remote possibility. The 47-year-old Mr. Putin is not only likely to re-energize relations with the West. He is likely to intensify diplomacy on other fronts, including former Soviet republics as well as Iran and China.
Clinton administration officials are also well aware of Mr. Putin's talent for telling his audience what it wants to hear. And some take his talk of Russia's fondness for the West's mentality and values with a large grain of salt. Just imagine, they say, what Mr. Putin will say about the United States when he meets with the Chinese.

HEADLINE: Kuwaitis Are Exasperated By America's Oil Politics

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 26

 BODY:
Wearing an impeccably tailored charcoal pin-striped suit as he relaxed in his sprawling hotel suite here tonight, Sheik Saud Nasser al-Sabah of Kuwait was feeling distinctly worn out by American politics.
As oil and gasoline prices have soared in the last several months, members of Congress have charged that Kuwait has been enriching itself at the expense of American consumers and that it has blithely forgotten that the United States fought a war to liberate it from Iraq. 
 Now, under heavy American pressure, Kuwait and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are reluctantly planning to raise production and to bring modest relief.
But as Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Saud was far from happy about that and granted a rare on-the-record interview to The New York Times to make his case.
"Today's price is fair and reasonable as far as we are concerned," he said. "What really made the difference was that in April 1999 people in the United States could buy gasoline for 98 or 99 cents a gallon. When prices corrected, there was an uproar."
Far from enjoying an unearned windfall, he asserted, Kuwait was barely recovering from the disastrous decline in prices in 1998 and early 1999.
"Unfortunately, we are in an election year," the sheik continued, referring to the American campaigns for president and Congress. "We are in a situation where Republicans are trying to upstage Democrats. We don't want to become entangled in domestic American politics, but we are becoming entwined."
This has not been a particularly good decade for oil producers. Adjusted for inflation, oil prices have consistently slumped far below the heights reached in OPEC's heyday in the 1970's. Analysts estimate that OPEC lost about $65 billion in revenue last year as a result of declines in oil prices, to as low as $11 a barrel.
For Kuwait, a tiny country sitting atop some of the world's biggest oil reserves, the downturn had a huge impact. With 93 percent of its revenues coming from oil, the government's $4.4 billion budget was short $2 billion in both 1998 and 1999.
"To balance our budget, we need to sell Kuwaiti oil at about $21 or $22 a barrel," said Sheik Saud. "We're not even talking about a surplus. Is that too much to ask for?"
The talks in Vienna this year have been unusually sensitive because oil prices have nearly tripled in the last 12 months and American gasoline prices have soared from about $1 to well over $1.60 in many cities.
Saudi Arabia, the world's largest producer and the country that overshadows all other OPEC members, has been the leading proponent for an increase in production of about 1.7 million barrels a day. Kuwait and other gulf states like the United Arab Emirates and Qatar have been less enthusiastic but prepared to follow the Saudi lead.
"It is completely exaggerated," Sheik Saud contended, for Americans to complain that Kuwait is ungrateful for American willingness to lead the Persian Gulf war and to force Iraq out of Kuwait after its invasion in 1990.
"Had the United States not intervened to help Kuwait then, Kuwait would not have any oil to export now," he said. "We don't want to harm the United States. We just want to defend our own interests."
On Thursday, the House of Representatives passed a bill that would urge the administration to consider cutting off aid and military sales to OPEC countries that try to push up oil prices by constraining demand.
President Clinton has opposed the bill, arguing that it is much too heavy-handed. But the energy secretary, Bill Richardson, has toured the capitals of many oil exporting countries in the last few weeks in an effort to persuade them of the need for big increases in oil production.
The fact that oil prices could take another plunge is not the least of the sheik's worries. Two years ago, prices plunged after OPEC agreed on modest increases in production. A year ago they soared far beyond all expectations after new cutbacks.
In the last two weeks, prices have once again started sinking, though at $28 a barrel on Friday they were at levels that most producers would consider close to nirvana.
"We would like to know," the sheik said, "What price do the Americans consider acceptable? We feel as if we are between a rock and a hard place."
