HEADLINE: OPEC Oil Increase Likely to Fall Short Of Clinton's Target

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 26

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is on the verge of an agreement to increase its oil production limits by about 1.7 million barrels a day, officials from several oil exporting countries said today.
That would be a larger increase than many analysts had expected, although the exact amount was still being debated and it would be less than the 2.5 million barrels sought by a Clinton administration worried about the ramifications of high gasoline prices. The rise could reduce the price of oil by several dollars a barrel, but when that would happen and whether it would be passed on to consumers remained unclear. 
 One senior OPEC official said the increase would just about reverse the production cuts the cartel agreed upon one year ago, which sent oil prices soaring and ignited a political uproar in the United States as American gasoline prices surged to more than $1.60 a gallon in many cities.
"We believe this number will result in bringing back market stability," the official said. "It is a reasonable increase, a very reasonable increase to make sure there are reasonable stocks in the second quarter." Asked if there was much uncertainty about the outcome when OPEC oil ministers meet here on Monday, he firmly shook his head.
The oil ministers are also expected to announce plans for a follow-up meeting in June at which they could choose to raise production levels again if the price stays near $30 a barrel. Saudi officials want to get the price down to about $25 a barrel.
Iran, OPEC's second largest producer after Saudi Arabia, is among several countries still opposed to such a big boost in production. But other OPEC officials predicted that they would agree on an increase of at least 1.5 million barrels a day -- but more likely 1.7 million -- levels that have been urged by the Saudis.
"What is being discussed is a return of the 1.7 million barrels that were removed from production last year," Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Saud Nasser al-Sabah, said in an interview here tonight. Although he described an increase in production as a move driven by politics rather than economics, he predicted that the agreement would be close to the levels sought by Saudi Arabia.
Sheik Saud added that oil prices were likely to fall: "The market will look at this as an increase, and will react by reducing prices."
The surge in gasoline prices has become a major election-year topic in the United States. Lawmakers in Congress have lambasted OPEC countries in recent weeks and accused Saudi Arabia and Kuwait of paying no heed to the role the United States played in rescuing Kuwait during the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
George W. Bush, the likely Republican presidential nominee, has called for a big reduction in gasoline taxes. Vice President Al Gore, the expected Democratic nominee, has been peppered with complaints and the Clinton administration has waged an intense lobbying campaign to persuade OPEC countries to agree to a large increase.
Oil ministers from the 11 nations in OPEC will meet in Vienna on Monday to formally discuss the plan. But the countries have been talking for weeks and have held intensive meetings in the last few days.
Analysts cautioned that the expected increase would probably have only a modest impact on gasoline prices, probably no more than 10 cents a gallon.
Nonetheless, said Gary N. Ross, president of PIRA Energy Group, an oil industry consulting firm, the increases would have a tangible impact and coincide with unexpectedly weak demand for oil in the first months of this year. "They have made it clear they want to see lower prices," Mr. Ross said, referring to the Saudis. "They want to get oil out of the newspaper headlines."
The last two years have shown that oil prices are notoriously difficult to predict, for OPEC or for anybody else. Few analysts, if any, expected prices to plunge as low as $11 a barrel one year ago; just as few, if any, predicted the abrupt surge to about $28 a barrel today.
Peter Ginoux, head of the oil trading desk at Salomon Smith Barney in London, said increasing OPEC's quota by 1.7 million barrels is inherently less than it appears because OPEC nations are already cheating on their own restrictions, overshooting their official limit of 23 million barrels a day by about 1 million barrels.
But because the limits are always exceeded to some extent, he said, the real net increase could be about 1 million barrels a day. And though cheating could continue at nearly the present pace, many smaller OPEC producers are already producing at nearly their current capacity.
"Non-compliance can only come now from the big guys, and they are the ones who are charged with keeping prices up," Mr. Ginoux said today. "If we take the net new supply to be 1 million barrels a day, I am horribly afraid that this will go to restocking -- and probably keep prices right where they are."
Within OPEC, the view is considerably different.
Iran has argued loudly that OPEC should not raise production by more than about 700,000 or one million barrels a day. And even pro-Western countries like Kuwait are worried about a repeat of the catastrophic decline in prices that came after OPEC raised production modestly in September 1997.
"I am worried," said Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Saud. "The market has already dropped by $5 a barrel. I don't see any compelling reason to increase production other than to be political, to be quite honest."
In reality, the total increase in production extends beyond the official OPEC quotas. Mexico, Norway and Oman, who are not members of the oil cartel, moved in tandem with OPEC last year, slashing their combined production by about 400,000 barrels a day.
Mexican officials have said they plan to raise their output by as much as 300,000 barrels. Norway said it would decide the issue after OPEC meets, but it would probably go back to its earlier levels as well.
On top of that there is Iraq, which is part of OPEC but is allowed to pump at maximum levels under a system regulated by the United Nations sanctions program installed after the gulf war. Iraq cut its production by about 700,000 barrels a day last year, complaining that it could not get the parts it needed. But after conciliatory moves by the United Nations, Iraq announced last week that it would go back to full production in the next few months.
American officials refused to comment tonight on OPEC's likely production increases, saying it would be premature. Although the increases are expected to be less than those advocated by Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson, the Clinton administration will likely express relief.
At the same time, many OPEC countries that have good relations with the United States were angry at the Americans' pressure in recent weeks. "It is strange that the champion of the free market economy is acting in a way that would put Marxists to shame," the daily Saudi Gazette said of threats by Congress to impose sanctions if OPEC did not raise production. The editorial called the effort "an atrocious proposal which violates the norms of the market and defies common sense."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Tracking the Toll After 2 Breadwinners Lose Jobs

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
For a decade, Bill Moyers has been tracking the downs and ups of two blue-collar Milwaukee families, the Neumanns and the Stanleys. Both were hit hard in the early 1990's, after Tony Neumann and Claude Stanley lost their jobs at Briggs & Stratton, which, like other industrial mainstays, gave way to recession. The company cut some 4,000 jobs in Milwaukee.
The Neumanns are white and the Stanleys are black, but when bad times struck, color proved less decisive than economics. Suddenly the recently well-paid workers found themselves scrambling for minimum-wage jobs as bills mounted. They ran behind on mortgage payments and had to accept handouts of food. 
 Along with battling to make ends meet, both families watched their neighborhoods deteriorate, with increasingly dangerous streets posing risks to their children . A bout of illness could play havoc with the household budget; a fever sent Claude Stanley to a hospital for two months in 1997, leaving him with a $30,000 bill not covered by insurance. Raising college tuition for an ambitious son, the first Stanley to get a college degree, required juggling credit-card debt at an interest rate of 23 percent.
Terry Neumann and Jackie Stanley pitched in, but earning $6 an hour while they paid $1.50 an hour for child care didn't ease matters. The children -- five Stanleys and three Neumanns -- felt the impact as they tried to help out with odd jobs and adjusted to homes with both parents working and with domestic tensions rising.
The choice facing both women, as Terry Neumann puts it, was "Either we make ends meet, or we stay home with the kids." She found a job at a school cafeteria, which paid only $20 a day, but allowed her to get home before her children. Working a double shift, Tony Neumann hardly saw them or Terry. "We don't sleep together anymore," he tells Mr. Moyers. "It stinks."
The program's title, "Surviving the Good Times," is a comment on the gap between an America that was prospering during the heady 1990's and hard workers like the Neumanns and Stanleys who were not able to share in the prosperity. But this report is also a tribute to the resilience of their close-knit families and the efforts of all members to pull together. Terry Neumann became a truck driver; Jackie Stanley went into selling real estate, not easy for a black woman whose potential clients are limited to the inner city.
As the program ends, the Stanleys are hopeful but still haven't caught up to what they made in the Brooks & Stratton years. Prospects are brighter for the Neumanns, with Tony making $18 an hour and Terry looking ahead to a Teamsters job at $19 an hour. "If the money's there," she says, "that's where I'll be."

A Moyers Report

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Africa: Aid or Harm?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I wrote recently in support of the African Growth and Opportunity Act, a bill designed to provide sub-Saharan African countries with duty-free access to the U.S. for their textile and apparel exports. The act, now being debated by Congress, is embarrassing for U.S. unions, such as the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and Unite, because they are opposing any duty-free access for Africa even though studies show it would create jobs in Africa and scarcely affect employment here.
Afterward I was bombarded with letters from union officials, who didn't like having their opposition to African imports exposed. The letters from Unite and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., though, really stood out. Both asserted that the U.S. unions were against this bill because it harmed African workers -- who were also against it. 
 "Wow," I thought, "am I urging passage of a bill to help create investment and jobs in Africa that Africans don't want?"
To find out, I first called Roble Olhaye, the Ambassador to the U.S. from Djibouti and the dean of the African ambassador corps. He said: "There are people in the U.S. who have vested interests in not letting anything from Africa be imported, but they don't want to say that, so they say that Africans don't want it. Let me tell you, there is not a single leader in Africa who is not supporting this bill -- without reservations."
Then I phoned Ebrahim Patel in Cape Town, South Africa, who heads the Southern African Clothing and Textile Workers' Union, the biggest textile union in southern Africa. Mr. Patel respects the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and Unite. They supported South African workers in the struggle against apartheid. He said he would never want to do anything harmful to them. But he also made clear that his union favored duty-free access for African textiles and apparel to the U.S. market, as part of a broad strategy for promoting development.
"We support the concept of duty-free access for Africa in textiles and apparel," he said. "As with all the poorest economies of the world, one way to raise our development quickly is for you to give us preferential access to your markets."
While Mr. Patel endorsed duty-free access for African textiles and apparel, he expressed reservations with three clauses in the Growth Act. First is the condition (written in by the U.S. textile lobby) stipulating that if African countries want duty-free access to America they must first buy all the cloth and yarn in America, then ship it to Africa to be sewn, then ship it back. Mr. Patel said Africans need to be able to use their own cloth too, otherwise there would be little economic benefit for them.
Second, said Mr. Patel, African unions are concerned about demands in the bill for African states to adopt more corporate-friendly, free-market policies in return for duty-free access. "Some of these demands infringe on our sovereignty," said Mr. Patel.
Third, he said, African trade unions want to ensure that any African factories given duty-free access to the U.S. be required to meet the core labor standards of the International Labor Organization, with union involvement in monitoring and verification. (The act already meets the I.L.O. standard, but does not yet include provision for monitoring by unions.)
"I believe Unite and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are committed to a fair global trading system," said Mr. Patel. " But as regards any duty-free arrangement for Africa, I think that if we were to interact with them, in a warm way, we could structure adequate worker rights conditions, in such a duty-free arrangement, that would improve the number of jobs in Africa, and the standards in the workplace, in a way consistent with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s global mission."
That is good advice. Africa's workers desperately need duty-free access to our markets to create jobs. The African unions have concerns about some side issues that should be addressed. The U.S. unions, though, oppose any duty-free access for Africa under any conditions -- but they don't want to say that. So they take these African side concerns, highlight them, and then say that even Africans don't want this duty-free bill. That is simply untrue.
There is a way for Africa to gain duty-free access in textiles to the U.S. market, without harming U.S. workers or worker standards in Africa, but it takes a will to find it. Africa's unions have that will. How about ours?

HEADLINE: Greenspan Endorses Paying Down U.S. Debt

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, sought to bolster Congress's resolve today to save huge government surpluses for use in paying down the national debt. Nothing would have a more beneficial impact on the nation's ability to meet the expenses of baby boomers' retirements, he said.
"Saving the surpluses -- if politically feasible -- is, in my judgment, the most important fiscal measure we can take at this time to foster continued improvements in productivity," Mr. Greenspan said in testimony before the Senate Special Committee on Aging. 
 He said, however, that he had no strong views on whether future income taxes should be transferred directly to Social Security and Medicare -- something that President Clinton has proposed. Republicans and some moderate Democrats object to a direct transfer.
Mr. Greenspan also sought to minimize concerns expressed by some lawmakers that a recent increase in fuel prices could have a negative effect on the overall economy or on projected surpluses.
"Currently, we do not as yet, and emphasize as yet, see any significant indication that crude oil price increases are in the process of embedding themselves in other areas of the economy and inflating the general price structure," he said.
Mr. Greenspan said, however, that such an effect would not be impossible.
He said it was unclear what level of energy inflation would be needed before price increases would begin to spread to other areas of the economy.
Promising future income tax surpluses to Social Security and Medicare could create a political incentive for lawmakers to follow through on paying down the national debt, Mr. Greenspan said.
"Given that our record of sustaining surpluses for extended periods of time is not good, any device that might accomplish this goal is worth examining," he said.
The Fed chairman also raised concerns that promising more money to the retirement programs "could take the steam out" of efforts to make money-saving changes he said should be considered, like increasing the retirement age and improving health care systems.
Mr. Greenspan raised the possibility that limited, short-term income tax transfers to Social Security and Medicare "would not necessarily eliminate all fiscal responsibility."
Today's committee hearing was intended to address a crucial issue facing Congressional budget makers this year: whether surpluses that come from income taxes, rather than from the special payroll taxes that finance Social Security and Medicare, should be dedicated to the programs.

HEADLINE: Sales of Existing Homes Rose in February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Americans pushed up sales of existing homes in February after two consecutive months of declines caused in part by higher mortgage rates.
Sales of existing single-family homes bounced back by a modest 6.7 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.75 million units, the National Association of Realtors said today. 
 With plentiful jobs, rising incomes, stock market gains and low inflation, Americans are feeling wealthy and in a mood to buy despite an upswing in mortgage rates, economists said.
"The higher-interest-rate story is being overridden by the amount of wealth potential homeowners have amassed," said Richard Yamarone, an economist with the Argus Research Corporation.
Last week, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the fifth time since June 30.
The Fed did this to slow the red-hot economy and keep inflation under control. Given continuing strong growth, many economists believe the central bank will increase interest rates again on May 16.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 8.33 percent in February, up from 8.21 percent in January. In February 1999, the average rate on a 30-year mortgage was 6.81 percent.
"The fact sales improved in the face of continuing increases in mortgage interest rates demonstrates the very high demand for housing in the United States," said Dennis Cronk, president of the realtors association.
Even with the gain, however, February's sales are 7.6 percent lower than the sales rate of 5.14 million posted in February 1999.
In January, existing-home sales fell 13.4 percent, sharper than previously reported. Economists had blamed the earlier-reported higher mortgage rates and a record low 2.6-month supply of homes available to sell in January. In December, existing-home sales dropped 0.2 percent.
The stock of existing homes for sale rose in February but remained at a low 2.8 months, meaning it would take 2.8 months to exhaust the supply at February's sales pace.
By region, the South saw existing-home sales rise 10.7 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.97 million units.
In the West, sales rose 8.7 percent, to a rate of 1.12 million units, and in the Midwest they grew by 5.7 percent, to a rate of 1.12 million units. But sales fell 6.9 percent in the Northeast, to a rate of 540,000 units.
The median existing-home sales price, meaning half sold for more and half for less, was $131,100 last month. That was 0.8 percent lower than the January median price but was 2.3 percent higher than the median price recorded for February 1999.

HEADLINE: OPEC Leaves Question Of Oil Increase on Table

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 27

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries adjourned its ministerial meeting here tonight without an agreement on modest production increases, and delegates agreed to reconvene on Tuesday.
But as they grappled with how to reach an accord, one question looming behind almost all their talks was whether anybody was really in control of oil prices. 
 Though American consumers have been shocked to see gasoline surge to $1.59 a gallon from an average of $1.27 six months ago, oil producers in and out of OPEC have been on a roller coaster in the last two years.
And for all the mystique of private meetings between Middle Eastern sheiks and technocrats from Mexico and Venezuela, the 11 nations of OPEC produce only 40 percent of the world's oil and have been repeatedly blindsided by market forces.
The obstacles to price "stability," a buzzword embraced as warmly by the United States as by Saudi Arabia, have been numerous: chronic cheating within the cartel on its self-imposed output restrictions; inaccurate estimates of demand and inventories; poor forecasting; and the inevitable surprises induced by weather, war and other calamities.
In the fall of 1997, Saudi Arabia persuaded OPEC to increase production by one million barrels a day. Prices then sank to the low teens in 1998 and hit $11 a barrel a year ago.
Panic-driven production cuts of 4.3 million barrels a day in 1998 and 1999 helped prices climb back. They surged to $34 in early March.
Since then, they have slipped back to about $28.
Today, fear of causing another steep plunge prevented OPEC members from completing a deal to increase their daily production quota by 1.5 to 1.7 million barrels.
After several informal and then formal meetings, oil ministers adjourned with plans to meet again on Tuesday morning. Officials on all sides of the debate publicly predicted that they would agree on a plan to raise production, but Iran continued to push for less than the 1.7 million barrels that Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states want to add.
"We are not opposed to an increase," said Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zangeneh, shortly before oil ministers met at OPEC offices here this evening. "I won't talk on numbers, but we don't want a market shortage."
Many OPEC leaders now say their target price is $25 a barrel, and American officials have implied that they can live with that level.
But the larger question remains unanswered: does OPEC, or any other group, have enough influence to keep oil prices within a tight range?
"Total world production is 75 million to 78 million barrels a day, but sometimes all you have to do is be off by a million barrels," said Joseph A. Stanislaw, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "That's how much they increased production in 1997, but they increased right when demand was about to go down."
The memories of that miscalculation are still vivid for many oil ministers here, especially those who felt themselves dragged into the increase by Saudi Arabia's power as the world's largest producer.
"When I talk about these questions with the Saudis, I ask them if they think their forecasts are better this time than back in Jakarta," said Sheik Saud Nasser Al-Sabah, Kuwait's oil minister.
Saudi officials admit that they miscalculated, principally because they failed to anticipate that the Asian financial crisis would reduce world oil demand as sharply as it did.
"We are trying to avoid volatility, but this is something that you cannot guarantee," said a senior Saudi official here on Sunday.
Beyond the unpredictability of the world economy, data about the oil market and even something as simple as OPEC production itself is often inaccurate.
Members of the cartel chronically overshoot their official quotas, though the price collapses of 1998 and 1999 prompted them to adhere to discipline more closely than they had in the past.
Cheating on quotas is so persistent and so important to oil prices that numerous organizations make monthly estimates by monitoring oil tankers and pipeline activities.
OPEC itself does not even have its own statistics on its production, partly because members do not trust each other to provide reliable data. As a result, OPEC officials rely on research provided by outside companies and organizations.
The most widely watched estimates are those of the International Energy Agency, a research organization in Paris funded primarily by the United States and other Western countries. The agency estimates that OPEC countries are cheating by about one million barrels a day.
But estimating cheating is still a nebulous art, prone to errors. Even more difficult is the job of estimating oil inventories, which are held by oil producers around the world as well as petroleum refiners, traders and distributors.
The International Energy Agency and private researchers admit that they seriously overestimated the reduction of inventories in January.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Little Inflation Seen
 By The New York Times
 WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that higher oil prices are not generating inflation in the United States, and that the country is better able to absorb rising energy costs than it was two decades ago.
"We do not, as yet -- I emphasize as yet -- see any significant indication that crude oil price increases are in the process of embedding themselves in other areas of the economy and inflating the general price structure," Mr. Greenspan said in response to a question at a hearing before a Senate committee.
Mr. Greenspan said that as long as average oil prices remained roughly where they are now, he doubted that they would be sufficient to set off a surge in inflation. But he warned that a big, sustained jump in prices could still be harmful to the American economy, as well as, in the long run, to the oil-producing nations.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Manage Only a Modest Rise

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose modestly yesterday, restrained by the belief that the Federal Reserve might need to raise interest rates repeatedly to keep inflation from gaining any foothold in the economy.
The central bank has raised rates by a quarter-point five times since June, with little effect so far on the pace of growth. 
 "The Fed is a long way from being done here, and most people would agree that we are looking at at least one and probably two more tightenings and this will continue to put pressure on interest rates," said Bill Kirby, co-head of government trading at Prudential Securities.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 7/32 , to 10326/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.98 percent from 5.99 percent on Friday.
With a light calendar of economic data this week, Treasuries turned their attention to the potential for sharper rate increases. The market also focused on a Vienna meeting of world oil ministers. The officials are expected to ease output limits, which should allow some decrease in the price of oil.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said that recent oil price rises had not yet ignited general inflation and were unlikely to do so if the price of oil settled in the mid-$20-a-barrel range.
Oil for May delivery fell 23 cents yesterday, to $27.79 a barrel, down from more than $30 a barrel earlier this month.
Nervousness about prospects for more aggressive rate increases by the Fed sent bond prices sharply lower on Friday, and this anxiety also caused price swings yesterday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
OPEC Pricing Revisited: What a Difference 20 Years Makes. Right?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
As the oil ministers met in Vienna, there was great concern about whether the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would give the rest of the world a break and do something to restrain high oil prices. Reporters were hanging on every word from the ministers, some of whom had felt intense American diplomatic pressure. Iran took a militant position, while Saudi Arabia was more accommodative, and the meeting was extended as agreement proved elusive.
So it was nearly 20 years ago, when OPEC met in the fall of 1980. And so it was yesterday. 
 But there are important differences between then and now. Then, inflation was widely feared in the developed world, and it was believed that oil prices were sure to rise for years to come. Then, widespread efforts at energy conservation were having an effect, and oil companies were intensifying their search for new oil fields.
Now all those factors have changed. Complacency has replaced urgency on Main Street, on Capitol Hill and in the executive suites of major oil companies. All expect prices to fall, and therefore see little need for action.
In part the changes reflect the way the world economy has changed. Oil is less important to economic growth in the information age than it once was, and inflation has declined sharply. We have seen that cartels are very hard to hold together, and that widespread cheating on oil production quotas has often made it very hard for oil exporters to keep prices up.
But while many things have changed, the fact is that relatively high oil prices have persisted many months longer than the experts forecast, and they could continue to do so -- particularly if there continues to be little indication of a determination to act to fight high prices.
In retrospect, four things helped to end the era of high oil prices. Recessions and sluggish growth in the developed world helped to cut demand. So did energy conservation efforts, including government-mandated fuel economy standards. The world's energy companies spent heavily to find new oil supplies and to seek alternative sources of energy. And oil producers cheated on quotas.
Of those, only one is still around. There is reported to be cheating on the OPEC quotas, of around 1 million to 1.5 million barrels a day. So far efforts to agree on a quota increase have failed, although some agreement is expected today. Whether or not cheating will increase, assuming there is a deal, will be a subject of widespread speculation.
But the other factors are all gone. In 1980, oil companies were earning profits that one politician called obscene and their share prices reflected wild enthusiasm. Drilling for oil was going on at a formidable rate, with 3,099 oil rigs operating in this country, according to figures from Baker Hughes. Now oil profits are also good, but share prices have shown little strength, in large part because it is generally believed that the profits will fade as oil prices inevitably fall.
Moreover, the lesson that the oil companies have learned from recent history is that they would be foolish to ramp up their exploration efforts. They did that in 1997, when oil prices were above $20 a barrel, only to suffer when prices plunged. Exploration budgets are being held down across most of the industry. Budgets are up a bit from 1999, but "we're well below the 1998 level of spending," said Frederick P. Leuffer, an oil analyst at Bear, Stearns.
The United States rig count, at 768, is less than it was in the summer of 1998, when oil prices were half what they are today. But the companies are announcing large repurchases of their own shares, and some are expected to raise shareholder dividends.
Nowhere is the atmospheric difference greater than in Washington. In 1980, there was debate about raising gasoline taxes and taking other steps to limit demand for gasoline. In fact, by then the rising price of gasoline had prompted Americans to search for vehicles with better fuel economy. Now, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, is suggesting that federal gasoline taxes be temporarily removed, the better to ease the pain for drivers.
That pain is real, but so far it has not done much to affect consumer behavior. In a booming economy, most motorists are willing to spend more rather than move to more fuel-efficient vehicles. Sport utility vehicles, which are far from fuel efficient, now make up 17 percent of total sales of cars and light trucks, up from under 2 percent in 1980. The average fuel economy of cars and light trucks sold in the 1981 model year was 24.1 miles a gallon. In the 1999 model year, the latest for which figures are available, it was 23.8.
Gasoline prices now are about 25 cents a gallon higher than they were in September 1980. But those figures are not adjusted for inflation, and in real terms the price of gasoline is far lower.
Six months ago, when oil climbed above $24 a barrel, there was virtual unanimity that the price could not hold. The futures market forecast that oil prices would fall 13 percent within six months. Instead, they rose, peaking above $34 earlier this month before coming down to $27.79 yesterday, on expectations that the OPEC meeting will raise production. But one thing has not changed much. Prices are now expected to fall 11 percent over the next six months.
Oil prices went up for a variety of reasons. Weather was part of the story, as was economic strength. So, too, was a widespread belief that prices would come down because of OPEC cheating. That left the entire industry, from international companies down to neighborhood fuel oil dealers, hesitant to maintain high inventories that were likely to decline in value. When things did not go as expected, those low inventories accelerated the price rise.
In the long run, it is in the interests of Saudi Arabia in particular to avoid letting oil get so expensive that it stimulates the search for alternative fuels and leads consuming countries to slash their demand. But for now, there is no sign either is about to happen. As a result, oil prices could stay relatively high far longer than most experts anticipate.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Treasury Secretary Wants New Stress on Latin Poverty

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, March 27

 BODY:
Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers called today for sweeping changes in the way international aid agencies try to combat poverty in Latin America, amid signs that robust economic growth there has left more people behind than many economists expected.
Mr. Summers, speaking to Latin American finance ministers and development experts at the annual meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank, said the United States wanted the bank to conduct a full review of its lending programs, to raise the interest rates it charges its wealthiest borrowers, and to adopt more effective ways of increasing education levels and fighting poverty. 
 The Washington-based international agency, financed by leading industrial nations, makes about $7 billion in development loans to Latin America each year. Together with lending by the World Bank, it is the main vehicle for the United States and other wealthy nations to help alleviate poverty in the region.
Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and other major Latin American nations have all grown faster in the last year than economists anticipated. They recovered swiftly from financial crisis, and bank officials estimated today that the region would grow at a pace of 3 percent to 4 percent in 2000, compared with an estimated 0.3 percent last year.
Yet the recession erased some progress in fighting poverty from the boom years of the early and mid-90's, and inequality has remained stubbornly high -- increasing by some measures. The situation has frustrated international financial officials, who expected that Latin America would follow the pattern of the Asian recovery and that rapid economic growth would lift all boats and ease social tensions more than it has.
"Latin America's economic success in recent years has not been associated with a reduction in inequality," Mr. Summers said in an interview. "The pressing economic problem for Latin America is to create an environment in which all people have a chance to benefit from growth."
A study by the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America found that 15 percent of the region's people live in extreme poverty, a level it said had barely budged in two decades. And the Inter-American Development Bank released a report saying that 150 million people in the region live on $2 a day or less, and that the gap between rich and poor widened in the 1990's.
This persistent income gap, some fear, may threaten the consensus that has brought Latin American economies closer to world levels in the last decade, especially at a time when globalization is under attack by some labor unions and nongovernment organizations.
Though most of the pressure against global integration comes from interest groups in industrial nations, protesters in third world countries argue that free trade and international financial agencies benefit the rich at the expense of the poor.
Low-key demonstrations against the Inter-American Development Bank occurred today. Three protesters slipped into the opening ceremony for delegates, unfurling a banner that read "Shut Down the Bank," before they were evicted.
Mr. Summers and many of the other finance ministers maintained that high and sustained economic growth still constituted the best antidote to poverty and had already improved living standards for millions throughout the region. But they acknowledged that growth alone had fallen short of achieving Latin American social goals, and there appeared to be broad agreement that the development bank should shift its priorities accordingly.
"Our countries are changing, our markets our changing and our social needs are changing, so the I.D.B. must also change," Jose Angel Gurria, Mexico's finance minister, said in an interview. "At a time when most countries in the region have better access to private capital, this should free up resources at the bank that can be used for poverty programs."
While Mr. Summers noted that the Inter-American Development Bank had already begun redirecting resources away from big projects, like power plants, to support poverty reduction, he said that more could be done. He declined to pass judgment on individual lending projects, but suggested that some of the largest loans the bank was considering, including one to finance a Brazilian dam, could deplete capital that was better devoted to smaller, more specific poverty-fighting efforts.
The United States is pushing the bank to establish performance benchmarks that measure the effectiveness of its poverty programs.
The Treasury secretary also urged the bank to conserve its resources in good times to be better prepared to increase spending when times are tough and the poor need help most.
The changes are part of an overhaul Mr. Summers has proposed for all the major lending institutions, including the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and regional development banks. Mr. Summers has sought to blunt an attack on the I.M.F. and the banks by some members of Congress, who argue that they have outlived their usefulness and may do more harm than good.
Last week, he said the World Bank should refocus its efforts toward reducing poverty in the poorest nations and leave most commercial projects to private business, particularly in countries with good credit ratings.

HEADLINE: Robust Economy Is Contributing To a Loss of Affordable Housing

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
While the nation enjoys continuing prosperity, affordable housing for many of the working poor has become harder to find, a federal report said today.
The report, issued by Andrew Cuomo, the secretary of housing and urban development, found that 5.4 million low-income families were paying more than half their income for housing or living in dilapidated units, a rise of 12 percent since the economic expansion began in 1991. 
 The government regards housing for low-income people affordable if it consumes less than a third of a family's income.
"This is the highest need for affordable housing since we have been taking numbers," Mr. Cuomo said.
Low-income housing, he said, "is getting old, it is coming out of service, it is being knocked down."
He cited several factors for the squeeze on the working poor, including the rising economy.
In the past, building owners accepted low-income tenants whose rent was paid from their own earnings and from subsidies from a government voucher program known as Section 8. But because of the continuing prosperity, Mr. Cuomo said, many property owners have found that higher-income tenants have bid up the prices of apartments beyond the poorer tenants' ability to pay, even with the Section 8 subsidies.
Mr. Cuomo also criticized Congress's refusal to approve more Section 8 housing from 1995 through 1998, "when we went out of the housing business."
He blamed the Republicans in Congress for the lack of new Section 8 units, saying, "We had proposals in the tens of thousands for every year and Congress said zero."
Representative Rick Lazio, the New York Republican who is chairman of a housing subcommittee, said a Republican objection during that time had been a "take one, take all" provision that required landlords accepting any families with vouchers to accept all families with them.
Republican complaints were satisfied, Mr. Lazio said, and 50,000 new housing vouchers were approved for 1999 and 60,000 more for this year.
As to President Clinton's request for 120,000 more for next year -- which would cost $6 billion -- Mr. Lazio said he had introduced a measure for 100,000 units, "so we are very close." But he said that the administration had to show where the money would come from.
Told of Mr. Lazio's comments, Mr. Cuomo said his call for 100,000 new vouchers was "a tad disingenuous and misleading." While Mr. Lazio may push a bill seeking the new vouchers, Mr. Cuomo said, the Republican leadership has said it will not approve the money for them.
Mr. Cuomo said the added 120,000 vouchers would help ease the "cruel irony" of the strong economy hurting the poor by driving up rents.
Asked if his agency should not share in the responsibility for the shortage, he said, "If there was any failure, it was our failure to persuade Congress to provide funds."

HEADLINE: Putin Tells Advisers to Prepare 'Weighty' Economic Plan

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 27

 BODY:
On the day after his decisive victory in a field of 11 candidates in the presidential election on Sunday, Vladimir V. Putin told his cabinet today that it was time to put "all our work" on a new economic program into one "weighty document" by the time he is sworn in and appoints his new government in early May.
Mr. Putin's reference to an economic blueprint that he steadfastly refused to discuss during the campaign was a pointed reminder that planning was well under way for his presidency. 
 Tonight, Mr. Putin met with former President Boris N. Yeltsin and received warm praise from the patron who plucked Mr. Putin from political obscurity last fall as the head of the country's intelligence agency, appointed him prime minister, and then announced that the 47-year-old ex-K.G.B. officer would make a good successor. Mr. Yeltsin resigned on Dec. 31, appointing Mr. Putin acting president.
With more than 95 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Putin had polled nearly 53 percent of the ballots. The Communist Party candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, was a strong second in the crowded field with almost 30 percent.
A number of world leaders, including President Clinton, President Jiang Zemin of China and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, spoke with Mr. Putin by telephone today, extending congratulations and expressing their own hopes for Russia's future. Mr. Clinton urged the new Russian leader to strengthen democracy and its international ties, while Mr. Jiang urged him to deepen the "strategic partnership" between Russia and China. The New China News Agency said Mr. Putin had agreed to visit China this year.
Mr. Clinton also expressed the hope that Mr. Putin would carry out "impartial and transparent investigations of reported human rights violations" during the military campaign Russia has waged in the breakaway republic of Chechnya.
Mr. Putin met with his security advisers for an update on the war in Chechnya. He also sent a greeting to the Interior Ministry troops who, along with the Russian Army, have been fighting in Chechnya. "Your bravery and dignity are a safe guarantee that this region will be freed of the bandits and that peaceful life will be restored there," it said.
The strong showing by the Communist candidate, Mr. Zyuganov, drew considerable notice here. A number of commentators saw it as evidence of the enduring strength of the Communist opposition, which has consistently garnered close to a third of the national vote, and suggested that Mr. Putin might seek a collaborative relationship with it.
Mr. Putin will need to avoid political conflicts that would hamper efforts to move forward with difficult reforms of the banking system, taxation and land ownership. The Communists, for their part, are interested in sharing power and attracting new partners after losing the coalition through which they dominated Parliament in the last five years.
Leonid Dobrokhotov, an adviser to Mr. Zyuganov, said tonight that the Communist Party would consider working with Mr. Putin's allies in Parliament if the president accepted the party's demands on "raising the living standards" and strengthening industry, agriculture, and education.
"The popularity of the Communist Party is the result of the suffering of the people," Mr. Dobrokhotov said. "We don't want to fight with the party in power. We want to solve the social problems of the people."
Boris Makarenko, deputy director of the Center for Political Technology, a consulting firm, said today that the new government would be more centrist, with the Communists as a "junior partner," adding, "This is a new role for the Communists."
At the same time, the poor showing of Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the Yabloko Party leader, who polled less than 6 percent of the vote, reflected the disarray of Russia's liberal politicians. It suggested that Mr. Yavlinsky's personal base of support was shrinking, and reflected the fact that many liberal voters fell in behind either Mr. Putin or one of several liberals who ran as independents, including Konstantin Titov, the progressive governor of the Samara region, or Ella Pamfilova, the Women's Party candidate.
One of the strongest new liberal forces is the Union of Right Forces, which made a surprisingly strong showing in parliamentary elections in December. But its leaders, who include prominent reformers from Mr. Yeltsin's governments, decided not to field a presidential candidate, and then quarreled publicly over whether to endorse Mr. Putin, as most eventually did.
In general, most Russian political organizations other than the Communist Party have usually been groupings around specific leaders, and not national parties. Mr. Putin has not identified himself with any of those, though last fall the Kremlin helped form the Unity Party, an amalgam of mayors, governors and other regional officials.
But the only party with longevity, ideology and a national following remains the Communist Party. Michael McFaul, senior associate of the Moscow Carnegie Center, called this circumstance "sad progress for democracy and its legacy."
By any normal standard, Mr. Putin's victory with nearly 53 percent of the vote, compared with just under 30 percent for Mr. Zyuganov, would be considered a landslide. But the fact that Mr. Putin's popularity, which had hovered around 60 percent this winter, sagged in the final weeks of the campaign while the Communists rallied left a haze of uncertainty over the Kremlin, where Mr. Putin and his advisers were trying to figure out what kind of mandate they had received.
But it also appeared that Mr. Putin's victory was broad-based. Where Mr. Yeltsin in 1996 managed to carry only 57 of Russia's 89 administrative regions, Mr. Putin won majorities in all be six, including Mr. Zyuganov's home district.
"What is important is victory," said Aleksandr Voloshin, the presidential chief of staff, putting the best face on the results in an interview with the newspaper Izvestia to be published on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Clinton Wishes Putin Well And Brings Up Chechnya

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
President Clinton congratulated President-elect Vladimir V. Putin today on his victory in the Russian election, but also reiterated in a brief telephone conversation White House concerns about Russia's continuing conflict in Chechnya.
Mr. Clinton placed the call this morning after it became clear that Mr. Putin had received enough votes in the balloting on Sunday to avoid a runoff next month against Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, who finished a distant second. Mr. Clinton's remarks reflected the administration's optimism toward Mr. Putin but also its wait-and-see attitude toward the former intelligence officer who has spoken of being a reformer and of integrating Russia into the world community. 
 "President-elect Putin has an opportunity to translate his electoral mandate into concrete steps to advance economic reform, to strengthen the rule of law, to intensify the fight against crime and corruption, and to join with us on a broad common agenda of international security including arms control, nonproliferation and regional peace and stability," the president said in a statement.
He added that during his 15-minute conversation he "emphasized the importance to Russia and the world of strengthening the foundations of Russia's democracy and deepening its international integration."
What remains to be seen, according to administration officials, is whether Mr. Putin follows through on his plans to reform the Russian tax system and judiciary, introduce land reform and fight corruption, and whether he institutes law and order without cracking down on human rights.
Today's conversation did not delve into the key issues between the two nations, such as the administration's effort to persuade the Russians to modify the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. But on the subject of Chechnya, where the brutal fighting continues, Mr. Clinton said he did raise his concerns about Russian aggression.
"I stressed to President-elect Putin the importance of launching impartial and transparent investigations of reported human rights violations and providing prompt and full access for international organizations and the press," he said.
But Mr. Putin, whose tough handling of Chechnya was considered an asset in the campaign, gave no signs of altering Russia's military campaign, aides said.
The two leaders last spoke on New Year's Day after President Boris N. Yeltsin announced that he was stepping down and that he was appointing Mr. Putin, then prime minister, as acting president. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Putin met face to face last year in Oslo and New Zealand.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Man Who Gives Credit Where It's Due

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
HERBERT STURZ is not a name readily recognizable to 98 percent of New Yorkers. This pleases Mr. Sturz.
But inquire of the remaining 2 percent -- public- and private-sector types alike, who have left their own crater-size footprints in criminal justice, real estate development and social welfare policies in the city -- and the booming response is inevitably, "Oh sure! I've known Herb for 30 years!" This pleases Mr. Sturz, too. 
 For one secret of his startling ability to have jump-started so many ideas in those areas, including his latest, a George Soros-sponsored after-school program now in 100 city schools, is his shrewdness in knowing the right people to beseech and then publicly giving them credit.
"The more you take credit, the less able you are to do something the next time," said Mr. Sturz, 69, who is regarded as much for his penetrating social vision as for his sly-fox strategies for applying bricks and mortar to his ideas. His two-year-old Soros project, the After School Corporation, is a three-to-one matching fund that contracts with community programs to provide 26,000 New York City schoolchildren, so far, with activities in their schools until 6 p.m. Similar initiatives are rapidly taking hold around the country.
Mr. Sturz holds no degree in law, urban planning or education, areas in which he has made his name, or rather, other people's. But "I know a few people," he said with a smile.
As both a deputy mayor for criminal justice during the Koch administration and in such private-sector positions as founding director of the Vera Institute of Justice, Mr. Sturz has nudged into being a bail-reform project for the indigent that became a national model, aid for the city's crime victims, services for mentally ill and addicted offenders, and the award-winning Midtown Community Court. (In recognition for his criminal justice activities, the Correctional Association of New York is honoring him tonight.)
"I was able to engage the idealism of a lot of wonderful people," said Mr. Sturz, whose selling style has been described by admirers as graciously flattering and by the dubious as a touch unctuous. But his mild demeanor is only a kindly cover for a tough-minded, ambitious thinker who is also a wickedly good poker player. When facing a politician, developer or community leader who might oppose his project, Mr. Sturz says he tries to figure out, "Where does that person's enlightened self-interest lie?"
Mr. Sturz had another life, as chairman of the city planning commission under Mr. Koch. During his seven-year tenure as chairman, a period of economic boom, Mr. Sturz helped curb development on the East Side of Manhattan while spurring it on the West Side and in downtown Brooklyn. Though the new Times Square was not his idea -- he is, typically, quick to underscore that point -- he brokered the deal in its embryonic stage.
ADD to his teeming resume a stint in the late 1980's on the editorial board of The New York Times, followed by the hard-won development of a 43-story moderate-income co-op in Hunters Point, Queens, and, more recently, helping to establish a Soros matching fund for 50,000 new homes in South African townships, and Mr. Sturz, son of an immigrant tavern owner in Bayonne, N.J., may indeed be congratulated for having tabled an indifferent career as a fiction writer.
(He did publish a now vanished novel about a Spanish fishing village, where he lived in the 1950's with his Texas-born co-author and girlfriend, Elizabeth, to whom he has been married for more than 40 years.)
Mr. Sturz, who spoke in his office at Mr. Soros's foundation, the Open Society Institute, in Manhattan, was at a loss only when asked what had shaped his restless, imaginative and compassionate thinking.
"My father was lovely, giving and decent and he never cared much for what I might accomplish," Mr. Sturz recalled. "His love was much more elemental." Mr. Sturz's promising tennis and track future was cut short during his senior year in high school when he contracted polio, which permanently weakened his arms and hands. "Even today," he said uncomfortably, "it's hard to know what impact it had on me, except that I became more serious."
After getting a master's degree in English from Columbia, Mr. Sturz worked in a mental ward and in youth homes, lived in Europe, and then returned to become an editor at Boy's Life magazine.
His series on law and justice was read by the philanthropist Louis Schweitzer, who, with Mr. Sturz brainstorming, sponsored a think tank that tackled seemingly intractable problems in the courts. Mr. Sturz's earliest efforts with the Vera Institute of Justice included ways to set reasonable bail for poor defendants and the diversion of Bowery alcoholics from the courts to clinics.
At first glance, Mr. Sturz's current schools project, on which Mr. Soros has spent $20 million, seems a distance from his criminal justice background. But in giving students activities until their parents can pick them up, the project seeks to reduce juvenile crime and help parents on welfare join the work force: issues addressed by Vera satellites.
"I always start narrow when I'm learning about a new subject, but it usually leads me to ask, 'Is this a solution for other problems?' " Mr. Sturz said. "What makes you think I've gotten everything done that I've wanted to?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Treasury Secretary Urges A Focus on Latin Poverty
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers called for sweeping changes in the way international aid agencies combat poverty in Latin America amid signs that robust growth there has left more people behind than many economists expected.
At a meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank, Mr. Summers said the United States wanted the bank to raise the rates it charges its wealthiest borrowers and adopt more effective ways of improving education and fighting poverty. Page C4. 

Daimler to Buy 33.4% of Mitsubishi
DaimlerChrysler, the world's third-largest maker of motor vehicles, agreed to buy 33.4 percent of Mitsubishi Motors, securing the toehold in Asia it had long wanted. "We have closed the circle," Jurgen E. Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chairman, said at a news conference. "We have covered all the markets of the world." The $2.1 billion deal leaves Toyota and Honda as Japan's last major carmakers without big foreign partners. C4.
 
$20 Million Award in Tobacco Case
A jury in San Francisco ordered Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds to pay a total of $20 million in punitive damages in the first case decided on behalf of a person who started smoking after the government required that warning labels appear on cigarette packages. A14.
 
Juniper Has New Switching System
Continuing its march into the data networking market, Juniper Networks intends to announce today that it is shipping what appears to be the fastest electronic switch for Internet information. Several leading communications carriers have agreed to buy the new system. C2.
 
Stocks Slide, Led by Microsoft
The three main stock gauges slumped, dragged down by declines in financial service and bank stocks and by a big decline in Microsoft. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 86.87 points, to 11,025.85. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.60 points, to 1,523.86, while the Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.47 points, to 4,958.56. C16.
 
Waste Management Posts a Loss
Waste Management, the nation's largest trash hauler, reported a fourth-quarter loss because it spent $360 million to fix its accounting and computer systems and invested in landfills and new garbage trucks. The company lost $114.7 million, or 19 cents a share. Excluding the one-time costs, the company would have earned $200 million, or 32 cents a share, just shy of expectations. Shares of Waste Management rose 68.75 cents, to $14.25. C27.
 
Greenspan Urges Paying Off Debt
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, sought in Senate testimony to bolster Congress's resolve to save huge government surpluses to pay down the national debt. Nothing would have more effect on the nation's ability to meet the expenses of baby boomers' retirements, he said. C12.
 
Low-Power Radio Plan Moves Ahead
Federal regulators pressed ahead with plans to issue low-power FM community radio licenses despite efforts by commercial broadcasters to block the program. C8.
 
Home Sales Rose 6.7% in February
Americans pushed up sales of existing homes in February by 6.7 percent after two consecutive months of declines. C12.
 
Rogue Trader Seen in Swedish Ads
Nicholas W. Leeson, the rogue stock trader who caused the collapse of Britain's oldest merchant bank, Barings, is appearing in a campaign that promotes a Swedish online stock trading company. Advertising. C10.
 
Investors Hope Putin Acts Quickly
Foreign investors and local business people say the new Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, has to take decisive action over the next few months for the country to see marked increases in investment. A10.

HEADLINE: After Shootings, Livery Drivers Keep a Wary Eye in the Mirror

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Judging by statistics alone, New York is relatively safer these days for its more than 41,000 livery-cab drivers, the drivers who make up the only cab industry in most of the city, cruising the streets where yellow cabs are rarely seen.
During the first four years of the 1990's, for example, 139 livery drivers were killed in shootings, stabbings and beatings, in a crime wave so stunning it provoked taxi drivers to stage a protest that tied up traffic for hours in Manhattan. By contrast, 8 livery drivers were killed in 1998, 11 were killed last year, and robberies have fallen almost 64 percent since they peaked in 1992. 
 But try to tell Lakhwander Singh that his job is any less dangerous.
Yesterday, Mr. Singh was propped up in bed in Richmond Hills, Queens, with two bullet holes in his bandaged right shoulder. And the only reason he was alive, he said, was because the two men who robbed him of $50 on Sunday night had trouble aiming after he stepped on his accelerator to race for help and crashed into a truck.
"I said, 'Please take the money and don't shoot me,' " Mr. Singh, 40, said, sitting stiffly in a sparse bedroom he shares with his cousin, also a livery driver. "And they took the money, and they shot me anyway."
Mr. Singh was one of three livery cab drivers shot in a 24-hour period Sunday, and he was the lucky one. Mohammed Chahon, 42, was in serious but stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, shot in the face, buttocks and stomach after he picked up a passenger who tried to rob him near the Brooklyn Navy Yard early Sunday morning. Rafael Cruz, 58, was in guarded condition at Brookdale Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn after he was shot in the head by a man he had driven to Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Sunday evening. Mr. Cruz clung to consciousness and drove himself to the hospital.
The police say that just since the beginning of the year, four livery drivers have been shot and killed in robberies, and three have now been critically injured.
As in the past, murders and robberies involving livery drivers far outpace those involving yellow cabs, which tend to operate in much safer neighborhoods and now all have bulletproof shields.
And so even before the latest round of shootings, drivers say, a climate of fear and anger had returned to the livery industry, one unlike any seen since the early 1990's. Car services that rely on radio calls have become more careful in the screening of passengers, sometimes rejecting calls that sound the least bit suspicious, or calls that come from streets considered dangerous.
Livery drivers who try to make ends meet by picking up passengers on the street -- a violation, since only yellow cabs may legally accept hails -- say they have been refusing more people in hardscrabble neighborhoods in the Bronx and Brooklyn. Such refusals are common among livery services, but people who are passed by can complain to the Taxi and Limousine Commission.
But livery drivers say that even when their guts tell them they are safe, there is no way to be sure. "I always try to pick up nice guys, guys who don't look like they will give me any trouble," said Mr. Singh, whose brother was also robbed, and pistol-whipped, two months ago while driving a livery car. "These two guys, they looked good to me," he said of the robbers, who hailed him at the Long Island Rail Road station in Jamaica, Queens, and rode to East New York, Brooklyn, where one put a gun to Mr. Singh's head when he stopped.
The sharp spike in crime against livery drivers prompted the police to create a task force last month to work with the industry, the first such publicized focus by the police in several years.
The Taxi and Limousine Commission also said that, starting Saturday, it would vigorously enforce a requirement that many livery drivers, like yellow cab drivers, have bulletproof partitions between their front and back seats. The commission's rules say that livery cars operated by more than one driver -- typically cars owned by livery companies -- must have the partitions. Cars owned and driven by individual drivers, which account for 90 percent of all livery cars, are allowed to have either the partitions or tiny infrared surveillance cameras installed beneath a driver's rearview mirror.
The different requirements for the two groups, said Allan J. Fromberg, a spokesman for the taxi commission, came about because many individual driver-owners also use their livery cars as family cars, and the commission decided that requiring a partition would have burdened them unfairly.
Mr. Fromberg said that, especially after the latest round of shootings, the agency intended to try harder to make sure that livery drivers were doing what they needed to do to protect themselves.
Many livery drivers -- especially the driver-owners, who have less money than the livery companies -- have resisted protective measures because of the cost. Even cheap partitions cost about $300, and the surveillance cameras can cost from $600 to $1,000.
"I would say we're going to be rededicating our efforts to this," Mr. Fromberg said.
Drivers say that in addition to helping themselves, they need more help from the police and the legal system. Yesterday, about 100 livery cab drivers carrying placards demonstrated in front of the Bronx Criminal Court building, calling for more serious charges to be filed against Gerard Soricelli, 40, of Eastchester Road in the Bronx, who was indicted on assault and robbery charges in connection with the robbery and beating of a livery driver, Ramon Burgos.
Mr. Burgos, 38, a Dominican immigrant and father of three girls, said he picked up Mr. Soricelli and another man near Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx on Feb. 18, and they later robbed him, nearly strangled him with a rope, and hit him in the head with a metal pipe, opening a gash that required 50 stitches. "I thought I was going to die," Mr. Burgos said yesterday.
Fidel F. Del Valle, the chairman of the taxi commission from 1991 to 1995, said he thought the rise in such brutal crimes had come about because the improved economy had put more liveries on the streets, and with business better, criminals tended to see the cabs as "rolling banks."
"The awareness of this was so high for so long," Mr. Del Valle said. But he added that drivers and the police "have tended to -- I don't want to say slack off -- but they're not as vigilant." He added, "I think we're seeing the results."

HEADLINE: Ex-Comptroller Regan to Head CUNY's Baruch College

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Edward V. Regan, who was New York State's comptroller for 14 years, was appointed yesterday as the next president of Baruch College in Manhattan, which has become one of the City University's most selective campuses.
As comptroller from 1979 to 1993, Mr. Regan oversaw the growth of the state pension fund to $56 billion from $10 billion. As he invested more of the fund in the stock market, he got to know many of the money managers on Wall Street, a plus that helped him win a job that increasingly requires a talent for raising funds. 
 Mr. Regan said yesterday that he relished the opportunity to join Baruch.
"Telling the Baruch story will be great fun," he said. "Taking first- and second-generation students and lower- and middle-income students and giving them a career ladder is what New York City does, and that is what Baruch does extremely well."
He said fund-raising "will be a big part of the job."
Since stepping down as comptroller, Mr. Regan, 69, has been chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the watchdog agency that monitors New York City's finances, and a fellow at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College, and has served on a variety of boards.
The City University trustees also named a new president for Queensborough Community College: Eduardo J. Marti, an immigrant who fled Cuba shortly after Castro's takeover. He has been president of Corning Community College since 1994 and, before that, headed Tompkins Cortland Community College, both campuses in the State University system.
Dr. Marti, a biologist who earned his doctorate at New York University, taught at CUNY's Borough of Manhattan Community College from 1966 to 1979 and was associate dean of the faculty there.
He said he was attracted to Queensborough by the opportunity to help immigrant students. Nearly half of Queensborough's 10,400 students are immigrants. Corning has 5,300 students.
These appointments represent the first two permanent senior appointments since Matthew Goldstein became CUNY's chancellor last summer. Although the CUNY trustees formally appoint all presidents -- they approved these two during an executive session yesterday afternoon -- Dr. Goldstein recommends candidates to them.
Dr. Goldstein, who has been eager to cast CUNY more favorably following the brutal battles it faced over remedial instruction for under-prepared students, has a particular interest in Baruch. As president, he built it into one of CUNY's most prestigious colleges and brought in more than $50 million in gifts. He left Baruch in 1998 to become president of Adelphi University.
Dr. Goldstein said that although they are very different, Mr. Regan and Dr. Marti were both strong additions to CUNY. They will start on July 1.
"Ned Regan has a record of extensive and impeccable public service and can blend the political arena and the world of academe," he said. "Eduardo Marti is smart and focused and cares about advancing the goals of students."
What also pleased him, Dr. Goldstein said, was that CUNY had "an exemplary pool of candidates" to choose from. He halted a nearly-completed search for Baruch's president last year and initiated a new one because he did not think the group of candidates was broad enough.
Some at Baruch applauded Mr. Regan's appointment yesterday, saying that they expected him to be a strong fund-raiser.
Sidney I. Lirtzman, the former dean of Baruch's Zicklin School of Business and now the college's acting president, called Mr. Regan a great choice.
"He's well connected, and he knows the city and the state," Mr. Lirtzman said. "This should allow us to raise large sums of money to support the college programs that require private support."
Business and public administration are two of Baruch's primary programs.
Mr. Regan, who has a law degree from the SUNY law school at Buffalo, said that he had wanted to become more involved with academia. He said he had written more than 30 scholarly articles on government and financial issues, and has served as a trustee at Marymount College, New York University's Stern School of Business and New York Law School, and as an adjunct professor at Stern, Canisius College and the SUNY College at Buffalo.
When he heard last fall that the Baruch post was open, he expressed interest to Jack Nash, a former Wall Street executive with whom he shared an office for several years. A Baruch graduate and a major donor to the school, Mr. Nash recommended Mr. Regan to the search committee.
Mr. Nash expressed delight yesterday that the post was finally being filled and that Mr. Regan would fill it. "He'll do a good job," Mr. Nash said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Close Lower on Declines by Microsoft and Banks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Major stock market averages moved lower yesterday, dragged down by financial service and bank stocks and by a big decline in Microsoft, as it slumped on reports that it remained far from any agreement to settle the government's antitrust lawsuit.
Microsoft, part of the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500 index and the Nasdaq composite index, fell 7 5/8, to 1041/16 . 
The software company's drop was responsible for 37.9 points of the 86.87 decline in the Dow. That index closed at 11,025.85, down 0.8 percent from the close on Friday.
The Standard & Poor's index fell 3.60, or 0.2 percent, to 1,523.86. The decline in Microsoft shares was offset in part by gains in several other large technology issues, including America Online and Sun Microsystems.
The Nasdaq composite index fared better, closing at 4,958.56, down 4.47 points, or 0.1 percent. Gains in stocks like Qualcomm, Yahoo and Nextel tempered losses in JDS Uniphase and CMGI, as well as Microsoft.
Also, the Russell 2000 small-stock index dipped 3.6, or 0.1 percent, to 573.66.
Traders and analysts said there was no real trend to yesterday's action. Activity was light, the end of the first quarter is fast approaching and there is little in the way of economic news to be reported this week that seems likely to move financial markets.
"If there is one theme, it is that the larger-capitalization stocks are dominant again," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald in Stamford, Conn.
"Unless the bond market really falls apart," he added, "the stock market is likely to do all right until first-quarter earnings reports start to come in."
The bond market was fairly quiet yesterday, with little or no change in interest rates. But that did not prevent stock traders from pounding bank and brokerage stocks.
J. P. Morgan, a Dow component, fell 511/16 , to 131 1/8. Citigroup, which is also in the Dow, lost 1/2, to 601/16 . Mellon Financial declined 7/8, to 30 5/8. And Chase Manhattan dropped 1 1/2, to 9411/16 .
Mr. Meehan said that troubles at Finova Group might have caused jitters among holders of other bank stocks.
Yesterday Finova, which lends to midsize companies, warned that it would miss first-quarter profit goals because of a bad loan. The company also said its chief executive was retiring for health reasons.
Finova's stock price slid sharply, closing at 19 7/8, down 121/16 .
Brokerage stocks, which have been red hot lately, also slumped.
Their dive was led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which fell 99/16 , to 57 3/4, after the stock was downgraded by a Morgan Stanley analyst.
As it turns out, Morgan Stanley was also one of the biggest losers in the S.& P. 500. The stock closed at 90, down 513/16 . Charles Schwab slumped 5 1/8, to 5913/16 . And PaineWebber fell 3 1/2, to 439/16 .
Many big technology companies were immune from the problems that plagued Microsoft.
I.B.M., for one, closed at 126139/16 , up 597/16 . Hewlett-Packard gained 31513/16 , to 14635/16 . And Intel rose 3 5/8, to 1421147/16 .
Peter Canelo, an investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and a longtime optimist about the direction of stock prices, issued an even brighter assessment yesterday.
Before the market opened, Mr. Canelo raised his estimates for both the Standard & Poor's 500 and the Nasdaq composite.
"We think oil prices have clearly peaked, and will fall to the mid-$20 a barrel range," he said in an interview. "Also, bond yields have fallen to the level where they are not competitive with stock market earnings. And I am positive about earnings. We have raised our earnings estimates for the S.& P. 500 to 15 percent from 12 percent for the calendar year."
Mr. Canelo said the market was likely to broaden beyond technology stocks into energy, financial services, capital goods and cyclical stocks that would benefit from an improving global economy.
By midsummer, he projects that the the S.& P. 500 index will be comfortably above 1,600. And he added that the Nasdaq composite had the potential to rise another 10 percent.
