SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1668 words

HEADLINE: Florio, Senate Hopeful, Runs Against Boom

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 27

 BODY:
Running against motherhood or apple pie you could almost understand. But running against the boom?
With the nation's economic expansion entering its 109th consecutive month and much of New Jersey awash in prosperity, it seems like an odd strategy. 
 But in New Jersey's United States Senate contest, unlike any other major political race in the country, a convergence of unusual circumstances has transformed the Democratic primary into a race that has put the economic boom on trial.
 Jon S. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has swathed himself in the flag of prosperity, asserting that his work on Wall Street helped New Jersey companies create and retain hundreds of thousands of jobs. If elected to the Senate, Mr. Corzine says, he will use his business acumen to spread that wealth to the poor by offering a banquet of expansive social programs.
Those arguments have prompted his opponent, former Gov. Jim Florio, to warn voters that a dark cloud has been obscured by the economic silver lining. On issues ranging from Social Security and pension financing to corporate mergers, trade policy and government borrowing, Mr. Florio has hammered his opponent with the kind of class-based attacks Democrats usually aim at Republicans.
He has accused Wall Street titans of raking in billions in profits at the expense of poor and working-class Americans, and has blamed Goldman, Sachs for underwriting corporate mergers that cost more than 75,000 Americans their jobs under Mr. Corzine's leadership.
Mr. Florio has also cautioned voters not to let Wall Street's blazing performance in recent years lure them into accepting the Clinton administration's proposal to invest some Social Security money in the stock market, an initiative Mr. Corzine supports.
Such a plan would result in billions of dollars in investment fees for Wall Street firms, Mr. Florio argues, but leave low-income retirees at the mercy of volatile market fluctuations.
"Every week, you hear stories about economic disparities in this boom period, with more and more people in the top end doing better and people in the lower end doing worse in terms of purchasing power," Mr. Florio said.
At the heart of the exchanges are two starkly different visions of the economy and the Democratic Party.
Mr. Corzine (pronounced kore-ZYNE) is convinced that the economic expansion has brought benefits to enough people that his Wall Street resume will inspire confidence in working-class voters. Mr. Florio believes that the Democratic Party's traditional base in New Jersey -- factory workers, union stewards, minimum-wage employees and retirees -- is inherently wary of the rich.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said the race was a test case of how prosperity may have shifted the political landscape within the Democratic Party.
"It's really a question of new economy versus old economy," Dr. Hughes said. "What proportion of new economy workers, information economy workers, financial services employees, the people benefiting from the boom are going to vote in a Democratic primary?"
Leaders of the national Democratic and Republican Parties have debated whether Ronald Reagan or Bill Clinton deserves credit for the soaring economy.
Candidates like Hillary Rodham Clinton have occasionally suggested that some pockets of the country, like upstate New York, have not shared equally in the boom. But no one has critiqued the economy's performance as directly, or as harshly, as Mr. Florio, said Larry Sabato, a political science professor at the University of Virginia.
Robert H. Frank, a Cornell professor who has written extensively about the inequities and excesses of the 1990's, said Mr. Florio's argument may be a tough sell to voters.
"I can't think of any other candidate out there arguing against the boom," Dr. Frank said. "The Republicans aren't going to come out against an economy that has benefited their supporters, the rich. For Democrats, there is a case that Florio is making. But why make that case when you can just say we're responsible for greatest economic expansion of all time?"
It is somewhat surprising that such an appeal is being attempted in a place as prosperous as New Jersey. The state's per capita income -- $35,559 in 1998 -- is the second-highest in the nation.
Nearly 60 percent of New Jersey households have an interest in the stock market, either directly or through 401k plans or mutual funds. And the state's high-tech and pharmaceutical industries have expanded rapidly in recent years, helping drive the unemployment rate down to just 4.1 percent.
Nonetheless, some recent polls suggest that the boom has not completely erased New Jersey voters' suspicion of powerful establishments.
"Democrats are distrustful of big institutions, like big business, even if people are doing well financially," said Clifford Zukin, a Rutgers political science professor who heads the university's polling institute. "So in a Democratic primary, it makes some sense to rail against big money."
In many ways, the economic platform embraced by each candidate has been shaped by strategic necessity. Mr. Corzine, a political neophyte, has little choice but to maintain that his business triumphs are a harbinger of success in the Senate.
Mr. Florio left office in 1994, a year before most New Jerseyans began to fully feel the end of the recession, so it would be difficult for him to claim credit for the state's resurgence. Mr. Florio's campaign resources are also dwarfed by Mr. Corzine's $300 million fortune (and his pledge to spend as much as necessary to win).
So the former governor has blasted Mr. Corzine's costly advertising appeals in hopes that "free media," newspapers and television, will convey his message to voters.
What has emerged is a series of increasingly heated disagreements about economic disparity and the corrosive power of wealth that at times seem more at home in the Dust Bowl era than the Microsoft era.
On the day Mr. Corzine released his new television commercials this month, campaign officials for Mr. Florio held a news conference in which a prominent supporter ominously suggested that Mr. Corzine's fortune might actually be worth more than $1 billion.
"There are 450 billionaires in the U.S.," warned the supporter, Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a Democrat from Paterson. "And if they fan out across the country, they can consume all of the congressional districts."
Mr. Corzine has tried to counter Mr. Florio's appeals to class resentment by pointing out his working-class roots. He also contends that the campaign is not about Wall Street, but about the ability to understand and shape a rapidly changing economy. "I think Jim Florio is just out of touch with where the economy of the U.S. is in this day and age," Mr. Corzine said.
In a recent advertising campaign, Mr. Corzine claimed some credit for job growth in recent years, stating that during his stewardship of Goldman, Sachs, the company's investments helped New Jersey companies create or retain 700,000 jobs.
Mr. Florio ridiculed that assertion, saying it was absurd for an investment banker to take credit for jobs created by his borrowers. Many political analysts also characterized Mr. Corzine's ads as exaggerations.
But Mr. Corzine maintains that the ads are technically accurate and that their message is that he learned to direct capital to areas where it can spur economic development. He said he would use that expertise in the Senate by pushing for an urban redevelopment bank to encourage business growth in inner cities and by proposing bountiful subsidies for health care, preschool, long-term care and college education.
Mr. Corzine also blames Mr. Florio for New Jersey's economic stagnation in the early 1990's, saying the governor's decision to push a $2.8 billion tax increase through the Legislature in 1990 scared off businesses, fueled unemployment and contributed to his being voted out of office.
"You can't argue that it was going to be a generator of business to New Jersey," Mr. Corzine said. "It had a deleterious impact."
Mr. Florio, whose tax increase was enacted to pay for court-ordered increases in school financing, dismisses those criticisms as the naive quibbling of someone who has never had to make a tough political decision.
Mr. Florio also contends that his long career in state politics has made him singularly attuned to the worries of New Jersey families. Mr. Florio cited several recent studies that show the gap between New Jersey's rich and poor widening.
As he makes campaign appearances at countless centers for the elderly, union halls and kaffeeklatsches, Mr. Florio says he is frequently surprised at the deep concern many New Jerseyans have about their long-term financial security.
Mr. Florio is scheduled to release an economic position paper early next month. Drafts of the document call for tax cuts aimed at certain segments of the population, money for worker retraining and trade sanctions against countries that do not uphold environmental and labor standards. But thus far, most of the economic debate in the campaign has been a critique of Mr. Corzine's ideas and Wall Street resume.
Jon Shure, whose liberal research organization, New Jersey Policy Perspective, has released several studies about economic disparity in the state, said it was heartening to hear any political candidate making Mr. Florio's call for economic justice. But Mr. Shure, who was Mr. Florio's communications director but is not involved in his Senate campaign, also warned that those people left behind by the boom also constitute the segment of the population least likely to bother voting.
Mr. Florio says he is undaunted.
"No one ever accused me of taking the easy way," he said. "But that's what leadership is about. Talking about important things that many people aren't yet ready to address."

HEADLINE: SHOPPING;
An Internet Dummy Logs On for a Comparative Adventure

BYLINE: By BRIAN ALEXANDER; Brian Alexander contributes to Wired and other publications.

 BODY:
SENATOR JOHN McCAIN thinks that shopping online is so vital to America's prosperity that it should be tax free. Until now, I had shirked my patriotic duty. I had never shopped online. When I confessed this, people reacted the way women at Vogue magazine would react if someone mispronounced "Manolo Blahnik."
To avoid being labeled a misfit and to help keep our national economic engine humming, I jumped at the chance to shop on the Web for things I really needed and wanted. I then compared online and real-world shopping experiences by buying the same items the old-fashioned way. 
I kept score by price, time and frustration level (a 0 is no frustration; 3 is highest), and included driving time when judging real store shopping. To be fair, I should admit a few things. First, I am biased toward interacting with real people rather than sitting at home with my computer and credit card. So if the scores for the real stores and the online stores were close, I favored the real stores. Second, there is a learning curve to shopping online. My early purchases proved more frustrating than later ones. For example, it took hours for me to realize that typing a fairly common word into a search engine was hopeless. A search for "modems" generated a list of more than a million Web pages.
Third, regardless of where I shopped on the Internet, I was continually assaulted by DoubleClick advertisements; requests for "cookies"; warnings about my Netscape security certificate lapsing (whatever that means); windows upon windows alerting me to a "Java Script Error" (whatever that means); and my favorite: "This program has performed an illegal operation and will be shut down." I half- expected Eliot Ness to burst through my door. (I also learned to click "O.K." or "Continue" and keep my fingers crossed.)
Finally, my perception was also influenced by the fact that my computer is almost five years old. It has a 75-megahertz processor and 16 megabytes of memory. The modem is a 14.4K. I have made coffee while waiting for sites to download. In Silicon Valley's view, this means I should buy a new computer.
 
Modem
Instead of replacing my computer, however, I hijacked my wife's laptop and beefed it up with a new 56K modem. After two hours of ineffective searching, I found the 3Com Web site and selected a 56K V.90 Wintel modem card. The purchase took 20 minutes, only because I read the 14-paragraph legal document headed "Contract" and the privacy statement that said, essentially, there was no such thing as privacy. I paid $133.81, including tax and shipping.
The modem arrived three days early. Installing it was tricky, so I added 25 penalty minutes for consulting a technician by phone, plus 10 minutes for the moment he said, "Man, I give this a 2-to-1 shot of ever working."
It worked, finally, but did not increase the laptop's speed because of its limited memory. I returned to my own digital jalopy.
Shopping at a real store for the same type of modem was even more frustrating. I drove to Radio Shack, Circuit City and Staples. None stocked the modem. Circuit City had an Actiontec for $99.99; with tax, $107.75.
WINNER -- Online shopping.
TOTAL TIME -- Two and a half hours.
TOTAL COST -- $133.81, including tax and shipping.
FRUSTRATION -- 2.
THE RETURN -- 3Com accepted the return without a hitch and promised to credit my charge card, but I had to pay to ship the modem back.
 
Prosciutto
Two hours into my search for prosciutto, I knew more about Parma, Italy, home of arguably the best prosciutto in the world, but had failed to order any of the ham. I did find Muscovy duck prosciutto. At last I settled for Serrano ham, a Spanish prosciutto, from Dean & Deluca, in New York. That site was easy to use, and the ham arrived in two days, on time, packed in an ice chest. But I paid $47.21 (yikes!), including shipping, for one pound.
Prosciutto was simple to find at the Italian deli a couple of miles from my house. The guy behind the counter had suggested San Daniele, for only $19.95 a pound. No shipping.
WINNER -- The store.
TOTAL TIME -- 20 minutes.
TOTAL COST -- $19.95.
FRUSTRATION -- None.
THE RETURN -- Dean & Deluca would accept the return of the meat if it was unopened, but I would have to pay shipping. The deli would not accept the return of perishable food.
 
Termite Stakes
I have been fighting a chemical war with termites for two years. So I clicked onto an America Online shopping link for HomeTownStores.com, an online hardware store. The site required that I register and select a password, which I immediately forgot. When I searched for "termite" I found termite paper and termite shields. I had no idea what they did, and the site did not tell me. I scrolled down and found termite stakes, which are placed in the ground around the house to kill termite colonies. I ordered and paid $67.37, including shipping.
Unfortunately, the stakes arrived almost a week later than promised, but they weren't stakes. The box, in fact, contained four washing-machine hoses. Somewhere there is a guy in dirty clothes holding 20 termite stakes.
Home Depot stocked the Terminate brand stakes, charging only $49 for 20.
WINNER -- The store.
TOTAL TIME -- 35 minutes.
TOTAL COST -- $52.60, with tax.
FRUSTRATION -- 2 (I forgot where I had parked my car).
THE RETURN -- Easy at Home Depot, except for the long line at the return counter. I paid to ship the hoses back to HomeTownStores.com, and it promised to credit my account.
 
Toaster Oven
Several months after my wife and I moved into our house, we realized, thanks to the oven door's exploding open, that the gas ignition was not working properly. Last month, the handle on our toaster fell off. So we decided to buy a countertop toaster oven, solving two problems at once.
First we tried the Yahoo Kitchen and Home site. We chose a DeLonghi convection toaster oven for $179.95, which was at least $100 more than I had expected to pay, but it was Italian and sounded sexy, so we got it.
The next day I received an e-mail message saying that the company was out of the ovens. That same morning, however, I had seen an advertisement in a newspaper for a site called Tavolo.com. I typed in the Web address, the site popped up, I searched for DeLonghi ovens, and there they were. Unlike other sites, Tavolo offered the option of not registering an account with passwords and other information. I liked that. The oven was also $179.95, so I bought it. With tax, I paid $193.04. Tavolo did not charge for shipping. The oven showed up three days later, as promised. A week later, Tavolo .com sent me free jam and chocolate candy.
I drove to a local Williams-Sonoma store and quickly found the same oven. It was also $179.95. With tax, it would be $193.90.
WINNER -- A tie. Tavolo was easy and took less time, but I liked the saleswoman at Williams-Sonoma, who showed me how to use the oven.
TOTAL TIME -- One hour for Williams-Sonoma; 15 minutes for Tavolo.com.
TOTAL COST -- $193.90.
FRUSTRATION -- 1.
THE RETURN -- Both items were simple to return. Williams-Sonoma's policy is unconditional, as is Tavolo's. Tavolo will have the appliance picked up under most circumstances. No charge for shipping, though I was unable to make my computer print out the no-postage coupon Tavolo sent by e-mail. On second try, Tavolo faxed the coupon to me.
 
Coffee
My wife and I buy our coffee at a warehouse store. It is not great coffee, but it is about $8 for two pounds of whole beans, a deal. I figured that the Web might offer better coffee at a good price and that I might be able to subscribe to a service that would ship coffee to my door every month.
Many sites sell coffee, but few offer regular home delivery. Then I found E-Java.com. It offered a choice of three coffees, each in 12-ounce bags to be delivered monthly. I ordered Vienna Roast, Guatemala Antigua and French Roast. Including shipping, I paid $24.49 for the three bags, or 36 ounces. I also got a friendly e-mail message confirming the order, and when the coffee arrived on time two days later, the box included two samples as well as coffee candy.
Because the site did not sell the cut-rate beans I was after, I compared the E-Java.com deal with what was available at a local gourmet roaster. The shop sold beans by the pound. Vienna Roast, French Roast and Guatemala beans were $10 a pound each; 48 ounces cost $30, no tax.
WINNER -- A close call, but the store was cheaper.
TOTAL TIME -- 40 minutes.
TOTAL COST -- $30.
FRUSTRATION -- 2. (I got caught in traffic and realized I could not afford good coffee from either source.)
THE RETURN -- E-Java would accept the return and credit my account, but I would have to pay the shipping costs. The roaster did not accept returns.
 
Book
When I told people I had never bought anything online, they responded, "Not even a book?" So I clicked onto Amazon.com.
I considered buying "Technopoly: The Surrender of Culture to Technology," by Neil Postman, a techno-skeptic and cultural critic.
Ready to click the buy button, I recalled all the people who had considered me a rube. I also thought of John McCain and my nation's economy. So I raised a white flag and ordered "The Complete Idiot's Guide to Internet Shopping" for $18.43, including shipping. It arrived two days later, on time.
I then drove to a large bookstore, but the book was out of stock. The store could order it in four or five days for $18.26, including tax, but I would have to pick it up.
WINNER -- Amazon.com.
TOTAL TIME -- 10 minutes.
TOTAL COST -- $18.43.
FRUSTRATION -- 1. (I took a point off for the brief identity crisis I suffered upon re-entering the site: "Hello, Brian Alexander! If you are not Brian Alexander, click here.")
THE RETURN -- I paid the shipping costs to return the book to Amazon.com. The store would accept returns if the book was in its original condition.
 
Postscript
One week after my shopping excursion, I bowed to the inevitable and ordered a 700 MHz computer at the Hewlett-Packard Web site. I am also signing up for a digital subscriber line. Now let them smirk.

HEADLINE: SHOPPING;
Nobody Pays Retail, but the Real Bargains May Fade Away

BYLINE: By STACY KRAVETZ; Stacy Kravetz covers business issues from Los Angeles.

 BODY:
COME on, admit it. Who does not love getting a deal, no matter how much it costs?
Marketers depend on consumers' desires to go after deals, even for things we would never buy without a dollar-off coupon. Online retailers are equally savvy, offering all types of discounts for shopping on their sites. The fact is that online discounts are much like their real-store counterparts: they lure us in, get us to spend more than we planned and send us home reassured that we got a bargain. 
 Keep this in mind: Online retailers are not charities. Even Web sites will need to make money some day.
To be sure, there have been bona fide deals, especially around the recent holidays. In December, for instance, many sites offered free shipping and deep discounts that undercut prices at their very own brick-and-mortar stores.
But as post-holiday reality set in, discounts reverted to more typical forms: most were 9 percent to 16 percent off the regular price, but many retailers compensated with costly shipping and handling, or by charging fees for returns. Retailers make higher profits on shipping charges than on merchandise.
Some sites make comparison shopping arduous by forcing you to click through multiple screens to find out what a sweater really costs, all told, with tax, shipping and handling. Retailers hope you will invest so much time that you will go ahead and make the purchase, discounted or not.
In case that makes you want to head for the malls, here are some of the newest players in the online retail contest: sites that help you get a good deal at other sites.
* Reverse auctions. Sites like priceline .com, buyersedge.com and liquidprice.com have popularized the concept of searching for a retailer to match the price you are willing to pay. Often such sites automatically charge the item to your credit card if a retailer agrees to your price (so you had better want it). Others allow retailers to bid against each other until one prevails with the lowest price.
* Group purchasing. Buytogether.com, mercata.com and accompany.com gather buyers who are interested in the same product and offer a group discount. The price goes down as more buyers enter the group until a specified deadline.
* Online coupons. Hotcoupons.com and clickrewards.com, among other sites, give you incentives ranging from frequent-flier miles to online coupons for local stores.
Then there are sites that help you navigate through the discount jungle. Most people do not even know they exist. A study of 5,831 online shoppers revealed that only 34 percent were aware of sites that compare prices, according to Forrester Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Price-comparison sites will sift through discounters when you specify the item you want. Automated shopping robots, or bots, like mysimon.com and hotbot.com, scan the Web for the lowest price on the item. Pricing engines like dealtime.com, bottomdollar .com, deals.com and pricegrabber.com list online retailers who carry the item and offer merchant ratings and delivery information.
Other sites, like bizrate.com, offer rating systems that evaluate an online retailer's prices, promptness of delivery and shipping charges.
All this assistance, however, does not necessarily mean that there are great deals to be had. Experts say, for example, that the bargains carry costs of their own.
DAVID COOPERSTEIN, the director of online retail research at Forrester, says that by and large, Web discounters are worth looking at when you are buying an item that costs a few hundred dollars or more. If you can save 5 percent by shopping comparatively for 15 minutes, it is usually worthwhile.
But consider the trade-offs.
Time, for instance. How long does it take to find a good price, and how long until delivery? Do you really want a weeklong delay for a Zip disk drive to travel via ground transport just because the out-of-state purchase allows you to skirt sales tax?
Some online retailers offer a good deal if you are willing to give information about yourself and do not mind having your name circulating among marketers. You can get anything from rebates to a free mouse pad for filling out customer surveys and product registration information.
If you like your privacy, you should save your money another way.
"Retailers make consumers choose," Mr. Cooperstein said. "To get discounts you have to give some data or spend your time researching."
Web shopping is no place for suckers. The discounting sites shout at you with bold colors and spinning logos, prodding you to jump at the low, low prices. Some retailers pay to advertise on price comparison sites, fooling you into thinking that their price is the best. Sometimes deep discounts are real, albeit temporary -- meant to build loyalty and subliminally lure you to buy full-price items later.
"Sites in the health- and beauty-aids business may offer incredible discounts on over-the-counter items to hook you so you'll come back to buy more expensive items," said Alan Alper, an analyst with Gomez Advisors in Lincoln, Mass.
Brand-name items, like the Sony Walkman or the Apple iMac, are less likely to have wide swings in prices, whether online or in a retail store.
If you do not care about buying a brand name, your chances of finding a deep discount are greater. Your chances of being enormously confused are, unfortunately, also greater, because your searches will turn up hundreds of choices.
Online shopping, of course, is in its infancy. It has the potential to offer one-stop shopping through sites that can build profiles for shoppers to be used to troll the Web for sales, deals and new online retailers that will match shoppers' exact specifications.
That is still a leap into the future. But one thing is certain. For people who seek a deal, Internet shopping provides one more way to persuade themselves that they have found one.

HEADLINE: Is Anybody Not Out for E-Billions? Josie True, for One

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
JOSIE TRUE, a Chinese-American cartoon girl in an online game, hunts for her missing teacher by time-traveling. Along the way, she strikes up conversations with little-known historical heroines like Bessie Coleman, the first African-American to earn an international pilot's license.
Unlike most Web-based action games, which generally interest boys, "The Adventures of Josie True" is designed to appeal to girls' interests in characters and narratives. In sly fashion, Josie also introduces players to role models absent from most history books, while increasing their computer fluency. 
 "This is not a moneymaking scheme," said Mary Flanagan, an assistant professor of media studies at the University of Buffalo, who is developing the game with a grant of $199,920 from the National Science Foundation. Her concern is the lack of educational software aimed at girls, particularly minority girls.
Tapping this overlooked market, Ms. Flanagan thought, could help solve a stubborn gender gap. Girls still take fewer advanced computer-science classes than boys and are more likely to shy away from careers like engineering, said a 1998 report by the American Association of University Women. Part of the reason, the report said, was that boys play computer games more than girls and enter classrooms far more comfortable with computers.
"It's a software developer's dream to do something you're committed to," said Ms. Flanagan, who hired graduate students to finish the online game (www.buffalo.edu /scripts/newnews/index.cgi?article =theadventu) by the end of this year. For schools and girls without Web access, Ms. Flanagan intends to produce CD-ROM's.
With modest government assistance and a passion for closing the digital gender gap, Ms. Flanagan is demonstrating how the Internet can be an egalitarian tool for self-expression. The site, like other noncommercial sites being developed around the United States, is intended to be an example of high-minded goals that have not been eclipsed by the cacophony of e-commerce.
Without millions of dollars of investors' money to buy mass-market advertising, noncommercial sites, especially ones catering to untapped or underserved sectors, face an uphill battle as they try to gather like-minded audiences from the far corners of cyberspace. But such efforts are far from a lost cause.
"It's not different from any other medium," said Ekaterina Walsh, a consumer analyst for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. Compared with slickly packaged Web content for mass audiences, original and unadorned sites are a breath of fresh air that gain word-of-mouth (or e-mail) credibility "in the same way NPR and PBS stand out on radio and TV," Ms. Walsh said.
And developers of noncommercial sites can salve their dot-com envy with a patina of respect. Research shows that consumers are more likely to trust nonprofit sites than commercial ones, Ms. Walsh said.
Unable to penetrate popular culture through radio and television advertisements, some developers of noncommercial sites have resorted to grass-roots efforts to build an audience, particularly among those without Internet connections. This approach can be successful when the audience itself ends up being the supplier of low-cost content.
For example, in public libraries in Newark, Harlem and Melbourne, Australia, youngsters are dabbling at a test site, www.kahootz.com.au, where they can create and publish animated stories and inventions online, then "chat" about their work.
At a recent tryout of the site in Newark, schoolchildren on two continents showed off their child-centric creations: a homework helper and a dirt-to-food machine. "We're creating a channel for interactive design to stimulate girls and kids who don't have computers at home, to get them to start thinking of themselves as designers and inventors," said Dorothy T. Bennett, the project director of the Education Development Center for Children and Technology, which is developing the site with the Children's Television Foundation in Australia.
Another grass-roots project has already drawn participation from nearly 1,000 children in 139 countries. Their contributions filled an online bulletin board devoted to how young people believe technology can improve the world. The first Web site, www.jrsummit.net, spawned a second, www.nation1.org. The project began with professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab, who contacted education officials around the world to attract young people to participate.
"It's all about bringing underrepresented groups online," said Justine Cassell, a Media Lab professor who was one of the program's organizers and is a co-editor of the book "From Barbie to Mortal Kombat: Gender and Computer Games."
Another approach to reaching such an overlooked audience comes from Oakland, Calif., the eighth-largest city in the state. Pummeled by the 1989 earthquake and a catastrophic fire in 1994, the city is struggling to make an economic comeback, particularly in East and West Oakland, which are characterized by a mix of stately but aging Victorian houses, boarded-up storefronts and few commercial services, like supermarkets and bank branches.
"For the underserved communities to move to the served category," the community, not corporations, will have to create the content, said David Geilhufe, the director of the Eastmont Computing Center in Oakland, where 350 people receive computer training financed by the National Science Foundation.
This version of urban renewal is aimed at compressing the digital divide in poorer neighborhoods without typically putting computers in every classroom. Instead, the city and its philanthropic partners are counting on the virtual world to provide banking services that are unavailable to many residents in the community. The cost of developing an e-banking service in this market, about $300,000, with investment payback expected to be slow, is being shared by four lenders led by Union Bank of California.
"We'll mobilize and test and pull people into it," said Donald Vial, the chairman of the California Foundation on the Environment and Economy, a nonprofit group in San Francisco. Starting in May, about 200 people will use the service, which will be offered at five community technology centers, among them Eastmont.
Participants will receive training in computers and household financial management and learn how to navigate an e-banking site that will be customized for language and culture, said Norman Jayo, the foundation's senior strategist.
E-banking has the potential to show people that technology can make a difference in their lives, whether by helping a small business grow or helping someone on welfare to find a job, he said.
A goal of Oakland's e-banking site is to show lenders and other Web businesses that demand exists in neighborhoods being bypassed by e-commerce. "When the application is significant to them, it takes off," Mr. Jayo said. "It's using technology as a base for empowerment."

LENGTH: 1239 words

HEADLINE: NEXT NEW ERA;
For the Small Retailer, Life on the Internet Is One Big Bazaar

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
WHEN GeniusBabies.com, a fledgling business owned by Michelle Donahue-Arpas, joined the giant online mall Yahoo Stores last April, its sales doubled a month later and reached $20,000 a month by November.
But if Yahoo has served Ms. Donahue-Arpas well -- with a 95 percent customer approval rating she is a featured merchant -- she knows she should expand her horizons. 
 "Yahoo giveth and Yahoo can taketh away," she said, referring to the "featured merchant" designation, which raises the profile of her business, a seller of educational and developmental toys for babies and toddlers.
As a small fish swimming in a very big pond, Ms. Donahue-Arpas, like other small retailers, must make careful decisions about how to expand her company. In such a world, it would be easy to be overwhelmed, overshadowed or swallowed up if she is not careful.
With a growing number of shopping platforms from which small businesses can choose, a free-for-all is developing in online retailing. Portal shopping centers are offering an increasing number of services like gift registries, price-comparison tools and reviews to lure consumers while bolstering their base of merchants by making it easy to set up and run an online store. Amazon.com has opened an Internet bazaar it calls zShops, and a growing number of companies known as e-business service providers are offering retailers free tools to establish and maintain online stores with them.
Each alternative has advantages and disadvantages for merchants, and no clear answers have emerged about the best way to go.
"Most retailers are still unclear on how to do it and, more importantly, who to do it with," said Kneko Burney, director of markets and computing at Cahners In-Stat Group, a research group in Scottsdale, Ariz. "The big hurdle for them is building a Web presence that makes sense and making it known."
In-Stat estimates that 60 percent of the small companies in the United States have Web sites and about 80 percent use the Internet, but few do an effective job of selling products or services online.
"There are a lot of platforms that offer a quick fix for big bucks," said Sue Schwartz, who developed YarnXpress.com, which sells specialty yarns, with the help of an e-business service provider called Freemerchant.com. "It's really 'Let the buyers beware,' " she said, referring to the merchants.
Yet if caution is in order, analysts think there is also opportunity. Seema Williams of Forrester Research, which analyzes e-commerce, observed, "A bit of a free-for-all is actually a good thing," opening up options for small retailers. It is important to remember where interests lie.
For example, she noted, Amazon.com is foremost a store, and its interests will come first. Shopping portals like Yahoo, which is not a retailer, will always have more allegiance to their big-name merchants, who pay more money to be on the site.
The bottom line is that small merchants must look out for themselves, getting their names out in any way possible and using resources as long as they are cost-effective.
Ms. Schwartz, of YarnXpress, could not agree more. She said she was pleased with the set-up features offered by Freemerchant.com, but played down the links it provided to search engines as a way of generating business. More valuable, she said, was the link to eBay, which led to the sales on which she built her business. Rather than pay to put her business on established sites, she has used other strategies, including starting an online group for knitters and advertising in a knitting magazine.
Freemerchant sees itself as giving small businesses "a techno grub stake," offering free site construction, free hosting and back-office support like inventory control and sales-tax calculation. But it stops short of being a shopping destination.
By contrast, online malls and portal shopping centers have the benefit of traffic and built-in name recognition that can give an instant lift to a merchant. While the cost of aligning with some of these sites remains prohibitively high, other sites are lowering monthly fees and offering business-related services.
AltaVista, for example, is adding a variety of direct-marketing capabilities to its Shopping.com service while plugging more stores -- large and small -- into the search and product listings areas.
But such a relationship costs a few thousand dollars a month, more than what many small retailers can afford. In addition, analysts said, the big shopping sites' focus on comparison shopping, particularly regarding price, is not often advantageous for small retailers, who will be undercut by larger merchandisers.
At Yahoo, whose goal is to be the leading shopping site on the Web, Jennifer Dulski, a brand manager for Yahoo Shopping, which includes Yahoo Stores, said services were geared to buyers as well as sellers. Yahoo Shopping, which includes 9,500 stores and an auction, offers tools to merchants to help them establish and manage Web sites. The cost is about $100 a month to post 50 items, but rises from there.
In late September, Amazon.com introduced zShops, which offers merchants the chance to list their stores for $9.99 a month. Amazon can process credit-card orders for an additional 2.25 percent of the total sale. Merchants can also take advantage of Amazon's one-click shopping feature, which allows consumers to store their shipping and credit-card information in a database.
Ms. Williams, a senior analyst with Forrester Research, said that while Amazon would provide a retailer with traffic for a while, "the worry is, you're going to lose your category if Amazon decides to offer your product."
Still, linking with a site that has a customer base of 17 million people is enticing. "I believe the people who have the financial resources to advertise their Web site or latch on to those who can advertise for them are the ones that are going to be successful," said John Arnold, a customer service manager with the Pacific Cookie Company in Santa Cruz, Calif.
PACIFIC COOKIE has established a Web presence mainly through partnerships in which it provides goods to sites wholesale but pays nothing up front. It began with sites like Greatfood.com, and then established relationships with entities like Givechocolate.com, a gift site.
When approached by Amazon about joining zShops, Pacific Cookie readily agreed. "We haven't seen a lot of orders from them," Mr. Arnold said, "but just to be on a site like Amazon we thought was worth the cost we were putting forward."
Pacific Cookie will not stop there. By this summer, Mr. Arnold said, the company will be listed on about 10 shopping platforms, most of which cost the company nothing.
By contrast, Bryan Matthews, who sells antique books in Los Angeles, has stuck mostly to putting his books on databases. Although he said he was approached daily by online virtual malls to join their sites, he has gone with zShops because of his longstanding relationship with Amazon.com.
Instead, Mr. Matthews is investing his time and energy in developing the first online cooperative of booksellers, which he thinks will protect his business interests in the long run.
"It will let people know there are all these independent booksellers and turn them away from the brands and the big platforms," he said. "We want to let buyers know they are better off dealing with personalities. We're the ones that have the books."

LENGTH: 1966 words

HEADLINE: Behind 'Name Your Own Price' Lies a Mesh of Partners

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
PRICELINE.COM does not even look like your normal dot-com company. Its headquarters are not in Silicon Valley, but in a suburban office park. Instead of 20-somethings in jeans and T-shirts with long hair and short resumes, many of its inhabitants are gray-haired recruits from companies like Citigroup and AT&T. Some wear neat, casual clothes, while others wear suits.
Looks are not deceiving. For all its e-commerce, new-economy credentials, Priceline wants to be a member of the Old World corporate club. Instead of battling older, more traditional companies, Jay S. Walker, its 46-year-old founder and largest shareholder, and his lieutenants have turned them into partners and allies. If he does well, he says, so will Delta Airlines, American Airlines, AT&T, A&P, D'Agostino's, Pathmark, the National and Budget car rental companies and the Ford Motor Company. 
 "We don't compete against these companies," Mr. Walker said at his office. "We don't seek to own an airline. We don't seek to be a car dealer. We don't seek to be a grocery store. We don't seek to be a phone company. We seek to improve the profitability of our partners rather than cannibalize it."
Instead of conducting auctions with rising bids, Priceline allows a buyer to propose a price that the seller, whether of airline tickets or orange juice, can choose to accept or reject. Translated into Pricelinese, this approach comes out as the slogan "Name Your Own Price."
For all Priceline's establishment stripes, what Mr. Walker has in mind is more radical than eBay, pushing a strategy that is becoming more important throughout e-commerce: partnerships.
More and more, when customers call up a Web site, they see a single entrance to a structure made up of many businesses in a tangle of alliances and subsidies. Entrepreneurs like Mr. Walker concentrate on what they do best, finding partners for everything else.
"We distribute prices, not products," Mr. Walker said, his bushy eyebrows rising and falling for emphasis.
Priceline, he said, is demonstrating how the Web can introduce a new series of relationships between seller and buyer. "You can't wheel a grocery cart down the aisle and have AT&T say, 'You know what? I'll pay for all the meat in your grocery cart if you'll try our long-distance service for 7 cents a minute.' The Net allows for far richer, far more customized, instantaneously creative partnering."
In general, Priceline's target is not the customer who wants favorite grocery brands delivered to the door, who wants to fly direct flights at reasonable hours and stay in favorite hotels. All those desires are served well by other companies and Web sites. Priceline targets the bargain hunter.
Stores like Wal-Mart manage to offer low prices partly by using their size to win special breaks from their suppliers. Mr. Walker does not. He wants sellers to have the flexibility to lower their prices, then raise them. "We do not use our size to try to extract concessionary prices," he said. "Sellers like us because they can use us to balance supply and demand in a constantly changing business."
But isn't Mr. Walker dishing out some unrealistic bargains? Yes, he said, at least for now. "The model in every business is subsidize first to build traffic," he said. "Every business spends money to acquire customers. It's every grand-opening sale that has ever existed."
Analysts like Henry Blodget, at Merrill Lynch, remain optimistic about Priceline's prospects, but they also wonder what will happen when the grand-opening sale ends. "The question is what happens when the discounts narrow and the consumers won't be getting such a great deal," Mr. Blodget said.
Mr. Walker said that Priceline will be able to sustain attractive discounts. Bidding and buying through Priceline, he said, can involve a deal with up to five parties: Priceline, the customer, a retailer like a grocery store, a manufacturer or a service provider, and the provider of an unrelated service like long-distance calling or credit cards or magazine subscriptions. The issuer of Discover cards, for instance, will add $30 to Priceline customers' bids for airline tickets if they apply for the cards. Another $5 from Discover goes to Priceline.
The corporate partners are so important to Mr. Walker that he often identifies them, not his online buyers, as his true market, as when he said, "We're not here to compete with our customers."
His office seems like a shrine to those partners-cum-customers. Against an incongruous background of bookshelves filled with leather-bound classics, he displays dozens of packages -- Cheerios, Dove soap, Joy dishwashing detergent -- and model jets.
So strong is Mr. Walker's belief in his strategy's distinctiveness that he has taken out several patents, recorded on plaques that line a Priceline.com hallway, to protect his business processes. He has sued Microsoft, maintaining that it has infringed on Priceline, a contention Microsoft strongly disputes.
Whether this strategy will benefit consumers or investors once consumers exhaust their specials and Wall Street starts demanding profits is unclear.
So far, Wall Street's passion remains strong. Though Lauren Cooks Levitan, an analyst at Robertson Stephens, raises questions about how many industries will be receptive to Mr. Walker's approach, she praises the concept. "I think Jay stands apart as a real visionary," she said. "He isn't just trying to shift market share online, but develop a whole new business model."
THE Priceline strategy has been applied to hotel rooms, rental cars, mortgages, groceries, new cars, castoff household appliances and, as announced just last month, gasoline, but it will not work everywhere. Given the opportunity to offer name-your-own-terms credit cards, many major issuers have balked, as have some large manufacturers.
Kraft Foods, a unit of Philip Morris and the nation's largest maker of packaged foods, has also balked. So for the time being, shoppers who want Kool-Aid, Jell-O, Post cereals, Maxwell House coffee, Kraft cheeses or Oscar Mayer hot dogs cannot order through Priceline. "We are not participating," said Moyra Knight, a spokeswoman for Kraft. "We just need a better understanding of their performance."
Airline tickets, the closest thing to a certifiable success for Priceline, have features that suit the company's strategy, a point Mr. Walker readily confirmed. Airlines have to unload a highly perishable inventory, seats that would otherwise be empty, at low prices, without sacrificing revenue from business travelers and others willing to pay high prices. Priceline allows the airlines to find travelers willing to accept inconvenient connections and departure times in return for a bargain.
Just as clothing stores do not usually post signs telling shoppers about their outlets, airlines do not play up their Priceline partnerships. American Airlines, for example, refused to comment.
But other partners see so many benefits, and so few risks, that they are happy to voice their praise. "The stores like it and the customers seem to be happy," said Nick D'Agostino III, a vice president at D'Agostino Supermarkets Inc. of New York. Priceline allows his stores to sell groceries over the Web at no extra cost to them, he said, because the manufacturers provide the discounts and the customers pick up the groceries themselves.
Mr. Walker came to his big idea in stages. As a student at Cornell University, he was sued by Parker Brothers to prevent him from publishing a guide to winning at Monopoly, and watched the weekly newspaper he started in Ithaca, N.Y., collapse under competition from a local daily owned by the Gannett Company chain. "As you become more experienced in business, you learn that picking a fight is usually the last thing you want to do," he said. "War is the ultimate failure of diplomacy."
When Priceline began operating in April 1998, inviting customers to propose prices for airline tickets, its diplomacy led to the signing of only two, relatively meek carriers: T.W.A. and America West. Securing major airlines as partners took money, in the form of Priceline shares. That summer, Delta Airlines agreed to sell its tickets on Priceline's Web site in return for, among other goodies, rights to buy millions of shares for nearly nothing. Other major airlines followed, with American and United also receiving Priceline stakes, although smaller. The total cost to Priceline -- if not in cash, in the ability to raise it -- is about $1 billion.
Analysts were understanding. "There is no way they could have primed the pump without doing that," Mr. Blodget said. Mr. Walker, saying that such concessions are not habit forming, said that he has not had to give equity stakes to any other partners.
And if Priceline initially subsidized the tickets, paying the airlines more than it was receiving from customers, the company is paying less now. Marketing expenses, including those television advertisements with the actor William Shatner, still leave Priceline with heavy but narrowing losses.
Will the strategy work? The results, so far, are unclear. But it is a strategy distinct from the backward-looking approaches to selling over the Web. "We're not just catalogs online," Mr. Walker said. "That's not the future of e-commerce."
 
Grocery-Service Novice Finds Bargains, but No Bananas
 MY first experience with Priceline.com's new Webhouse Club name-your-price grocery service could have been accompanied by its pitchman, William Shatner, singing, "Yes, We Have No Bananas."
I wanted to bid on bananas, but when I tried, I was insistently asked to apply electronic discount tokens to the purchase. I received six such tokens just for trying out the grocery site. But by the time I bought the bananas, I had applied the tokens to salmon and boneless, skinless chicken breasts -- more expensive items for which tokens meant greater savings.
My future savings would come mostly from the producers. I could obtain discount tokens by answering surveys, accepting free introductory subscriptions to magazines and the like.
For my visit, I had to sign up online for a Webhouse card, which I received in about two days via priority mail, but learned later that I could have picked up at a participating store. On the site, I was quoted the odds of successful bids. For a half-gallon of orange juice, the site gave a range of $2.19 to $2.79 (high, I thought), and said that at $1.95, I had an 85 percent chance of filling my order; at $1.82 a 66 percent chance, and so forth. I bid $1.82 for two half-gallons and got Tropicana, any variety.
Among my other successes were two pounds of salmon, a bargain $2.82 a pound, using the discount tokens (regularly about $4.99); skim milk at $1.50 a gallon, saving about $1, and six cups of Colombo yogurt, at 51 cents a cup (though I prefer Dannon).
At 7:30 on a Sunday night at the A&P in Montclair, N.J., one of several local stores that participate in Webhouse Club, I found that the fresh seafood had been removed from the counter 90 minutes earlier. Yes, we have no salmon. And the yogurt, normally 95 cents, was on sale at 4 for $2.
Having prepaid on the Web site, I presented my printed receipt at the checkout counter and swiped my Priceline Webhouse card. The receipt said I had three months to pick up my groceries, meaning I could return for the salmon. After that, the charges for any groceries I had not picked up would be credited to my card.
The bottom line was an hour on the Web site and a savings of $3.78, offset by not being able to buy all the groceries I had wanted. With practice, however, I could probably do my electronic shopping in 10 or 15 minutes.
And that Colombo yogurt was not bad. ALLEN R. MYERSON

SECTION: Section H; Page 12; Column 1; E-Commerce

HEADLINE: NEXT NEW ERA;
The New Economy's Currency Is Stock, Stock and Stock

BYLINE: By MARTHA BAER; Martha Baer is a senior contributing editor of Wired magazine.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
A BAY Area urologist treating a patient who works at an Internet start-up recently had an idea. For their next appointment, the urologist joked, he wanted to be paid in shares.
"Think of what the guy does all day, for a doctor's salary," the Internet executive said sympathetically. "Of course he wants to get into the game." 
 Like the bankers, lawyers and venture capitalists he reads about in the papers daily, the urologist wanted in on the action, and these days it seems that everyone but the doctor is welcome.
Today, hordes of business-to-business contractors who make deals with high-technology companies are trading their services for equity. While law firms have long taken slices of their clients' companies on top of regular fees, consultants are now doing the same, along with public relations agencies, executive search firms and commercial landlords. Even independent engineers and building contractors are participating in the equity swap meet.
"We're five for five," said Ed Niehaus, a cofounder of Niehaus Ryan Wong, a San Francisco public relations firm that serves technology-company clients. "We've taken cash plus shares as payment from five companies and have seen all five go public." A sixth company, spun off from one of the five, went bankrupt, but Yahoo and OnSale.com were among the group, according to an executive close to the deals.
For public relations agencies that work with high-technology ventures, the opportunities for such deals are rife. Because of a shortage of agencies that are expert in technology, firms like Niehaus Ryan Wong are picking and choosing whom they will work with and how they will be paid. And venture capitalists, or V.C.'s, warn start-ups that their business plans must incorporate publicity efforts, which sends 30 to 50 companies knocking on Niehaus's door every week, many offering stock.
All of which makes signing contracts with new clients resemble aggressive stock picking. "You're acting like a venture capitalist when you do this," Mr. Niehaus said.
Sunny Bates has placed about 20 such bets since she founded Sunny Bates Associates, an executive search firm, in New York 11 years ago. The firm serves high-techology companies and the news media. She said, "We've hit twice, once with Priceline and now with a company still in its quiet period.
"These sorts of deals not only help us develop the value of our company and get our recruiters involved," Ms. Bates continued, "but they also guarantee a different kind of relationship -- not a hit-and-run, but a mind-share involvement. If you're a stakeholder, you give freely of your introductions and your time, your contacts. You're not hoarding."
For recruiters, equity reimbursements often follow the same formula as cash fees. Search agencies have traditionally taken a third of the newly placed executive's first year's salary, but now that fee is combined with a third of the executive's first year's stock options. Stock deals can be complicated, however, and vary widely. Some require no vesting or "lock-up" period, so recipients can cash in the minute a company hits the public market. Some deals involve options and some warrants. Both represent the right to buy stock at a given price in the future. Warrants, however, tend to be subject to fewer tax and accounting rules and can be issued on a more ad hoc basis than options.
In real estate, where the equity-as-currency phenomenon is stirring up this fairly traditional industry, landlords are agreeing to take warrants in lieu of security deposits. A wildly competitive real estate market can give the landlords more discretion over tenants and how they can structure deals.
"Rents are going up on a biweekly basis in my area," said Ted Caulkins, an associate director of leasing services in San Francisco for Cushman & Wakefield, the international real estate brokerage firm. "A landlord usually has three to six offers, and it becomes a beauty contest. That's where the stock element gets very attractive."
Within the high-technology sector and other companies that are likely to go public, roughly half the deals Mr. Caulkins negotiates involve warrants or options.
Even in New York, where large, institutional landlords reign supreme, stock-for-space swaps are occurring in smaller niches. Rudin Management, which owns highly visible commercial properties like 55 Broad Street and 110 Wall Street in the financial district of Manhattan, has done four such deals. When Rudin Management negotiated with xBind, a networking-technology company, "we liked their business model," said William Rudin, the president. With Homedelivery.com, which accepts orders for local merchants through its Web site, Rudin Management saw other possible collaborations. "We own a lot of residential apartments in Manhattan, and Homedelivery.com's services can add value for our customers."
WHEN New York landlords and dot-coms start talking synergy, times have changed. Or have they?
"My grandfather's philosophy was to buy stock in a company that moved into his building," Mr. Rudin said. "It's a slight variation of the theme."
But buying stock in companies beyond your balance sheet is not the same as taking stock for pay. At Cushman & Wakefield, Thomas Falus, the president of the New York operations, does not favor the equity high-wire act.
"We're investing vast amounts of money in earnings to grow our business in China and South America," Mr. Falus said. "We can't afford not to be profitable in mature markets like New York." For him, playing the equity game with square footage is no better than playing the horses without knowing a thing about thoroughbreds.
Mr. Caulkins agreed that companies needed to do their homework. "These deals put the landlord in the position of a V.C.," he said.
Scott Jamar sang the same refrain: "I use the same criteria in negotiating with clients that a V.C. would use." A marketing consultant with 20 years' experience in high-tech businesses, Mr. Jamar has taken noncash payment to the next level by incorporating it into his business model. "It's become a core component of my strategy, to build a portfolio of equity in companies. Right now I have stock, or agreements to take stock, in four companies. I imagine over the next 12 to 18 months, I'll probably hold equity in 10 to 15 companies."
Because he works with early-stage start-up companies, Mr. Jamar asks for a minimum of their scarce cash and most of his compensation in options. But this risky ride suits him well, he said. "The new Jaguar convertible is going to have to wait for a while, but I don't feel like I'm selling myself short."
At this end of the spectrum -- where e-commerce companies are even cutting in one-man-show consultants who would otherwise be billing at $150 an hour -- the territory is relatively untested. "This is a brave new world for most independent contractors and their clients," said Michael Dortch, who has been following the high-technology industry as an independent research analyst for most of the last 25 years. "Think about it just on a logistical basis: companies tend to work with a lot of contractors; for each equity arrangement you've got to go before your board and write up a specific contract; no one has the time to manage that much overhead."
Still, that momentum is building. "Somewhere down the road," Mr. Dortch predicted, "forward thinking start-ups might build into their business plans classes of equity specifically for independent contractors."
So, does all this swapping portend a world in which every office temp and smoothie delivery person builds a portfolio of investments in the start-ups they serve?
Not exactly. While the equity flows between businesses and their contractors in ever larger quantities, plenty of young companies are clutching to their ownership, declaring their equity too valuable to hand off to outsiders.
Michael Hudes, the president of Organic Online, a Web company that builds sites and provides marketing services and that went public in February, held firm when potential landlords proposed that Mr. Hudes pay in equity. "If we gave equity to any number of partners who approached us, we'd have missed out on giving ownership to the people who matter most, our employees."
Todd Sotkeiwicz, the chief operating officer of Bigwords.com, an e-commerce retailer targeting the college market, is also careful. "A short-term relationship I would never pay for with equity," he said. "It's got to be really long term and really strategic."
In addition, after an initial offering, most companies become stingy. "When you get capitalized," said Isabel Maxwell, the president of CommTouch Software, a provider of e-mail services, "you're looking at mergers and acquisitions. You buy what you need. I doubt you'll find well-capped companies who would give away stock to small contractors."
But as long as word keeps spreading that dot-com options are today's top dollar, contractors will clamor for them. Take the building contractor who badgered a San Francisco executive for warrants. "It was a total knucklehead request," the executive said. "Ten thousand shares, he kept on insisting, 10,000 shares. But he had no idea of the exercise price or how many shares we had outstanding!"

HEADLINE: NEXT NEW ERA;
Now That They've Come, What Can We Sell Them?

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
BEFORE people realized they could make a million dollars on the Web by putting an "e" in front of any word in the dictionary, registering the new name and shaking down a venture capitalist for seed money, the Internet was a much more communal place.
Perhaps because it was populated largely by academics and technology geeks who either cared little about getting rich or considered the idea so outlandish as to be irrelevant, the Internet assumed a quaint identity as a place where people offered information freely. 
 Personal home pages, chat rooms, bulletin boards and Usenet groups, which are open-discussion forums on various topics, drew millions seeking advice, news or companionship. Those running the sites frequently relied on surplus computer space from universities or whatever network power they could scrape together with spare money.
Then, of course, came e-commerce, a phenomenon that prompted the tripartite categorization of the Internet: now, alongside commerce sites are content sites, in which a publisher provides news and information, and community sites, in which the users create the content.
But the tremendous interest in making money from the large number of people who frequent a site, or "monetizing eyeballs" (in industry parlance), also foretold profound changes for community sites.
Community sites began selling advertising to stay in business. The sites incorporated and wrote business plans. Some, like TheGlobe.com, went public. Others, like the Internet Movie Database (IMDb.com), were bought by bigger sites (Amazon.com in this case). Still others, like Deja News.com, a buying guide in which consumers rate products and give advice, assumed a new identity (Deja.com) and charged headlong into the e-commerce fray.
In some cases, the community sites angered their constituencies, who accused them of selling out to commercial interests. In others, the transitions were smooth. But whatever the story, analysts and executives of community sites say the e-commerce revolution changed the face of the Internet.
"Community sites have been wandering the desert in search of a revenue stream," said Lisa Allen, an e-commerce analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "Now they've latched on to e-commerce, which is the fair-haired child of the Internet. The only problem is, commerce isn't making any of them rich, either."
Sometimes, commerce has alienated the users who helped create the sites' content. Tom Phillips, the chief executive of Deja .com, said that site angered "a lot of people when we made the change."
The change Mr. Phillips referred to took place last year. DejaNews.com, one of the few sites to provide easy access to and retrieval of Usenet topics and information, became Deja.com, a site devoted to users who wanted information about a range of products. DejaNews.com had generated a loyal following and had made money by selling advertising. But when Deja.com rolled out, it began posting boxes on the site's pages, requesting opinions and ratings on products.
Those opinions were aggregated into a vast (and anonymous) database, the linchpin of the new Deja.com site. But as Mr. Phillips said, "we sort of force-fed people the ratings and reviews, and it slowed the site down," leaving it less navigable.
David Wilson, Deja's senior vice president, said, "The complaints mostly talked about how Deja was, and is, the standard-bearer of Usenet, and they were concerned we'd take our eye off the Usenet ball and everyone would suffer for it."
As a result, Mr. Phillips said, "we lost a chunk of people, but we also gained some, so our traffic has been pretty flat."
He added that Deja would drop the ratings boxes and that "given the viral nature of Usenet," he expected those who left the site to return.
But Deja is not dropping its e-commerce ambitions.
Rather, the company's newest incarnation, released this month, expands its offerings of purchase information and includes direct links to merchants selling goods featured on the Deja site.
The transition from community to commerce was much less bumpy for the Internet Movie Database, a compendium of movie trivia built largely by contributions from movie buffs around the world who gathered on the IMDb.com site.
According to Col Needham, who founded the database in 1990 in Britain, the site received four complaints when it decided to start selling advertisements in 1996, and no complaints when it was bought by Amazon in 1998.
Not all the people who used the database were thrilled. Some felt that a friendly and comfortable online community had been swallowed by a giant.
Still, Mr. Needham said that not only did the alliance with Amazon lead to an increase in the number of contributors to the database; as it has grown, the database has hired some of the people who contributed voluntarily.
"I think that in the end, most people understand that when you have e-commerce in a content site, you can fund the future growth of the site, so users win both ways," he said. "They can buy things they're interested in, and they have better content."
Yahoo encountered trouble last year when it bought GeoCities, a site that allows users to create free home pages. Soon after the acquisition, Yahoo posted a notice on its GeoCities site (http://geocities.yahoo .com), suggesting that Yahoo could take the content from a person's GeoCities site and use it in a book, for example, without compensating the home-page publisher.
The event caused a stir among the GeoCities faithful, spawning a boycott and inquiries from at least one consumer group.
"I can understand where the users were coming from," said Doug Hirsch, a senior production director for Yahoo Communities.
"But at the end of the story, we did change our terms of service," he said, to assure home-page publishers that their content was, in fact, their property.
"Consumers are very wary of what commerce sites are doing with content they provide -- and they should be," Mr. Hirsch said. He argued, however, that GeoCities had become less commercial since Yahoo bought it, notably containing less intrusive advertising. "I'm actually proud that it hasn't lost its grass-roots vibe," he said.
OTHER community sites are heading into e-commerce, hoping to make a similar claim in the future. Gamers .com, a site devoted to video game enthusiasts, is one such venture. Among other things, it lets users rate video games and post notes on message boards about anything related to games.
According to the site's chief executive, Dennis Fong -- known in professional computer game circles as Thresh, the undefeated world champion -- the company will soon introduce a service that allows users to buy games on the site from retailers or buy from other users in an auction format. In addition, he said, they will be able to trade games.
Mr. Fong said he expected no resistance from users because the site was committed to the open exchange of information about every game on it. "We're the Switzerland of the games industry," he said.
Nonetheless, he added, the transition should be done carefully, lest it wave the e-commerce flag too proudly in the process. "The last thing we want to be known as is a store," he said. "It's very hard for a store to be cool."

HEADLINE: Transforming Art Into Enterprise

BYLINE: By BILL WELLMAN 

 BODY:
While many chief executives have nailed down the art of the deal, not many know the deal on art.
Enter Wendell Castle, artist-in-residence at the Rochester Institute of Technology and one of America's foremost furniture makers. His one-of-a-kind art pieces have graced corporate collections all over the country and hang in such cultural emporiums as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Smithsonian and the Art Institute of Chicago. 
 And if you have to ask the price, well, you can't afford it. His pieces start around $20,000 and then begin to become expensive.
So why has Mr. Castle decided to disrupt a successful art career at the age of 67 and become an entrepreneur? Last year, he started a business called Icon Design that will market a "budget" line of his works -- the Wendell Castle Collection, as it is called -- for prices ranging from $1,000 to around $15,000. Icon will also look into producing pieces designed by other furniture makers.
Part of his motivation for going downscale was to make more money, Mr. Castle said. "There are only two ways I can think of if you want to have a better income out of it: you can either make more or charge more," he said. "I sort of tried the making more back in the early 80's and really didn't like it. There was always somebody saying, 'What am I going to do next?' It distracted me so much that I couldn't really concentrate."
"Charging more is a great option," he added. "But you can't just do that instantly. You kind of have to tweak the prices up."
"But I wanted to do more than that. I had all these ideas for things that I probably was never going to do because they really weren't far out enough to justify making one."
So he decided to make a lot of copies of these new designs, none of which duplicate his art pieces.
Every year, hundreds of thousands of Americans start their own businesses, from gift-basket ventures to Web retailers. And no matter how high- or low-technology their products are, most of these entrepreneurs share two distinct traits, the experts say: A desire to run their own show and a knack for seizing opportunities nobody else sees. Mr. Castle filled the bill on both counts.
His brainstorm came when he starting running numbers through his head. The effort of making more than just one would pay off financially if he made 20 copies, or 50, he figured. But then, he said, "I thought, if you have something really nice why do you want to stop at 20 or 50, especially if somebody else is making them."
Now, he was talking mass production -- albeit on a limited scale -- and that takes more than a studio, even if the studio is as large and rambling as Mr. Castle's in Scottsville, near Rochester. The Wendell Castle Collection is already being made on a small scale in the studio, but is about to be transferred to Icon's new 37,000-square-foot plant in nearby Le Roy.
Mr. Castle designs the pieces -- sold at Holly Hunt in New York and other locations -- for the new line and builds prototypes, but after that the work is turned over to his crew. He expects to add designs every year and to retire pieces that don't sell. After all, as he put it in Rule No. 10 of a 1996 poster, "My 10 adopted rules of thumb," that graces his Web site (www.wendellcastle .com): "If you hit the bull's-eye every time, the target is too near."
The new plant was bought last fall and is expected to be in full operation this spring. It will eventually have about 50 workers and will be laid out with production efficiency in mind -- unlike the Scottsville studio with its Escher-like stairs that seem to lead down to higher levels when they are not taking you up to lower ones.
Going to all of this trouble to open a plant also points out another reason to produce in quantity, although Mr. Castle said it was not the most important one: "An artist really never has a business that you can sell. Other businesses have value. You build a business up and you can sell it to somebody."
But back to the president and chief executive formerly known as the artist.
Icon is about a $2 million project, Mr. Castle said. He said he had sold 30 percent of the company to raise $1 million and then had received low-interest loans and grants to cover the rest. He estimates revenues of $1.2 million for this year, and expects the company to become profitable in 2001. Most of that business, he says, will be with people who use architects or interior designers. And to his delight, people who already own his art pieces are also buying his new line.
"Another way of doing this is to not sell any of it and start much slower," he added. "I didn't have a million dollars lying around, but I could come up with a couple hundred thousand and start much smaller and grow."
But when you're in your 60's, he added, "the idea of slow isn't so appealing."
All of this has created new challenges. Mr. Castle has always been skillful at marketing his artwork, but the intricacies of marketing an entire company are of a different magnitude. He is now involved with bringing in a public relations team and a marketing team -- another associate, Hunter Kariher, the operations officer, will run the plant day to day. "Everything I've ever done in my whole life, I think I probably jumped in naively," he said. "I didn't realize how much we have to do."
In the midst of this he is still carrying on at R.I.T., where he has no teaching schedule but does give seminars, "where we talk about current issues, design problems, problems of starting a business -- some of the practical things that go along with furniture making in addition to aesthetics."
Is something lost when an artist takes on the role of full-fledged entrepreneur?
"I like to think that it's possible to wear two hats," Mr. Castle said, "though it is pretty hard to wear them at the same time. You have to take one off to put the other one on. And the transition is not instant. It takes a little adjustment period. Right now I'm in the production mode, and after this spring we're introducing about 12 new things so some pressure will be off. And at that point I really can get back to some art work.
"If economics didn't enter the picture," he added, "the art work would be the clear choice."
