HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Fine Values From Italy's Sun-Baked South

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
SOUTHERN Italy is torrid in more ways than one these days. In the course of a few years it has become one of the most sought-after wine-producing regions in the world.
Not by wine drinkers, at least not yet, except for a handful of smart shoppers who know enough to shrug off labels and grapes, and concentrate on value. No, the wine people who are most interested in southern Italy at the moment are big producers from the north like Antinori, Santa Margherita and Zonin, which, lured by bargain prices, are buying hundreds of acres of actual or potential vineyard land, and importers from Britain and the United States looking for good affordable wines. 
 Ten years ago, the talk in the wine trade was of Tuscany, Piedmont and the Veneto, with Lombardy, the Alto Adige and Friuli following along. Now, Abruzzi, Campania, Apulia, Sicily and Sardinia are hot topics, with Calabria, Basilicata and even obscure Molise beginning to be known for their wine and wine potential.
It's not as if southern Italy hasn't been involved in wine in the past. The Greeks, who colonized the region before Roman times, called it Oenotria, which comes from the word oinos, Greek for wine. Greco del Tufo from Campania, greco di bianco and greco nero from Calabria and grechetto from north of Rome all trace their origins to early Greek settlers.
These sun-baked provinces have always produced wine, most of it heavy alcoholic stuff shipped off in bulk for blending with thin northern wines. There have been good wines made here, too. The Mastroberardinos have been making fine wines near Naples for generations, while families in Sicily have produced well-known wines like Corvo and Regaleali for hundreds of years.
But hundreds of other wines have been made and enjoyed in the south, ignored by the Northerners and totally unknown to the rest of the world. Suddenly, people are talking about grapes with names like negroamaro, cannonau, primitivo, aglianico (which derives from Hellenic) and the nero d'Avola, the best grape of Sicily and perhaps one of the best in Italy.
Southern Italy is usually defined as everything south of Rome, plus the Abruzzi to the east and the islands of Sicily and Sardinia. On the mainland, almost all of this region is cut off from the north by the Apennine mountains, meaning it suffers few of the weather problems that plague Tuscany and the Piedmont. It is an area as yet untouched by large international demand; it's out of reach for wine enthusiasts who drive down from Germany and Switzerland to bid the prices of Italian wines up to Bordeaux and Burgundy levels.
Southern Italy is an impoverished region. Unemployment in the Veneto, the booming industrial and wine-producing region around Verona in the north, is about 4 percent. In the far south, it is 15 to 20 percent, and more.
Southern Italy, at least until now, has enjoyed a special kind of stability, unknown in more modern cultures. As Leonardo Locascio, an American importer, said: "These regions have lived under so many conquerors -- Greeks, Muslims, Normans, Spanish -- that there has always been a visceral attachment to family and land, particularly land. Property, at least until recently, never changed hands."
"Consequently," he explained, "the price of a bottle of wine rarely reflects rising land prices the way it does in northern Italy, where prime vineyard land currently sells for $200,000 an acre."
Thus, low demand, a willing work force, good land prices and unfamiliar wine names have all contributed to what is still an attractive relationship between price and quality. Many of these wines are between $8 and $12 a bottle.
Not all the names are unfamiliar. Sicilian wines, for example, have long been widely available in this country. Now, there are some new ones. Try La Segreta wines from Planeta, particularly the merlot-based red. Or Regaleali's delightful Nozze d'Oro (Golden Wedding) sauvignon blanc, created for the fifth wedding anniversary of the owners, Giuseppe and Franca Tasca. Morgante's nero d'Avola, which resembles a young syrah, is also worth seeking out.
Sardinia, a truly remote wine source a decade ago, now exports several intriguing wines from Argiolas, including Turriga, a red blend of cannonau and malvasia nera, and a Cannonau di Sardegna Riserva from Sella & Mosca, the island's largest wine producer. Cannonau is the local name for grenache, the principal grape in Spain, which once owned Sardinia. For a unique but engaging cabernet sauvignon, try the barrel-aged Marchese di Villamarina, also from Sella & Mosca.
Mastroberardino is still the most respected wine name in Campania, and for me its most respected red is its Taurasi, made from the aglianico grape. The riserva is aged up to four years and can be laid down for many more. Falerno del Massico Rosso, from the Villa Matilde, is another Campania red worth sampling.
Of course, Mastroberardino is also the best-known source of greco del Tufo, a fine dry wine with a hint of almonds. For an inexpensive red that still manages to display some complexity, the Copertino Riserva, made from the negroamaro grape at a cooperative in Apulia, is a good bet, although, like others on this list, not yet widely distributed. The Vigna Spano from Calo, another Apulia producer, is a bigger wine, with depth and a long finish.
Another Apulian wine rather well known in America is Salice Salentino, also made from the negroamaro grape. It, too, is a big wine, made to last. A prominent producer is Taurino. It also comes in a rose version. (One day, southern Italy's rose wines will be much sought after. They are lighter than the reds but have body and lots of flavor. Some people apparently age them successfully.)
The aglianico grape turns up in another relatively well-known red wine, Aglianico del Vultura, from vineyards near Potenza, in Basilicata. This is another keeper, with great power and concentrated flavors. I'm told the 1985's are just now at their best.
These are just a few of the hundreds of wines produced in the southernmost reaches of the Italian boot. If they are not yet in your local shops, try the ones that are. A whole new world of wine awaits.

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK;
When the Age of Courtship Ends

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN 

 BODY:
WE know it will end. It's only a question of when. Even the longest economic expansion in history cannot continue forever.
And when it ends, what will happen to the smaller revolutions it has created? To the transformation of the office into a place where workers are acknowledged to have families? To the growing insistence of employees that their lives matter? Is all this talk of work-life balance really a change to the social core, or is it just cocktail conversation that will fade when the party's over? 
 I recently spent a day in Boston at a company called Circles, the ultimate icing on the work-life cake. If your employer contracts with Circles, you are entitled to call a "convenience coordinator" who will run your errands. Coordinators won't do anything "that isn't legal, moral or nice," says Janet Kraus, co-founder and chief executive of Circles, but they will wait for the cable repairman, plan your child's birthday party or take your car in for servicing.
On the morning I arrived, Kelly Medico, a coordinator, sat at her computer searching for the perfect birthday gift for a Vietnam veteran who collects war memorabilia. For nearly two hours, Ms. Medico trawled the Web, choosing between a World War II wrist compass, an unopened pack of Lucky Strike Greens and a Saddam Hussein pincushion doll. And all the while the giver of the gift, an Ernst & Young employee, was doing her own work, which is why Ernst & Young was paying for this in the first place.
"We view it as a way to increase productivity," says Denise Hoffman, the manager of work-life balance at Ernst & Young. "It's valuable in retention of employees, and we use it as a recruiting tool."
Recruitment, retention and the bottom line. Those -- not generosity or love -- have always been the underpinnings of human-resource policies, says Ann Vincola, a longtime work-life consultant in Boston. She said that chief executives are not sold on job sharing, or flex time or lactation rooms "just because you present this as the right thing to do; there has to be some perceived advantage to the company."
There is no doubt that companies are eagerly seizing that advantage. The Society for Human Resource Management conducts an annual survey, asking its members what benefits they offer. Three years ago, there were 92 choices on the menu. Last year, there were 110. Not only does the survey show an increase in what are now considered traditional benefits (53 percent offer flex time, an increase of 7 percent from 1997), but the new perks are growing, too. Massage therapy is hot now (8 percent of respondents say their companies offer this), as are concierge services (now at 4 percent and double the percentage a year ago).
But if we accept that all this attention to our lives is spurred less by enlightenment than by economics, what can we expect when the economic realities change? "There will," Ms. Vincola says, "be a tightening of the belt." Those programs that make financial sense will remain, she predicts. Telecommuting, for instance, which frees office space. Or compressed workweeks, which don't cost the company more if they're done right. But things that simply make lives easier will probably be cut.
The people who make their living from work-life programs understand this, and they are quietly preparing for the inevitable. Two weeks ago, I attended a work-life conference, and the talk at one lunch table was about a human-resource executive's push to get on-site child care "right now when times are flush because once it's built they're less likely to take it away."
Ms. Kraus of Circles is also storing nuts. "We're diversifying our risk," she says, describing a recent deal with a major credit card company: sign up for their platinum card and get a free Circles membership.
If the economy stalls, she reasons, "there is a future for us in the customer loyalty market."
In the meantime, her coordinators keep fielding requests from harried but pampered employees. Find a psychologist in Florida who will perform an I.Q. test on a preschooler. Find a gym within five miles of Harvard Square with a basketball court that is open past 10 p.m. A housekeeper with good references in New York. Child-friendly hotels in Maui. Willie Nelson tickets any place he'll be playing.
We are standing on a sliver of a moment in a most unusual time. It may be cold comfort, but you might never be more valued by your boss than you are right this minute. Savor that while it lasts.

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Another Evil Empire, This One in the Mirror

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

BLOWBACK
The Costs and Consequences of American Empire
By Chalmers Johnson
268 pages. Metropolitan Books, Henry Holt. $26.
Chalmers Johnson starts his new book with an account of how he came to change his view of the American role in the world. A onetime supporter of the Vietnam War who now wishes he had "stood with the antiwar protest movement," Mr. Johnson, professor emeritus at the University of California, San Diego, spent a decade studying Japanese industrial policy. His research, which inevitably covered the American relationship with Japan, led him, he writes, "to see clearly for the first time the shape of the empire that I had so long uncritically supported."
The empire in question is the American empire, the term itself indicating the extent to which Mr. Johnson has now come to see things very critically indeed. His new book, "Blowback: The Costs and Consequences of American Empire," is a take-no-prisoners tirade against what he portrays as classic imperial overextension worthy of Rome or the Ottoman Empire. His main contention is that the United States, by resorting to "bluster, military force and financial manipulation," all harnessed to its goal of global hegemony, is subjecting itself to acts of retribution around the world -- that retribution being the "blowback" of his title. In other words, the World Trade Center bombings and other anti-American terrorist acts may be just the beginning. 
 In this sense Mr. Johnson's book is a useful and timely alert by a man with robustly contrarian views. But Mr. Johnson's turn from uncritical to critical about the American empire is a vastly more radical project than just a warning. Underlying his book is a strong but unsubstantiated conviction that the United States has all along been little better than any other imperial power, including the Soviet Union, seeking amoral advantage wherever and however it could -- and reaping blowback as a consequence. Extending blowback to just about every area of American action in the world gives the book a boldly provocative edge; unfortunately, it also makes Mr. Johnson sound like some of the more rigidly ideological protesters he used to disdain.
This is not to say that Mr. Johnson fails to raise important questions or to make persuasive arguments about the deleterious consequences of the global American presence. Among the questions is whether it is really necessary for the United States to maintain some 65 major military installations outside its borders. Mr. Johnson describes the most important of those installations, in Okinawa, as a place where the impact of so many soldiers on such a small island has been ruinous for the permanent inhabitants. One of his major villains is the International Monetary Fund, whose narrow America-centered view of developement is, in Mr. Johnson's jaundiced view, responsible for economic hardship around the world, and this view, though sketchily presented, merits a hearing.
Mr. Johnson also mounts a thought-provoking critique of American behavior during the Korean crisis of 1994 and 1995, when North Korea seemed about to embark on a nuclear weapons program. He demonstrates that the threat was grossly exaggerated to begin with and then deceitfully managed, with the result that the Korean peninsula is more potentially dangerous than it was before. His two chapters on China, which he portrays as a likely superpower of the 21st century, are incisive, informed and common-sensical.
But these sections of Mr. Johnson's book are marred by an overriding, sweeping and cranky one-sidedness. The basic problem is that Mr. Johnson is a good deal readier to see hidden similarities -- between, say, the nature of the former Soviet satellite East Germany and the American "satellite" Japan -- than to admit obvious distinctions. His account of the American relationship with South Korea is a case in point.
He begins with the highly debatable assertion that for much of their history North and South Korea were "nearly indistinguishable in terms of human rights abuses and Stalinist-style development policies." Mr. Johnson then focuses largely on the suppression of a democratic uprising in 1980 in the city of Kwangju against South Korea's military dictator of the moment, Gen. Chun Doo Hwan. To Mr. Johnson, General Chun's crackdown, more violent than China's Tiananmen Square crackdown a decade later, was of a piece with Soviet repression in Hungary in 1956 and Czechoslovakia in 1968 and illustrates the basic similarity between Soviet and American imperialisms.
It is a deceptive, even cynical argument. Nobody that I know of has much love for General Chun or approves of his handling of the Kwangju crisis, but Mr. Johnson's eagerness to draw Soviet-American parallels leads him to pass lightly over crucial facts and arguments. Most generally, he does not consider that the invasions of Czechoslovakia and Hungary were Soviet totalitarianism expressing its nature, whereas the slaughter in Kwangju represented neither American values nor American goals. He dismisses as almost irrelevant the signal fact that no American troops were in Kwangju but Soviet forces were in Eastern Europe.
Equally troubling, Mr. Johnson relies on a few snippets of very inconclusive evidence to accuse American officials in Korea and Washington of authorizing General Chun's Kwangju actions in advance, but he ignores a substantial evidence and published testimony that point to a contrary conclusion. Mr. Johnson even muses that when General Chun later was tried for the Kwangju massacre, these American officials "might well have belonged in the dock alongside their Korean colleagues."
Most important perhaps, Mr. Johnson fails to offer alternatives to American policy in Korea or the likely consequences of those alternatives. In Hungary and Czechoslovakia the alternative to the Soviet invasion was the survival of less repressive new governments. In Korea the alternative to continued backing for General Chun would probably have been a collapse of order in South Korea, which might have induced North Korea to attact.
Mr. Johnson is even unwilling to give the United States any moral credit for the overall outcome of its engagement in Asia: namely, conditions of relative peace and stability in which a core of fairly prosperous democracies has emerged. Mr. Johnson may label these democracies -- among them Japan, South Korea and now possibly even Indonesia -- as mere "satellites" of the American empire, but that characterization probably says more about Mr. Johnson than it does about the realities of world politics.

HEADLINE: An Iowa Heirloom: Pork With Real Flavor

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: STATE CENTER, Iowa

 BODY:
AGRICULTURE, they tell you the moment you get to Des Moines, no longer rules the local economy. Corn and pigs are no longer kings.
Well, maybe not, but farm traditions die hard. Although almost half of Iowa's pork producers went out of business between 1992 and 1997, the surviving family farmers cling to their debt-ridden, often economically marginal farms the way grand old English families hang on to their country houses, even when the roof leaks and the servants are long gone. 
 Hogs still outnumber people here five to one. Lots of people eat pork sandwiches, made from breaded, deep-fried tenderloins, instead of hamburgers. At the Iowa State Fair, an 11-day extravaganza each August, hungry Hawkeyes in bib overalls and print dresses flock to a huge dining hall called the Pork Tent.
And Iowa still chooses a lissome young thing every year to wear a crown and a pigskin sash that identifies her as the Iowa Pork Queen.
Pork queen? Anywhere else, call a young woman a pork queen and she breaks down in sobs, heads for the guidance counselor and asks her mother where she went wrong. In Iowa, the title is a badge of honor.
Big corporate operators have taken over the bulk of Iowa's pork production, with dire results not only for the small farmer but also for those of us who were raised on succulent pork chops and pork roasts. Fat gives pork some of its flavor, but modern hogs are bred to minimize fat; producers noticed that Americans were choosing chicken over beef. Raised in close quarters inside enormous metal buildings, the hogs foul the air for miles around, and their meat is bland, dry and tough when cooked.
"Pork, the other white meat," the ads say. Right they are; much of it, as Edward Behr wrote last summer in his erudite newsletter, The Art of Eating, "is as lean and characterless as factory chicken breast."
Happily, Iowa's rich, dark soil holds onto people like Kelly Biensen, a fifth-generation hog farmer, and his wife, Nina, a pair of stubborn, well-educated souls who want to do things differently. They are retro-pioneers who produce pork the old-fashioned way, giving their pigs lots of room to move about and eschewing the drugs and hormones many use.
They have also organized a marketing group called Eden Farms, which sells pork from their farm and 85 other family farms that raise pigs known as Berkshires, which originated in England 300 years ago. The breed is well known for its flavorful meat, well marbled with fat.
Try the gingered pork tenderloin at Bistro 43 in Des Moines, and you will taste the difference. Jeremy Morrow, 32, the chef, told me that he always has Eden Farms pork on his menu, prepared in a number of ways. The meat is moist, tender and almost buttery, with a bright, fresh taste. You know that you have hold of a piece of pig.
THE Biensens know that their pork tastes better, but for them, what is more important is that it commands a premium price. It has enabled them to escape the trap of commodity pricing.
Overproduction has driven the price of everyday pork below the amount that it costs a small farmer to produce. Mr. Biensen said that as a rule of thumb, it takes about $100 to raise a hog for market, and the price has fallen below that level more often in the last few years than it has risen above it. Most small farmers struggle to break even.
Things are bad for little guys everywhere. Glenn Grimes, an economist who does studies for the National Pork Producers Council, estimated recently that 8,000 hog farmers across the country quit the business in 1998 and 8,000 more quit last year.
"Life has not been very easy," said Mr. Biensen, 47, who lives in a battered farmhouse, surrounded by pens and barns, at the center of his 248 acres. "We haven't lived as well as we should. My wife has a Ph.D. in animal husbandry from Iowa State University. We could have done other things if our goal was money. But we wanted this, our own farm."
Mr. Biensen pronounces his family name, which is Alsatian in origin, BUY-en-son. He wears steel-rimmed glasses that make him look rather professorial, and as he talked, seated at a computer in a corner of the worn family kitchen, a small, rueful smile flickered across his face.
"The big change is the cost of farming," he told me one snowy morning in January. "In only about 40 years, we went from $300 to $500 for an acre of land, to $3,500 an acre. It has settled back to $2,500, but that's still almost 10 times as much. Forty years ago, the biggest tractor was 70 horsepower. Now, they look like a house coming across the field.
"As a result, labor is being replaced by capital as the essential element," Mr. Biensen continued. "The big producer, with more to invest, gets bigger, and he can make a deal with the packing houses. The more hogs you can give a packer, the higher a price you get."
At the moment, it costs about 40 cents to produce a pound of pork, which then sells for 38 to 39 cents. Eden Farms pork, however, fetches roughly 50 cents a pound from its customers, mostly clubs and restaurants in central Iowa. The Biensens grossed only $2,300 in January 1999, not long after they began. But business is growing steadily in their niche market: in December, they grossed $13,800.
SEVERAL things, Mr. Biensen suggested, account for the bland flavor of most supermarket pork.
One is the modern method of raising hogs in confinement -- "always indoors," he said, "in the same exact spot for their whole lives," eating there, sleeping there, defecating there, through the slatted floor into vast, smelly manure lagoons. Moving in and out of shelters, roaming in open lots, the way the Biensens' pigs do, even in cold weather, seems to yield firmer, juicier, tastier pork.
Hogs that are too lean cannot stand the cold outdoors.
A second factor is P.S.S., for porcine stress syndrome, which is caused by a gene often carried by breeds used for factory farming. It makes the animals more efficient -- that is, they produce more pounds of lean meat per pound. But they often produce meat that Mr. Biensen describes as P.S.E. The letters stand for pale, soft and exudative. Exudative meat loses much of its moisture as it cooks, which is why a fried pork chop can taste like leather.
Beef is classified by the federal government, with "utility" at the bottom of the scale, "prime" at the top. The more marbling, the higher the grade, but no such classification exists for pork.
Ken Prusa, a professor of food science at Iowa State University in Ames, argued that moisture, not fat, is the key to flavor. Low-fat, high-moisture pork, if not overcooked, can be delicious, he asserted, although most top chefs pay top dollar to get pork with a higher fat content.
One problem is that most home cooks and some chefs overcook pork in their determination to kill any lurking trichinae, the parasites that cause trichinosis. But with the disappearance of pork produced from pigs fed on garbage, and improvements in hog-rearing methods, Professor Prusa said, the chances of contracting trichinosis are nearly nil.
In any event, he added, no one need fear pork cooked to medium -- 160 degrees, with a bit of pink at the center. Other food technologists assert that medium-rare pork, cooked to 145 degrees, is perfectly safe. Some professional cooks here and abroad cook pork less than that. Heston Blumenthal, the chef at the Fat Duck near London, which has two stars in the Michelin guide, cooks his chops, cut from the loins of Tamworth or Middlewhite hogs, less than that, serving them at 135 degrees, still rosy-pink.
"The chances of someone getting sick from eating pork are a thousand times smaller than those of picking up bacteria from chicken," Mr. Blumenthal said. "I think that pork is probably the safest thing we serve."
Breed also counts. Berkshires produce somewhat smaller loins, which means fewer pounds of salable meat, but the meat has very fine fibers, which give it greater water retention capacity, and more tiny veins of intramuscular fat, which give it a more full-bodied flavor.
The Biensens raise both purebred Berkshires and Berkshire hybrids, for which Berkshires are crossed with other breeds like Durocs, one of the major commercial breeds. The hybrids, 75 percent Berkshire, grow faster, and the sows give birth to larger litters, while retaining, Mr. Biensen said, the desirable characteristics of purebreds.
His charges are fed soybean meal, ground corn and vitamins and minerals, but no animal byproducts and no antibiotics, which are standard for many factory pigs. They are energetic, curious beasts, mostly black with an occasional splotch of brown. Almost all of them have a white flash on the face, a white tip on the tail and white markings on all four feet.
As I watched them, I thought about Wilbur, E. B. White's lovable pig, who learns the hard facts about life and death in "Charlotte's Web."
EVENTUALLY, Mr. Biensen wants to sell his pork nationwide. Already, he noted, Berkshire pork has attracted a wide following; Japanese customers, who are notoriously picky about meat, like Berkshire pork so much that they buy most of the production of farmers affiliated with another marketing group, American Berkshire Gold.
Chefs across this country, dissatisfied with the pork available through normal channels, have found alternatives. Alice Waters of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., turned to Niman Ranch in nearby Marin County, whose beef had long been featured on her menus, and Niman Ranch eventually hooked up with Paul Willis, an Iowa farmer.
His and 36 other farms, in Iowa and nearby states, now supply Niman, which sells to restaurants (including Gramercy Tavern and Lutece in New York), a few retail outlets (including Fairway and Eli's in New York and Fresh Fields in Washington and Baltimore) and also direct to consumers. Telephone orders can be placed at (510) 808-0330, and Niman promises Internet ordering soon.
At Fairway, Niman Ranch's seven-rib rack Frenched is $8.99 a pound. At Eli's Manhattan, Niman center-cut pork chops with bone are $8.99 a pound, and shoulder roast is $5.99 a pound.
I discovered another top-flight producer, Four Story Hill Farm in Honesdale, Pa., 30 miles northeast of Scranton, by asking about the source of the dish "Black Pig Variation" (a pig's trotter stuffed with morels and a feather-light pork cutlet) that I tasted at Seeger's, a superb restaurant in Atlanta.
When I called the farm, Sylvia Pryzant, who runs it with her husband, Stephen, told me that they custom raise poultry and pigs for chefs like Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Wayne Nish in New York, Charlie Trotter in Chicago and Thomas Keller in the Napa Valley. The Pryzants also concentrate on Berkshire hogs, fed in part on chopped fresh apples, mostly McIntoshes, and slaughter them when they are younger (12 weeks old) and smaller (55 pounds dressed weight) than is usual with the pig farmers in the Midwest.
Mr. Pryzant, 48, and Ms. Pryzant, 44 and Tunisian-born, moved in 1992 to Pennsylvania from the New York suburbs, where she had been working for a nonprofit organization and he had worked in food service in a nursing home. He learned farming on a kibbutz in Israel. Now, she said, they watch their pampered porkers "running around in happy circles every morning."
 
SOY-MARINATED PORK TENDERLOIN WITH SHIITAKE CREAM
Adapted from Bistro 43, Des Moines, Iowa
Time: 1 hour plus 4 hours' marinating
 
2 tablespoons chopped ginger
2 tablespoons chopped cilantro
2 tablespoons chopped basil
 1/4 cup sake
 1/4 cup soy sauce
1 2-pound pork tenderloin
Vegetable oil or non-stick spray
 1/2 cup sliced shiitake mushrooms
2 tablespoons chopped scallions
 1/2 cup heavy cream
 1/4 cup chicken stock or low-sodium canned chicken broth
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
Gingered sweet potatoes (see recipe).
1. To prepare marinade: In a blender, combine ginger, cilantro, basil, sake and soy sauce. Puree until smooth. Place pork in a large bowl, and pour soy mixture over. Cover and refrigerate for 4 to 6 hours.
2. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Coat bottom of a roasting pan with oil or non-stick spray. Transfer pork from marinade to roasting pan, reserving 1/4 cup of marinade. Roast pork until internal temperature reaches 150 degrees, about 50 minutes; do not overcook, center should remain slightly pink. While pork is roasting, prepare shiitake cream.
3. To prepare shiitake cream: In a skillet over medium heat, heat 1 tablespoon oil and add mushrooms and scallions. Saute until mushrooms are softened, about 2 minutes. Add reserved marinade, heavy cream and chicken stock. Simmer until liquid has been reduced to 3/4 of its original volume. Season with salt and pepper to taste, and keep warm.
4. To serve, thinly slice the tenderloin, and place a portion on each of four warmed serving plates. Spoon shiitake cream over pork, and serve with a portion of gingered sweet potatoes.
Yield: 4 to 6 servings.
 
GINGERED SWEET POTATOES
Time: 1 hour
 
3 tablespoons unsalted butter
 1/4 cup heavy cream
3 tablespoons finely chopped ginger
3 tablespoons finely chopped garlic
2 pounds (about 3 large) sweet potatoes
Salt and freshly ground black pepper.
1. In a small saucepan over low heat, melt butter and add heavy cream. Remove from heat, and add ginger and garlic. Set aside to steep.
2. Fill a large pot halfway with water, and bring to a boil over high heat. Add sweet potatoes (whole and unpeeled) and boil until potatoes are tender in center when pierced with a knife, about 30 minutes. Allow to cool enough to be handled, then peel. Place in a medium saucepan, and cover to keep warm.
3. Place a fine-meshed strainer over a medium bowl. Pour ginger and garlic mixture in and press on solids to extract as much liquid as possible. Discard solids, and add liquid to the sweet potatoes.
4. Place saucepan of potatoes over low heat, and mash until potatoes are smooth and reheated. Season with salt and pepper, and serve hot.
Yield: 4 to 6 servings.

HEADLINE: Land of the Automobile

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your March 24 Weiskirchen Journal from Germany suggests that Europeans sacrifice mobility to save energy. Although Europeans make only half as many car trips per day, they make four to eight times as many public transit trips as Americans, and four to five times as many walking and bicycling trips. In most European countries, at least half of all trips are by either public transit, walking or bicycling (compared with less than 10 percent here). 
 Our nation's auto dependence puts us at the mercy of oil-producing cartels and jeopardizes our long-run economic and political independence. It also pollutes our environment, accelerates global warming and robs us of valuable cardiovascular exercise.
 
JOHN PUCHER
New Brunswick, N.J., March 28, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: Pataki Offers Plan for a Women's Museum in Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 28

 BODY:
More than 150 years after the first convention on women's rights in upstate New York, Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed building one of the first museums in the country to be devoted to women's history.
The $125 million museum would be in Battery Park City near the southern tip of Manhattan, joining several recent museum projects like the Jewish Heritage Museum and the planned Skyscraper Museum. Mr. Pataki, a Republican, has provided $1 million in state money for the project and promises to carve out more from this year's budget. Advocates for the museum, which include a group of prominent civic and business leaders, are planning to raise the rest from private donations. 
 "We certainly have outstanding elements of history here in New York," Mr. Pataki said in a telephone interview. "The next logical step is to pull it all together in one site that is visible and reachable by most people. I think we're going to see a great deal of support for it."
Mr. Pataki said the idea originated with a one-year commission that he appointed in 1998 to honor the achievements of women. Libby Pataki, the governor's wife, headed the commission, and its 52 other members included Beverly Sills, Billie Jean King and Roz Abrams, the television anchor.
Although the museum is still in the planning stage, it has been laid out on paper by Ralph Appelbaum Associates, a design company that has left its imprint on the newly renovated Hayden Planetarium in Manhattan and the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington. A drawing shows a 10-story building whose floors,linked by ramps, overlook a multilevel visual display at the museum's center.
The new museum, known formally as the Museum of Women: The Leadership Center, would differ from existing collections around the state in that it would not focus on individuals, but would offer a comprehensive view of women's contributions to American history, said Lynn Rollins, former deputy director of the state's Division for Women, who is leading the efforts for the new museum.
Ms. Rollins said the exhibits would include photographs, artifacts and interactive displays that help tell the story of women in American history, from the pioneers and suffragists to recent immigrants. "We want every woman to walk through the museum and feel like they're part of their history," she said.
The exhibits will not be limited to things of interest only to New Yorkers, Ms. Rollins said, but would be planned in consultation with a national advisory board of historians. The building would also include conference rooms and an auditorium to provide training classes in leadership and business skills.
"So much of the seminal history of women took place in New York, and this is a tourist mecca," she said. "This is an opportunity to let people know what women in America have achieved."
Mr. Pataki's aides said they had approached Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Battery Park City Authority, a three-member state board appointed by the governor, about the project. It would require the approval of city and state officials and the authority.
"It sounds like a good idea, and we look forward to reviewing the plan," said Matthew Higgins, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani.
Timothy S. Carey, president of the Battery Park City Authority, said the arrangement would be similar to one that helped bring the Museum of Jewish Heritage there in 1997. If approved, the women's history museum would not have to pay rent or other fees on the property for 20 years, Mr. Carey said.
In recent years, a diverse coalition of advocacy groups, scholars and politicians around the country has sought to promote women's history. A 1997 campaign persuaded Congress to restore a marble statue depicting three suffragists -- Susan B. Anthony, Lucretia Mott and Elizabeth Cady Stanton -- to the Capitol Rotunda. The statue, which was commissioned by the National Woman's Party in 1921, had been kept in a downstairs corridor.
A former opera house in Dallas is being transformed with $25 million in public and private money into the Women's Museum: An Institute for the Future, which is expected to open in September. It will borrow artifacts from the Smithsonian and other museums to chronicle women's history from the 1500's to the present.
Plans are also under way for the National Museum of Women's History in Washington. And a host of educational programs and Internet sites have sprung up to inform women about their role in history.
"There's a need for women's history museums," said Galen Sherwin, president of the New York City chapter of the National Organization for Women, who supports the creation of another one in Manhattan. "The problem with the study of history is that its focus is on politics and economics, areas that, up until recently, mostly excluded women."
In New York, some of the earliest exhibits about women's history can be found in Seneca Falls, a village halfway between Syracuse and Rochester that was the hometown of Mrs. Stanton, the suffragist. She helped organize the first women's rights conference there in 1848, drawing nearly 300 people and setting off the American women's movement.
Today, these historic events are commemorated there by the Women's Rights National Historical Park, which is managed by the federal government, and the National Women's Hall of Fame, a private center that opened in 1969 to honor the achievements of individuals from Mrs. Stanton to Madeleine K. Albright.
The Hall of Fame, which has inducted 157 women so far, has rebounded in recent years after nearly closing in 1989 because of financial troubles. Mary Ann Oppenheimer, the executive director, said the center now takes in enough from ticket sales and donations to cover its $350,000 annual operating budget. Attendance has climbed steadily to 10,000 visitors last year.
"There's so much out there that could be told," said Ms. Oppenheimer, who praised the idea of a new women's history museum in Manhattan. "It's a very interesting idea, and I think there are lots of opportunities for organizations like ours to find ways to work together and achieve our mission."
Nancy Cott, a professor of history and women's studies at Yale University, said the new museum would give historians an opportunity to reach a broader audience. Other scholars and advocates said they would like to see exhibits on everything from the changing image of femininity in the 1990's to the role that women played in the Civil War.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Poughkeepskie Students Try to Shape City Policy

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA ROWE 

DATELINE: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 28

 BODY:
Within a few miles of this tough Hudson River city are two elite colleges, a renowned cooking school, a college with a nationally watched political polling center and two state undergraduate institutions. Yet the thousands of students at these campuses seldom venture past the gates to mingle with their city neighbors, who often struggle with poverty, homelessness and the city's faltering attempts at urban renewal.
But 27 students from the six schools -- Vassar, Bard, Marist, Dutchess County Community College, the State University of New York at New Paltz and the Culinary Institute of America -- are involved in an unusual cross-campus class that uses the city as a laboratory and whose findings the city, by legislative fiat, must examine. 
 Several evenings a week, Catherine Schloegel, a senior at Vassar who describes herself as a typical, "innocent-looking college kid," waits at the bus stop where homeless men pick up a shuttle to the county shelter. There, she and Terri-Ann Sweet, a student at Dutchess County Community, speak to as many men as will allow them an interview. The results of their work will be included in a report to the city on the realities and causes of Poughkeepsie's homelessness.
"The first night people were like, 'You're never going to understand what it's like to be homeless,' " Ms. Schloegel said.
Ms. Schloegel, of Boulder, Colo., hung on long enough to watch one of her subjects, a man who had been homeless for 17 years, find a job and a place to live. The experience has changed her so much that she plans to remain in Poughkeepsie after graduation and work in education.
Each year, the program, known as the Poughkeepsie Institute, tackles an issue important to Poughkeepsie, offering research and an academic perspective with the hopes of affecting government policy. Last year, the subjects were race and ethnicity. Previous classes have focused on mass transportation and welfare. Students from the Culinary Institute, whose schedule does not mesh with those of the other colleges, serve meals to the hungry.
While the Poughkeepsie Institute's impact has thus far been small, last year's class on race and ethnicity increased awareness of issues surrounding the surging Mexican population and was a factor in prodding the city's Common Council to hold an annual Cinco de Mayo festival for Hispanic immigrants.
Certainly, the issues could be explored through conventional lectures and books, but the real-life fieldwork, students and college officials say, has been invaluable. "The question for undergraduates is how do you connect theory and practice," said Leon Botstein, president of Bard College. When looking at these issues by working in the field, he said, students "leave the realm of cliched generalizations immediately."
While unusual in that it involves a group of colleges, the Poughkeepsie initiative is not unique. Colleges around the country have abandoned a fortress-like, town-gown isolation and are finding a variety of ways, from anthropological and sociological study to outright redevelopment, of building bridges to their host communities.
One reason is that the real-world problem-solving is valued by career-minded students; another is that campuses want to make their host cities as attractive as possible to prospective recruits. Harvard is building low-cost housing in Cambridge, the University of Pennsylvania has helped rebuild parts of West Philadelphia and the president of Connecticut College is chairwoman of New London's development authority.
Peter Leonard, chairman of the institute and a Vassar College faculty member, believes Poughkeepsie's comparatively small size (population: 29,000) makes it an ideal place for such an effort.
"It's small enough that you can become a player on any issue and big enough to have all the problems and all the promise of a major American city," he said.
In Poughkeepsie, the governing powers welcome the help. Both Mayor Colette Lafuente and the chairman of the city's Common Council, Thomas O'Neill, are institute board members. Mr. O'Neill said in his annual address that he hoped to use the students' information "as a cornerstone of any meaningful reform."
Natasha Thomas, 22, a biology major at Dutchess County Community College, spends much of her time videotaping interviews with homeless men and women and has learned just how simplistic her previous notions about homelessness were.
At the Living Room, a daytime center for the homeless run by the Mental Health Association of Dutchess County, Ms. Thomas leaned forward, her hand on her chin, as she asked Trudy Dillard, 35, about her trips in and out of prison, questioned Nancy Reyes, 32, about the children who were taken away from her, and asked 25-year-old Carmen McClaurin about a life of physical abuse and the time she spent in jail for stabbing her boyfriend in self-defense.
"How did you become homeless?" she asked, filming every minute. "Were you abused as a child? What would turn things around for you?"
The video will be presented to the city's Common Council at the end of the year.
"Your story touched me," she told Ms. McClaurin. "For so many women, this is the real issue, domestic abuse, and homelessness is just the end of a long cycle."
Ms. McClaurin, a tough-looking woman who can shut down communication instantly, nodded and then hugged her interviewer.
"They're learning about us as people, who are out there on the street," she said.
In many ways, the class, which is held in a community center in downtown Poughkeepsie, is structured in traditional fashion, with three hours of classes and required reading. Students work under a team of teachers representing each college and a variety of disciplines.
"It's just a different way of learning," Ms. Schloegel said. "I think a traditional classroom experience is valuable, but so is knowing where you live. In fact, I think it's more important to understand the lives of people around us."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The I.M.F.as 'a Crucial Cornerstone'

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 28

 BODY:
Laying out his vision of the future of the International Monetary Fund, Horst Kohler, the new managing director, said today that rather than shrinking as some critics have suggested, the fund should expand its role as "a crucial cornerstone" of globalization.
His remarks, in one of the first interviews he has given since his appointment this month, came amid a welter of conflicting proposals for overhauling the I.M.F., one of the world's important financial institutions, both in the United States Congress and the Clinton administration. 
 The thrust of some of those arguments, notably in a report from a Congressional commission led by Allan H. Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon University, was that both the I.M.F. and its sister institution, the World Bank, should be radically pared back because they often do more harm than good in developing countries.
Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers has opposed some of the commission's findings, and Mr. Kohler, a 57-year-old former high official in the German finance ministry, sought in the interview to avoid an impression that he and Mr. Summers were on a collision course.
"I do see a lot of commonality in the ideas expressed by Larry Summers," he said.
But in the 45-minute interview at his office at the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, where he will leave as president to join the I.M.F., Mr. Kohler made clear that his concept of reform would not limit the broad reach of I.M.F. influence that some critics want trimmed.
"My own vision is, in rather broad terms, that the I.M.F. should be even more than in the past a crucial cornerstone to secure growth and stability in the world, or in the global economy," he said.
"Whatever we do with crisis management, aid to the developing countries, the most important thing to achieve is sustained growth in the world economy, and that's not only in developed countries but really in the global economy including the developing countries and the emerging markets. That's my most important thing."
He acknowledged, however, that the huge capital flows that have come to be associated with globalization had implications both for the I.M.F.'s role as a lender and the relationship between its loans and those available on the international capital markets.
"I do think that after the experience with the crises in Russia and Asia," Mr. Kohler said, "the I.M.F. should be the center of excellence for the international financial markets for the international financial and monetary system."
To that end, he continued, the I.M.F. should "set up standards and codes for sound banking systems, sound behavior and, based on that, do more to prevent crisis."
But he made clear that this did not preclude a shift in the way the fund allocates its multibillion-dollar resources. "The I.M.F. also, of course, has to adapt to changes in the world economy," he said. And, reflecting the views of the Clinton administration, he said that in seeking to promote growth, "the biggest part should be done by the private capital markets."
"I do think that there's need to review the focus of the I.M.F.," Mr. Kohler said. "And reviewing the focus also means that we have to understand I.M.F. lending in principle as a temporary lending, and not as a permanent lending, which would substitute the possibilities of the private capital markets."
The German official is joining the I.M.F. after 18 months as head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, an institution established in the early 1990's to promote private investment and market economic values in the countries of the old Soviet bloc.
He took up that job within weeks of the Russian default in August 1998, and was obliged to write off a series of bad Russian debts. The experience has bred a degree of caution.
Mr. Kohler was one of the first Western officials to meet with Russia's president-elect, Vladimir V. Putin, as he gained prominence during the presidential election campaign that just ended.
While Mr. Kohler said today that the I.M.F. should "remain engaged in Russia," and while he praised Russia's "progress in terms of adjusting to a market economy," he also urged Mr. Putin to avoid his country's past mistakes.
"The lesson from some experience in the past," he said, "is that the I.M.F., like others, should judge Mr. Putin and the Russian government not just by their words but by their deeds. And I hope that President Putin will build up new confidence in demonstrating that he's able to take prior action before international support is coming in."
Many of the issues he addressed coincided with American emphases, such as the idea that the I.M.F. should be prepared for greater transparency in its dealings with "civil society."
Asked about demands from some developing countries for the cancellation of their debts, he said that any debt cancellation should only be part of a broader strategy for third world economic recovery.
He repeatedly emphasized that the I.M.F.'s lending should continue as a means of influencing the economic development of these countries, rather than concentrating simply on emergencies. Without lending to developing nations, he said, the I.M.F. would have little influence on economic policy.
Mr. Kohler was chosen for the top job at the I.M.F. after tortuous trans-Atlantic wrangling that soured relations between the Clinton administration and Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schroder. Mr. Schroder lobbied first for one German candidate, Caio Koch-Weser, who was vetoed by President Clinton, then swung his weight behind Mr. Kohler.
President Clinton's endorsement of Mr. Kohler was depicted in Washington as a reluctant move principally intended to avoid further strains with Germany. Some European officials supporting different candidates raised questions about Mr. Kohler's stature, despite his prominent role in designing the financial framework of German reunification and in setting up the European single currency.
But Mr. Kohler insisted that those circumstances would not undermine his authority as head of the I.M.F. "I think that the dust will settle after this rather heated debate," he said. "I'm quite confident that we'll do a good job."

HEADLINE: Confidence Of Consumers Weakened For 2d Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumers' confidence in the economy fell for the second consecutive month in March, and their expectations for later this year sank to a five-month low, a private survey showed yesterday.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell to 136.7 this month from 140.8 in February and the record of 144.7 in January. The index that measures consumer expectations for the next six months dropped to 106.2, the lowest level since October, amid higher oil and gasoline prices and volatile stocks. 
 That could signal the economy will slow in the coming months, something Federal Reserve policy makers are eager to see. The Fed has raised the federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks five times since last June, to 6 percent, the highest in five years, to keep inflation in check.
"Clearly consumers are aware of how strong economic growth is but are also aware that the Fed is working to change that," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
Consumers are "waiting to see if a further erosion in confidence triggers a slowdown in consumer spending," said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's consumer research center. "As for now, a moderate cutback in consumer spending is unlikely to stifle still-strong economic growth."
As the economy enters a record 10th year of expansion this week, confident consumers, an unemployment rate near a 30-year low and rising incomes have translated into increased spending on goods and services. That is a concern for Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and his colleagues, who have signaled interest rates will have to keep rising if demand exceeds the economy's ability to supply goods and services.
The Conference Board's latest survey showed the share of respondents who see jobs as plentiful rose to 52.7 percent, from 51.2 percent in February. The share seeing jobs as hard to get fell to 10.4 percent from 11.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Will Lissner, 91, Times Reporter Who Specialized in Economics

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Will Lissner, a reporter for The New York Times from 1926 until he retired in 1976, died on Saturday in a nursing home in Dunedin, Fla. He was 91 and lived in Clearwater, Fla.
For many years, Mr. Lissner specialized in writing about economics, but his varied assignments as a reporter and rewrite man included Prohibition raids, tong wars in Chinatown and coverage of The Times itself. In 1935, he contributed to The Times's coverage of the death of Adolph S. Ochs, who was then its publisher -- unbylined, as was the practice at that time. 
 In 1969, Mr. Lissner prepared a confidential 138-page report for Turner Catledge, who was then a vice president of The Times, entitled "Arthur Hays Sulzberger and the Eastland Investigation." James O. Eastland was a senator from Mississippi whose subcommittee in the 1950's was investigating, among other things, the extent of Communist infiltration and influence that he believed existed at The Times. Mr. Lissner's report, intended for the paper's archives and its senior executives, largely recapitulated the ways in which the paper and Mr. Sulzberger -- then the publisher, and grandfather of the present one -- had responded to Mr. Eastland. It was also an account of Communist Party activity in the newspaper business in New York from the 1930's to 1950's.
In 1980, Harrison E. Salisbury, a Pulitzer-Prize winning reporter and later an editor at The Times, cited Mr. Lissner's report in his book "Without Fear or Favor: The New York Times and Its Times." Mr. Salisbury wrote: "When I was sent as correspondent to Moscow in January 1949, as the McCarthy tensions were building up," The Times's management "took pains to make certain that the dispatches of the new man from Moscow were carefully scrutinized by a veteran Times reporter, Will Lissner, a dedicated anti-Communist and Soviet economics specialist. Lissner was able to report no signs of Communist bias in the new man's report; quite the reverse."
Mr. Lissner, a native New Yorker, graduated from Stuyvesant High School and studied and taught at the New School for Social Research. He founded the American Journal of Economics and Sociology in 1941 and continued his ties to it after leaving The Times.
His 1929 marriage to Ellen Batters ended in divorce in 1971.
He is survived by his wife, the former Dorothy Burnham; two daughters, Claire Shepherd of Milwaukee and Ellen Benjamin of Dover, Mass.; 9 grandchildren and 17 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Gain as Investors Shift Makeup of Portfolios

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices were mostly higher amid a drop in the main stock market gauges, which caused some investors to seek shelter in fixed-income securities.
The shift out of stocks came after Abby Joseph Cohen, the chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, recommended that her firm's clients reduce their allocation of stocks to 65 percent from 70 percent, with the 5 percent going into cash. She also recommended switching from a 5 percent allocation in long bonds to 5 percent in short-term Treasuries. 
 As a result, shorter-maturity paper led the market higher. The price of the two-year note rose 2/32 , to 9927/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, dropped to 6.58 percent from 6.62 percent on Monday. The 30-year bond lagged, gaining only 1/32 , to 10325/32 . Its yield was unchanged at 5.98 percent.
The 30-year bond also was held back by the fact that OPEC is having trouble agreeing on increases in oil production.
Treasuries took some strength from yesterday's consumer confidence data from the Conference Board; that index fell for the second consecutive month after reaching a record in January. The index that measures consumer expectations for the next six months also dropped, to its lowest level since October, after the most recent increase by the Federal Reserve in short-term interest rates, the fifth since June.
Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio, said, "Going into this confidence report, credit market investors painfully realized that the Fed is facing an economy that just doesn't seem to want to slow down despite the cumulative increase of 125 basis points in the federal funds rate."
"Therefore, in this environment, there is no doubt that many investors have begun questioning whether the Fed is falling behind in its fight against potential inflationary forces."
Although he disagrees with that assessment, Mr. Chan said, it cannot be fully erased from investors' minds. "As a result," he said, "the dip in the confidence, especially in the more important expectations component, had to offer great relief to those that have spent countless hours worrying about the growth pace last quarter and what they can expect to learn in the first quarter."
Mr. Chan said that Ms. Cohen's announcement was a breath of fresh air for the credit market, where most investors took the news as an indication that the bond market might face less competition from the equity market.
Investors in the longer maturities did not celebrate at first glance because they viewed her comments as being more beneficial to the shorter maturities. They did, however, embrace her statements as the day wore on.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., said all the markets were skittish, making hedging ineffective and forcing many investors to sit on positions longer because of the lack of liquidity.
Elsewhere, Treasury supply is back in force this week, and the market is not expected to have much trouble digesting everything. The government sold $35 billion in 21-day cash-management bills yesterday and will offer $30 billion in 19-day bills today along with $12 billion of two-year notes.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Opening the Oil Spigot

 BODY:
The decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase its oil production by 1.45 million barrels a day is welcome and may, over time, lead to lower American gasoline prices. The action, which Iran, an OPEC member, unexpectedly refused to take part in, restores just over a third of production cut by the cartel over the past two years. But it should not be seen as a definitive answer to the recent sharp rise in oil prices.
Those prices reached a peak of $34 a barrel in early March, more than three times what they had been a year earlier. But those 1999 prices were artificially depressed -- lower, once inflation is accounted for, than at any time since the 1970's. A rebound to more realistic levels was inevitable. 
 OPEC's power is not what it once was. Its 11 member countries now account for less than 40 percent of world oil production, down from more than 50 percent in 1974. Internal discipline is weak, with many countries cheating on their production quotas to earn extra revenue. Even before the OPEC meeting, prices had dropped by almost 20 percent, to about $28 a barrel. Raising production should bring further price declines.
Yesterday's OPEC decision came in response to strong American pressure. Aside from Iran, most other OPEC countries preferred not to risk being cast as villains in American political debate if oil prices remain high. Many of these countries also recognize that their own self-interest calls for moderation to protect the economies of major oil-consuming nations.
Washington had sought a larger production boost, of at least two million barrels a day. But the Vienna decision is constructive and will take significant pressure off world oil prices, which may now stabilize around $25 a barrel. Gasoline prices, which reflect low inventories as well as expensive oil, will probably stay high for a few more months. But their inflationary impact on the American economy is likely to be relatively small.
After the oil shocks of the 1970's and early 1980's, the United States and other industrial countries undertook significant energy conservation measures, like raising automobile fuel economy standards. They also intensified efforts to discover and exploit new energy sources, including non-OPEC oil. With oil prices as low as they have been in recent years, conservation measures have lagged and the search for new supplies has slowed. By reviving these efforts, America can gain some protection against future oil price increases.

HEADLINE: Waiting for Oil Costs' Other Shoe

BYLINE: ByRICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 28

 BODY:
Donald Patman, a Texas farmer, is paying 40 cents a gallon more this year to fuel his diesel combines and tractors, adding as much as $240 a day to his costs during cotton-picking season. Soon he expects increases in the costs of pesticides and fertilizers to dent his budget even more. Pass the increases on to his customers? Forget it.
Officials at the H. B. Fuller Company, the St. Paul-based adhesives maker that sells mainly to other businesses, however, see some relief where Mr. Patman does not: they are raising prices 5 percent or more on many of their products to offset raw materials costs that have grown mainly because of higher petroleum prices. 
 And while the Centex Corporation, the Dallas builder, has watched suppliers raise prices as much as 5 percent for some petroleum-derived products, including carpets, Centex is not feeling the pain. It has purchase contracts that locked in lower prices for 6 to 12 months. After that, however, if oil prices remain high, the contract prices will probably rise also.
Though surging fuel prices and rising costs for chemicals, plastics, resins and other products have driven up expenses for many businesses, not all industries or companies have been affected equally.
And those that have suffered have not, by and large, passed along the higher costs; in part because global competition and a relatively strong dollar have made it unwise to raise prices.
Even inflation hawks, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, have noted that consumers have generally been spared, outside of direct expenses for gasoline and home heating oil. On Monday, Mr. Greenspan told a Senate panel that, so far, there was no significant evidence that higher energy costs were "in the process of embedding themselves in other areas of the economy and inflating the general price structure." And that is unlikely to occur, he added, if oil stays around the mid-$20-a-barrel level.
Yesterday, a majority of the members of OPEC agreed to reverse production cuts they made last year. Oil prices fell sharply earlier in the day, to about $27 a barrel, as traders anticipated the cartel would raise output. Still, oil is nearly twice as expensive as a year ago.
Many businesses have been able to cut other costs or increase productivity to offset the higher materials prices. But many others are swallowing the difference, at least for now: higher prices have already contributed to earnings disappointments at several companies, including Fuller and Procter & Gamble.
Within industries, too, oil prices have hit companies in sharply different ways. It is no surprise, for example, that the rise in fuel prices has stung the airlines, so, many have raised their ticket prices by about $20.
Five of the larger United States air carriers are expected to report either losses or very small profits for the first quarter, in large part because of the rise in jet fuel prices.
But some airlines are hurting more than others: US Airways Group, which had no hedges in place at year-end to protect against high fuel costs, experienced a 52 percent spike in its average price for a gallon of fuel from a year earlier. That contributed to a fourth-quarter loss.
In contrast, Delta Air Lines stunned analysts in January by reporting earnings per share that were 12 cents higher than expected, largely because of fuel hedging. For the quarter that ended in December, Delta's average cost rose just 6 percent and the airline reported a gain of $99 million on fuel-hedging contracts. Delta has three-quarters of its fuel requirements hedged for the rest of this fiscal year, which ends June 30, and 55 percent for next fiscal year.
Another industry hard hit by rising oil costs is freight transportation. Federal Express and others have responded by tacking on fuel surcharges to their rates.
But even that tactic does not guarantee earnings' protection. At J. B. Hunt Transport Services, a big trucking firm based in Lowell, Ark., fourth-quarter earnings per share fell 14 cents below what they otherwise would have been, the company said, despite fuel surcharges it added to customers' bills.
According to the Fed's most recent "beige book" report on the economy, some truckers indicate they are hurt more than might be expected because competition from rail carriers hampers their ability to pass on higher costs. Various groups of truckers have protested in Washington.
The beige book also noted that in the Southwest, some refiners have been pinched because prices for oil, their raw material, have risen faster than prices they charge for the fuels they produce. And oil services concerns continue to be frustrated by the surprisingly tepid pace of new exploration and development, as producers use cash flow to pay down debt instead of increasing their efforts to find more oil.
The big issue, if petroleum prices stay high, is whether manufacturers can continue to hold back prices, said David M. Jones, chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, the New York bond dealer.
"Businesses are having extreme difficulty in this world of intense global competition making price increases stick, and it's pretty much across the board, so they have to suffer with higher costs," Mr. Jones said. Oil plays a far smaller role today in the overall economy than it did the last time prices soared, in the late 1970's. But if high prices persist, many businesses will face a profit squeeze or "will try once again to make prices stick" -- spurring a reaction from the Fed if they succeed and inflation looms.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan cautioned on Monday that crude oil "is still quite formidable." He added, "And there is no doubt in my mind that energy, which tends to cut across all aspects of this economy, if it gets sufficiently costly, could have materially negative effects."
Though that has not happened, many manufacturers are feeling squeezed. The National Association of Purchasing Management's price index rose again last month, to its highest reading in five years. That indicated that cost increases were still accelerating. Industries paying higher prices include clothing, electronic components and equipment, and rubber and plastic.
But manufacturers are mostly not charging more, because they feel they cannot.
Save for some notable exceptions, cost pressures have not torpedoed earnings yet. Edward M. Kerschner, PaineWebber's chief investment strategist, predicted on Monday that first-quarter earnings for companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index would rise 15 percent from the period a year earlier.
Still, several recent surveys have found that manufacturing executives expect higher energy and related raw materials costs to crimp profits later this year.
Even though oil prices began rising a year ago, the increases are only now beginning to work their way down to some companies.
Some costs may not be felt soon for yet other reasons. For example, while the Labor Department reported that prices for electric power rose only slightly in the last year, the prices that electric utilities pay for natural gas rose by almost one-third. Natural gas-fired plants are the largest source of generation at many utilities, but increases in their rates often take months to get through commission rate hearings.
Ernie Goss, an economics professor at Creighton University in Omaha, said his monthly survey of 1,100 companies in nine Midwestern states found that only in the last month have many manufacturers begun to feel rising petroleum prices. "There were an unusually high number of manufacturers reporting that oil prices were really squeezing them," he said. "It was odd. We didn't see these comments till February."
A Dun & Bradstreet survey found that manufacturing executives believe that over the next three months rising materials costs will force either slimmer profits or higher prices for finished goods. David Kresge, Dun & Bradstreet's chief economist, said manufacturers reported only recently that they hoped to raise prices to offset higher costs. "Whether they are able to do that in the face of competition remains an open issue," Mr. Kresge said.
Temporary price increases can be swallowed by manufacturers, said Richard Edwards, director of investor relations at H. B. Fuller, whose stock dropped almost 20 percent earlier this month when it disclosed that first-quarter profits were likely to fall short of expectations. But, he added, "there's only so much that suppliers and manufacturers can absorb."
Mr. Patman, who farms about 6,000 acres near Waxahachie, Tex., about 30 miles south of Dallas, says the higher fuel prices have helped change his view of the business.
"For years, as you made less net profit per acre, you leased more land to maintain a certain income," he said. "But now, bigger is not better -- you have too much at stake out there," because one bad year can wipe out a farmer's equity in his equipment.
It would be a lot better if farmers could pass on some of the higher costs, he said, but they do not have the power to do so. Between the higher prices and the drought across the South and in the Midwest, Mr. Patman said, "I'm sure a lot of producers won't be able to stay in business" after this year.
Higher petroleum costs will cut $3 billion, or about 6 percent, from farmers' net cash income this year, if oil prices average $28 a barrel, estimates Terry Francl, a senior economist at the American Farm Bureau Federation in Chicago. But that is only the half of it: once stockpiles of fertilizers and pesticides are depleted, replacements could cost $800 million more later this year, and $2 billion to $3 billion more next year, he said.
According to a model prepared by the Dallas branch of the Federal Reserve, it can take about nine months for the economy to feel a significant effect from higher oil prices, said Mine K. Yucel, head of the regional group of economists there.
But so far, competition has meant that businesses that cannot increase productivity or cut costs to offset higher prices "are suffering in terms of profits; they're eating it," Ms. Yucel said.

HEADLINE: No Relief at the Pumps Is Seen Until Fall

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 28

 BODY:
Regardless of how quickly oil-exporting nations can increase production, motorists in the United States may not get relief from high gasoline prices until this autumn at the earliest.
While the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries negotiated a new production agreement today, petroleum industry analysts said pump prices could remain at current levels for most of the summer, or even rise, because domestic supplies of gasoline and crude oil were severely depleted. 
 "What we're seeing now is inventories that look closer to what we'd expect after the summer driving season, rather than heading into it," said Jonathan Cogan, a spokesman for the United States Energy Information Administration, part of the Department of Energy.
As of mid-March, motor gasoline stocks were at 199.3 million barrels, compared with 221.6 million barrels at the same time last year, according to the agency. Similarly, crude-oil inventories had 292.6 million barrels at mid-March, compared with 330.9 million barrels last year.
It takes two months or so for Middle East oil to travel to the United States, be refined into gasoline, and make it to the gasoline pumps. But some analysts say an OPEC production increase might not have a noticeable effect on gasoline prices even after that time. Not only are domestic supplies already very low, but American consumers, feeling prosperous from the strong economy, are expected to take a lot of driving vacations this summer, regardless of the price. That will keep demand for fuel high.
"Almost any action taken now is an action that will have its greatest effect next fall or next winter," said Philip K. Verleger, a senior adviser to the Brattle Group, an economic consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Government forecasters have predicted that average retail gasoline prices could peak at $1.75 to $1.80 this summer. Prices could rise even more in some parts of the country, particularly California, which has requirements for cleaner-burning fuel.
Even with the run-up in gasoline prices, refiners have not been refining as much fuel as they can. The reason is that the price they have paid for crude oil, until recently, had risen faster than the prices for the refined products they sell, giving them less reason to produce more gasoline. In a report earlier this month, the International Energy Agency, which monitors petroleum consumption in developed countries, said this was an important reason why gasoline supplies in the United States were low.
On top of that, Mr. Verleger said, some lenders have grown more cautious with the credit lines that refiners use to buy crude oil because of the uncertainty over prices -- another reason why refiners have not been increasing production.
Mr. Verleger said any major refinery disruptions this summer -- including fires, maintenance and damage from Gulf Coast hurricanes -- could help drive up prices more.
"The direction of gas prices this summer will be determined primarily by the success of the refining industry," he said.
Political pressure has been building to release oil from the United States' Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Were that to happen, it could have a quicker impact on gasoline prices, he added, because it would take only a few weeks for that oil, which is in Louisiana and Texas, to flow to the market.
