HEADLINE: Foundation Giving Is at $23 Billion High

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Flush with ballooning endowments and new money from wealthy individuals and corporations, the nation's foundations set a record by giving away an estimated $22.8 billion in grants in 1999, according to a study to be released today.
Forced by law to give away larger and larger sums, many foundations are increasing the size of their donations, sometimes giving away tens of millions of dollars to a single charity. With greater resources, many are financing sweeping, ambitious programs in areas like education and health care rather than making what were often scattered and short-term grants in those fields. 
 Giving by every type of foundation has increased, according to the Foundation Center, the New York group that tracks foundation giving and conducted the study. The $22.8 billion in grants to nonprofit groups in 1999 compares with $19.5 billion in 1998. A decade ago, foundation giving was $8.7 billion.
"The increase in assets provides an incredible opportunity for the whole field," said Sara Engelhardt, president of the Foundation Center. The largest foundations may be able to accomplish goals on a scale not seen since the Carnegies and Rockefellers created their foundations earlier in the last century, she said.
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, for example, is tackling disease in developing countries by providing $750 million over five years to vaccinate children. "Scale is helpful when you can cause a bigger system change," said Patty Stonesifer, the co-chairwoman and president of the Gates Foundation, which is expected to give away about $1 billion in grants this year.
The foundation is also able to take a long view, supporting projects for as long as 20 years, in the case of its $1 billion scholarship program. By making a long-term commitment, the foundation can relieve the burden of many nonprofit groups, which "are always scrambling for resources," said Ms. Stonesifer.
Over all, the number of grants of $5 million or more is climbing sharply, according to a sample taken by the Foundation Center. While the number of such grants was under 50 for much of the early 1990's, it reached 147 in 1998.
The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, among the largest in the nation, spent $50 million over the last two years toward the purchase of 271,000 acres in California -- the rough equivalent of all of Los Angeles -- as part of its conservation efforts. The foundation hopes to preserve another 500,000 acres in the next few years.
Even much smaller community foundations are benefiting from a significant increase in resources, the result of the surging stock market and the largess of individual donors. "Every foundation that has invested in the equity market has had 10 years of galloping growth, especially in recent years," said Jack Shakely, president of the California Community Foundation, which has $525 million in assets.
The foundation, based in Los Angeles, now finances projects over several years instead of committing a single year at a time. Excited about the prospect of a new project to give books to children as a way to encourage reading, for example, the foundation was able to pledge $1.5 million over three years.
In Ohio, foundations including the Cleveland Foundation, whose assets have climbed by more than 50 percent over the last five years, have committed $10 million toward a $40 million initiative by Cuyahoga County to provide health care and child care for very young children.
Much of the rise in giving nationwide is a result of the soaring value of foundation endowments, which reached $385 billion at the end of 1998, the latest figure available, according to the center. By law, most foundations are required to give away at least 5 percent of their assets each year or run afoul of the Internal Revenue Service.
But large donations to foundations and the formation of new foundations are also fueling the increase, according to the center. The number of foundations has more than doubled since 1980 to nearly 47,000, and newly active foundations were responsible for one-fifth of the rise in foundation giving from 1997 to 1998.
Corporate foundations increased the amount they made in grants by a record 22 percent to an estimated $3 billion last year, according to the center. Many of them are also making larger gifts. The Bank of America Foundation, for example, is giving $50 million over five years to United Way of America to help children learn to read and get vaccinations.
"We don't want the margarine approach," said Caroline Boitano, executive director for the Bank of America Foundation, referring to giving that is spread out thinly among numerous causes.
The surge in the amount of money available for giving causes some concerns for foundations. The Packard foundation, for example, gave away about $400 million in grants in 1999, more than double the amount it gave away just two years ago. "It is a challenge for any organization to go through the kind of growth we have," acknowledged Richard Schlosberg III, president of the foundation, which increased its staff last year by about 25 percent to 150 people and expects a similar increase this year.
The Lilly Endowment also saw its giving climb steeply, by about two- thirds from the previous year to $425 million in 1998. The foundation now routinely gives away amounts like $50 million to the Hispanic Scholarship Fund and $30 million to the American Indian College Fund, compared with five years ago when its largest grant was about $6 million. Lilly has also significantly increased its giving to community foundations in Indiana, where it is based.
The tendency to give larger grants, often to large charities with national agendas, gives some cause for concern. "It can be counter to what people see as strategic grant making," said Ms. Engelhardt of the Foundation Center. Foundations may "look for more of the sure bets," established charities, rather than fostering experiments or creativity by financing small nonprofit organizations.
The rise in assets has also caused some individuals to call on foundations to give away more than the minimum required by law. The California Community Foundation, for example, gives away what it calls a "community dividend" with some of the money its investments have generated in recent years.
"I think foundations have a responsibility to get that money out and get it percolated," Mr. Shakely said.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Slouching Toward '92

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In a droll speech to a ballroom full of journalists and pols at the Gridiron dinner last Saturday night, Al Gore confided his "secret" plan for winning the White House.
He would associate himself with the good stuff that has happened during the last eight years and disassociate himself from the bad stuff. 
 "A low unemployment rate and a sound economy? Clinton-Gore," he said. "Grand jury testimony? Clinton . . . Impeachment? Not me."
The vice president was mocking his own image as an opportunist. He was also ribbing his Republican rival, whose campaign is based on the assumption that everyone is fed up with "the Clinton-Gore era."
But America is bursting with contentment. Our only worry is a new malady that The L.A. Times calls "sudden wealth syndrome," the ennui that comes from making too many millions too fast.
People scorned Bill Clinton's morals. But they love his economy, and the way he tackles hard things, like the Middle East, Ireland and guns.
If W. keeps banking on disgust with Clinton-Gore to propel him to the White House, he'll lose.
"It won't work to connect Gore to Clinton," a Gore adviser says. "It didn't even work to connect Clinton to Clinton."
The Republicans tried to run against Bill Clinton's character in '92, '96 and '98. It didn't work.
So it is truly remarkable that W. is repeating the willful mistakes of '92, given that the loss was so searing.
The father thought: I can't lose to a low-class hick from Arkansas. Now the son thinks: I can't lose to a cutthroat phony who did stinky things with a low class-hick from Arkansas.
The contempt of the Bushes blinds them to the need to fight harder, fight sooner and fight smarter.
After he soared to 90 percent with his victory in the Persian Gulf, the father coasted, failing to capitalize with any grand domestic plans.
W. coasts also, on his first national run (compared with four for Mr. Gore). He does not go on the offensive or offer much substance. He does not communicate in any interesting way, or outline core principles. He merely waits for the public to realize he is the better man. His campaign is like the Cheshire cat, fading to a smirk.
He parrots sound bites about reform, but he doesn't have the foggiest notion of why John McCain evoked such excitement. The governor finally deigned to call the senator yesterday, after prodding by Bob Dole.
Asked by The Times about the McCain phenomenon, Mr. Bush replied curtly: "Well, then how come he didn't win?"
As Lars-Erik Nelson wrote, it was an eerie echo of the comeback favored by Bush senior when he rejected advice in '92: "If you're so smart, why aren't you president?"
W. appealed to Republicans because he was a baby boomer, but he keeps Reagan hours. You picture Al up all night plotting. (You know Karenna has already chosen the convention theme song.) You picture W. hugging his pillow and belittling his rivals for being too hungry. But voters like to see a little gumption.
W. thinks the vice president will come off as duplicitous for pouncing on campaign finance reform. He thinks the words "Buddhist temple" will end any argument. But the Republican can't play the purist. Voters know he shot the moon on campaign money, too. And Americans believe in redemption. A real crack at a campaign finance plan from Gore the reformed sinner is still better than W.'s empty-shell proposal.
His insular Austin team keeps trying to graft a campaign onto a brand name. Realizing how hard it is to get Bush the Younger intellectually engaged, his advisers have reshaped his campaign to be about the one subject -- besides baseball -- in which he seems fluent: education. But his big speech yesterday, reviving his mother's pet issue, literacy, does not a vision-thing make.
Like his father's, W.'s basic message is: Trust me -- I've been bred for this job. Like Bill Bradley, W. is counting on Mr. Gore's smarmy, Eddie Haskell personality to rub people the wrong way.
But W. is expecting Americans to get riled up about what they already know. He might take a page from Bill Clinton: Elections are always about the future, not the past.

HEADLINE: Restaurant and Bar Workers Who Get Tips May Also Get Lesser Increase in Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 28

 BODY:
On Friday, the minimum wage will rise for New York's lowest-paid workers, but lawmakers plan to prevent the absolute lowest wage earners, restaurant and bar employees who earn tips, from collecting the entire increase.
Under a combination of federal and state laws, restaurants and bars in New York can pay their workers as little as $2.90 an hour if they also earn tips, a wage that has not changed in nine years. On Friday, the minimum for some groups of workers will rise to $5.15 an hour from $4.25, and the minimum for those who make tips is slated to increase to $3.52 from $2.90. 
 But the Democrats who control the Assembly, including Speaker Sheldon Silver, want to set a new minimum for restaurant and bar workers who earn tips at $3.30, not $3.52. Until last week, they proposed freezing the wage at $2.90.
The Assembly is expected to pass the bill Wednesday or Thursday, said Patricia Lynch, spokeswoman for Mr. Silver. The speaker's office declined to discuss the rationale for the bill. The Republican-controlled State Senate has approved a bill freezing the minimum for tipped workers at $2.90. Michael McKeon, spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, said that the governor supports the idea of setting the wage below $3.52, but that he objects to some technical provisions of the Assembly bill.
The debate pits some of the Democrats' traditional constituencies, low-wage workers and unions, against powerful small-business lobbying groups. It also strikes a dissonant note at a time when the economic talk is of stock options, dot-coms and full employment -- a reminder that in the service economy, low wages persist even in rosy times.
"I make $200, $250 a week, with tips," said Fernando, a Colombian immigrant who buses tables in a downtown Manhattan restaurant, and asked that his surname not be used for fear he would lose his job. "I have a wife and two children. It's not enough."
Ed Donnelly, legislative director of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "To take the lowest-paid worker, a waitress in a greasy spoon, and convene the best minds in the Capitol to rob her of a quarter, to me is immoral."
But restaurant owners insist that workers have done well in the booming economy. "We don't think those people need a statutorily authorized 62-cent-an-hour increase in pay," said Scott Wexler, executive director of the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association, which represents 5,000 small businesses. "For our average member, that would cost $15,000 a year."
He said that among his group's members, employees who are paid $2.90 an hour actually earn, on average, $10 an hour with tips. But a 1997 survey by the State Department of Labor found that the average income for waiters and waitresses was $6.34 an hour, with tips.
The "tipped wage" varies enormously from state to state, and New York's ranks 17th. The highest minimum is $6.50 in Washington State, which does not differentiate between tip earners and others. The low is $2.13, in several states, including New Jersey. Connecticut's is $4.73.
Federal law sets the minimum wage for most workers at $5.15, but it allows states to set lower minimums for a few categories of workers. (A handful of states actually have higher minimums than the federal standard.) New York's minimum wage has stood at $4.25 an hour since 1991.
In December, state lawmakers raised the minimum to $5.15 from $4.25, effective March 31. Under a 1991 ruling by the State Department of Labor, that would automatically raise the wage for workers who make tips, by the same percentage, to $3.52 from $2.90. The current bills would overturn that rule.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Pursuing Happiness

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
The big winner at the Oscars was "American Beauty," a film based on the daring and original premise that material possessions don't bring happiness. Oh, well. Anyway, not all trite ideas are wrong. In fact, there is quite a lot of evidence indicating that, sure enough, money doesn't buy happiness -- or at least not so you'd notice.
At this point I could cite the accumulated wisdom of the ages -- but hey, it's the modern world, so let's talk about the polls. Since World War II, random samples of people in the United States and elsewhere have repeatedly been asked how happy they are. When the economic historian Richard Easterlin surveyed these surveys in a classic 1974 paper, he formulated what has come to be known as the "Easterlin paradox": Basically, above a very low level economic growth does not seem to improve human welfare. Later evidence confirms his observation. Americans were no more likely to describe themselves as happy in the 1990's than they had been in the 1940's. Even the Japanese, who went from near-third-world conditions to widespread affluence between the 1950's and the 1980's, did not become happier. 
 Mr. Easterlin argued that the reason economic growth doesn't make us happier is that people judge themselves largely by their position relative to other people. Someone with an income of $32,000 in a society where the median is $40,000 feels as socially disadvantaged as someone with an income of $8,000 in a society where the median is $10,000; so even quadrupling people's real income may not make much difference in how they feel. Other evidence suggests that even relative income makes less difference than most of us imagine: the rich are happier than you and I, but not very much so.
In a recent paper David Blanchflower and Andrew Oswald estimated "happiness equations" from American and British survey data. They found that when you carefully control for other things, more money actually does make people a bit happier -- but its influence is swamped by non-pecuniary factors. Being married is far more important than being rich; having a job is much more important than how much the job pays.
So what are the implications? Anti-growth types tend to like the Easterlin paradox; they see it as yet another reason to favor the simple, ecologically sound life. Milder sorts like Robert Frank, author of the book "Luxury Fever," argue that if people care about their relative position -- as they clearly do -- then conspicuous consumption is not just in bad taste but a sort of psychological pollution, as real in its adverse impact as acid rain. The answer? A highly progressive tax system, which Mr. Frank supports for the same reason The Wall Street Journal opposes it -- that it reduces the incentive to make more money.
But before you denounce (or applaud) happiness research as leftist propaganda, be aware that it also cuts the other way. For example, how do you feel about the "living wage" movement, which in effect wants a large increase in the minimum wage? That would certainly increase the incomes of the lowest-paid workers; but it would also surely have at least some adverse effect on the number of jobs available. You may think that a price worth paying -- but the equations say that the extra unemployment would be a very bad thing for those who lose their jobs, while a higher wage would make only a small difference to the happiness of those who remain employed.
Or think of it this way. If you don't want a society in which everyone is desperately trying to get ahead in a zero-sum status game, you might advocate government policies that slow down the rat race: high tax rates, generous health and unemployment benefits, long mandatory paid vacations, maybe even a limit on individual working hours. In other words, you might want to turn America into France. But France has an unemployment rate more than twice as high as America's, largely because of those same government policies. And unemployment -- even comfortable European-style unemployment -- makes people very unhappy, because it is demoralizing.
Is there any way out of the dilemma? Well, East Germany had full employment without a rat race -- but it fell a bit short in the life and liberty departments. I'd say that given the alternatives, the American system, though not beautiful, still takes the prize.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
Citing a Crisis, Bush Proposes Literacy Effort

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: MANVILLE, N.J., March 28

 BODY:
Once again mooring a traditionally Democratic issue to the agenda of his Republican presidential campaign, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today proposed a five-year, $5 billion program to address what he termed a national literacy crisis among children.
Mr. Bush said the program would provide grants to states to test reading in kindergarten and first grade, to make tutoring available to poor readers and to train teachers. He soberly contrasted the nation's economic success with its educational failings, and declared that he would bring the same improvements in reading on the national level that he said he had achieved in Texas. 
 He said every child should know how to read by third grade, and vowed that states that failed to improve student performance would lose federal aid.
"There is nothing more fundamental than teaching our children how to read," Mr. Bush said in a speech this afternoon in Reston, Va., the first in a series of events this week intended to spotlight his commitment to improving education.
"America must confront a national emergency," he said. "Too many of our children cannot read. In the highest-poverty schools -- I want you to hear this statistic -- in the highest-poverty schools in America, 68 percent of fourth graders could not read at a basic level in 1998."
Aides to Mr. Bush said his plan would help roughly 900,000 children with poor reading skills, at a cost of $1,000 per child per year for tutoring and other assistance. Besides that $900 million, an additional $100 million a year would go to testing and teacher training.
The Bush plan was quickly dismissed by aides to the apparent Democratic presidential nominee, Vice President Al Gore. They sought to shift attention to Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal, saying it would leave no money for new education initiatives.
Since the fall, Mr. Bush has introduced a variety of education proposals, but none of the others would entail spending anywhere close to the $5 billion he spoke of today. That sum in turn is dwarfed by the $115 billion that Mr. Gore would spend for new education initiatives over 10 years, and the disparity in the size of the two candidates' approaches highlights the challenge facing Mr. Bush: convincing voters that he can lead the nation to new educational excellence without spending huge new sums, which would clash with his broader fiscal policies.
Mr. Bush introduced his plan as his party continued to close ranks around him. Tonight Steve Forbes, who had attacked the governor as insufficiently conservative before withdrawing from his own race for the Republican nomination, endorsed the governor here at a meeting of the Somerset County Republican Party.
"As the American people are learning, and will learn," Mr. Forbes said at the meeting, in his home state, "he is a good man. He has been tested -- I tried to test him -- and he emerged the stronger for it."
Mr. Bush's chief rival during the primary season, Senator John McCain of Arizona, has resisted endorsing him, but Mr. Bush called Mr. McCain today in an apparent effort to salve some of the lingering wounds. Mr. Bush said he hoped that the two would meet soon, and described the conversation as amiable.
"John and I both understand that the past is the past and it's time to move forward," Mr. Bush told reporters aboard his campaign plane.
Mr. Bush's speech in Virginia offered striking evidence of a return to his original campaign strategy -- positioning himself as a soft-edged, centrist Republican -- after he veered to the right in the primaries to fend off Mr. McCain.
In that talk today, to a coalition of Asian-American groups at the headquarters of the Student Loan Marketing Association, the federally sponsored provider of student loans, he proclaimed that the federal government had to redouble its efforts to confront the educational plight of poor people.
"We will not tolerate illiteracy amongst the disadvantaged students in the great country called America," he said. "I know this is something a little new. Others have proposed throwing money at the problem. But they have proposed resources without reform. That approach has no history of results, and really no prospect of success. Under my plan, new resources will be an instrument of reform, not another investment in failure."
In echo of language once used by the Kerner Commission to describe the country's racial chasm, Mr. Bush said: "More and more we are divided into two nations: one that reads and one that can't, and therefore one that dreams and one that doesn't. Reading is the basis for all learning, and it must be the foundation for all other education reforms."
Still, Mr. Bush is not abandoning his belief that the federal government should not meddle in what, he says, is rightly a state and local issue. This evening, at a fund-raiser in Parsippany, N.J., with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, he declared, as he often did during the primaries, that he did not want to be the "federal superintendent of schools."
"You are looking at the wrong man if you want me to be the national principal," he said. "I believe in local control of schools. The best education policy is that which bubbles up from the bottom."
Indeed, Mr. Bush has shaped his education proposals as a whole around the notion that the states should have more leeway in spending federal dollars, as well as the idea that schools must be held more accountable for their performance. He would encourage the creation of charter schools and has also proposed a voucher program for students of poorly performing public schools. He has urged too that Head Start, the early-childhood development program, be primarily a literacy program.
In his speech in Virginia, Mr. Bush's tone was largely conciliatory; he barely mentioned Mr. Gore.
But the Gore campaign showed no such reticence. Douglas Hattaway, a campaign spokesman, said that the governor's plan would be ineffective and that given his tax cut, "he won't have the money to pay for a new initiative like this without dipping into the Social Security surplus or going back to deficit spending."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George W. Bush addressed the Somerset County Republican Party in Manville, N.J., last night after winning the endorsement of Steve Forbes, right, and cheers from Mr. Forbes's wife, Sabina. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)(pg. A20)
 
SIDE BY SIDE
Comparing Two Plans for Education
 
Since the fall, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore have made several proposals on education.
 
Mr. Bush would:
nProvide students in low-performing schools that fail to improve after three years $1,500 a year for use at a parochial or other private school or for tutoring. Money would be drawn from the Title I program, for schools in poor districts.
nRequire students in Grades 3 through 8 to be tested in reading and math, with states and districts drawing up tests. States would have to publish report cards with annual test results.
nSpend nearly $1 billion a year for five years to diagnose reading problems in kindergartners and first graders and enable districts to create programs to elevate literacy.
nMake the Head Start early-childhood development program primarily a literacy program.
nMake available $3 billion of loan guarantees to help establish or improve 2,000 charter schools.
nRaise the annual contributions parents can make to education savings accounts to $5,000 from $500 per student.
 
Mr. Gore would:
nOppose school vouchers.
nSpend $115 billion over 10 years, $50 billion of it to make pre-school available to all 4-year-olds and many 3-year-olds by 2004.
nHelp families pay for college by making up to $10,000 of tuition and fees tax deductible, providing up to $2,800 a year in tax relief for each family.
nUse $25 billion in bonds to pay for new school construction and modernization.
nSupport a national teacher corps that would provide college aid or "signing bonuses" to 75,000 people who agree to teach in schools in inner cities or rural areas.
nProvide aid to schools that come up with their own plans to reduce class size or to reduce the size of schools.
nIncrease salaries for teachers in districts that adopt aggressive plans to increase the quality of teachers and that also get rid of low-performing teachers.(pg. A20)

HEADLINE: Agency Votes To Accept Bid For 2 A-Plants

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Capping an unlikely bidding war, the New York Power Authority voted yesterday to sell its two nuclear plants to a Mississippi company for $967 million in what would be by far the largest sale of nuclear reactors in United States history.
The winning bid by Entergy Nuclear, of Jackson, Miss., for the Indian Point 3 plant in Buchanan, in Westchester County, and the James A. FitzPatrick plant in Oswego County, broke ground in myriad ways. It was the largest sale of a public asset in New York State history. It was the first transaction involving the privatization of a publicly run nuclear plant in the country. And the $967 million price tag was at least four times as much as any previous sale of a nuclear plant, based on dollars per generating capacity. 
 It may have been the ultimate sign of the resuscitation of an industry once thought to be too moribund, costly and unsafe to continue operating that the sale yesterday occurred on the 21st anniversary of the industry's darkest moment in the United States: the Three Mile Island partial core meltdown in Pennsylvania.
Entergy's offer topped an unsolicited, last-minute offer from Dominion Resources of Richmond, Va., valued at $946 million. Both offers are at levels far below what was invested to build the plants. In that sense, the offers reflected the depths to which nuclear power had fallen as well as its improved safety record since Three Mile Island and the improved prospects for keeping aging nuclear plants in operation.
But the fact that there were two major companies dueling for two plants with spotty records illuminated how utility deregulation and rock-bottom prices helped provide a market for plants that in the past might not have found a buyer.
"There was no market a year and a half ago," said Clarence D. Rappleyea, the chairman and chief executive of the power authority, at a signing ceremony after the trustees' meeting in Manhattan.
But like any enormous transaction involving real estate -- much less one with thousands of employees -- this one is fraught with potential pitfalls. So how the transfer of ownership, expected to take six months, plays out may affect the structuring of deals for plants like the two Millstone reactors for sale in Waterford, Conn., and Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 plant in Buchanan, next to Indian Point 3.
"This is unique," Mr. Rappleyea said. "This is not anything that there's a road map to. I guess we're cutting new trail here."
For the power authority, the proposed sale, which is still subject to approval from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, would free resources to pay the remaining debt of $316 million on Indian Point 3, and to focus more on economic development and energy efficiency, Mr. Rappleyea said.
Eventually, Mr. Rappleyea predicted, there will be a "distinct possibility" that the sale will result in lower electric bills.
For Entergy, a subsidiary of Entergy Corporation in New Orleans, the sale would put it in a commanding position to dominate the nuclear power industry in New York State. The company is already bidding to operate two other upstate plants, the Nine Mile Point reactors, which are adjacent to the Fitzpatrick plant in Scriba, on Lake Ontario.
And yesterday, Entergy offered its bluntest statement about its interest in the troubled Indian Point 2 plant, which had a radiation leak last month at its Hudson River site, about 35 miles north of New York City.
"We would very much like to buy that plant and put these two plants with some synergies, pull them back together, and operate them the way they were originally designed to operate, as a single entity," said Jerry W. Yelverton, the chief executive of Entergy Nuclear, referring to Indian Point 2 and 3. (Indian Point 1 closed in 1974.)
Some watchdogs of nuclear power, though, were ambivalent about the sale. For months, many legislators, environmentalists and professors criticized the bidding process as being less than competitive and open, since Entergy was the preferred choice all along. And yesterday, some said that while the $967 million figure sounded impressive, it was almost $200 million more than Entergy's original bid -- and stoked speculation as to what a thoroughly open process might have produced.
"We would've been better off putting this on eBay in the beginning, and letting the market drive the price," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Committee on Environmental Conservation.
Mr. Brodsky also questioned why the five trustees, all Republicans, did not delay their decision another month or so to consider the deal's financial ramifications. But Mr. Rappleyea said that the longer the board waited, the less likely it would be able to close the deal before a scheduled refueling at the FitzPatrick plant this fall -- a possible $30 million expense.
Under the deal, Entergy would pay $636 million for the plants, $171 for nuclear fuel stockpiles, $92 million for eventual decommissioning expenses and $68 million in return for the power authority's commitment to buy more electricity in the future.
Entergy would also guarantee employment, and no contractual changes, for the 1,700 workers -- almost half of whom are unionized -- at the two plants and the power authority's office in White Plains.
The power authority is expected to pay most of the costs of the eventual decommissioning, and has been building a fund, now valued at $630 million, in anticipation of those obligations. By 2015, when the licenses of both plants are to expire, that fund is expected to be worth $1.9 billion -- more than enough to cover the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's projection of $1.18 billion to decommission the plants.
But if that fund were subject to taxes because the public power authority sold its plants to a private entity, or if that fund were counted as taxable income for the new owner, then taxes would sap that $1.9 billion. And while that possibility is highly unlikely, the possible exposure to as much as $250 million in tax liability proved to be a crucial turning point in favor of Entergy, because Entergy had said it would assume that liability, while Dominion had not.
Yesterday, the board was careful to praise both bids as tremendous. But Dominion, clearly, felt that it had not gotten a fair shot.
"We are disappointed that N.Y.P.A. presented us with a complex tax issue at the 11th hour of its meeting on March 20 and gave us only eight days to resolve it," Thomas E. Capps, Dominion's president and chief executive, said in a statement.

HEADLINE: WITH IRAN BALKING, OPEC NATIONS PLAN TO SELL MORE OIL

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Wednesday, March 29

 BODY:
After two days of disputes, OPEC decided today to increase oil production without the participation of its second-largest producer, Iran. But the increase was not what the United States had pressed for, and was not expected to bring down gasoline prices any time soon.
In a rare break in the solidarity of its ranks, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced that nine of its members would raise production by a total of 1.45 million barrels a day, despite bitter opposition from Iran to any increase. The higher production would begin next month. 
 With Iran, the total would have been about 1.7 million barrels, but analysts said the actual increase would end up significantly higher because other OPEC members were likely to seize the opportunity to cheat on their quotas to fill the gap left by Iran.
The United States had pressed for increases of up to 2.5 million barrels a day to reduce gasoline prices, which have soared to more than $1.60 a gallon in most cities. Iran's irritation at the American pressures was apparently one reason behind its opposition to any increase.
Experts estimated that it would take at least six to eight weeks before any additional oil production found its way to the gasoline pumps, and with inventories already unusually low in the United States as the summer driving season approaches, gasoline prices are not expected to decline soon. In fact, some analysts predicted, they would rise still more before easing by fall. Page A10.
"Anybody who expects to get back to gasoline at $1 or $1.20 a gallon will be seriously disappointed," said Raad Alkadiri, an analyst at Petroleum Finance Company, an industry research firm based in Washington. "Whatever happens, you're going to have a tight gasoline market this summer."
The agreement to increase daily production quotas by 1.45 million barrels is somewhat misleading. OPEC countries are already exceeding their production limits by about one million barrels a day and much of that output will simply be absorbed within the higher limits.
The Clinton administration, however, was optimistic about the effects of the increase and said that several other oil-producing nations that do not belong to OPEC would also increase output. "I think our quiet diplomacy worked," said Bill Richardson, the energy secretary, at a White House briefing on Tuesday evening.
Mr. Richardson said that when all sources of production were taken into account, "we will be well above our objective." He and other officials pointed out that prices were already down, to about $27 a barrel from a high of $34 a barrel, in anticipation of more production.
In New York trading on Tuesday, crude oil for May delivery fell 70 cents, to $27.09 a barrel.
The unusual break in OPEC ranks came after two days of wrangling between Iran and Saudi Arabia, the largest producer, which pushed for an increase in production. In the end, OPEC announced that 9 of its 11 members would go ahead and increase their quotas. The production of Iraq, which says it now produces 2.4 million barrels a day, has been separately governed by United Nations resolutions since the 1991 Persian Gulf war. Iraq said tonight that it planned to significantly increase its production by the end of the year, but experts were skeptical.
The fissure with Iran has major implications for the United States. Indeed, the battle within OPEC was as much political as economic, and much of the debate was over whether the group would be capitulating to pressure from the United States for lower oil prices.
It was OPEC's decision to cut production last year, joined by several non-OPEC nations like Mexico and Norway, that sent oil and gasoline prices soaring.
Today's split could damage OPEC's discipline and credibility, just as the organization seemed to have regained some of the power it had in the 1970's and early 1980's.
Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zangeneh, accused the other OPEC countries of trying to ram through decisions that were not justified by economic conditions. "OPEC is not an organization to rubber-stamp the decisions already made," Mr. Zangeneh said in a short but biting statement about 1 a.m. today.
"We tried to show our flexibility," he continued. "OPEC needs a spirit of compromise, which unfortunately we didn't trace at this time."
If OPEC's discipline does come unhinged, the United States could be a major beneficiary and see its bill for imported oil drop. In the past, when OPEC failed to agree on production limits, prices have plummeted as production soared.
"OPEC had a commendable record in the past year, and now one of its founding members is not taking part in their agreement," said Gary N. Ross, chief executive of PIRA Energy Group, an oil industry research firm based in Manhattan.
Today's split comes after a bitter test of wills between Iran and Saudi Arabia, which was determined to reverse the production cuts of last year and allow the price of oil to settle at about $25 a barrel, compared with about $27.50 today and its recent high of $34 in early March.
Saudi officials wanted to raise production, partly because the United States is its biggest market and partly because of concern about political wrath from Congress, where some lawmakers have pushed for legislation to block aid and sales of military equipment to OPEC nations.
Iranian leaders, on the other hand, had angrily denounced American and Saudi demands and insisted that OPEC should not make decisions in response to political pressure.
Oil experts and Saudi leaders argued here that Iran was already producing virtually all the oil it could pump, about 3 million barrels a day, and any increase in production would come from other countries -- Saudi Arabia in particular -- leading to lower prices that could only hurt Iran.
Saudi Arabia, with a daily output of 7.6 million barrels, has enough spare capacity to flood world markets in a matter of weeks.
The Clinton administration has been lobbying OPEC leaders intensively for the last several weeks, arguing that the world markets needed more oil to meet demand and to restore depleted inventories.
It has been clear that OPEC would not go as far as the United States desired, but Saudi Arabia had managed to persuade all other members except Iran to reverse the cuts they had imposed on themselves last year.
The Saudis have made it clear that they want the price of oil to settle near $25 a barrel, a price they say could be sustained and would allow the United States and other major oil-consuming countries to rebuild badly depleted inventories.
Even with the agreement this morning, many OPEC leaders were still fuming about what they viewed as heavy-handed pressure from Washington that only made their own political situation more awkward.
Venezuelan leaders, taking a cue from their outspoken president, Hugo Chavez, have been particularly sensitive about being portrayed as puppets of the American government, and went out of their way last week to criticize lobbying efforts by Mr. Richardson, the energy secretary. Venezuela is one of the top suppliers of crude oil to the United States.
On Monday, Iranian officials almost gleefully pounced on the issue of American pressure when Mr. Richardson reportedly called the oil minister of Qatar, another OPEC member, just as he was meeting with his counterparts.
Though modest, the proposed increases are still important. Indeed, oil prices have already drifted down about 18 percent since March 8, to about $28 a barrel from $34, and most of that decline reflected the anticipation that OPEC would agree on an increase of roughly that magnitude.
But the increase would also fall well short of what the Saudis envisioned. Experts said it would provide only a modest relief in gasoline prices.
Rilwanu Lukman, secretary general of OPEC, tried to put the best possible face on today's split, noting that countries have on occasion dissented from the organization's decisions before.
"We will remain as a group despite all of these tensions," he said after Iran announced that it would not join in the agreement. "Many people wrote off OPEC many years ago, and we're still here."

HEADLINE: Seeing the Future in an Old Triumph: Trolleys

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: BAYONNE, N.J., March 28

 BODY:
A half-century after the region's last streetcar tracks were torn up to make way for more cars and buses, New Jersey officials are set to open the first leg of a $1.1 billion trolley system along the Hudson River. It will carry 25,000 riders a day, and the entire project, when completed in 2010, is expected to move more than 100,000 people through the most densely populated region in the state.
The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail, which will carry its first fare-paying passenger on April 15, is the metropolitan region's most ambitious public transportation project since the 1960's, the largest public works program in New Jersey history and an intriguing look at the prospects for a transit system long deemed a part of the past, not the future. Officials say they hope the system will one day extend across New Jersey, linking light rail systems that are on the drawing board in other parts of the state. 
 "This is one of those infrastructure investments you make at the beginning of a century that serves you throughout the century," said the state's transportation commissioner, James Weinstein.
Whether enough commuters can be coaxed out of their cars to make the system a success remains to be seen. But officials say they believe that when completed, the 20.5-mile system will not only persuade commuters to leave their cars at home, relieving clogged roads and easing polluted air, but will also spur redevelopment in places that have missed out on the region's economic boom.
Ten years in the making, the line will initially feed into the ferries and PATH trains that carry tens of thousands of commuters to jobs in Manhattan as well as those who work along New Jersey's booming Hudson River waterfront. Once a wasteland of abandoned rail yards and rotting piers, the so-called Gold Coast in Hudson County has been transformed over the last two decades into a new city of office towers and luxury apartment buildings.
But until now, there has been no easy way to move north and south, something that frustrates many of the 31,000 people who travel to jobs on the waterfront. "Without this rail line, we'll drown in our success," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the ranking Democrat on the Senate's Transportation Appropriation subcommittee who helped secure more than half the project's financing from the federal government.
More than just making the commute easier for white-collar workers, transportation planners see the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail as a lifeline to places that have long been cut off from most of the region's jobs. Until now, for example, residents of Bayonne who worked in Manhattan had to endure an hour bus ride. Starting April 15, the light rail will cut that commute in half.
For mass transit advocates, the Hudson-Bergen line's birth is somewhat bittersweet. Before the car became king in the years after World War II, this heavily urbanized wedge of New Jersey was crisscrossed by trolley car lines, nearly all of them ending at the waterfront, where riders could hop a train or ferry to Manhattan. "We've clearly come full circle," said Martin Robins, director of the Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center at Rutgers University.
The concept of light rail was born in the 1970's, when engineers began marrying new technology with the traditional streetcar. The cars, which run on low-voltage electric lines, can quickly accelerate to 55 miles per hour, effortlessly climb hills and brake faster than a bus. And unlike commuter rail or subway lines, which often take decades to plan and build, light rail lines can be laid out on existing streets with minimal disruption. In the case of the Hudson-Bergen line, more than 17 of its 20 miles of track were set on rail beds that had been abandoned decades ago.
Most important, light rail advocates say, the lines are far less expensive to build than subways, "which makes them very attractive to both taxpayers and politicians," said David Phelps, a light rail specialist at the American Public Transportation Association in Washington.
Spurred by increasing traffic congestion and decreasing air quality, two dozen American cities now have light rail systems, among them such car-dependent stalwarts as Dallas, Los Angeles and Denver. Another dozen systems, Mr. Phelps said, are being planned or built. "The verdict so far has been almost unanimously favorable," he said.
Not everyone is so optimistic.
Alan E. Pisarski, a transportation specialist and the author of the book "Commuting in America," said cities like Buffalo and Baltimore have found that their initial ridership estimates were wildly overstated. As in many parts of the country, more and more New Jersey residents are commuting from suburb to suburb, not from suburb to city. Such commuters, he said, cannot be served by light rail. "I don't think light rail is a slam-dunk solution to the problem of congestion," he said.
Still, some developers are already betting on the project. On Jersey City's Martin Luther King Boulevard, one of the area's most neglected neighborhoods, a new shopping center recently opened next to a light rail station. A dozen blocks away, not far from a vast expanse of metal scrap yards and vacant warehouses, the sleek black-and-white cars glide past wooden skeletons for dozens of luxury town houses.
"The light rail will open up sites for development that until now have been virtually inaccessible," said Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who took a ride on the line this afternoon.
Transit officials plan to run the trains every seven and a half minutes at rush hour and every 15 minutes at other times. Jeffrey A. Warsh, the executive director of New Jersey Transit, said the $1.50 one-way fare comes down to 60 cents if passengers use a monthly pass, which costs $53 and allows for free transfers to local buses.
In addition to the 12 stations opening next month, four more stops along the Jersey City and Hoboken waterfronts will open by 2002, linking the system to New Jersey Transit's commuter rail terminus and the half-dozen Manhattan-bound ferries operated by New York Waterway. In 2010, when the line is scheduled to reach the Vince Lombardi Park and Ride station in suburban Ridgefield, transit officials said, it will carry more passengers than all of New Jersey Transit's rail lines combined.

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Births Rose in 1998; First Increase Since 1990

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Propelled by a strong economy and an increase in the number of women of childbearing age, births in the United States rose 2 percent in 1998, the first increase since 1990, the government reported today.
Births to unwed mothers reached an all-time high, but researchers said it was single women in their 20's and 30's, not teenagers, who were responsible for the boomlet. 
 There were 3.94 million births in 1998, or about 14.6 for every 1,000 people, the report by the National Center for Health Statistics showed. In 1997, 3.88 million children were born, and the rate of births was slightly lower at 14.5 per 1,000.
The increase was the first since 1990, when 4.1 million children were born.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
A Detroit Museum on the Rebound With van Gogh

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 28

 BODY:
Great museums acquire their reputations not just through the size and quality of their collections but through the special exhibitions they organize, borrowing works from around the world. Even fairly small museums have won fame by wheedling prized artworks from scattered institutions and bringing them together briefly for the world to see.
By contrast, the Detroit Institute of Arts, the fifth-largest art museum in the nation in terms of floor space and the largest west of the Appalachians, has drifted into obscurity because financial troubles prevented it from initiating any major exhibitions for the last 14 years. But a new management structure and a big infusion of cash from private donors have brought the museum back from the brink of closing, allowing it to organize a major exhibition of paintings and drawings by van Gogh that opened on March 12. 
"Van Gogh: Face to Face" has been an instant hit. More than a third of the tickets have been sold for the show, which runs through June 4 before moving to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston and then the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
The institute has temporarily stopped closing on Mondays and Tuesdays, as visitors from southeastern Michigan and a sprinkling of people from elsewhere cause traffic jams and parking shortages in the once-desolate cultural quarter of the city.
In keeping with its status as a privately managed but city-owned institution in the largest American city with a black majority, the museum has tried to attract a racially diverse audience. It has advertised heavily in publications catering to African-Americans and has advertised mostly on billboards in the city rather than the suburbs.
William Daniels, a retired teacher and Detroit resident, was surprised and pleased by the heavy turnout on a recent day. "I haven't seen it this crowded, the lines were terrific," he said, sitting on a bench after seeing the exhibition.
"Face to Face" is being praised by scholars too. Though there have been many van Gogh exhibitions in the last 20 years, the Detroit show is the first to focus on the painter's development as a portrait artist.
Van Gogh's portraits have been analyzed in books, but the current exhibition brings them together for ready comparison, a first, according to Bogomila Welsh-Ovcharov, a professor of fine art at the University of Toronto who has written six books on van Gogh and was not involved in organizing the exhibition. "What is more contributory and interesting for scholars and connoisseurs is to see them in a new context," she said.
With 31 drawings and 36 paintings, the exhibition traces van Gogh's rapid development in capturing faces on canvas. The earliest drawings demonstrate how van Gogh, a disillusioned theology student literally studying how-to books on becoming an artist, produced works of a style and vision that went far beyond the instructions in the manuals. The later paintings show his evolution from realistic representations of the faces of the poor to interpretations of his face and those of friends in his final years, in France.
So strict were the curators of the Detroit, Boston and Philadelphia museums about keeping the emphasis on portraiture that they did not ask to borrow one of van Gogh's "The Potato Eaters," because it depicts five peasants instead of just one and because it presents an entire scene.
George S. Keyes, the Elizabeth and Allan Shelden Curator of European Painting at the museum, said that the inspiration for the exhibition had come after Josephine Ford, a granddaughter of Henry Ford, donated a famous van Gogh portrait of a postman, Joseph Roulin, to the museum in late 1996.
In early 1997 the museum began organizing an exhibition of van Gogh's paintings of the Roulin family, then broadened its scope to the gamut of the artist's portraiture after discussions with the Philadelphia and Boston museums, Mr. Keyes said.
The institute only recently emerged from near financial disaster. The museum has long had an excellent collection and a sprawling building because of big donations by the Ford family and other auto barons, but it never had much of an endowment or received many donations for operations and maintenance.
It struggled through the hard times of Detroit and American automakers in the 1970's and 80's. Its last major exhibition, in 1986, featured the work of Diego Rivera, a Mexican muralist who painted one of his finest works in the huge marble central court of the museum in 1932.
The institution's management spent the late 80's planning an ambitious renovation and expansion of the buildings, only to be devastated in 1991 when Gov. John Engler, a Republican trying to balance Michigan's budget, cut almost all state aid to the museum. A third of the museum's $25 million annual budget disappeared, forcing a reduction in museum hours to 12 1/2 a week from 48, and the elimination of many educational programs.
"There were exhibitions planned that had to go right into the trash can because staying alive became the first order of business," said Samuel Sachs II, the museum's director from 1985 to 1997 and now the director of the Frick Collection in Manhattan.
The museum had trouble attracting donations for its operating budget partly because it was city-owned and staffed mainly by civil servants. After a nasty two-year political battle that ended in early 1998, daily management of the museum was transferred to its private donors, who live mostly in the suburbs.
The donors have given lavishly since then: a fund-raising campaign that began 11 months ago has brought in $93 million. The state government, flush again from the strong economy, has offered another $40 million if further matching contributions can be raised. An ambitious five-year renovation of the museum's main building and its two annexes will begin after the van Gogh exhibition closes, although the museum will remain open during construction.
The rejuvenation of the auto industry has also helped the museum raise money. DaimlerChrysler, for instance, is sponsoring the van Gogh exhibition. Eager to allay local worries about foreign control and to please the many German managers assigned to what some of them perceive as a Midwestern cultural backwater, DaimlerChrysler says it has increased by 20 percent the already substantial donations that Chrysler had been making to the arts in southeastern Michigan before it was purchased by Daimler-Benz in 1997.
Ms. Welsh-Ovcharov, the van Gogh expert, said that the Detroit museum's choice of van Gogh for its return to presenting world-class exhibitions showed the strength of its financial revival. Impressionist paintings and Post Impressionist works like those by van Gogh have become so valuable that the insurance and other costs of exhibiting them exceed the resources of most institutions, she said.
"It's a major coup from their point of view," she said. "Van Goghs are very difficult because of the financial budget required."

HEADLINE: SHOPPING;
Customer Service: Solving Problems Or Preventing Them?

BYLINE: By PAUL GRIMES; Paul Grimes writes the syndicated column "The Online Traveler."

 BODY:
EXPEDIA, the giant online travel agency that is owned primarily by Microsoft, prides itself on customer service. In a gesture to uneasy visitors to its Web site (www.expedia.msn.com), it recently stopped insisting that they register and provide personal information before browsing for flights, car rentals and hotel rooms. The site now requires registration only when a browser turns into a purchaser.
The site promises replies to e-mail messages within 24 hours, offers immediate assistance by telephone at any time and meticulously follows up sales with offers of further service. For example, after Expedia sold me two airline tickets to San Juan, P.R., it followed up a week before departure with an e-mail message suggesting that the itinerary be reviewed, and offered to book a hotel room, arrange a car rental and even buy luggage. 
 Unfortunately, when I tried to look at the itinerary, I was stymied. I had forgotten my ID and password, which were issued when I bought the tickets. No wonder: I am registered with at least 50 Web sites and have many ID's and passwords.
As the Web site advised, I dialed (800) Expedia (397-3342) for help. After five minutes on hold, I was told that six calls were ahead of mine. Four minutes later, "Chuck" responded, but the connection was soon cut off. Six minutes later, I got through to "Lawanda," who quickly e-mailed my user name and password.
As online customer service goes, this experience was good. Web businesses may be proliferating, but customer service varies remarkably from site to site. As e-commerce is maturing, however, there is a new emphasis on customer service, and virtually every online trade conference addresses the issue. On the customer end, a recent report by Forrester Research, the market research firm, found that 90 percent of online shoppers consider good customer service to be critical when choosing a Web merchant.
Forrester calculated that 4.8 million people, or 37 percent of those who have made purchases on the Web, had used customer services while shopping on the Internet. The report cited unhappiness with service as a main reason shoppers stopped using Internet merchants.
The growing importance of online shopping is most apparent in travel. According to a November report issued by PhoCusWright Inc., a travel research company, 45 percent of online buyers said they had bought travel on the Internet.
The report said the number of Americans who had booked trips online had soared more than 80 percent in 1999, to 11 million. It estimated the value of the online travel market at $7 billion in 1999 and projected a rise to $20 billion in 2001. Improvements in customer service and security were cited as reasons for the increase. The report also noted that many people who browse online are reluctant to buy because they object to the lack of human contact and are uneasy about privacy and credit card security.
The more one reads about e-commerce customer service, the more apparent it is that this can mean many things. It can mean the way a business promotes its product (whether it gives a full, clear description, answering the predictable questions without being asked); the billing and checkout procedure (how simple is it, and how secure?); the way a company responds to consumer problems and questions. Is the purchase delivered as promised, with the customer able to track it electronically before delivery? How easily can it be returned for a replacement or credit?
Some e-commerce sites go beyond satisfying a customer by striving to build loyalty for future sales. Incentives include frequent-flier miles and bonus miles to those who book an airline on its own site. Some sites that sell beauty products send samples to customers; others may send chocolates or flowers.
Indeed, some sites go to great lengths to promote loyalty. Two years ago, I had Amazon.com send a book about Middle Eastern history to Shlomo Sokol, my brother-in-law in Israel. The book was charged to my Visa card. When I recently returned to Amazon to order a book for myself, Amazon asked, "Would you also like to send this book to Shlomo Sokol?" (My answer was no.)
Customer service is handled in several ways: referring queries to a telephone number (preferably toll-free); accepting or soliciting e-mail messages and replying by e-mail; accepting e-mail but replying by telephone; posting answers to predictable questions on the Web site; and live online communication, or chats, between the dealer and the customer.
LIVE chats, or in Internet terms the exchange of written messages, are among the most intriguing. The technique is used by several large companies, like Lands' End, which sells clothing and household goods through catalogs and online. Live chats work like most chat rooms on the Web: one person types a question and clicks "send," and the other replies. The aim is to have experts ready to answer customers' questions.
I recently tested this chat service on the Lands' End site (www.landsend.com). Typing in my question, I received a message on my computer screen that seemed remarkably like what I often hear on the telephone: "Your call is very important to us. Please continue to hold and an agent will be with you momentarily. Thank you." Actually, the wait was not long, but the ensuing exchange took longer than a discussion would have by phone.
Asking questions by e-mail presents other problems. Some sites promise quick replies and actually deliver them. Other sites take much time, and some never respond. Among some sites that do respond, it is clear from their generic or irrelevant replies that little attention is paid to the questions.
A relatively recent development is the subcontracting of customer-service business. Companies like I.B.M. (www .ibm.com/solutions), LivePerson (www.liveper son.com), PeopleSupport (www.peoplesupport .com) and Kana Communications (www.kana .com) provide services for companies that prefer not to manage their own. This means that when you have a live chat with Lands' End, you will probably speak with a representative provided by LivePerson.
Sometimes a real person actually intrudes. A shopper may be clicking on a retail site when suddenly word is received from a sales clerk offering help. The clerk has been watching without the shopper's knowledge.
The latest in customer-service communication online is by voice, and that is important, because it is as close as you can get to face-to-face communication. In an example, an online jewelry store, Miadora (www .miadora.com), offers voice chats, instant messaging, e-mail queries or toll-free telephone calls.
At almost every e-commerce site, customer service means, at least partly, posting responses to "frequently asked questions," or FAQ's. Sometimes that is sufficient, but there are almost always questions that cannot be answered this way. Forrester Research found that only 19 percent of online shoppers with questions searched for answers on the site, and only 11 percent went to the FAQ's.
Why? Because a FAQ is not personal contact, researchers say. They recognize that to answer all questions by e-mail or by telephone would be costly. But they say that if e-retailers would provide full product description, prompt shipment, delivery tracking services and, for repeat customers, perks like free express shipping, there would probably be fewer questions.

HEADLINE: A Legendary Harlem Club Preens for Its Second Act

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
I HOPE that's not the renovation," said a young woman wearing a black crochet cap and light purple lipstick, a leopard-print satchel on her shoulder, as she peered through the glass of the Lenox Lounge into the dark glitter of the unlighted bar. A nicked and scuffed cafe chair with a zebra-stripe seat stood by the window, the photographer Art Kane's "Jazz Portrait, Harlem 1958" above it.
"It looks the way it was," the young woman said, rolling her eyes and walking off down Lenox Avenue toward 124th Street. What she couldn't see were the 22 cans of oven cleaner that took three millimeters of gummed nicotine off the gold mirrors and chrome trim. What looks antique now had been an authentic dirt-brown. The fake fur is fresh. 
 After eight months of renovations and $600,000, the Lenox Lounge, the legendary Harlem night spot built in 1939 -- the year Billie Holiday first sang "Strange Fruit" -- is reopening tonight: the sole surviving Art Deco club interior in New York City. Holiday, a regular, sat in with musicians there in the 1940's; her table in the Zebra Room beyond the bar, beneath the mock-zebra wallpaper that gave the room its name, was the first on the left through the swinging doors. She is said to have loved Art Deco, as genuine as glamour ever got. Malcolm X was also a customer.
More recently, the lounge has been a featured location in fashion magazines, music videos and movies, from Madonna's 1995 "Secret" to the remake of "Shaft," starring Samuel L. Jackson, opening this summer.
"New Yorkers will appreciate the fact that Shaft hangs out at the Lenox Lounge," said John Singleton, the film's director. "It's a Harlem landmark; he's a very uptown kind of cat. You think about Holiday, or Billy Eckstine, walking through those doors, way back in the day. I couldn't resist having a glass of Hennessy between shots."
If the new Lenox Lounge looks faded, it's a fade-in, not a fade-out.
Alvin M. Reed, a retired policeman and postal worker who has owned the lounge since 1988, decided last year to bring the club, which he said was struggling to stay profitable, back to life. His strategy was to restore its glass-finned, turbine-shaped lighting towers, black and white hide walls, Bakelite-plated leather ceiling and other original details.
"I'm a person of the past; I love the past," he said. "When I first took over, I had some people who didn't really appreciate the decor of the place. They were like, 'Oh we're glad it's a new owner. Now you can modernize this place.' "
Mr. Reed, 60, wearing a black satin baseball jacket with "Lenox Lounge: A Cocktail Lounge for the Elite" stitched across the back with its picture, was standing by the bar on Saturday with Fred Ruffin, a friend, who was at the lounge's grand opening party in 1942. Mr. Reed said that a trademark dispute with El Morocco over the use of a zebra motif, for which that storied supper club was famous, had kept the lounge from opening officially in 1939. Mr. Ruffin, who was one of the few blacks in the crowd that night at the club, which like many was conceived for white patrons coming uptown, recalled that it was "a grand night."
"Beer was 30 cents a bottle," he said. "We were kicking on that because it was 10 cents cheaper in other places."
Because of an economic boom uptown that many are calling a second Harlem Renaissance, Mr. Reed said he believed there was also a renaissance in the wings for Harlem night life and its jazz scene.
With a $450,000 loan from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone -- a development corporation created by the federal government in 1994 that is also assisting Minton's Playhouse and other Harlem institutions -- Mr. Reed closed the lounge in September to begin work. Yui & Bloch, an architectural team that specializes in restaurant interiors, drew plans to renovate as well as to restore the lounge as a bar and dining room with a program of live jazz.
"I was raised around here, about 10 blocks down," Mr. Reed said. "You could go into any club and there was a set going on."
Community preservationists' concerns about the Disneyfication of Harlem (in particular, the not-unlikely threat of theme-restaurant-style renovations at period clubs like the Lenox Lounge) reached Mr. Reed through newspaper articles, he said. Neither he nor his architects retained historical restoration experts, confident that existing details, which matched 1939 postcards, could guide replacements.
"It would have been an easier thing to rip it out and put fresh sheetrock in," said Jimi Yui, the architect, whose office is also at work on Le Bernardin's new private dining rooms. "It's a restoration in spirit only. Historical restorations are incredibly expensive to do. But it's so rich in history. There's nothing that you could have created that would have been better than the history of what it was."
Beyond its physical fact -- in continuous operation since 1939, the lounge was never stripped for sale or vacant -- documentation of the design is scant. The designer may have been Judson E. Schnall, a Brooklyn-based architect whose name appears on a city construction permit for the address, 288 Lenox Avenue, in 1938. Mr. Reed bought the club from Dominick Greco, a nephew of the family that built it, after seeing it listed for sale in The Amsterdam News.
Memory of what was there from the start was hazy, too, as thick and stubborn to clear as the smoke on the walls. An Egyptian-inspired mural in the Zebra Room, left behind by the television crew from "New York Undercover" that created it in two hours in 1992, endeared itself inconveniently to patrons.
"I had more flack over that," Mr. Reed said. "Everybody said, 'Please don't tell me that's not original; I don't want to hear it.' " It was replaced by zebra wallpaper, based on a scrap discovered in the room.
Budget kept the historical picture from excessive retouching.
"The program from Day 1 was to upgrade the building's systems, but keep the feel of the original bar," said Zachary Kaplan, the president of the ZMK Group, the general contractor. A new restaurant kitchen was created at the back, with prep areas in the basement; the lounge's scarred wooden bar was left intact, not refinished.
"The larger part of that was driven by aesthetics, but some of it was driven by money, too," said Mr. Kaplan, who grew up on Riverside Drive at 116th Street and visited the lounge as a student in the 1980's.
Serendipity played its part in the renovation, too. Frosted-glass fins to replace those missing in light fixtures were found under five inches of mud in the basement. A box of glass ashtrays used as decorative studs in the diamond-square upholstered ceiling panels in the Zebra Room also appeared in the debris as new vinyl was being put up to replace the tarred leather.
When applicable, neighborhood subcontractors were hired.
"I felt it was important to work with as many locally based people as possible," Mr. Kaplan said.
Mr. Reed's clientele will be another issue.
"A lot of them really didn't want me to do this," he said. Prices will go up, and the staff will change. Mr. Reed's loan was dependent upon his creating 15 new jobs. Tourists and downtowners are likely to be the immediate mainstay of the Zebra Room. Mr. Reed has a 15-year lease, but he is three months behind on his rent, and "stretched out," as he said.
"People came in and said, 'Make sure you keep this and that,' and I'm like, 'Come in here and spend some money, you know?' " Mr. Reed recalled of the renovation. "Preservationists don't do that."
A man on the street in a gray suit, a smart black hat and a gold neck chain put his face to the window. Mr. Reed told Mr. Ruffin not to let him in, explaining that he had been asked to leave and not to come back seven years ago.
"Maybe he thinks it's a new owner," Mr. Reed said, in the whiskey glow of the unlighted Art Deco interior, suddenly right in the present.
