HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
Another Crash Raises More Questions About Colleges' Van Travel

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
A crash between a van and a tractor-trailer in Mississippi left the coach and two players from a college baseball team in critical condition yesterday and brought new attention to an inveterate problem in college sports: the widespread use of 15-passenger vans, driven by exhausted coaches or players, to transport teams to and from games.
"It's the economics of the situation," said Douglas Mosley, the sports information director for the National Association for Intercollegiate Athletics, whose members are mostly smaller schools with limited sports budgets. "Not everyone can fly. Not everyone can even charter buses. 
 "I can't remember a year that's gone by that we haven't had news of an accident involving a 15-passenger van."
The latest accident came just after midnight yesterday about 45 miles east of Memphis, where a tractor-trailer slammed into a van carrying the coach and nine members of the Tennessee-Martin baseball team. The team was returning from a game against Mississippi in Oxford.
The coach, Victor Cates, 40, was driving. The police said he pulled out in front of the oncoming truck at the intersection of two highways and stopped the van for an unknown reason. He was in critical condition at the Regional Medical Center in Memphis, along with two players, David Tillman, 20, and Jason Alford, 23, hospital officials said. Five other players remained hospitalized last night, none with life-threatening injuries.
That accident is the latest in a string of similar mishaps, prompting college athletic directors across the country to take a hard look at their transportation policies.
Four students from the Prairie View A&M track team died last month when the van they were traveling in swerved out of control in east Texas. A student was driving.
In January, a 21-year-old Kenyon College swimmer was killed when a van driven by a teammate flipped several times on an icy road just 30 miles from their campus in Gambier, Ohio. Since late December, there have been three other accidents involving vans transporting college teams, resulting in injuries to 22 athletes, some of them serious.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association sets no policy or guidelines regarding travel, leaving it up to state law and individual schools to decide when to use vans and who should be allowed to drive.
Not surprisingly, the policies vary widely. Some schools limit the distances team vans can travel, chartering buses for longer trips. Some require coaches and other staff members who drive the vans to obtain a chauffeur's license. Others allow students to drive when there are not enough coaches for all the vans needed. Students were driving in three of the six recent accidents.
But even insisting that coaches drive can be dangerous, several athletic directors said. Often the athletes are exhausted and fall asleep. The coach at the wheel is usually mulling over the game and has put in a long day's work. Add an icy road and disaster can ensue.
Since the Kenyon accident, said Jennie Bruening, the athletic director, the college has temporarily stopped using 15-passenger vans to transport its 22 sports teams and has banned students from driving. For now, the school is chartering buses for all events, but the college has also appointed a committee to come up with a long-term policy.
Still, chartering buses for every team, from golf to football, is "an economic impossibility," Bruening said.
"We have to try to figure out some kind of structure and formula" to decide when a chartered bus is prudent, she said.
Larry Raab, the vice president for university operations at Prairie View, said the university has tightened its policies somewhat since the fatal Feb. 10 accident. But with 350 athletes in 17 sports at more than 150 events away from campus, the school cannot afford to charter buses for every competition, he said.
"The use of vans at smaller colleges is inevitable," Raab said. "You know that accidents happen, and you just have to thank your lucky stars and pray that it doesn't happen to you."
Other small colleges, however, have decided the extra expense is worthwhile. St. Benedict, a Division III women's school in St. Joseph, Minn., with 1,940 students, has slowly phased out the use of vans since 1989, after two basketball players from Muskingum College in Ohio were killed in a van.
Carol Howe-Veenstra, the athletic director at St. Benedict, said the school now charters buses for the vast majority of road games. The vans cost about 65 cents a mile to operate, while charter buses cost more than $1.90 a mile, plus $9.50 for each hour the driver must wait, she said. The bottom line: the school now spends about $13,000 more to transport athletes in buses than it would if it still used vans.
But Howe-Veenstra, the college's former volleyball coach, said the peace of mind coaches enjoy is worth every penny. The college has also found other savings -- cutting meal allowances, for example -- to offset the extra costs.
Mosley, the N.A.I.A. spokesman, said the recent spate of accidents has prompted many small-college athletic directors to consider pushing sports governing bodies to establish guidelines for travel, even though such rules might be onerous for programs on tight budgets.
"I know it has created a buzz," Mosley said. "I don't doubt that in upcoming meetings this will be a topic of discussion."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Flight From Technology Bolsters Pillars of Old Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Technology stocks sent the Nasdaq stock market to the biggest of three consecutive losses yesterday as more investors abandoned recent market favorites for the perceived comfort of General Electric and other household names.
The Nasdaq composite index shed 189.22 points, or 3.9 percent, to 4,644.67. 
 The decline in terms of points was the biggest since March 14, and the percentage loss was the biggest since March 20.
Investors who as a group have been heavily overweighted in technology have become increasingly nervous about stretched valuations. In addition, yesterday there were reports that one of the biggest hedgefund operations, Tiger Management, has decided to close and "the news on Tiger Management clearly precipitated some rotation out of these higher-momentum areas," said Christine A. Callies, chief United States strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. This pall over the market was in spite of the fact that Tiger's holdings are mainly New York Stock Exchange issues.
Other analysts pointed also to a lingering effect from the recommendation on Tuesday by Abby Joseph Cohen, the influential Goldman, Sachs strategist, that investors trim their exposure to stocks and hold as much as 15 percent cash. Technology companies, she contended, were no longer undervalued.
As the Nasdaq sagged, the Dow Jones industrial average staged an afternoon rally of as much as 165 points before losing half of it toward the close. It ended the day with a gain of 82.61, or 0.76 percent, at 11,018.72.
G.E. accounted for nearly half the Dow's gain, jumping 8, to a record close of 164, after an analyst at Prudential Securities raised his price target to 210 from 185.
Wal-Mart and Exxon Mobil each surged more than 4. Exxon was among the many oil-related stocks that more than reversed Tuesday's ragged performance, as analysts and investors further digested O.P.E.C.'s announcement of plans to raise production.
"There's a realization now that crude prices are not going to collapse here," said M. J. Matts, a value-oriented portfolio manager at National City Investment Management in Cleveland. "The price can probably stay above $25 for a sustained period."
Chevron, Texaco and ARCO all gained more than 3, while oil-field companies Schlumberger and B. J. Services were up more than 4, and Halliburton was ahead more than 2.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, less dominated by high-technology than is Nasdaq, finished up 0.79 point, to 1,508.52. Of its components, 280 advanced and 203 declined, the biggest point-losers being technology companies like Motorola, Hewlett-Packard, Texas Instruments, Micron Technology and Yahoo, though some regained part of the lost ground after the normal 4 p.m. close. Micron's announcement of a 2-for-1 split may have contributed to the rebound.
Drug stocks joined energy in the winner's circle, with Warner-Lambert ahead more than 3, and Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb and American Home Products each ahead more than 2. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outnumbered declining ones 1,632 to 1,336, as 57 stocks hit new 52-week lows, and 54 hit new highs. Volume climbed to 1.06 billion shares.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Steady
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices were little changed yesterday as worries that economic growth has yet to slow were counteracted by weak technology shares, fragile agency debt markets and softer oil prices.
Prices of two-year and five-year notes were lifted for much of the day by flows out of agency debt, which was rocked by further reports that senior Washington officials back changes for federally chartered lending agencies like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
Treasury Under Secretary Gary Gensler sent agency debt markets into a spin last week after he backed moves to repeal the Treasury credit line to agencies and stressed that agency debt was not government-guaranteed.
The price of the 30-year Treasury rose 4/32 , to 10329/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.97 percent from 5.98 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A Onetime Highflying Hedge Fund Appears Likely to Shut Down

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Undone recently by bad bets on old-economy stocks, Julian H. Robertson Jr. is closing his Tiger Management investment company, according to someone close to the company.
Mr. Robertson, 67, who is revered for his long-term record as an investor, appears to be succumbing to rapid change in the world financial markets. At his peak two years ago, he had $23 billion under management at Tiger, which runs six investment pools known as hedge funds, putting him on a par with George Soros, the hedge fund manager known for his big currency bets. 
 But a combination of investment losses and heavy withdrawals have left Tiger a shadow of its former self. About $900 million will be distributed to investors who have requested redemptions as the first quarter ends tomorrow, leaving the company with just $5.2 billion in assets, according to the person close to the company.
In the last couple of years, Mr. Robertson has been on the wrong side of a series of big investment bets. The first was a $600 million loss in the fall of 1998 when Russia defaulted on its debt. It was followed by a $1 billion loss on the Japanese yen later that year.
Retreating then from global bets as many other hedge fund managers did, Mr. Robertson refocused on beaten-down stocks in the old economy, shares of US Airways Group, Bowater Inc. and the Sealed Air Corporation. Those stocks, too, have proved disappointing, continuing to lag far behind the white-hot technology sector.
In a letter to shareholders earlier this year, Mr. Robertson wrote, "We are in a market where reason does not prevail."
Rumors of Tiger's demise have raced through Wall Street before. But with Mr. Robertson's funds down about 13 percent so far this year after a 19 percent decline last year, the person said, the end seemed not just plausible but likely yesterday. A hedge fund manager, who insisted on not being identified, said: "It's hard to come back from being down that far."
Fraser Seitel, a Tiger spokesman, said yesterday: "Tiger is not commenting on the rumors. Tiger's investors have not been notified about anything." Neither Mr. Robertson nor Philip Duff, Tiger's chief operating officer, returned telephone calls.
A native of North Carolina, Mr. Robertson spent much of his career as a stockbroker and money manager at Kidder, Peabody. But in 1980, he left to found Tiger, taking a name suggested by one of his young sons.
With $2 million of his own money and $6 million in outside investments, Tiger surged from the start. Until 1998, it lost money in only two years: 1987, the year the stock market crashed, and 1994. In several years, returns exceeded 40 percent. Even after the tough years of 1998 and 1999, the Tiger Fund had a 27 percent average annual gain since its inception almost 20 years ago.
Over the years, Mr. Robertson started five additional funds, available only to wealthy individuals. The Jaguar and Puma funds were opened in 1986, the Lion Fund and two Ocelot funds in 1987.
Unlike the unwinding of Long-Term Capital Management, Tiger's unraveling did not rattle world financial markets. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 82.61 points on the day, while the Nasdaq lost 3.91 percent. Shares in some of the stocks that Mr. Robertson is known to own were weak.
US Airways, in which Tiger had a 25 percent stake at the end of the year, slipped 43.75 cents yesterday, to $25.44. According to end-of-year filings, Tiger's big positions included UAM, the fund management company in which it owned nearly 15 percent; Sealed Air at 7 percent; and the Bear Stearns Companies at almost 4 percent.
Because Mr. Robertson has lost so much money in recent years, the remaining assets could no longer generate enough fees to cover operating expenses, according to a person close to the firm. As is the case with other hedge funds, Mr. Robertson's clients pay incentive fees of 20 percent to the manager only if their gains exceed what is called a high-water mark. Because of that threshold, Mr. Robertson's recent losses meant that he would have to be up 85 percent this year to generate any incentive fees, according to the person close to the company.
Moreover, given that roughly $2 billion of the $5.2 billion remaining at Tiger is said to belong to Mr. Robertson and his colleagues, the $3 billion from outside investors would not generate enough in management fees -- 1 percent annually -- to pay for operations at the firm's elegant New York, London and Tokyo offices.
One thorny issue in the closing of Tiger is related to Mr. Robertson's incentive fees, which have been kept offshore where they compound tax-free until the funds are repatriated, according to a source. This person said that Mr. Robertson might have a $200 million tax liability on those fees.
While shutting Tiger Management seems to signal the end of an era for Mr. Robertson, his legacy runs up and down Wall Street. Indeed, 13 hedge funds, known as Tiger Cubs, are run by Tiger alumni. Last year, all but one of these funds had positive returns.
On Tuesday evening, even as word of Tiger's woes was once again seeping into the markets, Mr. Robertson was honored at a reception in New York held by a group of former Tiger managers. At the event, the managers announced that they had made a gift to the University of Virginia in Mr. Robertson's name. At the celebration and among old friends, Mr. Robertson was near tears, someone in attendance said.

For years, Tiger Management was among the most successful hedge funds. But its returns recently have been disappointing.

HEADLINE: Guggenheim May Face Fight Over Site

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Frank Gehry, the architect of the acclaimed Guggenheim Museum branch in Bilbao, Spain, has completed a design for what Guggenheim officials hope will be another branch of the museum, in lower Manhattan.
Museum officials hope to build it on city-owned waterfront piers along the East River near Wall Street. But the city is considering several other proposals for that site, including a floating hotel and marina, indoor tennis courts, a floating youth hostel, and an aquarium. 
 Bernadette O'Leary, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, confirmed the general nature of those proposals, but would not elaborate.
One real estate executive active in downtown Manhattan who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said that all the proposals faced an uphill fight. He said officials of the Development Corporation had narrowed the field to the Guggenheim and the floating hotel, but that the city did not seem keen on either one.
With a decision not yet at hand, the museum is releasing the Gehry design in the hope that it will attract public support for the plan, which calls for a curvilinear building that would rise as high as 45 stories on a platform over the piers. Community groups are usually wary of large projects that they fear will add to congestion and disrupt views.
Yesterday, the museum mailed letters inviting about 100 board members, prospective financial supporters and prominent New Yorkers to a "small exhibition" of the museum's plans and a dinner in honor of Mr. Gehry on April 18.
The museum then plans to exhibit Mr. Gehry's model through the summer in its flagship building at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street.
"What we would like is for a greater audience to see it," said Stephen C. Swid, the Guggenheim's vice president and treasurer. "It's no different from when the Municipal Art Society wants to save a building," he explained. "This is what you have to do. Bring pressure to bear. The city needs that nudge."
The invitation, signed by Thomas Krens, the museum's president, also describes how the new building would allow the Guggenheim to rearrange its collection. Under the plan, he wrote, the 89th Street building would house the Guggenheim Foundation's collections from the late 19th century to approximately 1945, while the new facility would be devoted to works from 1945 to the present and to special exhibitions.
The invitation delicately skirts the issue of the building's location. "Certain important issues with respect to the project remain open -- such as the formal identification and designation of the actual site for the building," Mr. Krens wrote. But he added that the design was "a unique cultural event of some significance."
Mr. Krens declined requests for an interview. Scott Gutterman, a spokesman for the museum, said "We don't wish to comment on this until our first formal presentation of it on April 18,"
Mr. Swid estimated that construction would cost $400 million, but added that the museum wanted to raise an equal amount as an endowment. "We have the money -- most of the money," he said. "We already have $250 million from one person and other interested donors who want to be part of this."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Japanese Worry About Being Overshadowed

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 29

 BODY:
For 12-year-old Kenji Nakanishi, watching the Mets and the Chicago Cubs play their season-opening game at the Tokyo Dome tonight was better than opening presents at Kurisumasu, Japanese for Christmas.
"It's like a dream come true," the sixth grader said, trying to control his emotions. "I got to see my baseball heroes Sammy Sosa and Mike Piazza, and I feel so excited, so tingly inside." 
 Few Japanese in the sellout crowd of 55,000 spectators, who paid as much as $120 for a ticket, would seem to disagree with young Kenji's assessment of the first regular-season major league game to be played outside North America.
Motoharu Yanamoto, managing editor of Weekly Baseball Magazine, said that for Japanese fans, holding a major league season opener in Tokyo was "a monumental, unbelievable event." The game was a rare opportunity to witness two of America's top teams in real competition, he said. In the past, only major league exhibition games have been held in Japan.
American and Japanese organizers of the event have said they hope the games will create new markets for Major League Baseball overseas while increasing interest in Japan's professional leagues and improving their level of play.
But not everyone was euphoric over the opening of Japan's normally highly protected borders to a prominent foreign product like major league baseball. Long before the Mets and the Cubs arrived here last weekend to great fanfare, many Japanese teams were expressing concerns that allowing the immensely popular major leagues into Japan could be devastating to the country's own professional baseball leagues, siphoning off their top talent and fan base.
Yoshiaki Kanai, secretary general of the Japan Professional Baseball Commissioner's Office, said the commissioner's office agonized over whether to allow the major leagues to stage the games but eventually decided to grant approval because Japan could no longer resist the growing globalization of sports.
"If Japanese baseball is to survive, it has to also make its debut on the global stage, and we need to gain experience competing at that level," Kanai said. "So we decided to open the door to major league baseball so we could raise the technical level and interest in the game in Japan."
With attendance at many Japanese baseball games already on the decline because of the country's stubborn recession and waning interest, some team officials are afraid that given a choice, fans will spend less money on local games and save their precious yen for the major league games. The officials are also upset over the high price of the major league tickets, which cost $120 for the best seats, compared with $59 for comparable seats at a Yomiuri Giants game.
Few Japanese baseball officials were willing to express their complaints on the record, but they have been complaining to the baseball commission and local sports reporters.
"The money fans have is limited these days, and I wonder if fans who bought expensive tickets to the major league games will come to our games, too," an official of a Tokyo-based baseball team told The Asahi Shinbun newspaper.
Moreover, with money from ticket sales, merchandising and broadcast rights flat or falling at many of Japan's 12 baseball franchises, the teams can scarcely afford to match the high salaries that their top players can make in the major leagues.
Some local sports commentators and reporters said the concerns of local Japanese teams are not entirely unjustified, especially if the number of American major league games staged in Japan increases. "The real danger for Japanese baseball is if we start to see a repeat and expansion of major league games here and if we see a growing exodus of top Japanese players to America," Yanamoto, the magazine editor, said. "That could rob us of local talent and focus the attention of Japanese fans to the major league teams where our local boys will be playing."
Many of the complaints about Major League Baseball are coming from Japanese teams that are struggling economically and have limited national television exposure. Japanese baseball is divided into two leagues, each with six clubs.
Teams in the Central League are profitable because they have a huge fan base, mainly because they compete against the Yomiuri Giants, who are backed by a powerful news media organization that broadcasts all its games. Clubs in the Pacific League are generally not profitable and have trouble filling their stadiums. To be profitable, a team must generate about $50 million in annual revenues. Some baseball watchers are concerned that if the situation does not improve, the sport could be reduced to one league with as little as eight or even six teams.
Masaru Ikei, a political science professor at Keio University who is considered an expert on Japanese baseball, said it remains unclear whether Major League Baseball would help or hurt the sport in Japan. But Ikei said that he believes the way Japanese play baseball will be greatly influenced by the staging of major leagues games in Japan. He expects that Japanese baseball games, which are notoriously slow, will become faster and that umpires, who are not highly regarded in Japan, will gain new credibility as the country adopts practices of the major league.
Tim Brosnan, executive vice president in charge of international business for Major League Baseball, sought to dispel any notions that his franchise was trampling over Japanese baseball in its efforts to expand internationally.
"Japanese baseball has had some concerns about this project," Brosnan said, "but we've consulted with them and we've been very mindful to avoid the downside of those issues. Anyone who says these major league games will make the fans think that Japanese teams can't compete hasn't been at the same games I've seen this week." The Giants won exhibition games this week against the Cubs and the Mets.
Many baseball officials and commentators believe there is enough interest in baseball in Japan that fans will watch both local and international team play.
Satoshi Izumida, a 22-year-old part-time worker, certainly thinks so. At the end of tonight's season opener, Izumida, who attended two of the major league exhibition matches this week, prepared to spend the night outside the Tokyo Dome to ensure that he could obtain tickets to the Giants' season opener on Friday.
"I like both the local teams here in Japan and those in the major leagues, but the only problem is that there's not enough money or time to see them all," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Hails OPEC Decision to Sell More Oil

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
President Clinton today welcomed the OPEC decision to increase crude oil production and urged oil companies to pass the savings quickly along to consumers.
At a news conference that covered issues from China policy to gun control to taxes on the Internet, the president began by saying that the production increase announced on Tuesday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was "good news for the economy and for the American consumer."
He proposed no new policies. Until it becomes clear whether gasoline and fuel oil prices fall and by how much, Mr. Clinton said, "we have to just keep our powder dry, keep our options open." 
 The Senate plans to take up legislation on Thursday to cut and potentially repeal the federal gasoline tax, but there is considerable opposition to the measure in Congress. Asked if he would veto the bill, the president said he did not anticipate having to make that decision because he did not expect Congress to approve the bill.
Republicans in Congress, hoping to get political mileage from the steep increase in gasoline prices this year, continued today to attack the administration on energy issues. "There is, unfortunately, a Clinton-Gore anti-energy policy, and the American people are paying the price -- at the gas pumps -- for eight years of neglect," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader.
Mr. Armey and many of his colleagues want tax breaks for oil producers and more oil and gas exploration on federal land, including the waters off Florida and California and the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.
Mr. Clinton opposes those measures. Today, he renewed the call he made in his State of the Union address in January for new steps to promote fuel conservation and alternative energy sources.
For years, the Republican Congress has rejected the administration's requests for more money for energy research and for tougher fuel economy standards for automobiles and trucks.
Republicans in Congress are divided over whether to try to lower the federal gasoline tax, now 24.4 cents a gallon. The measure before the Senate would immediately roll back the 4.3 cents enacted in 1993, which was part of a large budget measure approved by the Senate after Vice President Al Gore cast the tie-breaking vote. The remaining tax would be rescinded if average gasoline prices, now slightly above $1.50 a gallon, reached $2 a gallon.

HEADLINE: Reluctant Iran Falls in Line With OPEC Production Rise

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: VIENNA, March 29

 BODY:
Just hours after Iran angrily broke ranks with all other OPEC members here today, its leaders reversed themselves and announced that they would, after all, try to raise production in line with the rest of the oil-producing nations.
"We are going to keep and preserve our market share," said Iran's OPEC governor, Hossein Kazempour Ardebili. "Beyond that, we will see what will happen." 
 Iran's quick reversal added to the drama that has surrounded the meeting of oil ministers, which ended here early today when 9 of the 11 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to raise production quotas by 1.45 million barrels a day.
If Iran continues to pump in line with its share of the market, the cartel's production limit will rise by 1.7 million barrels a day, about 7 percent, beginning next month. Iraq is now the only OPEC member not a party to the accord.
Iran's reluctant acceptance reflected OPEC's continuing power to enforce a unified pricing strategy. Despite the messy process here, economic analysts said there was little danger that the group would dissolve into the bickering -- and erratic production -- that occurred years ago when prices plummeted.
Oil markets interpreted the agreement today as a sign that production would indeed rise, and prices fell moderately in commodity trading around the world.
In New York, oil prices fell 64 cents, or 2.4 percent, to $26.45 a barrel on the Mercantile Exchange, the lowest level since Jan. 12. Since a nine-year peak of $34.37 a barrel three weeks ago, prices have fallen 23 percent, mostly because traders had anticipated that oil cartel members would raise their production quotas here.
One OPEC official predicted that in the next few weeks, oil prices would continue to decline, and Iraq's oil minister, Amer Mohammed Rasheed, forecast that the decline would persist in coming months.
But lower prices at gasoline pumps in the United States are probably months away, experts said, especially with inventories low and demand for fuel likely to rise in the summer. Also, the increased production is not so sizable that it is expected to reduce prices substantially at the pump.
In practice, the total OPEC increase will be much smaller because several members are already overshooting quotas by 1.2 million barrels a day. Analysts estimate that after the quotas are raised, most of this cheating will simply be absorbed into the new limits.
As for crude oil prices, experts predict that they could start climbing again by this winter, because demand is likely to remain strong, the world's oil inventories are low and they will not be fully replenished.
What is more, several OPEC countries have little excess capacity and would not be able to exceed their production limits further, even if they wanted to.
Tuesday night when Iran refused to participate in the agreement, several analysts worried that the rift could set off a frenzy of cheating by a few OPEC members. But today, Iran's grudging compliance suggested that Saudi Arabia has enough power to enforce the pricing and production regime in the face of objections.
"The excess capacity is unevenly distributed," said Irene King, senior oil economist at J. P. Morgan & Company. "Seventy percent of the excess capacity is in three countries -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Abu Dhabi." Those countries, she added, are the ones most interested in preserving OPEC's grip on the market.
In a fierce feud with Saudi Arabia, Iranian officials had initially argued that any significant increase could send prices plunging and would be a capitulation to the United States.
But Iranian officials also knew that holding the line on oil production would be both futile and costly. On the one hand, their refusal to pump more crude would do little to keep oil prices high. On the other, Iran would lose sales as countries like Saudi Arabia simply filled the gap.
Indeed, the real point Iran wanted to make today was to attack the United States and its aggressive lobbying for higher production.
"This is a question about influence," said Mr. Ardebili today, asserting that Bill Richardson, the American energy secretary, had telephoned OPEC's president, Ali Rodriguez of Venezuela, just as the OPEC oil ministers were meeting on Tuesday.
"In the 40-year history of OPEC there has never been a case of the secretary of energy calling OPEC ministers in the middle of a meeting," Mr. Ardebili complained. "We are very upset and disappointed at the external pressure. We don't like it."
All in all, the increase in oil production quotas did not live up to the two million barrels a day that the United States had sought.
However, the OPEC agreement will probably be supplemented by several hundred thousand barrels from Mexico and Norway, non-OPEC countries that participated in last year's cuts.
Indeed in Mexico City today, the energy minister announced that the country would raise production by 150,000 barrels a day.
Exhausted oil ministers described marathon battles over ideology as much as money.
Saudi Arabia, the conservative kingdom whose enormous oil reserves overshadow those of any other OPEC member, was determined to increase production enough to bring oil prices down to about $25.
Why seek a lower price at all? Analysts say Saudi officials were worried that with oil at $30 a barrel or higher, demand in the United States would eventually decline.
"We want a stable market, we want a well-supplied market and we want a market that will be in equilibrium all the time," Ali al-Naimi, the Saudi minister, said.
But Mr. Ardebili of Iran wanted to keep prices high and worried that OPEC risked repeating the blunder made at a meeting in Jakarta in 1997, when Saudi Arabia pushed through a production increase only to see prices fall.
OPEC leaders have always wanted to present a unified front, and even the Saudis had preached about the need for consensus. But after hours of fruitless wrangling, Mr. Naimi idecided to ignore Iran and go ahead without its agreement.
"Oh but we do have consensus," Crown Prince Aziz said with a mischievous grin. "We have consensus among nine members, and we happen to have one that does not agree."

HEADLINE: China Bars Basketball Star From U.S. Event

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, March 29

 BODY:
China has barred a young basketball star from taking part this weekend in the Nike Hoop Summit in Indianapolis, an exhibition event meant to showcase the world's best young players and introduce them to the N.B.A.
The player, Yao Ming, 19, is a 7-foot-6 center for the Shanghai Sharks, a professional team, and has long been viewed as a possible future player in the N.B.A., which has had very few players his size. He had hoped to display his skills at the Nike games, which fall during the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four playoffs and are closely watched by agents and coaches looking to recruit international talent. 
 But China's basketball bureaucrats have decided that Mr. Yao should stay home. "Yao Ming has been chosen for China's national Olympic team and must start intensive training in Beijing on April 1," said Xu Minfeng, director of the Chinese Basketball Association's general office.
Mr. Xu said the "second reason" that Mr. Yao was not allowed to leave is that he "has played a lot of games in the past year, feels very tired and needs time to recover."
Mr. Yao apparently does not have any choice. The basketball association, a government agency, said Mr. Yao "must abide by the decision." Questions were referred to the State Sports General Administration's propaganda department, which could not be reached. Mr. Yao left Shanghai for Beijing today and was unavailable for comment. His father, reached by telephone, declined to discuss the matter.
China's decision is a stark reminder that despite advances in the country's economy, its people are not necessarily free to travel abroad at will and remain subject to the whims of the central government bureaucracy. The ban is reminiscent of the cold war era, when many Soviet athletes were prevented from traveling abroad or, when they did, defected to freer societies in the West.
It also darkens Mr. Yao's N.B.A. dreams, which would bring him millions of dollars if realized, compared with the $8,000 a year his team managers say he earns now.
The Jinan Times, the newspaper in Shandong Province that reported the travel ban, said Mr. Yao had hoped that this weekend's games would have shown that he ranked among the top international players. Basketball executives say the games were to have been Mr. Yao's "coming-out party," and would have helped him decide whether to put himself into the N.B.A. draft this year. Players under 22 must declare their desire to participate in the draft to the N.B.A., in writing, by mid-May.
"What a shame!" the Shandong newspaper quoted Mr. Yao as saying. "What a big shame! This is my last chance." He will not be eligible for the games next year.
The Jinan Times report was picked up by several Chinese-language Web sites and word of the government's decision spread quickly through the sporting community.
China is counting on Mr. Yao and another player, Wang Zhizhi, for a chance at winning a gold medal at this summer's Olympics, a hugely prestigious prize for a country obsessed with its standing in international forums. Mr. Wang was prevented from going to the United States last year after he was drafted by the Dallas Mavericks, and many people believe his value as an Olympic player was a primary reason.
China remains sensitive to what it considers a history of foreign exploitation, and that extends to sports. The country's fledgling basketball league is also reluctant to let the United States begin poaching its best players, even though a Chinese player in the N.B.A. would undoubtedly increase interest in the sport at home. "We need Yao Ming here," the Shanghai Sharks' general manager, Li Yaomin, said in a recent interview.
Still, provided that Mr. Yao is not injured, he will remain an attractive N.B.A. candidate for years, giving him time to wait for China to change its attitude.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Company Laying Off 400

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Fleming Companies will lay off 400 workers as it continues to close its warehouse and administrative operations in the Buffalo area.
Fleming, a food wholesaler and retailer in Oklahoma City, announced the plans in early February, followed by efforts of government and labor officials to change the company's mind. 
 Despite an offer of an incentive package worth at least $1.1 million to stay, the company is moving ahead with plans to shift the Buffalo work to an Ohio facility.
More than 80 warehouse workers reported to work for the last time on Friday. The remaining employees are expected to be released over the next few weeks.
At the time of the announcement of the closing, Fleming said economics prompted the decision. The company has closed eight other warehouse centers in the United States in the last two years.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 31; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 5220 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Big Shoulders, Buffed for Action

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
When friends from abroad come to the United States, I always send them to Chicago, or try to. It is the quintessential American city: muscular, inventive, wonderfully diverse, worldly-wise (if a bit oafish at times) and as unpretentious as its prairie-flat vowels.
"Chicago is American in every chitling and sparerib," H. L. Mencken wrote wickedly during the era when the city's stockyards, since demolished, were the biggest anywhere. "It is alive from snout to tail." 
 Reviled in the days of Al Capone and John Dillinger as a haven for hoodlums, Chicago was maligned for years for its cheerful civic corruption and dismissed in the effete East as a hick town. Nelson Algren, one of the writers who knew it best, said that "loving Chicago is like loving a woman with a broken nose." But no more. Chicago enters the 21st century as a prosperous, well-governed model for the rest of the country.
Richard M. Daley does the governing. He won a third term as mayor last year, and he and his minions sometimes seem to be everywhere at once, effacing graffiti, reshaping the schools and creating new green spaces like the 16-acre, $230-million Millennium Park, with a Frank O. Gehry band shell and pedestrian bridge, just north of the Art Institute. Consummate pol that he is, the mayor works hard to maintain links to arts groups, business, labor, blacks and Hispanics.
He bullies enemies. He mangles syntax, though not as mercilessly as his father, Richard J. Daley, who spoke unconsciously for all politicians everywhere when he harrumphed, "Together we must rise to ever higher and higher platitudes." But Richard M. -- "Richie" to his constituents -- never loses sight of his grand goal: ensuring the city's future by persuading its middle class to stay. He has made a good deal of headway.
Daley the elder, who ruled Chicago like a pharaoh for 21 years, also did a lot to beautify the city. But he is best remembered for flying into a black rage at the 1968 Democratic convention, siccing his cops on Vietnam War protesters and the reporters covering them. The ensuing melee, a grim spectacle of swirling tear gas and flailing billy clubs, all but guaranteed the defeat of the party's hapless nominee, Hubert H. Humphrey.
The first president nominated in Chicago was a favorite son named Abraham Lincoln, and a dozen others have been nominated here since. One of them was Warren Gamaliel Harding, whose grandiose middle name promised so much more than he delivered; he was chosen in the original smoke-filled room, Suite 408-409-410 of the Blackstone Hotel.
They must put something into the water in Chicago. Politics here -- national politics, local politics -- never pales. This is the city, you may recall, that produced not only the Daleys but also Daniel Rostenkowski, the consummate congressional deal maker, a stout political oak felled by a petty-cash scandal; aldermen-scoundrels of yore like Bathhouse John Coughlin and Hinky Dink Kenna and Paddy Bauler, who told the world in 1955, "Chicago ain't ready for reform"; and Mayor William Hale Thompson, who threatened to punch King George V in the nose if he dared set foot in the city.
Obviously there is nothing Old World about Chicago. Europe seems further away here than it does in Boston, New York or even San Francisco. And yet the genius who did more than anyone else to give the city its charm -- the architect Daniel H. Burnham, who planned waterfront pleasure parks and scenic drives where other cities have factories and warehouses -- did so in the name of transforming Chicago into Paris on the Lake. On Lake Michigan, which lies like an ocean at the city's feet, "so huge that you can't see across," as my awed wife, Betsey, said when she first came here.
"Make no little plans, for they have no magic to stir men's blood," said Burnham, the master planner who laid out the new city that rose from the rubble of the flimsy boom town consumed in the Great Fire of 1871. He made none, nor have the generations of builders who succeeded him.
 
Hot Dogs and Fancy Stuff
The old song warns, "Don't ever ask what Chicago is, unless you've got an hour or two or three."
Chicago is a lot of things: the fabulous Frango chocolate mints that they sell at Marshall Field's department store; Oprah Winfrey, queen of television talk; Ann Landers, ageless purveyor of newspaper advice to the lovelorn; the Chicago River, once a key link between the Great Lakes and the Mississippi, which is dyed green every St. Patrick's Day, and O'Hare Airport, the sprawling kingdom of fallen arches and missed connections used by 70 million passengers a year.
All that and the Lincoln Park Zoo, which makes a specialty of breeding gorillas; the Field Museum of Natural History; the vast Museum of Science and Industry, the youngsters' favorite, housed in the only building left from the World's Columbian Exposition of 1893; and the John G. Shedd Aquarium, the world's largest, which my sister, Barbara, calls "the whale jail."
Chicago is good eats: the frogs' legs at Phil Smidt's in Hammond, Ind., just across the city line, amid the smokestacks of the old industrial economy, and Italian beef sandwiches and deep-dish pizza and garlicky Chicago hot dogs (hold the ketchup). Fancy stuff, too. I remember when Jovan Trboyevic, the fastidious wonder worker who ran the much-mourned Le Perroquet, was alone in offering proper haute cuisine; now it's all over town.
Chicago is also a city of neighborhoods, so far-flung that the visitor can sample but a few.
Off to the northwest, in the gritty areas along Milwaukee and Lincoln Avenues, far from Michigan Avenue's glittering Magnificent Mile, where the affluent shop, immigrants have lived since the mid-19th century: first Germans and Scandinavians, then Poles, Russian Jews, Italians, Ukrainians, Slovaks and most recently Puerto Ricans. Shop signs in countless languages and churches with exotically shaped domes serve as testaments to the succeeding waves of newcomers.
 
Saving a Church
One of the churches, St. Stanislaus Kotka, which had the world's biggest Roman Catholic congregation only a century ago, was saved from the wrecker's ball by Mr. Rostenkowski, who used his legendary clout to divert a new federally financed expressway around it.
The South Side has been America's largest black community for most of the last century. It is home today to Jesse Jackson and Louis Farrakhan, two very different black leaders, and two prominent black members of Congress, Jesse Jackson Jr. and Bobby Rush. Once Mr. Rush was a Black Panther leader; now he is a moderate who says, "Most African-Americans just want a comfortable middle-class lifestyle." They find it more easily on the South Side than on the West Side, which is almost as bedraggled today as it was when the Nobel Prize winner Jane Addams and her staff at Hull House labored there early in the century.
Also to the south is the top-drawer University of Chicago, founded in 1890 with Rockefeller money. No fewer than 69 Nobel Prizes have been awarded to its teachers, students and researchers. Among the laureates are Saul Bellow, the novelist, and Milton Friedman, the conservative economist, whose teachings influenced not only his colleagues but also influential scholars at the university's law school, like Edward H. Levi, who served as attorney general in the Ford administration.
Beneath the Stagg Field grandstands, Enrico Fermi and his co-workers achieved the first controlled, self-sustaining nuclear reaction on Dec. 2, 1942, the most important step in developing the atomic bomb. The site is marked with a massive bronze by Henry Moore, "Nuclear Energy."
 
In the Loop
Frank Lloyd Wright's prototypical Prairie Style building, the Robie House, stands nearby, echoing the horizontality of the plains in its strip windows, the deep overhang of its eaves and even in the proportions of his trademark Roman bricks, very long and very skinny. The house made him world famous, along with the houses he built for himself and others in the western suburbs of Oak Park and River Forest. Also in Oak Park is Unity Temple, "my little jewel," as Wright called it, a masterpiece in reinforced concrete, built in 1905 on an awkward site for only $45,000.
But the birthplace of modern architecture, and of the skyscraper, was the Loop, as the central business district is known (after the elevated train tracks that circle it).
Chicago's architects capitalized on the fire of 1871, which began in Patrick and Catherine O'Leary's barn on DeKoven Street, much as Christopher Wren capitalized on London's Great Fire of 1666. They were influenced by the great Henry Hobson Richardson's startlingly original Glessner House, a rugged study in rusticated stone (1887) that turned its back to the street, opening instead onto a south-facing courtyard.
Louis Sullivan, Richardson's disciple and Wright's teacher, sensed "an intoxicating rawness, a sense of big things to be done," and began with the Auditorium Building in 1889. Its acoustically perfect 4,000-seat theater, spanned by vast flattened arches, illuminated by thousands of clear, unshaded bulbs, is one of America's great interiors.
At the same time Burnham & Root were designing the Rookery a few blocks away, organized around a graceful cast-iron light court that Wright reworked to good effect in 1906. In 1891 Burnham & Root built the brooding 16-story Monadnock Building, a pioneering skyscraper, and in 1899 Sullivan, in the Carson Pirie Scott & Company store, frankly expressed the revolutionary steel grid in bands of windows that became a Chicago School trademark. Below he applied webs of his luxuriant foliate ornament in cast iron.
All these buildings remain, on or near State Street, "that great street," a living textbook of modern architectural development.
Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, the German master who helped found the Bauhaus, came to Chicago to escape Nazi persecution and reinvigorated Chicago architecture. His deceptively simple stripped-down steel-and-concrete designs, like the apartment buildings on North Lake Shore Drive, the Federal Center in the Loop and the Illinois Tech campus on the South Side, achieve a rare elegance through the careful calibration of proportion.
From Mies's work grew such landmarks as the John Hancock Tower, the distinctively cross-braced high-rise by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill in the Magnificent Mile shopping area, and in reaction to it arose the postmodern movement, epitomized here by the sleek buildings of Helmut Jahn.
 
Icons of Isolation
In among the shining towers stands an unparalleled collection of modern street sculpture: not only Picasso's enigmatic Cor-Ten steel beast outside the Daley Center and a 100-foot-tall baseball bat by Claes Oldenburg on West Madison Street but also big works by Calder, Stella and Miro.
You can see many of the best surviving buildings on boat tours organized by the Chicago Architecture Foundation, and at the Art Institute you can see fragments of many that have been destroyed, including the entire, colorfully stenciled trading room of the old Chicago Stock Exchange by Louis Sullivan.
But it is for paintings that the Art Institute, a "universal" museum like the Metropolitan and the Louvre, is best known. There is a St. John the Baptist by Guido Reni, admired by Sister Wendy on a recent visit, but most of the lures are newer: Seurat's "Grande Jatte," the greatest of Pointillist canvases; "Paris Street: Rainy Day" by Gustave Caillebotte, a magnificent mood piece to which the institute gave pride of place long before the general revival of interest in his work; and two icons of American isolation, Edward Hopper's "Nighthawks" and Grant Wood's "American Gothic."
Farther up Michigan Avenue, the Terra Museum of American Art rotates its collection every few months; when we were last there, a George Luks called "Knitting for the Soldiers" (1918) struck us with its acid Kirchner-like colors. Nearby, the excellent Museum of Contemporary Art showcases its own holdings, which range from Bruce Nauman to Cindy Sherman and well beyond, in a series of barrel-vaulted galleries. The museum looks out across a cityscape typical of this part of Chicago, with wide, tree-lined sidewalks and an agreeable little park surrounded on three sides by tall buildings.
 
Da Bulls an' Da Bears
Chicago loves its sports. It loves the Cubs and their cozy little park, Wrigley Field, with ivy-covered outfield walls and seldom-used floodlights. (God made baseball to be played under his own light, the Cubs and their fans believe.) Forget the fact that the Cubs haven't played in a World Series since 1945 or won one since 1908. Chicago loved Da Bears in the heyday of Mike Ditka and Walter Payton. It swooned over Da Bulls and their balletic, clutch-loving, gravity-defying star of stars, Michael Jordan.
Air Jordan and the Bulls carried the city's name around the globe; so did Sir Georg Solti and the mighty Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which he made one of the finest on earth. But both are gone now, Air retired, Solti dead. The Bulls are rebuilding, and the orchestra has not quite managed to maintain its old luster, despite the manifold gifts of its current music director, Daniel Barenboim.
Mr. Barenboim's goals are different from those of Solti, a taskmaster if not a martinet, who drilled his players until they achieved a rare precision. At its peak the Chicago was best noted for the sonority of its brass choirs, especially in the late romantic repertory. Sometimes its Bruckner rang out with the awesome power of the horns of heaven.
Since taking over in 1991, Mr. Barenboim has encouraged subtlety. Today quiet passages are often as impressive as climaxes, though some critics, including James R. Oestreich of The New York Times, have detected occasional raggedness. Many listeners wonder how things will change when the virtuoso trumpeter Adolph Herseth, who is now 78, finally yields his chair.
Still, Mr. Barenboim is a musician of substance as well as a figure of glamour. At Orchestra Hall and on tour in the United States and abroad, he not only conducts but doubles as a piano soloist, and he has kept the orchestra ensconced among the nation's elite musical ensembles.
The big stir in Chicago music this past season came from the Lyric Opera's heralded premiere of a work it commissioned, William Bolcolm's "View From the Bridge," based on the Arthur Miller play. The critics were kind, and the company liked it so much that it has asked Mr. Bolcom, a genial University of Michigan professor who likes Gershwin and Youmans as much as Puccini, to produce two more new scores for production in the next decade.
It was a general director named Ardis Krainik, one of the rare women in her line of work, who propelled the Lyric into the first rank of American opera houses, along with the Metropolitan and San Francisco. (Some would add Houston to the list.) She died in 1997, to be succeeded by William Mason, and the company has gone from strength to strength. It sells more than 100 percent of its seats every year, an unparalleled accomplishment, because subscribers religiously turn in unwanted tickets for resale.
 
Dance and Drama
Chicago has also taken the Joffrey Ballet to its heart. Directed by Gerald Arpino, the company moved its base here in 1995 from New York after running into financial trouble. It seems to have restored its bank balance and renewed its classical style. Mr. Daley regularly attends performances.
Big-league drama abounds in the Windy City. Two of the most widely applauded Broadway productions of the past couple of years originated at the Goodman Theater here: Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," starring Brian Dennehy, and Eugene O'Neill's "Moon for the Misbegotten," starring Cherry Jones and Gabriel Byrne. Another O'Neill play, "Desire Under the Elms," directed by Walter Dallas, scored a hit this winter at the Court. And the Steppenwolf helped propel David Mamet and John Malkovich to fame.
No better evidence could be found that Chicago has long since shed the "Second City" complex A. J. Liebling diagnosed 50 years ago.
The Chicago Tribune, still ensconced in its lacy neo-Gothic tower on Michigan Avenue, is in almost every respect a different animal from the wacky, pugnaciously conservative, isolationist sheet full of local puffery and idiosyncratic spelling that Col. Robert R. McCormick oversaw in the 1940's and 50's. It is in the process of buying The Los Angeles Times, The Baltimore Sun and Newsday, plus several television stations, which will make it one of the nation's handful of dominant media conglomerates.
 
Patrons of the Arts
Swift and Armour and the other barons of beef are no more; Chicago is no longer "hog butcher to the world." Only a gate adorned with a bas-relief of a Hereford steer remains of the Union Stockyards, where in 1892 alone 2.5 million cattle and 5 million hogs were slaughtered. Many of the big corporations hereabouts, like Walgreen's, United Air Lines, Motorola and Sears, which abandoned its eponymous skyscraper in the Loop, are out in the suburbs. Amoco and Ameritech and a couple of big banks succumbed to takeovers. But many biggies remain, including Bank One, Sara Lee and Quaker Oats, to which the city gave $9.75 million in tax breaks to stay.
Most of them support the arts with enthusiasm. C. Steven McMillan, who takes over as chief executive of Sara Lee on July 1, told me not long ago, "The arts, politics and the business community are more heavily comingled in Chicago than in any other American city I know of, to everyone's benefit."
Down at the foot of La Salle Street, in a fine Art Deco building with a statue of Ceres on top, is the headquarters of the Chicago Board of Trade, where the big commodity traders do their (to me) incomprehensible thing.
"Few economic institutions," the social historian Thomas Cronon tells us sternly in "Nature's Metropolis" (Norton, 1991), "more powerfully affect human communities and natural ecosystems in the modern capitalist world. Even those of us who will never trade wheat or pork bellies on the Chicago futures markets depend upon those markets for our very survival."
I'll have to take his word for it. Meanwhile, allow me to focus for a moment on Chicago's writers: the early reformers Frank Norris and Upton Sinclair; the overearnest but underrated Theodore Dreiser, whose "Sister Carrie" still moves me; James T. Farrell, whose "Studs Lonigan" is set in one part of the South Side, and Richard Wright, whose "Native Son" is set in another; Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur, who gave us the greatest of all newspaper plays, "The Front Page," and Carl Sandburg, who for better or worse gave Chicago its overfamiliar nickname, "City of the Big Shoulders."
More recently, the city and its ways have been depicted by Mike Royko, the irascible newspaper columnist; Studs Turkel, the oral historian; and Ward Just, the novelist.
A moment, too, for the popular arts: the blues that Muddy Waters and others brought up the Illinois Central from Mississippi; the jazz that King Oliver and Louis Armstrong brought to the South Side, echoed by white kids from the suburbs like Benny Goodman and Eddie Condon; and the wacky, wonderful plaster cows (including Ferragamoo, sponsored by the Italian fashion house) that appeared all over the city in the summer of 1999.
It was Sinatra's kind of town, and it is mine, too.
 
You'll Have the Time, the Time of Your Life
 
Chicago is about 790 miles west of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
 
Where to Stay
 
BURNHAM, 1 West Washington Street, (312) 782-1111. In a minor miracle of adaptive restoration, D. H. Burnham's Reliance Building (1891), one of the world's first skyscrapers, has been raised from near-dead and turned into a boutique hotel, managed by the Kimpton Group of San Francisco. In the heart of the Loop, it has 103 rooms and 19 suites, average in size, below average in price. A lot of fine original detail has been retained, including the terra cotta facade, terrazzo floors and Carrara wainscoting. Double room: $135 to $230.
 
FAIRMONT, 200 North Columbus Drive, (312) 565-8000. A businessman's favorite a few blocks north of the Loop, the Fairmont occupies a 42-story post-modern tower sheathed in pink granite. Its 692 exceptionally large rooms offer drop-dead views over the city or the lake, plus marble-topped desks and tables. Give the Primavera restaurant a pass; the waiters sing. Double room: $159 to $259.
 
FOUR SEASONS, 120 East Delaware Place, (312) 280-8800. In city after American city, the Four Seasons is the top-rated hotel. The Windy City is no exception. The English-country-house-fantasy lobby occupies the 7th floor of a 66-story skyscraper, above a mall full of chic shops (Bloomie's, Bendel's). Whatever you want, it's right at hand: barber and beauty shop, sauna, indoor pool and a stellar restaurant, Seasons, with Mark Baker as chef. Double room: $465 to $900.
 
RITZ-CARLTON, 160 East Pearson Street, (312) 266-1000. Operated by the Four Seasons chain, despite the misleading name, this luxurious lair forms part of the Water Tower Place complex, smack in the middle of the Magnificent Mile. Its bright, expansive lobby, complete with octagonal fountain, is on the 12th floor. Guest rooms are all that anyone could ask, as is Sarah Stegner's cuisine; her Sunday brunch, Chicago's most sumptuous, ranges from gravlax to mini-souffles. Double room: $400 to $3,000.
 
WHITEHALL, 105 East Delaware Place, (312) 944-6300. European in style and ambiance, this little hideaway is tucked into a side street, well away from Michigan Avenue's noise and bustle. In-room faxes, phones with data ports and wall safes were installed in a recent renovation. On weekends and during special promotions, prices are low by Magnificent Mile standards. Double room: $199 to $379.
 
Where to Eat
 
ARUN, 4156 North Kedzie Avenue, (773) 539-1909. This is America's best Thai restaurant, a kitsch-free zone where the food on the plates is just as delicate as the ceremonial headdresses adorning the room. Miang kum, the first of 12 stellar dishes at a recent meal, consisted of batons of lime peel, ginger and coconut, heaped with tiny red peppers and peanuts on betel-nut leaves with tamarind sauce. It would awaken the most jaded palate. Superb Austrian and American wines; tasting menu only, $75 and worth it.
 
BERGHOFF, 17 West Adams Street, (312) 427-3170. Old Chicago, alive and kicking. Owned by the same clan since 1898, the Berghoff holds the first liquor license issued by the city after Repeal. It brews its own beers and root beer and serves all the old favorites from Mittel Europa, like herring, bratwurst and knackwurst with sauerkraut and real wiener schnitzel.
 
CHARLIE TROTTER'S, 816 West Armitage Avenue, (773) 248-6228. One of the nation's two or three premier chefs, Mr. Trotter makes gastronomic Faberge eggs. He bathes foie gras, salmon and Japanese mushrooms in a warm broth to create a dish that is both rich and refreshing: a rarity. The service is fluent and the wine list (check the big bottles) mind-blowing.
 
EVEREST, 440 South LaSalle Street, (312) 663-8920. The next time someone tells you he never eats on top of skyscrapers, send him to Jean Joho's place, 40 floors up. Alsatian-born, Mr. J. blends the cuisine of kings with the cooking of commoners in dishes like creamy sauerkraut soup with caviar. The attention to detail is constant, the tapestry of lights below stirring, the service urbane and the Alsatian wines the best in the hemisphere.
 
FRONTERA GRILL AND TOPOLOBAMPO, 445 North Clark Street, (312) 661-1434. You could spend half a lifetime in Oaxaca and know less about Mexican food than you will learn at Rick and Deann Bayless's two restaurants, one casual, the other less so. Both, saturated with vibrant color, serve food prepared with immense care from the best ingredients. Every sip or bite is a revelation, from margaritas to marlin ceviche to tacos al pastor.
 
GIBSONS, 1028 North Rush Street, (312) 266-8999. Chicago is a steak town from way back. It has plenty of places to satisfy your carnivorous impulses, but this one, packed with politicians, visiting show-biz types, bulky guys in warm-up jackets and head-turning dolls, epitomizes the city's exuberance. Order a martini, chopped chicken livers (try them on the house raisin bread) and either a W. R. Cut (a bone-in rib-eye named for the Tribune's food columnist, William Rice), or tender London broil (made with top sirloin). Desserts, like strawberry shortcake, are the size of a steamboat.
 
M K, 868 North Franklin Street, (312) 482-9179. The letters stand for Michael Kornick, the chef, and he stands for modern American cooking with bright, true flavors. Sweetbreads with caramelized endive, for example, and definitive calves' liver with grilled Vidalia onions, Nueske bacon strips and a sauce of mustard and pan juices. The decor is terminally chic.
 
SPIAGGIA, 980 North Michigan Avenue, (312) 280-2750. The name means "beach," and you can glimpse the lake from this snazzy aerie perched above the Magnificent Mile. But bag the view. Paul Bartolotta's thoroughbred Italian cooking, the best between New York and Santa Monica, is the thing to focus on here: full-flavored, grown-up, fantasy-free dishes like asparagus with unctuous fonduta, gnocchi with duck ragu and wood-roasted rabbit.
 
TRU, 676 North St. Clair Street, (312) 202-0001. In from the suburbs, Rick Tramonto and Gale Gand are challenging Charlie Trotter and Jean Joho for local supremacy in an airy glacier-white room. Mr. Tramonto sends out a lobster risotto in a miniature copper saucepan and serves dazzling savory sorbets (beet, orange pepper, etc.) in parmesan cones. Ms. Gand, his wife, whips up whimsies like pineapple "carpaccio." Well-chosen wines.

HEADLINE: Grace Under Pressure

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Johanna Winant complains that while people would not ask an unemployed adult about his job search, they usually don't hesitate to ask high school seniors about college applications (Op-Ed, March 27). But once Ms. Winant's college years have passed, she will learn that people usually don't know better than to ask about a job search and will usually pat a pregnant woman's belly. These gestures are not insensitive, but simply natural, interested responses. 
 Yes, patting bellies is somewhat intrusive, but if you tell an acquaintance you are unemployed, do you really expect him or her to whistle and talk about the weather?
With the shift to adulthood come challenges that require not only strength but also the ability to handle seemingly imprudent inquiries about those challenges with grace.
 
SARAH J. M. TUFF
Park City, Utah, March 27, 2000

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury PricesAdvance as Investors Seek a Safer Haven

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Largely ignoring news that the economy grew at a pace of 7.3 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, faster than previously reported, bonds reacted instead yesterday to a decline in stocks as investors sought the safety of Treasuries.
Bonds continue to be influenced by stocks, so when global stock markets dropped before the opening of the United States market, Treasury yields fell to their lowest level in more than a week. When the American stock market opened on a relatively firm note, Treasuries trimmed some of those earlier gains. But bonds advanced later as the Nasdaq slumped on a sell-off in technology shares. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 121/32 , to 1059/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 5.87 percent from 5.97 percent on Wednesday, its biggest one-day drop in almost two months. The yield is at its lowest level since Aug. 24, when the Federal Reserve raised its rate on overnight loans between banks by one-quarter point, the second of five increases since last June intended to slow the economy.
The Commerce Department's final estimate of gross domestic product for the last quarter of 1999 reported a growth rate of 7.3 percent, revised from the previous estimate of 6.9 percent and higher than economists' expectations of 7.1 percent. Even though it was a strong number, some market participants felt it was not necessarily new information.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said: "The U.S. economy is in uncharted waters, roaring ahead at a prodigious pace in the midst of the longest expansion on record. Indeed, G.D.P. growth has accelerated over the past nine months despite five pre-emptive tightening moves by the Federal Reserve. And while the nation's economic momentum during the first quarter of the year 2000 will not be quite as torrid as the blistering 7.3 percent pace registered during the fourth quarter of 1999, it will still be in excess of the Fed's perceived maximum noninflationary 3.5 percent trend rate of growth."
And for that reason, Mr. Fine says he thinks the Fed will continue to raise rates until it sees signs that the economy is moderating. Most market participants expect the Fed policy makers to raise rates by another quarter-point at their next meeting on May 16.
Another recurring theme in the bond market is the effect of the government budget surplus and buyback program, which have caused an inverted yield curve, in which investors who take on more risk by owning long-term debt are paid less than those holding short-term instruments. The yield on a two-year note is now at 6.48 percent, and yields on the longer maturities are lower.
"In addition," Mr. Fine said, "growing concerns about risks in other sectors have, at times, produced a flight-to-quality movement into Treasuries, and with asset allocations jumping around between cash, bonds, traditional stocks and particularly tech-sector equities, the markets appear to be searching for some kind of anchor in what has recently become a rather volatile financial world."
Elsewhere, corporate bonds got off to a bad start, with market participants concerned that the government would not be responsible for agencies like Fannie Mae if they default on their debt, which has caused some unwinding of those positions. A bill pending in the House of Representatives would repeal a conditional line of credit that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have with the Treasury, thus stripping them of some tax and regulatory advantages they now have over commercial and investment banks.

HEADLINE: Growth Rate For Economy Accelerates

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
The economy grew at a 7.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1999, the fastest in almost 16 years, revised government figures showed today.
The growth rate -- stronger than the 6.9 percent previously reported by the Commerce Department -- was paced by higher consumer spending and a smaller trade deficit. It capped the third consecutive year in which the economy grew faster than 4 percent. 
 Consumer spending, buoyed by rising confidence and unemployment at close to a three-decade low, fueled the fourth-quarter gain in gross domestic product as the economy closed in on a record expansion that begins its 10th year this week.
The fourth-quarter pace was the fastest since the economy grew at a 9 percent pace in the first quarter of 1984. It followed a 5.7 percent rate of growth in the third quarter.
For all of 1999, the economy expanded 4.2 percent. The last time the economy expanded at 4 percent or more for three consecutive years was 1976 to 1978.
The new numbers suggest the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates for a sixth time in less than a year when its policy makers meet again on May 16, economists said.
The Fed's five interest rate increases since June were intended "to slow down the growth of aggregate demand because we think it's growing at a rate that's not sustainable," Michael Moskow, president of the Fed Bank of Chicago, said in a speech today.
Adding to that concern is a dwindling supply of workers as the unemployment rate hovers close to a 30-year low. The Labor Department reported today that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by 3,000, to a seasonally adjusted 266,000, in the week ended March 25. Even with the increase, the level of claims is close to a 26-year low.
Still, faster fourth-quarter growth occurred without causing inflation to accelerate. The G.D.P. price deflator -- a measure of price increases that is watched by many investors -- rose at a 1.9 percent rate, previously reported as rising at a 2 percent pace.
The personal consumption expenditure price index, which the Fed uses to make inflation forecasts, rose at a 2.5 percent rate, unchanged from the previous estimate.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity, rose at a 5.9 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter, the same as previously reported and faster than the 4.9 percent pace of the third quarter.
A smaller deficit in services trade also had an effect on the final number. Exports grew faster and imports slower than first estimated.
Exports of goods and services rose at a revised 10.1 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, previously reported as an 8.7 percent increase. In the third quarter, exports rose at an 11.5 percent rate. Imports of goods and services grew at a revised 8.7 percent annual rate, previously reported as a 10 percent pace. Third-quarter imports advanced at a 14.9 percent rate.

HEADLINE: In Charmed India, Clinton Wooed, and Maybe Won

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, March 30

 BODY:
Without winning or conceding anything of substance on his tour of South Asia last week, President Clinton may still have helped modestly reduce the risk of war between nuclear-armed India and Pakistan by talking sweet to India and tough to Pakistan.
He spent five days courting India, the region's democratic colossus and rising economic power, with the ardor of a smitten suitor -- and half a day treating Pakistan, America's cold war ally and a nation yet again ruled by generals, like an old girlfriend who is part of the past. 
 After decades of estrangement, Mr. Clinton gambled that the best way to build a closer relationship with India, a nation of one billion people that is hungry for respect, and to encourage it to act soberly with regard to its smaller, but detested, rival, Pakistan, was to give it a dose of unconditional affection.
He demanded no quid pro quo for his visit here -- for example, requiring India's signing of the nuclear test ban treaty. And he seconded India's demand that Pakistan reduce the violence by militants it supports in Kashmir, the Himalayan territory both countries claim.
American diplomats and experts on the region have become increasingly worried that India, angered by intensified attacks by Pakistani-backed guerrillas, will strike across the so-called Line of Control that divides the Indian- and Pakistan-held parts of Kashmir to hit at militant training camps.
But in an interview, Brajesh Mishra, the national security adviser to India's prime minister, said India had assured the Americans that as long as there were no new large-scale Pakistani incursions into Indian territory, "we will not take any provocative action on the other side of the Line of Control."
The American approach to Pakistan was motivated by a different assumption: that Pakistani generals were operating under the illusion that if they stirred up enough trouble in Kashmir, the United States, fearing a conflict that could turn nuclear, would step in and insist that India make concessions.
In recent months, Pakistan-backed militants have become increasingly bold. At the same time, the Indians have added to an already immense military presence that has been criticized for well-documented human rights violations against the civilian population. Pakistan, weaker than India, has long pleaded for international intervention.
"I think for many years they thought that might get us involved and it won't," Mr. Clinton told Peter Jennings of ABC News days before his trip. "I'm not going to be dragged into something that, first of all, that India doesn't want us to be part of and secondly, that I got dragged into from deliberate acts of violence."
Mr. Clinton's sternly worded warnings, issued privately to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the army chief who has ruled Pakistan since an Oct. 12 coup, and in a televised address to the nation, were meant to leave the generals with no doubt that further violence in Kashmir would deepen Pakistan's international isolation and fail to bring America to the rescue.
But the significance of the trip was not limited to war and peace. In a traveling exhibition of political performance art, Mr. Clinton also began rebuilding America's long-estranged relationship with India, the world's most populous democracy.
In New Delhi, he wowed one of the world's most hard-boiled groups of politicians, the Indian Parliament. "As Clinton walked to the exit, suddenly, as if the dam of hostility had been breached, almost everyone wanted to shake his hand," the news weekly India Today reported.
In Rajasthan, the president danced spontaneously with village women. In Hyderabad, he sang the praises of India's fast-growing software industry.
Outlook, a national magazine, said Mr. Clinton would be remembered as "a warmhearted, fun-loving man."
Americans in the embassy here and those visiting from Washington were almost giddy with relief and amazement that India seemed to have fallen head over heels for Mr. Clinton. After all, the president was in the final year of a second term tainted by scandal, coming to a country that has had notoriously prickly relations with the United States.
But the good feelings of this moment could quickly fade. The administration had been warming up to India in 1997 and 1998 -- planning the first visit to India by an American president in more than two decades -- when India shocked the world with its nuclear tests in May 1998.
"They've been in the gulag for a couple of years and this was their chance to rehabilitate themselves," said an American diplomat.
A lot of the ground lost at the time of the tests was recovered last week as the Americans simply agreed to disagree with India on its development of a nuclear deterrent. But economic sanctions imposed by the United States after the tests are still in place. And the sensitivities of India to what it has often perceived as American highhandedness are still just below the surface.
It is also far from certain that Mr. Clinton's trip will produce the long-term results he seeks: that both nations accede to the test ban treaty, get back to the negotiating table, calm their hostilities and slow down spending on nuclear arsenals.
Though he did not fundamentally change the American position on Kashmir, the length and warmth of his visit to India and the brevity and coolness of his time in Pakistan left the impression in both that the United States has tilted toward India.
"When it became clear that Clinton would be tough with the Pakistanis when he went to Islamabad -- as indeed he was -- India smiled," said Dennis Kux, author of the definitive history of Indian-American relations, "Estranged Democracies" (Sage Publications, 1993).
A decade after the end of the cold war -- during which India drew close to the Soviets and Pakistan to the Americans -- there is a more solid foundation for cooperation between India and the United States.
Both are great, multicultural democracies.
The United States' thriving high technology industry has spawned a crop of successful Indian-born entrepreneurs who are becoming a force in American politics. India itself has a growing software industry with rapidly rising sales to American companies.
More broadly, India's more open, market-driven economy is producing opportunities for American investors, though the dollar amounts remain relatively small. While Mr. Clinton was in India, American companies signed deals worth about $4 billion with Indian firms and state governments in the high technology and power sectors, among others.
Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee has accepted an invitation to visit the White House before Mr. Clinton leaves office and both governments have committed themselves to high-level consultations on nuclear nonproliferation, trade, the environment and terrorism.
Nonetheless, Mr. Kux, the historian, cautioned that one good visit is no guarantee of better relations. "Only time will tell," he said, "if Clinton and his successor, whether Gore or Bush, and the Indians stay the course."
